('68', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('68', 0, 2, 3, 68) Unrevised WARDHA,
('68', 0, 3, 4, 86) September 23, 1935
('68', 0, 4, 5, 105) MY DEAR AMRIT,
('68', 0, 5, 6, 120) Your letter to Choudhury has told.
('68', 0, 5, 7, 155) He has taken it in the right spirit.
('68', 0, 5, 8, 192) There was no occasion for apology.
('68', 0, 5, 9, 227) And if you cannot call a spade a spade to your own people in your own home, which Maganwadi is, where could you do so?
('68', 0, 5, 10, 346) You must repeat the performance, whenever the occasion arises.
('68', 0, 5, 11, 409) This size is especially prepared for you.
('68', 0, 5, 12, 451) But you will give me your criticism on it.
('68', 0, 5, 13, 494) For the stinking lot you have to pay nothing.
('68', 0, 5, 14, 540) Has the stink gone with exposure to the sun and the air?
('68', 0, 6, 15, 597) Puri should send his detailed criticism without delay.
('68', 0, 6, 16, 652) He must not wait for the time when he comes here.
('68', 0, 6, 17, 702) I must not be kept in darkness.
('68', 0, 7, 18, 734) I am eating your apples with vengeance.
('68', 0, 7, 19, 774) And I needed them.
('68', 0, 7, 20, 793) They and musambis have acted like medicine.
('68', 0, 8, 21, 837) Mira is free from fever.
('68', 0, 8, 22, 862) But she is still terribly weak and the digestive apparatus does not respond as it should.
('68', 0, 8, 23, 952) In spite of big doses of Eno’s Fruit Salt, she has to take the enema in order to get a clearance.
('68', 0, 8, 24, 1050) But there is no anxiety on her behalf.
('68', 0, 8, 25, 1089) You won’t get full marks as a good nurse, nor Shummy as a good doctor, unless between you two [you] make Pyarelal take milk and your excellent butter.
('68', 0, 8, 26, 1240) Has Shummy anything to add to what I have given 1 in Harijan on snake bites?
('68', 0, 8, 27, 1317) Is there an easy way of distinguishing a poisonous from a non poisonous snake?
('68', 0, 8, 28, 1396) Does he recommend any book on it?
('68', 0, 9, 29, 1430) When does he think Kumarappa can be discharged?
('68', 0, 10, 30, 1478) Here are some letters for your guests 2 (!)
('68', 0, 13, 31, 1522) 1 Vide “Snake Poisoning”, 17 8 1935. 2 Pyarelal, Kumarappa and Devdas
('68', 1, 0, 1, 1592) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 1, 2, 2, 1632) When do you descend to the plains?
('68', 1, 2, 3, 1667) You may not overstay your time in Simla for the sake of the convalescents.

('68', 1, 13, 17, 2183) I have your letter.
('68', 1, 13, 18, 2203) If I didn’t know you, I would be displeased to get no letter from you.
('68', 1, 13, 19, 2274) I console myself thinking that you must have some good reason for not writing to me, either that you want to save my time or to save yours.
('68', 1, 13, 20, 2414) According to my nature, I would rather that persons like you wrote to me frequently so that I could know them better and hence could also help.
('68', 1, 13, 21, 2558) I have not yet been able to go through the report of the Harijan work in Kathiawar.
('68', 1, 13, 22, 2642) I do wish to read it.

('68', 1, 13, 25, 2754) And we cant’t also afford Jivanlal losing interest in it.
('68', 1, 13, 26, 2812) Can you make any suggestion?

('68', 2, 11, 19, 3785) Biswanath has got to be helped against himself.
('68', 2, 11, 20, 3833) 2 I do not suppose I know him at all but from the correspondence with Annada I have gathered the impression that he is one of your faithful workers.

('68', 2, 11, 22, 4072) Therefore even if you have to neglect your work a bit and if he would not come alone to me, you should bring him with you.

('68', 3, 4, 6, 4600) 6. LETTER TO B.G. KHER
('68', 3, 5, 7, 4623) September 24, 1935
('68', 3, 6, 8, 4642) MY DEAR KHER,
('68', 3, 7, 9, 4656) I ought to have written this to you whilst Swami was here, but I simply could not do it and then it escaped me altogether, till I got a reminder from Swami yesterday afternoon.
('68', 3, 7, 10, 4833) I see no contradiction between what Thakkar Bapa has written and what I conveyed to Swami, Harijan Sevek Sangh won’t take direct responsibility of owning the property in Pandharpur, but it will provide the majority of trustees and continue to do so, as vacancies occur by any reason whatsoever.
('68', 3, 7, 11, 5128) The idea behind this arrangement is that the Sangh should not undertake any financial responsibility.
('68', 3, 7, 12, 5230) Its burden would be fully discharged when it has appointed trustees who are able to manage property financially and otherwise.
('68', 3, 7, 13, 5357) This proposition was adopted under my advice.
('68', 3, 7, 14, 5403) The Sangh has not sufficient workers to enable it to take charge of properties that are being offered to it.
('68', 3, 7, 15, 5512) This Pandharpur proposition has been entertained because you and Swami are interested in it and because both of you are connected with the donor, who I am sure holds advanced and liberal views on untouchability and other matters and who wholly endorses the Sangh’s campaign against untouchability.
('68', 3, 7, 16, 5810) I hope this is sufficiently clear and quite satisfactory from the point of view of the Buva.
('68', 3, 7, 17, 5903) If any further elucidation is required please do not hesitate to write to me.
('68', 3, 7, 18, 5981) I understand from Shri Kavde who was here for two days that the Buva was expected to be somewhere near Wardha during the first week of October.
('68', 3, 7, 19, 6125) If that does happen I would like you to urge him to pass a few days with me at Maganwadi so that I can make his personal acquaintance and understand his desire about the management of the Dharmashala in Pandharpur.
('68', 3, 7, 20, 6340) In view of the conversation I had with Swami and Shri Kavde I would advise that in drawing up the trust deed you give the
('68', 4, 0, 1, 6462) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 5
('68', 4, 1, 2, 6506) trustees full powers of mortgage, alienation, etc., so long as the corpus is used for the exclusive benefit of Harijans.
('68', 4, 1, 3, 6627) I have explained to Swami why I consider the possession of this power by the trustees as a vital part of the deed.
('68', 4, 2, 4, 6742) Yours sincerely,
('68', 4, 3, 5, 6759) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('68', 4, 3, 6, 6789) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('68', 4, 4, 7, 6808) 7. LETTER TO DR.
('68', 4, 4, 8, 6825) GOPICHAND BHARGAVA
('68', 4, 5, 9, 6844) WARDHA, September 24, 1935
('68', 4, 6, 10, 6871) DEAR DR.
('68', 4, 6, 11, 6880) GOPICHAND,
('68', 4, 7, 12, 6891) I have your letter.
('68', 4, 7, 13, 6911) I am conferring with Shankerlal as to what should be done.
('68', 4, 7, 14, 6970) My own inclination is to hand the charge to Meerut people because they already know the working of the Kashmir Bhandar.
('68', 4, 7, 15, 7090) If that proposition does not commend itself to Shankerlal or to the council, your alternate proposals will be helpful.
('68', 4, 7, 16, 7209) Let us decide upon certain propositions as decisive, namely, that we shall not run any Bhandar at a loss.
('68', 4, 7, 17, 7315) Secondly we shall not make purchases even in the open market for replenishing our stocks if we do not know what wages the workers at those articles have received.
('68', 4, 7, 18, 7478) This applies to the market pattus 1 you have mentioned.
('68', 4, 7, 19, 7534) It is not enough for us to know, that the pattus come within our definition of khadi or swadeshi.
('68', 4, 8, 20, 7632) Yours sincerely, BAPU DR.
('68', 4, 8, 21, 7658) GOPICHAND BHARGAVA LAHORE
('68', 4, 9, 22, 7684) From a copy: Dr. Gopichand Bhargava Papers.

('68', 5, 1, 2, 7812) 8. LETTER TO VALJI G. DESAI September 24, 1935
('68', 5, 2, 3, 7859) VALJI, I couldn’t write to you because of heavy pressure of work.
('68', 5, 2, 4, 7925) Munshi’s writing is neither seductive nor obscene.
('68', 5, 2, 5, 7976) I didn’t see anything objectionable in his ridicule of brahmacharya.
('68', 5, 2, 6, 8045) I had read nearly the whole of it before writing the Foreword.
('68', 5, 2, 7, 8108) I had liked his effort.
('68', 5, 2, 8, 8132) The fact is that, having come to know Munshi personally, I have developed a partiality for him.
('68', 5, 2, 9, 8228) He has capacity for self sacrifice.
('68', 5, 2, 10, 8264) He seems to be a sincere man.
('68', 5, 2, 11, 8294) This does not mean that I like everything about him.
('68', 5, 2, 12, 8347) But we should regard others in the spirit of ahimsa, that is, with a broad mind.
('68', 5, 2, 13, 8428) In other words, we should judge everybody according to his limitations.
('68', 5, 2, 14, 8500) I hope this answers all your questions.
('68', 5, 2, 15, 8540) I received your article.
('68', 5, 2, 16, 8565) I hope all of you are well.
('68', 5, 3, 17, 8593) Blessings from BAPU
('68', 5, 4, 18, 8613) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 7474. Courtesy: Valji G. Desai
('68', 5, 5, 19, 8683) 9. MESSAGE ON BIRTHDAY 1
('68', 5, 6, 20, 8708) [On or after September 24, 1935] 2
('68', 5, 7, 21, 8743) These spurts are no good, if one sleeps away the rest of the year; and now that we have a definite ideal in front of us, viz., the working towards a minimum wage for eight hours’ work, some of us must try to do eight hours’ spinning, either single or by several combining together, keeping a regular record of everyone’s spinning and every
('68', 5, 8, 22, 9083) 1 The message extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai who had explained: “When some years ago Gandhiji came to know about the public celebration of his birthday’, he said: ‘Let the day be consecrated to spinning for Daridranarayana.’ And ever since, the celebrations have taken the form of some kind of khadi work.
('68', 5, 8, 23, 9406) This year the Hindu [Vikram era] date was separated from the Christian date by nine days and people devoted the whole time to extra spinning or selling khadi or making khadi collections.
('68', 5, 8, 24, 9593) As the 24th of September (birthday according to the Hindu year) coincided with the Harijan Day, in many parts of India effort was made to do some special acts of service for the Harijans .
('68', 5, 8, 25, 9782) Several places, including our own, had 16 hours’ unbroken spinning on wheel for the whole period.
('68', 5, 8, 26, 9880) But this was far from satisfying Gandhiji .
('68', 6, 0, 1, 9924) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 7
('68', 6, 1, 2, 9968) day’s spinning, so that one can arrive at a standard average spinning .
('68', 6, 1, 3, 10040) I understand the depth of feeling behind your wishing many returns of my birthday.
('68', 6, 1, 4, 10123) But as you know well, not a minute will be added by the Creator to the allotted span of my life, no matter what human effort is put forth.
('68', 6, 1, 5, 10262) Nevertheless, while it lasts we shall always continue to pray and otherwise strive for one another’s good and longevity.
('68', 6, 2, 6, 10383) Harijan, 12 10 1935

('68', 6, 8, 14, 10691) 11. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('68', 6, 9, 15, 10722) September 25, 1935
('68', 6, 10, 16, 10741) CHHAGANLAL,
('68', 6, 11, 17, 10753) I got your letter.
('68', 6, 11, 18, 10772) Reading about the things that Balvantrai has tolerated doesn’t lessen my grief.
('68', 6, 11, 19, 10852) Please tell him so, or convey it in a letter, if you have shown him my previous letter.
('68', 6, 11, 20, 10940) The news that the houses of Bhangis were satisfactorily completed though after much delay, was welcome.
('68', 6, 11, 21, 11044) Can you not, with the help of Dakshinamurti, find somebody in Bhavnagar who would take up debt relief work among Bhangis?
('68', 6, 11, 22, 11166) Valji’s nephew Rasik is studying in Shamaldas College.
('68', 6, 11, 23, 11221) College students are often found doing silent social work while studying.
('68', 6, 11, 24, 11295) See if you can tempt Rasik.
('68', 6, 11, 25, 11323) If he comes forward, he may also be able to draw his friends into the work.
('68', 6, 11, 26, 11399) The fact that 15 maunds of bones did not give even a basketful of manure means that they were heated more than necessary.
('68', 6, 11, 27, 11521) The bones should merely be charred, that is, heated till
('68', 7, 0, 1, 11578) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 7, 1, 2, 11618) they turn black.
('68', 7, 1, 3, 11635) They should be heated less than wood is when it is turned into charcoal.
('68', 7, 1, 4, 11708) There will then be hardly any loss of weight in the bones.
('68', 7, 1, 5, 11767) I performed the process myself and produced manure.
('68', 7, 1, 6, 11819) The experiment was demonstrated in Maganwadi.
('68', 7, 1, 7, 11865) The method is now frequently made use of in Nalvadi.
('68', 7, 1, 8, 11918) The fuel consists of dried stumps of uprooted hedge plants.
('68', 7, 1, 9, 11978) Wood should not be used for the purpose, and dry sticks not at all.
('68', 7, 1, 10, 12046) The material used for fuel should be such as would burn just a little longer than hay, so that when it is burnt up it will leave the bones unburnt.
('68', 7, 1, 11, 12194) It should be remembered that our aim is not even to heat the bones till they look like charcoal.
('68', 7, 1, 12, 12291) Charring bones means merely heating them till they turn black.
('68', 7, 1, 13, 12354) We have to go just a little further than smoking them.
('68', 7, 1, 14, 12409) Bones heated in this manner lose nothing besides a little nitrogen, and certainly no phosphorus.
('68', 7, 1, 15, 12506) If the phosphorus in bones is lost, their essence is lost.
('68', 7, 1, 16, 12565) Collect a few bones and make the experiment yourself several times till you have mastered the process.
('68', 7, 1, 17, 12668) Did you by any chance try to heat the 15 maunds of bones together at one time?
('68', 7, 1, 18, 12747) More and more bone mills and flour mills will continue to come up and people will go in for their products.
('68', 7, 1, 19, 12855) But wouldn’t a true brahmachari remain unshaken in his vow even in the midst of widespread immorality?
('68', 7, 1, 20, 12958) Going further than that, don’t we see that, though the threat of death hangs over everybody, the whole world strives, and commendably, to stave off the evil day?
('68', 7, 1, 21, 13120) If in the same way we regard it our duty to do our best, we would go on doing our work fearlessly and with faith and a cheerful mind no matter how often we fail.
('68', 7, 1, 22, 13282) The success of mills lies in being able to pay dividends, whereas ours lies in doing our duty.
('68', 7, 1, 23, 13377) One who has dedicated himself to a cause doesn’t hope for the reward of his work.
('68', 7, 1, 24, 13459) A person who travels to Hardwar in a train does nothing very great, but a pilgrim who travels on foot from Kanyakumari to Jamnotri may be said to have achieved something.
('68', 7, 1, 25, 13630) I say ‘something’ because after all Jamnotri is only a physical goal.
('68', 7, 1, 26, 13700) Our effort for the revival of village industries belongs to the same class.
('68', 7, 1, 27, 13776) But real effort consists in striving for an invisible goal.
('68', 7, 1, 28, 13836) Despite the coming into vogue of aeroplanes, we shall need our legs.
('68', 7, 1, 29, 13905) Likewise, despite the numerous mills which have sprung up, there will be need for village industries.
('68', 7, 1, 30, 14007) Just as it would be foolish to neglect cultivating strength of limbs because of the increasing use of aeroplanes, so it would be foolish to neglect village industries because
('68', 8, 0, 1, 14182) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 9
('68', 8, 1, 2, 14226) of the multiplication of mills.
('68', 8, 1, 3, 14258) We are trying to save to country from committing such folly.
('68', 8, 1, 4, 14319) There can be no room for despair in such effort.
('68', 8, 1, 5, 14368) The description of the condition of the cultivators in Samdhiyala proves that I am fully justified in giving the first place in our programme to village sanitation.
('68', 8, 1, 6, 14533) Even this first step in man’s education has come to be neglected.
('68', 8, 1, 7, 14599) The reason for that neglect is the unforgivable sin of the higher castes in looking down upon the lower castes.
('68', 8, 1, 8, 14711) If Dhiru has gone to Totaramji to learn agriculture or with the noble desire of serving him, my congratulations to him, Rama and you.
('68', 8, 1, 9, 14845) I never think about Harilal now.
('68', 8, 1, 10, 14878) I have already written to you about the result of my inquiry concerning .
('68', 8, 1, 11, 14952) .’s 1 character.
('68', 8, 1, 12, 14969) To me his letter seemed to be perfectly sincere.
('68', 8, 1, 13, 15018) It seems he is connected with several institutions in Rajkot.
('68', 8, 1, 14, 15080) He has suggested to me that, if I wish, I might make further inquiries to ascertain the correctness of the facts stated in his letter.
('68', 8, 1, 15, 15215) Narandas has no doubt regarding that, and Bhai Jethalal has produced before me no definite evidence.
('68', 8, 1, 16, 15316) I, therefore, have made no further enquiry.
('68', 8, 1, 17, 15360) However, I am prepared to do so if you produce definite evidence.
('68', 8, 1, 18, 15426) I have still kept that door open for you.
('68', 8, 1, 19, 15468) Personally, I have no bias either way in the matter.
('68', 8, 1, 20, 15521) My condition is like that of a judge who changes his view from time to time as more and more evidence for or against is brought forward.
('68', 8, 1, 21, 15658) I have sent Narandas’s letter to Jethalal Joshi.
('68', 8, 1, 22, 15707) Please tell him that he has not even acknowledged it, and, if he has not received my letter, inform me accordingly.
('68', 8, 1, 23, 15823) I haven’t even kept a copy of Narandas’s letter.

('68', 9, 10, 22, 17461) 13. LETTER TO K.M. MUNSHI
('68', 9, 11, 23, 17487) September 25, 1935
('68', 9, 12, 24, 17506) BHAI MUNSHI,
('68', 9, 13, 25, 17519) I add the good wishes of you both to those of many others.
('68', 9, 13, 26, 17578) But isn’t it God’s will that prevails in the end?
('68', 9, 13, 27, 17628) Who can thwart the decrees of Fate?
('68', 9, 13, 28, 17664) Have you considered what kind of figure I would cut in the Sahitya Parishad?
('68', 9, 13, 29, 17741) When my name was suggested on a similar occasion years ago, the late Ramanbhai had remarked that I did not know even as much Gujarati as a raw matriculate.
('68', 9, 13, 30, 17897) I had at that time agreed whole heartedly with him when I heard the remark.
('68', 9, 13, 31, 17973) As my era had already commenced then, others who heard that sincerely meant remark had felt hurt, but I saw in it nothing but sincerity of purpose and regard
('68', 10, 0, 1, 18131) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 11
('68', 10, 1, 2, 18176) for propriety.
('68', 10, 1, 3, 18191) Our people’s love is blind.
('68', 10, 1, 4, 18219) They believe that a person who is capable in one field must be so in other fields, too.
('68', 10, 1, 5, 18307) If the person is weak minded, he would therefore soon come to grief.
('68', 10, 1, 6, 18376) Ramanbhai’s remark made in 1915 16 holds true literally even today, and I am therefore shaking in my shoes ever since my name was suggested for the forthcoming session of the Parishad.
('68', 10, 1, 7, 18561) In cherishing the aspiration to make the Parishad a symbol of Gujarat’s unity and culture, don’t you think you are making its field unlimited?
('68', 10, 1, 8, 18704) And I see no likelihood of that aspiration being realized through my becoming its President.
('68', 10, 1, 9, 18797) This is precisely the state of my mind.
('68', 10, 1, 10, 18837) If even after knowing this all the members desire that I must become the President and if the Parishad is to meet next year, you may give me an opportunity to think again then.
('68', 10, 1, 11, 19014) 1 You have approached me as advocate of the Reception Committee, but now please become my advocate and reply to the Committee on my behalf that you are personally convinced by my argument and agree that I should be spared from having to become President.
('68', 10, 1, 12, 19269) Regarding the Advisory Committee for Hansa, I thought I had said my say.
('68', 10, 1, 13, 19342) 2 But Mahadev gave me your message just now.
('68', 10, 1, 14, 19387) I see that you have enumerated fifteen languages, from out of which you yourself agree to the exclusion of three, leaving twelve.
('68', 10, 1, 15, 19517) Fixing an upper limit of 20 for twelve languages, you may select whatever names you like.
('68', 10, 1, 16, 19607) I would find it difficult to make the selection, since I do not know everybody.
('68', 10, 1, 17, 19687) I was concerned only with the size, and if my argument on that point appeals to you, you yourself should select the agreed number of names.
('68', 10, 1, 18, 19827) I will accept your selection.

('68', 11, 1, 2, 20165) 14. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH
('68', 11, 2, 3, 20198) AGANWADI, WARDHA, September 26, 1935
('68', 11, 3, 4, 20235) NARAHARI, I got your letter.
('68', 11, 3, 5, 20264) We cannot afford to give way to despair in this manner.
('68', 11, 3, 6, 20320) I can’t explain much in a letter.
('68', 11, 3, 7, 20354) Find some time after Parikshitlal returns and come over for a while.
('68', 11, 3, 8, 20423) It is true that we are not able to give the girls as much as we ought to.
('68', 11, 3, 9, 20497) But it is also true that we do not have the necessary women workers.
('68', 11, 3, 10, 20566) God creates difficulties so that we might overcome them and not run away from them.
('68', 11, 3, 11, 20650) You acted rightly in relieving Bhagwanji.
('68', 11, 3, 12, 20692) Puratan may go to a village if he wishes.
('68', 11, 3, 13, 20734) We may certainly introduce any reforms that you desire and others also that we can think of.
('68', 11, 3, 14, 20827) While doing so we should bear only one thing in mind.
('68', 11, 3, 15, 20881) namely, that we must not abandon anything we have started so long as we see no immorality in it.
('68', 11, 3, 16, 20978) Think over this while you are waiting to come here.
('68', 11, 3, 17, 21030) Can Anasuyabehn take charge of the younger girls who give you trouble?
('68', 11, 3, 18, 21101) If she is short of space, can she shift her Bal Mandir to the Harijan Ashram?
('68', 11, 3, 19, 21179) You can do the tanning and the dairy work even there.
('68', 11, 3, 20, 21233) Where else will you get the facilities of land, etc., which you have there?
('68', 11, 3, 21, 21309) Valunjkar has been doing his work here so efficiently and intelligently that I am hopeful that he will soon be able to run tanneries at a number of places.
('68', 11, 3, 22, 21465) He has even undertaken to start one at Nasik.
('68', 11, 3, 23, 21511) A building is already under construction there and the work will start as soon as it is completed.
('68', 11, 3, 24, 21610) You will see that, too, when you come here.
('68', 11, 3, 25, 21654) Valunjkar has resolved to suffer no loss from the very beginning and all kinds of schemes are being thought out with that end in view.
('68', 11, 3, 26, 21789) I think from the economic point of view the work here will be more successful than Satisbabu’s project.
('68', 11, 3, 27, 21893) The latter has already consumed a lot of money by now.
('68', 11, 3, 28, 21948) The return has yet to come.
('68', 11, 3, 29, 21976) In Valunjkar’s project very little money has been invested, the hides are being tanned, there is a sufficient number of cobblers for the work and the trainees, too, are making progress.
('68', 11, 3, 30, 22162) Please remember that a servant of the people must display all the four qualities in proper balance, namely, the Brahmin’s wisdom, the Kshatriya’s fearlessness, the Vaishya’s purity of management and the
('68', 12, 0, 1, 22365) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 13
('68', 12, 1, 2, 22410) Shudra’s capacity for untiring labour.
('68', 12, 1, 3, 22449) The greatest shortcoming in us all is the lack of the Kshatriya spirit.
('68', 12, 1, 4, 22521) We lose heart much too soon.
('68', 12, 1, 5, 22550) We tremble to stand alone.
('68', 12, 1, 6, 22577) At sight of the tiger of difficulties, whether we are one or many we start running away.
('68', 12, 1, 7, 22666) Please do not think that any of these charges is directed against you alone.
('68', 12, 1, 8, 22743) I am explaining to you what I see all around me and even in myself.
('68', 12, 1, 9, 22811) As for myself, where can I run away to?
('68', 12, 1, 10, 22851) My condition, therefore, is like that of a Bania who had got himself tied on the back of a horse.
('68', 12, 1, 11, 22949) If you have not heard this story, please ask me some time.
('68', 12, 1, 12, 23008) I will enjoy telling it to you or, if you cannot come in the near future, will write to you.

('68', 12, 7, 18, 23278) From the 20th chapter: ‘I shall have written my lesson when you will come’.

Between two actions which will be happening in future the one that is going to be accomplished will take the Future Perfect.

('68', 13, 3, 4, 24216) RASIK, I have not preserved your letter, but the language was so clumsy that I had to read it twice to take in its meaning.
('68', 13, 3, 5, 24340) It is natural that you two couldn’t have any such meaning in your minds, but the letter did mean that you certainly wanted your money to be used for relief work but that I should send you an account showing the particulars of individuals to whom it was paid.
('68', 13, 3, 6, 24599) If Kanti has written to you and said that the money received by me was not being used, he is not right.

('68', 13, 3, 8, 24897) If, however, you felt it your dharma to send it, you should have quoted Kanti’swords and told me that your money should be spent immediately and should not lie with me unused.
('68', 13, 3, 9, 25073) I hope you will see that your error in writing in English was still more serious.
('68', 13, 3, 10, 25155) I was surprised to discover that, after having lived with me for so many years, you have not been able to understand and see that, however well one may know the English language, one should write or speak in it only when absolutely necessary.
('68', 13, 3, 11, 25398) Since there was no incivility anywhere in your letter, you need not have apologized for it.
('68', 13, 3, 12, 25490) If, however, you lose all that you have learnt in the Ashram, then will be the time for you to apologize.

('68', 15, 13, 25, 28988) 1 Not reproduced here; written by Harihar Sharma, it gave an account of the origin and progress of Dakshin Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha and the decision of its Executive Council to “organize Hindi Prachar Week from September 30 to October 6, 1935 .

('68', 16, 0, 1, 29436) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 17
('68', 16, 1, 2, 29481) 21. ABOUT ‘CONVERSION’
('68', 16, 2, 3, 29504) Mr. A. A. Paul of the Federation of International Fellowships asked me the other day to define in these columns my position on ‘conversion’.
('68', 16, 2, 4, 29645) I told him to frame definite questions on which he would like my answers.
('68', 16, 2, 5, 29719) The result was the following letter with a list of propositions attached:
('68', 16, 3, 6, 29793) You remember that a little over a month ago, I wrote to you asking you whether you would publish a statement giving your views on ‘conversion’.You wrote back to say that it would be easier for you if we could put them in the form of questions or assertions.
('68', 16, 3, 7, 30051) At the request of the Executive Committee of the Madras International Fellowship, one of our Christian members has prepared the enclosed statement and the Committee has asked me to pass it on to you with the request that you will kindly find it possible to answer these statements in Harijan.
('68', 16, 3, 8, 30344) Of course you will notice that the questions are framed from the Christian point of view; but the Committee feels that the questions will apply equally well to other Missionary Religions which are engaged in conversion programme.
('68', 16, 3, 9, 30574) May I hope that you will find it possible to explain your attitude to these questions?
('68', 16, 4, 10, 30661) PROPOSITIONS
('68', 16, 5, 11, 30674) 1. Conversion is a change of heart from sin to God.
('68', 16, 5, 12, 30726) It is the work of God.
('68', 16, 5, 13, 30749) Sin is separation from God.
('68', 16, 6, 14, 30777) 2. The Christian believes that Jesus is the fulfilment of God’s revelation to mankind, that He is our Saviour from sin, that He alone can bring the sinner to God and thus enable him to live.
('68', 16, 7, 15, 30968) 3. The Christian, to whom God has become a living reality and power through Christ, regards it as his privilege and duty to speak about Jesus and to proclaim the free offer which He came on earth to make.
('68', 16, 8, 16, 31173) 4. If any man’s heart is so moved by the hearing of this message as to repent and wish to live a new life as a disciple of Jesus, the Christian regards it as right to admit him to the company of His professed believers which is called the Christian Church.
('68', 16, 9, 17, 31430) 5. The Christian shall do all in his power to sound the sincerity of conviction in all such cases and shall point out, as he can, the consequences of such a step, stressing the duty a man owes to his family.
('68', 17, 0, 1, 31638) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 17, 1, 2, 31679) 6. The Christian shall do everything in his power to prevent any motives of self seeking on his part and of material considerations on the part of the convert.
('68', 17, 2, 3, 31839) 7. Inasmuch as Jesus came to give full life, and that as a matter of history conversion has often meant an enhancing of personality, the Christian shall not be accused of using material inducements if conversion results in the social uplift of the convert—it always being understood that such shall never be used as a means to an end.
('68', 17, 3, 4, 32174) 8. The Christian is right in accepting as his duty the care of the sincere convert—body, soul and mind.
('68', 17, 4, 5, 32278) 9. It shall not be brought against the Christian that he is using material inducements, when certain facts in Hindu social theory, out of his control, are in themselves an inducement to the Harijan.
('68', 17, 4, 6, 32477) (But see points 5 and 6.) In order to understand the background to these propositions, the reader should know that the origin of the main question was a discussion I was carrying on with Mr. A. A. Paul on the so called mass conversion of a village predominantly or wholly composed of Harijans.
('68', 17, 4, 7, 32771) The reader may later on read more of this ‘conversion’.
('68', 17, 4, 8, 32827) For the present purpose it is enough that he understands, that it is the method of mass conversion that has to be tested in the light of these propositions.
('68', 17, 4, 9, 32984) Indeed the ninth proposition almost says as much.
('68', 17, 4, 10, 33034) I have read the propositions several times, and the more I read them the more I feel that they can be applied only to individual contacts, never to the mass of mankind.
('68', 17, 4, 11, 33203) Take the very first proposition.
('68', 17, 4, 12, 33236) Sin is defined to be “separation from God”.
('68', 17, 4, 13, 33280) “Conversion is a change of heart from sin to God.
('68', 17, 4, 14, 33330) It is the work of God.” So says the author of the propositions.
('68', 17, 4, 15, 33394) If conversion is the work of God, why should that work be taken away from Him?
('68', 17, 4, 16, 33473) And who is man to take away anything from God?
('68', 17, 4, 17, 33520) He may become a humble instrument in the hands of God.
('68', 17, 4, 18, 33575) Even so he cannot be a judge of men’s hearts.
('68', 17, 4, 19, 33621) I often wonder whether we are always true judges of our own hearts.
('68', 17, 4, 20, 33689) ‘Man, know thyself’ must have been wrung out of a desparate heart.
('68', 17, 4, 21, 33756) And if we know so little of ourselves, how much less must we know of our neighbours and remote strangers who may differ from us in a multitude of things, some of which are of the highest moment?
('68', 17, 4, 22, 33951) The second proposition deals with the Christian belief handed to the believer from generation to generation, the truth of which thousands of Christians born are never called upon to test for themselves, and rightly not.
('68', 17, 4, 23, 34171) Surely it is a dangerous thing to present it
('68', 18, 0, 1, 34216) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 19
('68', 18, 1, 2, 34261) to those who have been brought up to a different belief.
('68', 18, 1, 3, 34318) And it would appear to me to be impertinent on my part to present my untested belief to the professor of another which for aught I know may be as true as mine.
('68', 18, 1, 4, 34478) It is highly likely that mine may be good enough for me and his for him.
('68', 18, 1, 5, 34551) A thick woollen coat would be the thing for one living in the cold region of the earth, as a piece of loincloth for another living near the equatorial regions.
('68', 18, 1, 6, 34711) The third proposition too, like the first, relates to the mysteries of religion which are not understood by the common people who take them in faith.
('68', 18, 1, 7, 34861) They work well enough among people living in the traditional faith.
('68', 18, 1, 8, 34929) They will repel those who have been brought up to believe something else.
('68', 18, 1, 9, 35003) The other five propositions deal with the conduct of the missionary among those whom he is seeking to convert.
('68', 18, 1, 10, 35114) They seemto me to be almost impossible of application in practice.
('68', 18, 1, 11, 35181) The start being wrong, all that follows must be necessarily so.
('68', 18, 1, 12, 35245) Thus how is the Christian to sound the sincerity of the conviction of his hearers?
('68', 18, 1, 13, 35328) By a show of hands?
('68', 18, 1, 14, 35348) By personal conversation?
('68', 18, 1, 15, 35374) By a temporary trial?
('68', 18, 1, 16, 35396) Any test that can be conceived will fail even to be reasonably conclusive.
('68', 18, 1, 17, 35471) No one but God knows a man’s heart.
('68', 18, 1, 18, 35507) Is the Christian so sure of his being so right in body, mind and soul as to feel comfortably “right in accepting as his duty the care of the sincere convert—body, soul and mind”?
('68', 18, 1, 19, 35686) The last proposition—the crown of all the preceding ones— takes one’s breath away.
('68', 18, 1, 20, 35769) For it makes it clear that the other eight are to be applied in all their fulness to the poor Harijans.
('68', 18, 1, 21, 35873) And yet the very first proposition has not ceased to puzzle the brains of some of the most intellectual and philosophical persons even in the present generation.
('68', 18, 1, 22, 36035) Who knows the nature of original sin?
('68', 18, 1, 23, 36073) What is the meaning of separation from God?
('68', 18, 1, 24, 36117) What is that of the union with God?
('68', 18, 1, 25, 36153) What are the signs of him who is united to God?
('68', 18, 1, 26, 36201) Are all who dare to preach the message of Jesus the Christ sure of their union with God?
('68', 18, 1, 27, 36290) If they are not, who will test the Harijans’ knowledge of these deep things?
('68', 18, 1, 28, 36367) This is my reaction to the foregoing propositions.
('68', 18, 1, 29, 36418) I hope no Christian who reads it will be offended by it.
('68', 18, 1, 30, 36475) I would have been false to my numerous Christian friends, if I had hidden from them my true position on the nine propositions.
('68', 18, 1, 31, 36602) My own detached view may now be stated in a few words.
('68', 19, 0, 1, 36657) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 19, 1, 2, 36698) believe that there is no such thing as conversion from one faith to another in the accepted sense of the term.
('68', 19, 1, 3, 36809) It is a highly personal matter for the individual and his God.
('68', 19, 1, 4, 36872) I may not have any design upon my neighbour as to his faith which I must honour even as I honour my own.
('68', 19, 1, 5, 36977) For I regard all the great religions of the world as true at any rate for the people professing them as mine is true for me.
('68', 19, 1, 6, 37102) Having reverently studied the scriptures of the world, I have no difficulty in perceiving the beauties in all of them.
('68', 19, 1, 7, 37221) I could no more think of asking a Christian or a Mussalman or a Parsi or a Jew to change his faith than I would think of changing my own.
('68', 19, 1, 8, 37359) This makes me no more oblivious of the limitations of the professors of those faiths, than it makes me of the grave limitations of the professors of mine.
('68', 19, 1, 9, 37514) And seeing that it takes all my resources in trying to bring my practice to the level of my faith and in preaching the same to my co religionists, I do not dream of preaching to the followers of other faiths.
('68', 19, 1, 10, 37723) “Judge not lest ye be judged” is sound maxim for one’s conduct.
('68', 19, 1, 11, 37787) It is a conviction daily growing upon me that the greatand rich Christian missions will render true service to India, if they can persuade themselves to confine their activities to humanitarian service without the ulterior motive of converting India or at least her unsophisticated villagers to Christianity, and destroying their social superstructure, which notwithstanding its many defects has stood now from time immemorial the onslaughts upon it from within and from without.
('68', 19, 1, 12, 38267) Whether they—the missionaries—and we wish it or not, what is true in the Hindu faith will abide, what is untrue will fall to pieces.
('68', 19, 1, 13, 38400) Every living faith must have within itself the power of rejuvenation if it is to live.
('68', 19, 2, 14, 38487) Harijan, 28 9 1935

('68', 20, 5, 6, 39380) WARDHA, September 28, 1935
('68', 20, 6, 7, 39407) MY DEAR AMRIT,
('68', 20, 7, 8, 39422) I better dictate this letter.
('68', 20, 7, 9, 39452) These ups and downs in Devdas’s health do not trouble me at all.

('68', 20, 7, 11, 39553) And I know further that he is in the best of hands.

('68', 20, 7, 13, 39657) Really and truly I have never felt better.
('68', 20, 7, 14, 39700) The whole of the last supply of your apples was practically finished by me.
('68', 20, 7, 15, 39776) And I was also taking musumbis.
('68', 20, 7, 16, 39808) Therefore there is no cause for worry, even on that score.
('68', 20, 7, 17, 39867) Whenever I feel the need for fruit I shall certainly take it.
('68', 20, 7, 18, 39929) I have not left off raw leaves.

('68', 20, 7, 20, 40016) So that was omitted.
('68', 20, 7, 21, 40037) But then all the vegetables were to be omitted if I was taking fruit and the fruit jam.
('68', 20, 7, 22, 40125) And now I have gone back to neem leaves.
('68', 20, 7, 23, 40166) The bhaji I have been taking in its cooked form in order to avoid constipation but I stopped it when I was taking apples.

('68', 21, 5, 16, 41690) CHHAGANLAL,
('68', 21, 6, 17, 41702) I got your letter written on Rentia Baras Day.
('68', 21, 6, 18, 41749) It looks very nice indeed that you are taking part in the uninterrupted spinning programme in the national school.
('68', 21, 6, 19, 41864) Thanks to Amtussalaam’s efforts, here also spinning is going on daily for 16 hours.

('68', 21, 6, 21, 41992) The spinning starts at 5 a.m.
('68', 21, 6, 22, 42022) and goes on up to 9 p.m.
('68', 21, 6, 23, 42047) About 3,500 rounds are spun daily.
('68', 21, 6, 24, 42082) I have suggested some changes in this programme, and my suggestion that one spinning wheel should be kept systematically working day and night is being discussed.
('68', 21, 6, 25, 42245) It seems you have not correctly understood my article 1. I did not give up the practice under pressure from anybody.
('68', 21, 6, 26, 42362) When Morarji and Chandulal came here to express their views, their arguments had no effect on my mind or could not make me give up the practice.
('68', 21, 6, 27, 42507) But when I was faced with the problem of how to save the young man, my attitude changed immediately.
('68', 21, 6, 28, 42608) I have done many things in my life with the motive of saving other persons.
('68', 21, 6, 29, 42684) Nor have I accepted it as a
('68', 21, 7, 30, 42712) 1 Vide “A Renunciation”, 21 9 1935.
('68', 22, 0, 1, 42748) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 23
('68', 22, 1, 2, 42793) principle never to yield to popular sentiments, though I do oppose doing anything merely to respect such sentiments.
('68', 22, 1, 3, 42910) My rule is this: Whenever respecting popular sentiments does not involve violation of moral principles or loss of self respect, they should be respected even at some cost to oneself.
('68', 22, 1, 4, 43093) For instance, if it was not for popular sentiments, I would most probably wear no clothes.
('68', 22, 1, 5, 43184) I would see for myself in such practice many moral benefits besides benefit to my health.
('68', 22, 1, 6, 43274) It would strengthen my self control.
('68', 22, 1, 7, 43311) But out of respect for popular sentiments I refrain from taking this very desirable step.
('68', 22, 1, 8, 43401) I learnt about Jivanlal’s resignation only from your letter.
('68', 22, 1, 9, 43462) You should have given more details.
('68', 22, 1, 10, 43498) If I am required to decide about it finally any details given by you would have been useful.

('68', 23, 1, 9, 45305) There are many objections against approving of compulsory sterilization of people suffering from leprosy.
('68', 23, 1, 10, 45411) The practice is likely to lead to numerous evils.
('68', 23, 1, 11, 45461) It is also not right to assume any disease to be incurable.
('68', 23, 1, 12, 45521) It seems safer to me to propagate the method of self control and be content with whatever results can be achieved in thatway.
('68', 23, 1, 13, 45647) I sense cowardice at every step.
('68', 23, 1, 14, 45680) A spinner who was a coward would cut apart tangled yarn.
('68', 23, 1, 15, 45737) A good spinner, on the other hand, would undo the tangle with patience and skill and keep the thread whole.
('68', 23, 1, 16, 45845) A follower of ahimsa would adopt some such method with persons suffering from supposedly incurable diseases.
('68', 23, 1, 17, 45954) Systematic foreign propaganda by us seems to me to be like a bullock cart competing with a railway train.
('68', 23, 1, 18, 46060) If we can spend a thousand for propaganda in the cause of truth, the adversary is in a position to spend a crore.
('68', 23, 1, 19, 46174) I am, therefore, convinced that we should be satisfied with whatever propaganda takes place in the normal course through the work of individuals.

('68', 38, 4, 9, 65998) 51. THREE QUESTIONS
('68', 38, 5, 10, 66018) Shri Gopabandhu Choudhury writing from Bari, Cuttack, sends the following three questions:
('68', 38, 6, 11, 66109) 1. In self sufficing khadi what should be the price of surplus khadi?
('68', 38, 7, 12, 66179) 2. If a villager has cotton but no spinners to give him the requirements of his family and he wants to have his cotton spun for his own family requirements by his co villagers or neighbouring villagers, what should be the wage?
('68', 38, 7, 13, 66407) Will the proposed living wage for commercial khadi be applicable here?
('68', 38, 7, 14, 66478) Or, will it be left to mutual adjustment?
('68', 38, 8, 15, 66520) 3. What should be the wage when the spinner has no cotton of her own and she spins not for wages in cash for living but for cotton and that also till she earns a quantity sufficient for her cloth need?
('68', 38, 8, 16, 66722) The price of surplus khadi passing through the A.I.S.A. can only be the same as that of any other in the same province.
('68', 38, 8, 17, 66842) Now that for the most part khadi sales, except for the requirements of cities, will be confined to the province where it is manufactured, the prices in different provinces will perhaps vary more than they do now.
('68', 38, 8, 18, 67055) But there connot be any distinction between surplus khadi and any other.
('68', 38, 8, 19, 67128) Indeed all khadi can only be surplus khadi, for khadi will not be accepted by the Association or its branches from anyone who is not himself or herself a full wearer of khadi.
('68', 38, 8, 20, 67304) Of course the rule may have to be relaxed during the transition stage.
('68', 38, 8, 21, 67375) On the analogy of the first answer, there is no doubt that so far as the Association is concerned it must pay all spinners alike.
('68', 38, 8, 22, 67505) But the Association will not regulate the dealings between spinners themselves.
('68', 38, 8, 23, 67585) They must be allowed to adjust their own mutual relations.
('68', 38, 8, 24, 67644) Any other policy must fail.
('68', 39, 0, 1, 67672) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 39, 1, 2, 67713) In the third case also the same principle applies as in the first two.
('68', 39, 1, 3, 67784) The thing to remember is that the Association will be responsible for the payment of the minimum subsistence wage where it is itself concerned.
('68', 39, 1, 4, 67928) If its policy becomes popular and therefore general, no doubt it will be difficult if not impossible for anyone to get things done for less wages.
('68', 39, 1, 5, 68075) And the co operation between A.I.S.A. and A.I.V.I.A. may beomce so powerful that wages in every other department will at once be levelled up to their standard.
('68', 39, 1, 6, 68235) The success of the effort will depend upon the hearty response from the buying public.
('68', 39, 1, 7, 68322) If they will realize that they may no longer exploit the poor villagers on whom depends their existence, the problem of unemploy ment and semi starvation will be automatically solved.
('68', 39, 2, 8, 68506) Harijan, 5 10 1935
('68', 39, 3, 9, 68525) 52. VACATE KAVITHA
('68', 39, 4, 10, 68544) A. V. Thakkar says in a letter 1 received last week: There is no help like self help.
('68', 39, 4, 11, 68630) God helps those who help them selves.
('68', 39, 4, 12, 68668) If the Harijans concerned will carry out their reported resolve to wipe the dust of Kavitha off their feet, they will not only be happy themselves but they will pave the way for others who may be similarly treated.
('68', 39, 4, 13, 68883) If people migrate in search of employment, how much more should they do so in search of self respect?
('68', 39, 4, 14, 68985) I hope that well wishers of Harijans will help these poor families to vacate inhospitable Kavitha.
('68', 39, 5, 15, 69084) Harijan, 5 10 1935
('68', 39, 6, 16, 69103) 53. A KNOTTY QUESTION
('68', 39, 7, 17, 69125) Since the talk of the rise in the wages of spinners khadi lovers are filled with all kinds of vague fears.
('68', 39, 7, 18, 69232) For instance, they fear a fall in the public demand for khadi in view of a rise in its price.
('68', 39, 7, 19, 69326) I am hoping that the public will appreciate the little rise that must take place in the price of khadi.
('68', 39, 7, 20, 69430) They have hitherto benefited by the continuous redu ction in prices which hitherto it has been the aim of the Association to achieve by extraordinary effort in the direction.
('68', 39, 7, 21, 69605) The price of khadi
('68', 39, 8, 22, 69624) 1 Not reproduced here.
('68', 39, 8, 23, 69647) Amritlal V. Thakkar had written that Harijans in Kavitha, a village in Ahmedabad district of Gujarat, had been subjected to great hardships by caste Hindus and therefore they had decided to vacate the village.
('68', 39, 8, 24, 69857) Vide also “Our Duty”, 31 8 1935.
('68', 40, 0, 1, 69890) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 41
('68', 40, 1, 2, 69935) has been never so low as it is today.
('68', 40, 1, 3, 69973) And yet the sales have gone down owing to want of propaganda.
('68', 40, 1, 4, 70035) If some systematic propaganda is carried on without increasing administrative expenses, I have little doubt that the sales of khadi can be increased in spite of the rise that will take place in the prices.
('68', 40, 1, 5, 70241) But it is well to be prepared for the worst.
('68', 40, 1, 6, 70286) The Association must not be deterred from doing the just thing by the spinners for fear of the public demand falling.
('68', 40, 1, 7, 70404) It must, however, if need be, remove from its list of spinners those who do not need the support of spinning for their food.
('68', 40, 1, 8, 70529) There are hundreds, if not thousands, of spinners who spin for gaining a few pice not for buying food, but for buying tobacco, bangles or the like.
('68', 40, 1, 9, 70677) If there is pressure, these may be told to abstain from competition with those who need coppers for their food.
('68', 40, 1, 10, 70789) The vast majority of spinners are such.
('68', 40, 1, 11, 70829) The question, therefore, for workers is to find who are the needy ones in terms of the Association scheme.
('68', 40, 1, 12, 70936) From the definition will be excluded those petty cultivators who employ labour and who are not ordinarily in want of food and clothing and who are not obliged to sell their holdings or other property to buy food with.
('68', 40, 1, 13, 71154) But it will strain every nerve to give spinning work or other work accessory to spinning, assuring for every one of the occupations not less than a minimum subsistence wage at the rate of eight hours a day, to all those landless and propertyless workers who would starve partially or wholly but for the work found for them by the A.I.S.A.or the A.I.V.I.A. Conversely, these Asso ciations will not concern themselvesnot for want of will but for want of sheer abilitywith those who eke out a living in some other way.
('68', 40, 1, 14, 71672) If these bodies succeed to the full in their mission, they will have not only fulfilled their mission but they will have indirectly helped all the other needy ones and turned their lives of blank despair into those of bright hope.
('68', 40, 2, 15, 71903) Harijan, 5 10 1935

('68', 48, 0, 1, 83613) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 49
('68', 48, 1, 2, 83658) You shouldn’t have had the difficulty which you had regarding the use of hand made paper.
('68', 48, 1, 3, 83748) The argument has often been advanced against the use of khadi and we have solved the difficulty in but one way.
('68', 48, 1, 4, 83860) Though khadi is relatively costly, those who have understood its importance have found a way of making it cheap for themselves.
('68', 48, 1, 5, 83988) Many of us, for instance, reduced the consumption of cloth after they started using costly khadi and on the whole effected some saving.
('68', 48, 1, 6, 84124) Those who could not reduce consumption saved on other items but did not accept defeat.
('68', 48, 1, 7, 84211) Similarly, when we resolved to use hand made paper, we reduced writing or included more matter in a given amount of space than previously.
('68', 48, 1, 8, 84350) We stopped using envelopes costing four or five pice and started using postcards costing three pice only.
('68', 48, 1, 9, 84456) I resumed here the practice of writing on small slips of paper, which I used to follow in jail.
('68', 48, 1, 10, 84552) On the balance, therefore, our expenditure on postage has not increased.
('68', 48, 1, 11, 84625) I do not know how things are in Delhi.
('68', 48, 1, 12, 84664) But I hope Malkani has started practising economy.
('68', 48, 1, 13, 84715) What we give to the Government is in fact given to ourselves, It is, therefore, not right to think that we should spend less on postage because the money goes to the Government.
('68', 48, 1, 14, 84893) Even when the Government will be in our hands, it will certainly not be proper for public workers to spend extravagantly on postage.
('68', 48, 1, 15, 85026) In jail, we tried to keep the consumption of everything to a minimum because we thought that all things in the country belonged to us.
('68', 48, 1, 16, 85161) For, no matter who ran the Government, everything it owned belonged to us, the people.
('68', 48, 1, 17, 85248) The money that we give to the Government is spent for Government purposes.
('68', 48, 1, 18, 85323) Because the Government money is spent extravagantly when the Government is in foreign hands, it does not mean that such money ceases to be ours.
('68', 48, 1, 19, 85468) It is our duty of course to check its extravagance.
('68', 48, 1, 20, 85520) But so long as it continues, it is we, the people, who provide the money in one way or another.
('68', 48, 1, 21, 85616) Hence the argument of increase in postage should not be advanced against the use of hand made paper.
('68', 48, 1, 22, 85717) In propagating the use of such paper, the expenditure on postage may perhaps go up in the beginning.
('68', 48, 1, 23, 85818) Even them, if the use of hand made paper is likely to increase through our example we ought not to grudge the additional expense on postage.
('68', 48, 1, 24, 85959) Those teachers who see the moral necessity of manual work will themselves find out some crafts which they can take up.
('68', 48, 1, 25, 86078) Nobody else can advise them in this matter.
('68', 48, 1, 26, 86122) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5536

('68', 50, 4, 5, 87911) 68. LETTER TO A VILLAGE WORKER 2
('68', 50, 5, 6, 87944) [Before October 12, 1935]
('68', 50, 6, 7, 87970) You will borrow cotton this season, but next year you must grow your own cotton.
('68', 50, 6, 8, 88051) Anyone will permit you to grow a few cotton trees in his field.
('68', 50, 6, 9, 88115) The seed should be the tree cotton or devakapas.
('68', 50, 6, 10, 88164) It lasts for ten to fifteen years and the cotton, I am told, does not need to be carded.
('68', 50, 6, 11, 88253) I have not used to cotton myself but propose to do so.
('68', 50, 6, 12, 88308) You are right that I did not like your leaving your place even for a couple of days.
('68', 50, 6, 13, 88393) I did not like it because it is a pastime with you, and the best discipline for you is to settle down quietly and work away uninterruptedly for a year.
('68', 50, 6, 14, 88545) A villager absorbed in his work has no time to go on friendly visits.
('68', 50, 6, 15, 88615) We must try to emulate him.
('68', 50, 6, 16, 88643) You must therefore make it a rule not to move out beyond a radius of ten miles.
('68', 50, 6, 17, 88723) It is impossible to get under the skin of the villagers until one lives in their midst all the twenty four hours for an unbroken period.
('68', 50, 6, 18, 88860) The moment you relax the rule, you will find excuses for going.To be free from filth and the dog nuisance is certainly necessary, but one may not run away from them.
('68', 50, 6, 19, 89026) Everyone cannot go out of his house and find conveniences for himself.
('68', 50, 6, 20, 89097) One has also to cultivate that sense of cleanliness in others.
('68', 50, 6, 21, 89160) One must not therefore shun people.
('68', 50, 6, 22, 89196) One cannot serve them from a safe distance.
('68', 50, 6, 23, 89240) I know this is easier said than done, and if you cannot sleep in the midst of these nuisances you will continue to repair to the fields.
('68', 50, 6, 24, 89377) I do not want you to do anything at the risk of your health.
('68', 50, 6, 25, 89438) Yes, you may have in course of time a grass hut, but it should not be far from the village.
('68', 50, 6, 26, 89530) The people must be free to call upon us at all hours of the day and night.
('68', 50, 6, 27, 89605) We must always be within easy call.
('68', 50, 7, 28, 89641) 1 Balkrishna Bhave, younger brother of Vinoba Bhave 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('68', 50, 7, 29, 89743) The addressee, “one of the best workers working in a Gujarat village”, had restricted his needs to Rs. 5 a month.

('68', 51, 5, 17, 90968) As time advances, my private correspondence too keeps on advancing at an accelerated speed and leaves its adversary for behind.
('68', 51, 5, 18, 91096) My capacity to overtake this ever increasing correspondence decreases in the same ratio as the increase in the volume of my correspondence.
('68', 51, 5, 19, 91236) The mischief is aggravated by the new tasks that have come to me unsolicited.
('68', 51, 5, 20, 91314) The most absorbing and fascinating is the work of village regeneration or, to adopt a current word, rejuvenation.
('68', 51, 5, 21, 91428) The fascination increases with a growing perception of the difficulty of the work.
('68', 51, 5, 22, 91511) My mind is living in the villages.
('68', 51, 5, 23, 91546) They are calling me to bury myself in them.
('68', 51, 5, 24, 91590) I do not know how this internal struggle will end.
('68', 51, 5, 25, 91641) Difficulties are already cropping up to prevent such a burial.

('68', 52, 2, 18, 93587) DUTY OF SPEAKING GENTLY
('68', 52, 3, 19, 93611) A Gujarati correspondent writes: Speaking unnecessarily loud affects the health of hearers.
('68', 52, 3, 20, 93703) In this country and among us, women and children, more than men, are in the habit of speaking much louder than we need and a false sense of delicacy makes most of us, even though we may be aware of the noise and its ill effects, tolerate such speaking which really grates on our ears.
('68', 52, 3, 21, 93988) We would not protest.
('68', 52, 3, 22, 94010) This may be a sign of our ahimsa but I would not classify it under ‘courtesy’.
('68', 52, 3, 23, 94089) Model Montessory schools can be abodes of peace, not so our socalled homes, much less our institutions or our public roads.
('68', 52, 3, 24, 94213) You advise people not to tolerate insanitation.
('68', 52, 3, 25, 94261) Cay you not do likewise about noises that are almost equally injurious to health?
('68', 52, 3, 26, 94343) I am quite clear that gentle speech should have the same place in our system of education as sanitation.
('68', 52, 3, 27, 94448) May I warn you that you are yourself often guilty of tolerating
('68', 53, 0, 1, 94512) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 53, 1, 2, 94553) the vice of loud speaking about you and thus injuring your health and missing the opportunity of educating public opinion.
('68', 53, 2, 3, 94676) I must plead guilty to the charge.
('68', 53, 2, 4, 94711) What the correspondent says is largely true.
('68', 53, 2, 5, 94756) I have often tolerated maddening noises which could have been easily avoided.
('68', 53, 2, 6, 94834) I am well aware that they are injurious to health.
('68', 53, 2, 7, 94885) The object of giving place to this correspondent, however, is to draw the attention of teachers to this national defect and invite them to make a beginning by restraining their pupils from making noises and speaking loud in class rooms and outside.
('68', 53, 2, 8, 95134) In railway trains these noises are simply maddening.
('68', 53, 2, 9, 95187) They are made in total disregard of the feelings of fellow passengers.
('68', 53, 2, 10, 95258) Many indulge in loud talks which they can easily carry on in gentle tones.
('68', 53, 2, 11, 95333) In this connection I am reminded of the meetings of Sikhs in which whenever necessity arises someone on the platform puts up a board which is fastened onto a long bamboo containing the words “Please avoid loud talking” or “Peace Peace”.
('68', 53, 2, 12, 95570) Some such device can be adopted by passengers who notice such noises.
('68', 53, 3, 13, 95640) WASTE INTO WEALTH
('68', 53, 4, 14, 95658) Those who have been following what is being written in these columns on balanced diet will not have failed to understand the vast importance of bran which we simply throw away and give to our cattle.
('68', 53, 4, 15, 95858) I do not grudge the cattle what they get.
('68', 53, 4, 16, 95900) But it seems to me that we are thoughtless about cattle feeding as about many other things.
('68', 53, 4, 17, 95992) Cattle do not need bran so much as green fodder and seed cakes which they can easily divide with us if we will revert to the village oil presses.
('68', 53, 4, 18, 96138) But we need every ounce of the bran of wheat and rice if we are to become efficient instruments of production not to be beaten on this earth by any race, and yet without the necessity of entering into killing competition or literally killing one another.
('68', 53, 4, 19, 96393) But I must not prolong what is becoming a heavy preface to a simple recipe which a friend has passed on to me for treating wheat bran.
('68', 53, 4, 20, 96528) He is obliged to his sister for it.
('68', 53, 4, 21, 96564) Here it is:
('68', 53, 5, 22, 96576) Grind sufficient wheat coarse to give you one pound of bran which you get by passing the meal through a medium sieve.
('68', 53, 5, 23, 96694) Add 1 1 2 lb.
('68', 53, 5, 24, 96708) of cold water, eight tolas of pulverized clean gur and half a tea spoonful of clean salt to the bran and stir well.
('68', 53, 5, 25, 96824) Pour the mixture in a flat vessel, cover and let it stand for full half hour.
('68', 53, 5, 26, 96902) Then put a well fitting tava or dish on the pot
('68', 54, 0, 1, 96950) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 55
('68', 54, 1, 2, 96995) containing the mixture and stand it on hot coal and heap hot coals on top.
('68', 54, 1, 3, 97070) Keep the pot between the two fires for full five minutes.
('68', 54, 1, 4, 97128) Then transfer the mixture onto an iron kadai and roast on a slow fire till the water is fairly dried out.
('68', 54, 1, 5, 97234) Then take the pot off the chula and let the contents cool.
('68', 54, 1, 6, 97293) Then strain them through a sieve with clean hands and the contents will drop on a clean cloth or board in the form of threads.
('68', 54, 1, 7, 97420) Expose these to the sun till thoroughly dry.
('68', 54, 1, 8, 97465) These can be taken as they are or with hot or cold milk or hot water or whey.
('68', 54, 1, 9, 97543) Two ounces will make a good breakfast and is claimed to be a valuable aid to remove constipation—the bane of civilized life and precursor of many diseases.
('68', 54, 2, 10, 97699) FOR FOUR RUPEES A MONTH
('68', 54, 3, 11, 97723) Dr. Aykroyd, Director of Nutrition Research at Coonoor, recently delivered an instructive lecture at Bangalore.
('68', 54, 3, 12, 97835) From the lecture as published in the daily Press it appears that a well balanced diet need not cost more than Rs. 4 per month.
('68', 54, 3, 13, 97962) Thus the lecturer said that:
('68', 54, 4, 14, 97991) The dietary requirements of an adult man per day were 16 ounces of ragi 1, two ounces of soya bean 2, an ounce of jaggery, four ounces each of spinach and amaranth, an ounce each of potatoes and colacasia, 1.5 ounces of coconut oil and six ounces of buttermilk—all costing about two annas.

('68', 55, 3, 11, 100204) 71. THE GREATEST FORCE
('68', 55, 4, 12, 100227) Non violence is at the root of every one of my activities and therefore also of the three public activities on which I am just now visibly concentrating all my energy.
('68', 55, 4, 13, 100395) These are untouchability, khadi, and village regeneration in general.
('68', 55, 4, 14, 100465) Hindu Muslim unity is my fourth love.
('68', 55, 4, 15, 100503) But so far as any visible manifestation is concerned, I have owned defeat on that score.
('68', 55, 4, 16, 100592) Let the public, however, not assume therefrom that I am inactive.
('68', 55, 4, 17, 100658) If not during my lifetime, I know that after my death both Hindus and Mussalmans will bear witness that I had never ceased to yearn after communal peace.
('68', 55, 4, 18, 100812) Non violence to be a creed has to be all pervasive.
('68', 55, 4, 19, 100864) I cannot be non violent about one activity of mine and violent about others.
('68', 55, 4, 20, 100941) That would be a policy, not a life force.
('68', 55, 4, 21, 100983) That being so, I cannot be indif ferent about the war that Italy is now waging against Abyssinia.
('68', 55, 4, 22, 101081) But I have resisted 3 most pressing invitation to express my opinion and give a lead to the country.
('68', 55, 4, 23, 101182) Self suppression is often necessary in the inte rest of Truth and non violence.
('68', 55, 4, 24, 101262) If India had as a nation imbibed the creed of non violence, corporate or national, I should have had no
('68', 55, 5, 25, 101366) 1 The extracts from the chapter are not reproduced here.
('68', 55, 5, 26, 101423) 2 The source has “and”.
('68', 55, 5, 27, 101447) 3 Vide “Message on Italo Abyssinian Crisis”, 2 8 1935.
('68', 56, 0, 1, 101502) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 57
('68', 56, 1, 2, 101547) hesitation in giving a lead.
('68', 56, 1, 3, 101576) But in spite of a certain hold I have on the millions of this country, I know the very grave and glaring limitation of that hold.
('68', 56, 1, 4, 101706) India had an unbroken tradition of non violence from times imm emorial.
('68', 56, 1, 5, 101778) But at no time in her ancient history, as far as I know it, has it had complete non violence in action pervading the whole land.
('68', 56, 1, 6, 101907) Nevertheless, it is my unshakable belief that her destiny is to deliver the message of non violence to mankind.
('68', 56, 1, 7, 102019) It may take ages to come to fruition.
('68', 56, 1, 8, 102057) But so far as I can judge, no other country will precede her in the fulfilment of that mission.
('68', 56, 1, 9, 102153) Be that as it may, it is seasonable to contemplate the implications of that matchless force.
('68', 56, 1, 10, 102246) Three concrete questions were, the other day, incidentally asked by friends:
('68', 56, 2, 11, 102323) 1.What could ill armed Abyssinia do against well armed Italy, if she were non 
('68', 56, 3, 12, 102402) violent?
('68', 56, 4, 13, 102411) 2.What could England, the greatest and the most powerful member of the
('68', 56, 5, 14, 102482) League, do against determined Italy, if she (England) were non violent in your sense of the term?
('68', 56, 6, 15, 102580) 3. What could India do, if she suddenly became non violent in your sense of the term?
('68', 56, 6, 16, 102666) Before I answer the question let me lay down five simple axioms of non violence as I know it:
('68', 56, 7, 17, 102760) 1. Non violence implies as complete self purification as is humanly possible.
('68', 56, 7, 18, 102838) 2. Man for man the strength of non violence is in exact proportion to the ability, not the will, of the non violent person to inflict violence.
('68', 56, 7, 19, 102982) 3. Non violence is without exception superior to violence, i.e., the power at the disposal of a non violent person is always greater than he would have if he was violent.
('68', 56, 7, 20, 103153) 4. There is no such thing as defeat in non violence.
('68', 56, 7, 21, 103206) The end of violence is surest defeat.
('68', 56, 7, 22, 103244) 5. The ultimate end of non violence is surest victory—if such a term may be used of non violence.
('68', 56, 7, 23, 103342) In reality where there is no sense of defeat, there is no sense of victory.
('68', 56, 7, 24, 103418) The foregoing questions may be answered in the light of these axioms.
('68', 56, 8, 25, 103488) 1. If Abyssinia were non violent, she would have no arms, would want none.
('68', 56, 8, 26, 103563) She would make no appeal to the League or any other
('68', 57, 0, 1, 103615) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 57, 1, 2, 103656) power for armed intervention.
('68', 57, 1, 3, 103686) She would never give any cause for complaint.
('68', 57, 1, 4, 103732) And Italy would find nothing to conquer if Abyssinians would not offer armed resistance, nor would they give co operation willing or forced.
('68', 57, 1, 5, 103873) Italian occupation in that case would mean that of the land without its people.
('68', 57, 1, 6, 103953) That, however, is not Italy’s exact object.
('68', 57, 1, 7, 103997) She seeks submission of the people of the beautiful land.
('68', 57, 1, 8, 104055) 2. If Englishmen were as a nation to become non violent at heart, they would shed imperialism, they would give up the use of arms.
('68', 57, 1, 9, 104186) The moral force generated by such an act of renunciation would stagger Italy into willing surrender of her designs.
('68', 57, 1, 10, 104302) England would then be a living embodiment of the axioms I have laid down.
('68', 57, 1, 11, 104376) The effect of such conversion would mean the greatest miracle of all ages.
('68', 57, 1, 12, 104451) And yet if non violence is not an idle dream, some such thing has some day to come to pass somewhere.
('68', 57, 1, 13, 104553) I live in that faith.
('68', 57, 1, 14, 104575) 3. The last question may be answered thus.
('68', 57, 1, 15, 104618) As I have said, India as a nation is not non violent in the full sense of the term.
('68', 57, 1, 16, 104702) Neither has she any capacity for offering violence—not because she has no arms.
('68', 57, 1, 17, 104782) Physical possession of arms is the least necessity of the brave.
('68', 57, 1, 18, 104847) Her non violence is that of the weak.
('68', 57, 1, 19, 104885) She betrays her weakness in many of her daily acts.
('68', 57, 1, 20, 104937) She appears before the world today as a decaying nation.
('68', 57, 1, 21, 104994) I mean here not in the mere political sense but essentially in the non violent, moral sense.
('68', 57, 1, 22, 105087) She lacks the ability of offer physical resistance.
('68', 57, 1, 23, 105139) She has no consciousness of strength.
('68', 57, 1, 24, 105177) She is conscious only of her weakness.
('68', 57, 1, 25, 105216) If she were otherwise, there would be no communal problems, nor political.
('68', 57, 1, 26, 105291) If she were non violent in the consciousness of her strength, Englishmen would lose their role of distrustful conquerors.
('68', 57, 1, 27, 105413) We may talk politically as we like and often legitimately blame the English rulers.
('68', 57, 1, 28, 105497) But if we, as Indians, could but for a moment visualize ourselves as a strong people disdaining to strike, we should cease to fear Englishmen whether as soldiers, traders or administrators, and they to distrust us.
('68', 57, 1, 29, 105712) Therefore if we became truly non violent we should carry Englishmen with us in all we might do.
('68', 57, 1, 30, 105808) In other words, we being millions would be the greatest moral force in the world, and Italy would listen to our friendly word.
('68', 57, 2, 31, 105935) The reader has, I hope, by now perceived that my argument is but a feeble and clumsy attempt to prove my axioms which to be such must be self proved.
('68', 57, 2, 32, 106085) Till my eyes of geometrical understanding had been opened, my brain was swimming, as I read and re read the twelve axioms of

('68', 58, 1, 3, 106263) After the opening of my eyes geometry seemed to be the easiest science to learn.
('68', 58, 1, 4, 106344) Much more so is the case with non violence.
('68', 58, 1, 5, 106388) It is a matter of faith and experience, not of argument beyond a point.
('68', 58, 1, 6, 106460) So long as the world refuses to believe, she mustawait a miracle, i.e., an ocular demonstration of non violence on a mass scale.
('68', 58, 1, 7, 106589) They say this is against human nature—non violence is only for the individual.

('68', 58, 2, 10, 106749) 72. SPEECH AT A.I.S.A. COUNCIL MEETING 1
('68', 58, 3, 11, 106790) WARDHA, [On or before October 13, 1935] 2
('68', 58, 4, 12, 106832) We must once for all dismiss the thought of competing with futile soul killing economics.
('68', 58, 4, 13, 106922) Do you know the insidious way in which Japanese fents are glutting the market?
('68', 58, 4, 14, 107001) Whereas less than five years ago they were a few thousand yards, they amount to millions of yards today.
('68', 58, 4, 15, 107106) How can you compete with these?
('68', 58, 4, 16, 107138) No, we must no longer aim at reducing the prices in order to meet this competition.
('68', 58, 4, 17, 107222) We have all these years thought of the consumer and done precious little for the spinner, forgetting that the Association was a spinners’ association, not an association of consumers.
('68', 58, 4, 18, 107406) We have to be the true repre sen tatives of the spinners which we have ceased to be.
('68', 58, 4, 19, 107491) The result is that we have simply jogged on and relied on the political upheavals and indulged in a kind of gamble.
('68', 58, 4, 20, 107607) ‘What is the use of all the fancy advertisements that you have been giving?’ I asked Jerajani 3. ‘We shall soon end in justifying the charge that we are maintaining the institution in order to provide work for the middle class unemp loyed.’ It is therefore that I suggest that we should no more incur losses in order to exploit the neediest of our fellowmen.
('68', 58, 4, 21, 107966) ‘In order to give a hundred women a satisfactory wage, you will run the risk of depriving thousands of them of employment?’ is the question that was put to me.

('68', 60, 6, 8, 110728) The same circular states that the spinning wheel alone was used for spinning and women belonging to the Kanbi, Koli, Rajput, Vania, Brahmin, Khoja, Memon, Darji, Luhar, Suthar, Mochi, Ghanchi, Dhed, Bhangi and all other communities used to engage in spinning.
('68', 60, 6, 9, 110988) The Dheds alone did the work of weaving with looms.
('68', 60, 6, 10, 111040) Altogether, 53 spinning wheels and 10 looms were in operation.
('68', 60, 6, 11, 111103) The following is a communitywise break up of the women who did the work of spinning:
('68', 60, 7, 12, 111188) 11 Kanbi [peasant] 1 Brahmin
('68', 60, 8, 13, 111217) 10 Koli [farm labourer] 4 Rajput

('68', 60, 15, 20, 111482) 2 Suthar [carpenter] 1 Khavas [a mixed caste] The gentleman who has sent this circular writes to say that not even two seers of cotton is spun now at a place where sixty three years ago they used to spin 2,000 seers, not a single spinning wheel plies, the few weavers who are there weave millyarn.
('68', 60, 15, 21, 111780) The production of cotton in Vadod and Kathiawar has increased, not decreased.
('68', 60, 15, 22, 111858) And the situation that obtains in the large industries is also to be found in the smallest industries.
('68', 60, 15, 23, 111961) We can easily imagine how impoverished the people would become when they do not utilize the raw material grown in their vicinity but instead sell it to others.
('68', 60, 15, 24, 112121) And this is what we actually see today.
('68', 60, 15, 25, 112161) The small scale industries which once flourished in the villages are no longer there.
('68', 60, 15, 26, 112247) Hence men and women are unemployed for most of the time.
('68', 60, 15, 27, 112304) And what else could the idle minds be if not the Devil’s workshops?

('68', 63, 8, 23, 116490) WARDHA, October 15, 1935
('68', 63, 9, 24, 116515) With reference to Dr. Ambedkar’s speech 3 at Yeoli, Mahatma Gandhi said: The speech attributed to Dr. Ambedkar seems to be unbelievable.
('68', 63, 9, 25, 116652) If, however, he has made such a speech and the
('68', 63, 10, 26, 116699) 1 This last sentence has been included in “Letter to Mathuradas Trikumji”, 14 10 1935 2 This appeared in Harijan, 19 10 1935, under the title “Unfortunate”.
('68', 63, 10, 27, 116856) 3 On October 14 at the Bombay Presidency Depressed Classes Conference, Nasik, B.R. Ambedkar had said : “Because we have the misfortune to call ourselves Hindus, we are treated thus.
('68', 63, 10, 28, 117038) If we were members of another faith none dare treat us so .
('68', 63, 10, 29, 117098) Choose any religion which gives you equality of status and treatment.” On Ambedkar’s advice, the Conference unanimously passed a resolution urging complete severance of the Depressed Classes from the Hindu fold and their embracing any other religion which guaranteed them equal status and treatment with the other members of it.
('68', 64, 0, 1, 117427) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 65
('68', 64, 1, 2, 117472) conference adopted the resoultion of complete severance and acceptance of any faith that would guarantee equality, I regard both as unfortunate events, especially when one notices that in spite of isolated events to the contrary, untouchability is on its last legs.
('68', 64, 1, 3, 117738) I can understand the anger of a high souled and highly educated person like Dr. Ambedkar over the atrocities as were committed in Kavitha and other villages.
('68', 64, 1, 4, 117896) 1 But religion is not like a house or a cloak which can be changed at will.
('68', 64, 1, 5, 117972) It is more an integral part of one’s self than of one’s body.
('68', 64, 1, 6, 118034) Religion is the tie that binds one to one’s Creator and whilst the body perishes, as it has to, religion persists even after death.
('68', 64, 1, 7, 118166) If Dr. Ambedkar has faith in God, I would urge him to assuage his wrath and reconsider the position and examine his ancestral religion on its own merits and not through the weakness of its faithless followers.
('68', 64, 1, 8, 118376) Lastly, I am convinced that change of faith by him and those who passed the resolution will not serve the cause which they have at heart; for millions of unsophisticated, illiterate Harijans will not listen to him and them when they have disowned their ancestral faith, especially when it is remembered that their lives, for good or for evil, are intertwined with those of caste Hindus.
('68', 64, 2, 9, 118763) The Hitavada, 16 10 1935

('68', 67, 7, 15, 123085) 84. LETTER TO A UNIVERSITY STUDENT 2
('68', 67, 8, 16, 123122) [Before October 19, 1935]
('68', 67, 9, 17, 123148) You can serve the country: 1. By spinning daily even and strong yarn for the sake of Daridranarayana; by keeping a diary of the time for which you have spun, of the quantity spun, with its weight and count; and reporting the work to me every month.
('68', 67, 9, 18, 123397) Yarn should be carefully collected and held at my disposal.
('68', 67, 9, 19, 123457) 2. By daily selling some khadi on behalf of the local certified bhandar and by keeping a record of your daily sales.
('68', 67, 9, 20, 123574) 3. By saving at least one pice per day.
('68', 67, 9, 21, 123614) 4. By holding the collection at my disposal.
('68', 67, 9, 22, 123659) The implication of the adjective ‘least’ should be understood, namely, that if you are able to save more, you should pour more into Daridranarayana’s chest.
('68', 67, 10, 23, 123816) 1 The subscription is in Gujarati.

('68', 68, 1, 2, 124053) 5. By visiting Harijan quarters in company with other students; and with your companions cleaning the quarters, befriending the children and giving them useful lessons in sanitation, hygiene, etc.
('68', 68, 1, 3, 124250) Then if you can save some more time, you should learn some village industries for future service of villagers after finishing your studies.
('68', 68, 1, 4, 124390) When you have been able to do these things and have still time and ambition for doing more, consistently with your studies, you can ask me and I shall send you more suggestions.
