('68', 68, 3, 6, 124588) 85. SOYA BEANS
('68', 68, 4, 7, 124603) It has been found that soya beans can be cooked whold and eaten like any other beans.
('68', 68, 4, 8, 124689) Shri Narhar Bhave of Baroda, who has given his three gifted and gentle sons, Vinoba, Balkrishna and Shivaji, to national service, is himself a careful observer, 61 years old.
('68', 68, 4, 9, 124864) He is living almost wholly on milk and six ounces of soya beans and is keeping perfect health and strength.
('68', 68, 4, 10, 124972) He is of opinion that soya beans help him to avoid constipation which milk alone or milk taken in combination with cereals and vegetables could not do.
('68', 68, 4, 11, 125124) Soya beans have in his opinion helped him also to avoid flatulence which other pulses or milk produced.
('68', 68, 4, 12, 125228) He has come to this conclusion after an unbroken experience of over ten months.
('68', 68, 4, 13, 125308) I may add that Shri Bhave used to suffer from gout and corpulence and had a trace of diabetes.
('68', 68, 4, 14, 125403) He got rid of this triple disability by mere careful dieting.
('68', 68, 4, 15, 125465) In imitation of Shri Bhave the inmates of Maganwadi including me have been trying soya beans for the last few days.
('68', 68, 4, 16, 125581) It is too early yet to pronounce any opinion for ourselves.
('68', 68, 4, 17, 125641) Each inmate gets a heaped dessert spoonful per day.
('68', 68, 4, 18, 125693) This is how the beans are cooked: Clean the beans of foreign particles or dirt, wash in cold water and soak at least for twelve hours, and not more than eighteen, and drain off superfluous water.
('68', 68, 4, 19, 125889) Put these beans in boiling water and cook for fifteen minutes on a quick fire.
('68', 68, 4, 20, 125968) No salt or soda to be added while cooking.
('68', 68, 4, 21, 126011) Salt may be added later.
('68', 68, 4, 22, 126036) 1 At Maganwadi we steam them for two hours.
('68', 68, 4, 23, 126080) Let those who are interested in food reform from the poor man’s point of view try the experiment.
('68', 68, 4, 24, 126178) It should be remembered that
('68', 68, 5, 25, 126207) 1 The source has “after”.
('68', 69, 0, 1, 126233) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 69, 1, 2, 126274) soya beans are a most nutritious diet.
('68', 69, 1, 3, 126313) It stands at the top of all the known articles of diet because of its low percentage of carbohydrates and high percentage of salts, protein and fat.
('68', 69, 1, 4, 126462) Its energy value is 2, 100 calories per lb.
('68', 69, 1, 5, 126506) against 1,750 of wheat and 1,530 of gram.
('68', 69, 1, 6, 126548) It contains 40 per cent of protein and 20.3 per cent of fat against 19 and 4.3 respectively of gram and 14.8 and 10.5 of eggs.
('68', 69, 1, 7, 126675) Therefore no one should take soya beans in addition to the usual protein and fatty foods.
('68', 69, 1, 8, 126765) The quantity, therefore, of wheat and ghee should be reduced and dal omitted altogether, soya beans being themselves a highly nutritious dal.
('68', 69, 1, 9, 126907) We are just now trying the Manchurian variety.
('68', 69, 1, 10, 126954) The Baroda beans we have not tried.
('68', 69, 1, 11, 126990) Maganwadi has its own crop of soya beans.
('68', 69, 1, 12, 127032) I hope to report the quality of Indian varieties from a layman’s point of view as they come under my observation.
('68', 69, 1, 13, 127146) Those who have Indian varieties are requested to send me samples with prices.

('68', 70, 0, 1, 128418) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 71
('68', 70, 1, 2, 128463) 87. NOT PATCHWORK
('68', 70, 2, 3, 128481) A correspondent whose earnestness is unmistakable wrote some time ago a long, very long letter declaiming against the anti untouchability campaign and the methods adopted by the Harijan Sevak Sangh to combat the evil.
('68', 70, 2, 4, 128699) He called it all patchwork.
('68', 70, 2, 5, 128727) The letter lay in my file for several weeks, always making room for something which I then considered more important and pressing.
('68', 70, 2, 6, 128858) With great difficulty I have reduced the letter to readable compass.
('68', 70, 2, 7, 128927) Here it is:
('68', 70, 3, 8, 128939) I hold that your programme re: ‘untouchability’ is misconceived for the following reasons: You presume that ‘untouchability’ is nine tenths of the ills of Harijans and its removal the only cure.
('68', 70, 3, 9, 129134) You feel it a social and religious curse.
('68', 70, 3, 10, 129176) I respectfully disagree with you.
('68', 70, 3, 11, 129210) I hold the whole trouble is directly economic.
('68', 70, 3, 12, 129257) Social and religious aspects that have gained ascendancy in the public view only serve the purpose of sugar coating.
('68', 70, 3, 13, 129374) We have been long trained by our ancestors (who knew the proper clue to it) to close our eyes to the bitter pill inside, but it mocks at us grimly in all its naked truth.
('68', 70, 3, 14, 129545) I believe that ‘untouchability’ is bound to disappear along with the disappearance of the inferiority complex of the Harijan.
('68', 70, 3, 15, 129671) Remove the causee of his poverty, improve his economic conditions, fight for a more equitable distribution of national wealth, make the Harijan feel that he has to revolt against the existing capitalistic exploitation; then a panoramic view of his future will be opened to him and he will then need no outside agency to count the steps of his progress and caution halt at measured intervals.
('68', 70, 4, 16, 130063) You believe ‘untouchability’ is peculiar to Hindu society and confined to our own land.
('68', 70, 4, 17, 130151) But my view is totally different.
('68', 70, 4, 18, 130185) It is a universal problem facing every land and the Harijan that inhabits it.
('68', 70, 4, 19, 130263) So the solution to root out this evil must be one which is common to all lands, and which goes to the root of the matter, and one ought not to be satisfied only with lopping off the topmost branches.
('68', 70, 4, 20, 130463) After all, what is ‘untouchability’?
('68', 70, 4, 21, 130500) It is treating a whole race of men as lepers and denying the elementary rights to them.
('68', 70, 4, 22, 130588) Mere touching or not touching is just a symbol and a symptom of the corroding disease, viz., subjection, and matters little or nothing to the victim so long as the main cancer is not sought to be removed.
('68', 70, 4, 23, 130793) In this view, ‘untouchability’ is a universal menace and all oppressed peoples have got to rebel against it.
('68', 70, 4, 24, 130902) It has taken various guises in various countries with difference in degree.
('68', 70, 4, 25, 130978) Everywhere, its basis is economic which is miscalled ‘political’.
('68', 70, 4, 26, 131044) Indian ‘untouchability’ arose, I believe, out of the conquest of Aryans over the so called ‘Aborigines’ to whom the present day Harijan has to trace his ancestry.
('68', 71, 0, 1, 131207) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 71, 1, 2, 131248) American ‘untouchability’ towards the Negroes is rooted in the land greed of the white man who first travelled to America in the Mayflower.
('68', 71, 1, 3, 131388) The Hitlerian hatred of the Jew, the Bolshevik’s hatred of the bourgeoisie, the Chinaman’s fear of the ‘Mikado’ are all traceable to the same source, viz., economic exploitation, euphemistically called ‘Politics’.
('68', 71, 1, 4, 131602) The Indian ‘asprishyata’, the American ‘lynching’, the Belgian ‘Congo’, the Nazian persecution of the Jews are outstanding examples of this injustice, and world wars are their natural culmination.
('68', 71, 2, 5, 131799) Again ‘untouchability’ or, to speak more correctly, the inferiority complex of the conquered original owners of this land, was a bourgeoi political necessity of the Aryans for keeping the comparatively inferior races of the Harijans under eternal subjection solely for economic ends, that is, for permanently maintaining the superiority in status of the conqueror over the conquered.
('68', 71, 2, 6, 132183) The much advertised I.C.S. steelframe superiority, the recent uncouth reminder to the African Negro chief Tesh Kendy by his European masters, the preferential treatment claimed [by] and conceded to those of European extraction are but living reminders of this hiatus which have been carefully conceived to enable smaller but more powerful nations to exploit bigger but weaker peoples.
('68', 71, 3, 7, 132568) This explains and greatly probabilizes the imposition, for economic ends, of cruel disabilities by the conquering Aryan hordes over the vanquished forces of the sons of the soil.
('68', 71, 3, 8, 132747) Then followed as night did the day the engine of ruthless suppression, and every effort was made to introduce and establish this racial superiority in matters of residence, association, eating and drinking and in every walk of life.
('68', 71, 3, 9, 132980) Poets sang praises of this system and Puranas sealed it with divine approval.
('68', 71, 3, 10, 133058) The Harijan, like the Natal Indian, was feared in commercial competition, too, and there came the law ousting him from main business centres and important thriving trades.
('68', 71, 3, 11, 133230) The impoverished Harijan reduced to mere manual labour became half naked, huddled in huts, developed insanitation and illiteracy and, to use Arnold’s language, “bowed low and let the storm to pass”.
('68', 71, 3, 12, 133429) He had of course to pay the penalty for being a conquered nation, as others do.
('68', 71, 4, 13, 133509) You do not believe in the existence of class struggle and are not prepared to unseat those owners of the so called vested interests for the mere reason that their ‘status quo’ ought not to be disturbed.
('68', 71, 4, 14, 133712) You refuse to recognize that the interests of the capitalists and the labourers are bound to clash with each other so long as the inequality in their present position is approved and sought to be maintained.
('68', 71, 5, 15, 133920) The Harijan asks for bread but a stone is your answer.
('68', 71, 5, 16, 133975) For aught I know about the Harijan, he is least concerned about his ‘touch me not’ trouble.
('68', 71, 5, 17, 134067) I am sure you realize that the Harijan’s untouchability is too deep to be removed by an occasional inter dining, demonstrative sweeping in the slums, ceremonious entries into the village temples and merciful distribution of
('68', 72, 0, 1, 134291) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 73
('68', 72, 1, 2, 134336) clothing and sweetmeats, which seem to be the type design programme that is chalked out for the much tired Congressman.
('68', 72, 1, 3, 134456) To all appearance, the programme seems to go on merrily.
('68', 72, 1, 4, 134513) Details of boys holding scholarships in the till recently banned schools, instances of temples and wells thrown open, are tabulated in Harijan, but what strikes me most pointedly is: Is the Harijan going to bee satisfied with all this?
('68', 72, 1, 5, 134749) Can we say that he is on the shortest road to his salvation?
('68', 72, 1, 6, 134810) I would only wonder what the response would be if the public are asked to give better wages for shorter hours of work and do their duty by the impoverished Harijan.
('68', 72, 2, 7, 134975) To be true to you, I feel compelled to state that the too much stress you have laid on this comparatively minor problem, in preference to their more vital needs, leads the Harijans to self deception, binds them to the chariot wheel of capitalistic exploitation, and puts off indefinitely the day of their economic freedom, which their brethren in other countries are striving hard to secure.
('68', 72, 2, 8, 135367) Such argument was heard when I was touring in the South in the Harijan interest.
('68', 72, 2, 9, 135448) It is well, however, to have it summed up in a letter.
('68', 72, 2, 10, 135503) The mistake the correspondent makes is in thinking that the struggle against untouchability ends with the remonval of touch pollution.
('68', 72, 2, 11, 135638) The campaign had to begin with the removal of the impassable religious bar.
('68', 72, 2, 12, 135714) Those who come under the religious ban are a class apart.
('68', 72, 2, 13, 135772) To them the taint attaches by birth.
('68', 72, 2, 14, 135809) Who does not know that these men though they may be economically well off are still treated as social lepers?
('68', 72, 2, 15, 135919) Thousands of Ezhawas in Travancore and Namosudras in Bengal are very well off and yet to their great sorrow and to the equally great disgrace of the so called savarna Hindus, the former’s possession of the good things of the earth makes no difference in their social status.
('68', 72, 2, 16, 136194) There is no difficulty in admitting that much will remain to be done after the bar sinister is removed.
('68', 72, 2, 17, 136298) Indeed it is the recognition of this obvious fact that has impelled the Harijan Sevak Sangh to handle educational and economic work among Harijans which the correspondent seems to be little.
('68', 72, 2, 18, 136489) That work serves the Harijans tangibly and tests the sincerity of the reformers and brings them in close touch with those whom they are out to serve.
('68', 72, 2, 19, 136639) When untouchability is altogether gone, Harijans will share the benefit with the others of the economic uplift that is silently but surely going on.
('68', 72, 2, 20, 136788) Harijans contribute, say, 16 per cent of the total population of India.
('68', 72, 2, 21, 136860) But those who suffer from economic exploitation form at least 90 per cent of the population.
('68', 72, 2, 22, 136953) It is for that reason that I have said
('68', 73, 0, 1, 136992) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 73, 1, 2, 137033) in these columns that the missions of the A.I.S.A., A.I.V.I.A. and Harijan Sevak Sangh are inter related, and that is why the scope of Harijan has been extended.
('68', 73, 1, 3, 137195) The correspondent is wrong in suggesting that I do not believe in the existence of class struggle.
('68', 73, 1, 4, 137294) What I do not believe in is the necessity of fomenting and keeping it up.
('68', 73, 1, 5, 137368) I entertain a growing belief that it is perfectly possible to aviod it.
('68', 73, 1, 6, 137440) There is no virtue in fomenting it, as there is in preventing it.
('68', 73, 1, 7, 137506) The conflict between moneyed classes and labourers is merely seeming.
('68', 73, 1, 8, 137576) When labour is intelligent enough to organize itself and learns to act as one man, it will have the same weight as money if not much greater.
('68', 73, 1, 9, 137718) The conflict is really between intelligence and unintelligence.
('68', 73, 1, 10, 137782) Surely it will be folly to keep up such a conflict.
('68', 73, 1, 11, 137834) Unintelligence must be removed.
('68', 73, 1, 12, 137866) Money has its use as much as labour.
('68', 73, 1, 13, 137903) After all money is a token of exchange.
('68', 73, 1, 14, 137943) A person having 25 rupees has, say, 50 labourers per day at his disposal, regarding eight annas as the wage for a day of eight hours.
('68', 73, 1, 15, 138077) A labourer who has 49 fellow labourers working in unison with him is even with the person who has Rs. 25. The advantage, if any, will be with the one who has monopoly of labour.
('68', 73, 1, 16, 138255) If both are even there will be harmony.
('68', 73, 1, 17, 138295) The problem therefore is not to set class against class, but to educate labour to a sense of its dignity.
('68', 73, 1, 18, 138401) Moneyed men after all form a microscopic minority in the world.
('68', 73, 1, 19, 138465) They will act on the square, immediately labour realizes its power and yet acts on the square.
('68', 73, 1, 20, 138560) To inflame labour against moneyed men is to perpetuate class hatred and all the evil consequences flowing from it.
('68', 73, 1, 21, 138675) The strife is a vicious circle to be avoided at any cost.
('68', 73, 1, 22, 138733) It is an admission of weakness, a sign of inferiority complex.
('68', 73, 1, 23, 138796) The moment labour recognizes its own dignity, money will find its rightful place, i.e., it will be held in trust for labour.
('68', 73, 1, 24, 138921) For labour is more than money.
('68', 73, 2, 25, 138952) Harijan, 19 10 1935

('68', 73, 4, 27, 138994) I gladly publish the following letter 1 from the Principal, Sanatan Dharma College, Lahore: There can be no doubt that there must be a relentless war waged against this vice.
('68', 73, 4, 28, 139169) I have gone through the gruesome reports enclosed with this letter.
('68', 73, 4, 29, 139237) These are of a different type from those dealt with by
('68', 73, 5, 30, 139292) 1 This is not reproduced here.

('68', 74, 1, 2, 139368) me in the articles 1 to which the Principal refers.
('68', 74, 1, 3, 139420) They had reference to cases exclusively of seduction by teachers.
('68', 74, 1, 4, 139486) The reports now sent mostly deal with cases of unnatural assaults committed by goondas on boys of tender age and then murdered.
('68', 74, 1, 5, 139614) Though the cases of unnatural assaults followed by murder appear more hidious, I believe that they are more capable of being dealt with than the cases in which boys become willing victims of their teachers.
('68', 74, 1, 6, 139821) Both require incessant vigilance by the reformer and the rousing of public conscience against the commission of this disgusting crime.
('68', 74, 1, 7, 139956) It is the duty of leaders in the Punjab, in which this crime seems to flourish most, to get together, irrespective of race or creed, and devise methods of protecting the youth of the land of five rivers from criminals whether as seducers or ravishers and murderers.
('68', 74, 1, 8, 140222) It is no use passing resolutions condemning the criminals.
('68', 74, 1, 9, 140281) All crimes are different kinds of diseases and they should be treated as such by the reformers.
('68', 74, 1, 10, 140377) That does not mean that the police will suspend their function of regarding such cases as public crimes, but their measures are never intended to deal with causes of these social disturbances.
('68', 74, 1, 11, 140570) To do so is the special prerogative of the reformer.
('68', 74, 1, 12, 140623) And unless the moral tone of society is raised, in spite of whatever may be written in the newspapers such crimes will flourish, if only for the simple reason that the moral sense of these perverts had become blunt and they rarely read newspapers, especially those portions which contain fervent exhortation against such vices.
('68', 74, 1, 13, 140951) The only effective way I can conceive of, therefore, is for some enthusiastic reformers like the Principal of the Sanatan Dharma College, if he is one, to gather together other reformers and take concerted measures to deal with the evil.

('68', 76, 4, 18, 144163) 92. ABOUT SNAKE BITES
('68', 76, 5, 19, 144185) I give below a summary in my words of the questions put by a Harijan reader and my answers:
('68', 76, 6, 20, 144277) Q. Is there any risk involved in making vertical and horizontal cuts over a [snake ] bite?
('68', 76, 6, 21, 144368) And, if there is any, is it proper to invite one risk in order to avoid another?
('68', 76, 7, 22, 144449) A. There is no risk at all in making a cut over the bite.
('68', 76, 7, 23, 144507) It would have been easier to follow if the translator had used the word 'incision' instead of ‘cut’.
('68', 76, 7, 24, 144608) The only purpose of making an incision is to drain some blood out.
('68', 76, 7, 25, 144675) Such superficial incision does not hurt much; and anyone who has been bitten does not feel the pain at all and because he gradually tends to lose consciousness the cells in his brain become so insensitive that he has little awareness of what his body is being subjected to.
('68', 76, 8, 26, 144949) Q. Please explain clearly how the tender skin covering the bones escapes injury.
('68', 76, 9, 27, 145030) A. The previous passage explains this.
('68', 76, 9, 28, 145069) The razor's edge does not reach the bone while making an incision.
('68', 76, 9, 29, 145136) Instead of the skin we should think of layers.
('68', 76, 9, 30, 145183) We should imagine that there are layers
('68', 76, 10, 31, 145223) 1 Nrisinhaprasad Kalidas Bhatt, founder of the Lokbharati
('68', 77, 0, 1, 145281) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 77, 1, 2, 145322) beneath the skin which we can see and touch.
('68', 77, 1, 3, 145367) The incision which has to be made is just to open up the skin.
('68', 77, 1, 4, 145430) In that case the edge of the knife cannot even reach the layer of the skin immediately next to the bone.
('68', 77, 2, 5, 145535) Q. What is meant by "using the blade of the safety razor after passing it over a flame"?
('68', 77, 3, 6, 145624) A. The blade should be passed back and forth over a lighted match until the latter burns out.
('68', 77, 3, 7, 145718) This would take only a few seconds.
('68', 77, 4, 8, 145754) Q. Is there no danger of death to the person who sucks [the poison]?
('68', 77, 5, 9, 145823) A. If he has no ulcers in his mouth, there is no danger of death or of any other harm.
('68', 77, 5, 10, 145910) If he has ulcers, there is no question of his sucking.
('68', 77, 6, 11, 145965) Q. You write of mud pack remedies, but you cannot give any assurances.
('68', 77, 7, 12, 146036) A. I can give no guarantee whatsoever.
('68', 77, 7, 13, 146075) Moreover, who will permit me to make sufficient number of experiments to give any assurance?
('68', 77, 8, 14, 146168) Q. The sixth question is that I should have written 1
('68', 77, 9, 15, 146222) exhaustively about identifying the different kinds of snakes.
('68', 77, 10, 16, 146284) A. Nothing is gained by putting before the reader something which I find it difficult to understand because even if I understood, it cannot help me in identifying the kinds.
('68', 77, 10, 17, 146458) Those who [want to] understand this matter more than I do ought to obtain the literature for themselves and go through it; this literature can generally be found in libraries.
('68', 77, 10, 18, 146634) Finally, I may add that I am collecting further knowledge about snake bites and if I find anything more valuable, I shall certainly inform the readers.
('68', 77, 10, 19, 146786) An experienced doctor, who is an old friend, writes to say that there is no likelihood of anything new and worth communicating coming to light.
('68', 77, 10, 20, 146930) I may say that Ramanama is the remedy for a bite by a venomous cobra.
('68', 77, 10, 21, 147000) Luckily, such cobras are few.
('68', 77, 10, 22, 147030) There is little danger of death if the other bites are treated immediately in the manner suggested.

('68', 78, 1, 2, 147254) 93. TWO QUESTIONS
('68', 78, 2, 3, 147272) Many questions keep coming up about the new policy of the Spinner's Association, which is being framed.
('68', 78, 2, 4, 147376) Here are some of them:
('68', 78, 3, 5, 147399) Q. 1. How can workers prepare themselves to put into effect the new policy?
('68', 78, 3, 6, 147475) The best way is for those who have grown accustomed to the new policy to train workers from among villagers and persons who do not know English.
('68', 78, 3, 7, 147620) We shall need innumerable workers if the policy of self sufficing [khadi] is to be made widespread.
('68', 78, 3, 8, 147720) This poor country cannot afford them salaries if these happen to be large.
('68', 78, 3, 9, 147795) If workers are trained only from amongst the English educated persons they would demand large salaries as their needs have increased.
('68', 78, 3, 10, 147929) They no longer possess a hardy constitution.
('68', 78, 3, 11, 147974) And, in a sphere where a knowledge of the English language is not essential they cannot be said to be particularly useful.
('68', 78, 3, 12, 148097) Very often, their usefulness has indeed inclined.
('68', 78, 3, 13, 148147) For instance, they do not like living in villages and they try to import city life into the villages.
('68', 78, 3, 14, 148249) Their bodies are less supple and only in rare cases can they become skilled craftsmen.
('68', 78, 3, 15, 148336) Even when they learn a craft, they can seldom compete with ordinary craftsmen.
('68', 78, 3, 16, 148415) I only want to suggest here that we should give up the craze of looking for workers who know English.
('68', 78, 3, 17, 148517) This does not mean that we should boycott or despite those who know English.
('68', 78, 3, 18, 148594) We should welcome any such person who is available.
('68', 78, 3, 19, 148646) They are all right where they belong.
('68', 78, 3, 20, 148684) The only purpose of saying this is to rid ourselves of the false notion that only those who know English are fit to be workers.
('68', 78, 3, 21, 148812) If a village worker's services are available, he will bring in greater returns than the amount paid to him.
('68', 78, 3, 22, 148920) An allowance of not more than Rs. 10 to 15 should be required for such a worker.
('68', 78, 3, 23, 149001) And he can easily bring in by way of return that amount every month.
('68', 78, 3, 24, 149070) Organizers should train such workers wherever there are khadi centres and to that extent enlarge their field of work.
('68', 78, 3, 25, 149188) Workers should acquaint themselves with all the processes starting from growing cotton right up to making khadi.
('68', 78, 3, 26, 149301) And if those who are in charge of these centres are themselves efficient, they can readily produce such workers at no cost.
('68', 78, 3, 27, 149425) At present, I do not visualize any separate institution for training workers.
('68', 78, 4, 28, 149503) Q. 2. Will the number of private traders increase or decrease with the
('68', 78, 5, 29, 149574) implementation of the new policy?
('68', 79, 0, 1, 149608) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 79, 1, 2, 149649) There cannot be any increase in the number of private traders.
('68', 79, 1, 3, 149712) Making [khadi] self sufficing will be the principal policy.
('68', 79, 1, 4, 149772) Private traders have no place in it.
('68', 79, 1, 5, 149809) They will cotinue for the purpose of selling khadi in the cities.
('68', 79, 1, 6, 149875) There is very little likelihood of there being an increase in their numbers because, with the growing desire of craftsmen to add to their earnings, private traders will progressively decrease in number.
('68', 79, 1, 7, 150078) This is because the latter are impelled by the profit motive.
('68', 79, 1, 8, 150140) Hence they will not be satisfied.
('68', 79, 1, 9, 150174) In the new scheme, the ceilling to the seller's earnings will be fixed and whatever profit is there, will go to the craftsmen.
('68', 79, 2, 10, 150301) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 20 10 1935

('68', 82, 11, 20, 156223) 99. SPEECH TO VILLAGE WORKERS 1
('68', 82, 12, 21, 156255) October 22, 1935
('68', 82, 13, 22, 156272) As today's menu was selected by me with some careful thought, and especially with a view to the needs of village workers, I must speak to you about it at some length.
('68', 82, 13, 23, 156439) The idea was to provide you with food, nourishing and yet within the means of an average villager and within the possibility of an eight hours' minimum wage as we have fixed it, i.e., three annas.
('68', 82, 13, 24, 156636) We were 98 diners today and the total cost of our food was Rs. 9 14 3, which means that each meal cost slightly more than six pice.
('68', 82, 13, 25, 156768) Here are the details:
('68', 82, 14, 26, 156790) 1 As summarized by Mahadev Desai.
('68', 82, 14, 27, 156824) The workers had undergone a fortnight's study course from October 8 to 22.
('68', 83, 0, 1, 156899) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('68', 83, 13, 14, 157163) Total 9 14 3
('68', 83, 14, 15, 157176) Vinoba had passed on the suggestion to me that I need not worry about giving all of you roti 1 but might simply give you wheaten porridge (that we have here every morning) and thus save a lot of trouble.
('68', 83, 14, 16, 157380) No, said I to myself, you young men whom God has given strong teeth must have good hard well baked bhakhari 2, which anyone can make, which one can easily carry on one's person from place to place and which can keep for a couple of days.
('68', 83, 14, 17, 157618) Before the dough was kneaded it was treated with linseed oil.
('68', 83, 14, 18, 157680) This rendered it both soft and crisp.
('68', 83, 14, 19, 157718) Then, as we must have some greens and raw vegetables, we had tomatoes and two chutneys—one made of koth fruit available in plenty in these parts and another made of leaves available in our garden.
('68', 83, 14, 20, 157915) Koth fruit is known for both its aperient and astringent properties, and jaggery goes well with it and makes a delicious chutney.
('68', 83, 14, 21, 158045) The other chutney contained some cocoanut, tamarind and salt to spice the leaves.
('68', 83, 14, 22, 158127) Green leaves must be eaten by us in some form on other, in order what we may get proper vitamins in our diet.
('68', 83, 14, 23, 158237) The vegetable chosen was the cheapest available and grows everywhere in our villages.
('68', 83, 14, 24, 158323) You will see that I allowed the use of tamarind in the preparation of chutney.
('68', 83, 14, 25, 158402) In spite of the popular prejudice against tamarind, it has been found that it is a good aperient and blood purifier.
('68', 83, 14, 26, 158519) I gave copious doses of tamarind water to one of the inmates suffering from malaria with very good effect and have tried it in
('68', 83, 15, 27, 158646) 1 Bread 2 Crisp chapati
('68', 84, 0, 1, 158670) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 85
('68', 84, 1, 2, 158715) several cases of constipation.
('68', 84, 1, 3, 158746) Milk is an essential article of diet.
('68', 84, 1, 4, 158784) Your menu contained half a pound of milk, but you must have seen that I gave you no ghee.
('68', 84, 1, 5, 158874) I hope, however, that you did not miss it.
('68', 84, 1, 6, 158917) For I gave you soya beans and oil.
('68', 84, 1, 7, 158952) Soya beans are rich in oil (20 per cent) and proteins (40 per cent).
('68', 84, 1, 8, 159021) Ground nuts also are rich in oil, but they have the disadvantage of containing too much starch from which soya beans are comparatively free.
('68', 84, 1, 9, 159162) Milk with soya beans gives us almost all that we need in the shape of fats and there is no need for ghee at all.
('68', 84, 1, 10, 159275) Why then go to all the wasteful trouble of making ghee.
('68', 84, 1, 11, 159331) And where procuring good ghee is a doubtful proposition, why have spurious ghee?
('68', 84, 1, 12, 159412) But milk or buttermilk we ought to have, no matter how little.
('68', 84, 1, 13, 159475) Medical men say that it helps in the assimilation of the vegetable fats and proteids.
('68', 84, 1, 14, 159561) Therefore ghee you can omit with impunity.
('68', 84, 1, 15, 159604) I had recently two little children under my care whose diet I carefully regulated.
('68', 84, 1, 16, 159687) I cut out ghee from it and found that they were none the worse for the cutting out of ghee.
('68', 84, 1, 17, 159779) Of course I gave them as much milk as they wanted.
('68', 84, 1, 18, 159830) Our menu has cost us a little more than six pice.
('68', 84, 1, 19, 159880) It was a full meal and the other meals need not be so heavy as this.
('68', 84, 1, 20, 159949) They, therefore, need not cost more than an anna or so.
('68', 84, 1, 21, 160005) Milk may be omitted for the other meals.
('68', 84, 1, 22, 160046) Wheat bhakhari, soya bean and chutney should be quite enough.
('68', 84, 1, 23, 160108) So this is one of the two main things you have to do—to ensure to villagers a balanced diet, and to content yourselves with the same.
('68', 84, 1, 24, 160242) There may be some who burden their diet with useless articles and many whose diet is badly deficient in vitamins.
('68', 84, 1, 25, 160356) You have to introduce the right kind of diet to them.
('68', 84, 1, 26, 160410) You will learn cow keeping yourselves and encourage cow keeping among villagers.
('68', 84, 1, 27, 160491) It ought to be considered a shame that milk is not available in many of our villages.
('68', 84, 1, 28, 160577) The second main duty is sanitation—a most difficult thing indeed.
('68', 84, 1, 29, 160643) But if you have succeeded in introducing the right kind of diet and making the sanitation of your village tolerably good, you will have rendered human bodies worthy of becoming temples of God and efficient tools for doing a good day's work.
('68', 84, 1, 30, 160884) Khadi will certainly occupy the centre of the village industries.
('68', 84, 1, 31, 160950) But remember that we have to concentrate on making the villages self sufficing in khadi.
('68', 84, 1, 32, 161039) Out of self sufficing khadi will follow commercial khadi as a matter of course.
('68', 84, 1, 33, 161119) The argument you will find elaborated in the columns of Harijan.
('68', 84, 1, 34, 161184) But on you will depend the success of failure
('68', 85, 0, 1, 161230) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 85, 1, 2, 161271) of khadi.
('68', 85, 1, 3, 161281) People have been frightened by baseless scares.
('68', 85, 1, 4, 161329) You have to restore their faith in khadi and explain to them the new policy.
('68', 85, 2, 5, 161406) You will of course take up any other industry available in villages and for which you can find a market, care being taken that no shop has to be run at a loss and no article produced for which there is no market.
('68', 85, 2, 6, 161619) Give eight hours of your day to any home craft you like and show to the villagers that as you earn your wage, even so can they earn it by eight hours' work.
('68', 85, 2, 7, 161776) Make Vinoba your ideal here.
('68', 85, 2, 8, 161805) It is impossible for you to emulate his learning or to have his wonderful memory, but you can certainly emulate his industry and devotion to work.
('68', 85, 2, 9, 161952) Go not to the villages to write commentaries on the Upanishads, which you may well do in towns and cities.
('68', 85, 2, 10, 162059) Your work will provide the best commentary as does Vinoba's concentrated work.
('68', 85, 2, 11, 162138) We have to infect the villagers with our passion for work.
('68', 85, 2, 12, 162197) We say they have become hewers of wood and drawers of water 2. In order that they may stand erect and say they shall no longer be mere hewers of wood and drawers of water for us, you have to explain to them the reason for every one of their actions and make them voluntary workers for a living wage.
('68', 85, 2, 13, 162497) What Vinoba has done should be easier for these simple folks to achieve.
('68', 85, 2, 14, 162570) I am told a village lad called Gulab has already broken Vinoba's record in spinning.
('68', 85, 2, 15, 162655) You will also not take a companion to work with you.
('68', 85, 2, 16, 162708) Our policy is to send a single worker to a village or group of villages.
('68', 85, 2, 17, 162781) That will enable him to bring his resourcefulness into full play.
('68', 85, 2, 18, 162847) He may pick out any number of companions from the village itself.
('68', 85, 2, 19, 162913) They will work under his direction, but he will be mainly responsible for the village under his charge.
('68', 85, 2, 20, 163017) Let us not be tempted by the allurements of the machine age, let us concentrate on rendering our own body machines perfect and efficient instruments of work and let us get the best out of them.
('68', 85, 2, 21, 163211) This is your task.
('68', 85, 2, 22, 163230) Go ahead with it, without flinching.
('68', 85, 2, 23, 163267) There need be no despair in a field which Vinoba has made his own and where he has given the best of his 15 years.
('68', 85, 2, 24, 163382) I at least have no cause for despair and that is why you find me settled down here.

('68', 92, 4, 7, 173761) 110. ON ITS LAST LEGS
('68', 92, 5, 8, 173783) Some critics have not hesitated to observe that it was preposterous for me to claim, in answer to Dr. Ambedkar's threat to accept some other faith rather than die a Hindu, that untouchability was on its last legs in spite of Kavitha.
('68', 92, 5, 9, 174017) Indeed, Kavitha itself supports my claim.
('68', 92, 5, 10, 174059) Kavitha had gone on ever since its birth living peacefully till an our zealous worker, not knowing his own limitations, had put up Kavitha Harijans to dare to send their children to the local school, though he knew that there was opposition from some Kavitha savarnas.
('68', 92, 5, 11, 174328) He had hoped, as had happened elsewhere, that Harijans had successfully asserted their right to send their children to public schools.
('68', 92, 5, 12, 174463) But Kavitha savarnas showed that they had not recognized the time spirit.
('68', 92, 5, 13, 174537) Only a few years ago the Kavitha incident would have attracted no notice.
('68', 92, 5, 14, 174611) There were very few reformers then.
('68', 92, 5, 15, 174647) The few were to be found mostly in towns and cities.
('68', 92, 5, 16, 174700) Now, thank God, their number is increasing and presently every village will have its quota.
('68', 92, 5, 17, 174792) But a few years ago Harijans could not be induced to resist untouchability on any account whatsoever.
('68', 92, 5, 18, 174894) It was part of their faith as it was of savarnas' faith.
('68', 92, 5, 19, 174951) These columns contain sufficient evidence of the weekly progress made by the campaign against untouchability.
('68', 92, 5, 20, 175061) Phenomenal though the progress has been, Kavitha and the like show that it has not yet affected the majority of savarnas in many places.
('68', 92, 5, 21, 175198) The fact is a warning to the reformers and the Harijans that much has yet to be done before the hard hearts of savarnas are melted.
('68', 92, 5, 22, 175330) Let it be further observed that it was savarna reformers who advertised the Kavitha tragedy and gave it an all India importance.
('68', 92, 5, 23, 175459) It has agitated savarna conscience more than it has angered the
('68', 93, 0, 1, 175523) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 93, 1, 2, 175564) Harijans.
('68', 93, 1, 3, 175574) I have to note with shame and sorrow that even Kavitha Harijans no longer want to agitate for their rights.
('68', 93, 1, 4, 175682) They have meekly submitted to the savarna impudence.
('68', 93, 1, 5, 175735) In spite of all the help offered to them, they would not leave Kavitha.
('68', 93, 1, 6, 175807) It is easy enough for the few that are there to earn their bread by honourable toil elsewhere.
('68', 93, 1, 7, 175902) The attempt of the reformers to induce them to leave Kavitha under their protection has failed.
('68', 93, 1, 8, 175998) Even if change of faith, not on account of its inherent inadequacy but because of the unreasoning prejudice of many of its followers, were justified, in the present instance it can but defeat the cause intended to be served.
('68', 93, 1, 9, 176223) Secession of stalwarts like Dr. Ambedkar can but weaken the defences of Harijans.
('68', 93, 1, 10, 176305) We know, as a matter of fact, that non Hindu Harijans, no matter how eminent they may be, are not able to help Hindu Harijans.
('68', 93, 1, 11, 176432) Indeed, they are a class apart still in their adopted faiths.
('68', 93, 1, 12, 176494) Such is the hold untouchability of the Indian type has on the people in India.
('68', 93, 1, 13, 176573) Let not Dr. Ambedkar's just wrath deject the reformer, let it spur him to greater effort.
('68', 93, 1, 14, 176663) For whilst it is true that the number of workers against untouchability has greatly increased, there can be no doubt that the number is yet too small to overtake the prejudice of ages.
('68', 93, 1, 15, 176848) Nevertheless [with] a movement which has attained the proportions that the anti untouchability campaign has attained and in which the slightest untoward incident can attract world wide attention, [untouchability] cannot but be on its last legs.
('68', 93, 1, 16, 177093) Humanity will not suffer it any longer.
('68', 93, 2, 17, 177133) Harijan, 26 10 1935
('68', 93, 3, 18, 177153) 111. "DEV COTTON"
('68', 93, 4, 19, 177171) Some of the readers of Harijan may recall the periodical publications of khadi bulletins givng all kinds of useful information to khadi workers.
('68', 93, 4, 20, 177316) It was part of the pioneer work done by the late Maganlal Gandhi who built up the science of khadi.
('68', 93, 4, 21, 177416) Shri T. Sreenivas of Secunderabad sends me a copy of one of these bulletins called Dev Cotton published in 1923. It is almost prophetic or rather shows how attempts were being made even in the early stages of the movement to work out a scheme or self sufficing khadi.
('68', 93, 4, 22, 177684) Now that it is to have the
('68', 94, 0, 1, 177711) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 95
('68', 94, 1, 2, 177756) first place in the activities of the A.I.S.A. the reader will appreciate the reproduction of the bulletin 1:
('68', 94, 2, 3, 177865) Harijan, 26 10 1935
('68', 94, 3, 4, 177885) 112. NEW KHADI SCHEME
('68', 94, 4, 5, 177907) The resolution 2 adopted by the A.I.S.A. regarding spinners' wages and khadi policy generally deserves the careful study of every khadi worker.
('68', 94, 4, 6, 178051) It can produce great changes, if the new policy is properly worked.
('68', 94, 4, 7, 178119) In order to work it properly, all the instructions issued from time to time from the Centre should be meticulously carried out.
('68', 94, 4, 8, 178247) Self sufficing khadi has to receive the first place in all khadi organizations.
('68', 94, 4, 9, 178327) In a way, self sufficing khadi and production for sale will go together.
('68', 94, 4, 10, 178400) Production for sale will be a by product of self sufficing khadi, and the latter will ensure the success of the former.
('68', 94, 4, 11, 178520) As the condition of production is that the workers must be khadi clad, they will have to make or take khadi for themselves.
('68', 94, 4, 12, 178644) This they can easily do out of the (for them) very big rise in their wages which they will be receiving without having expected or demanded it.
('68', 94, 4, 13, 178788) But receipt of wages will depend upon the surplus production which to be of use must command a ready sale.
('68', 94, 4, 14, 178895) Thus self sufficing methods will be easy where there are producing centres.
('68', 94, 4, 15, 178971) For the spinners and other artisans will be more open to conviction than the others with whom workers have never come in touch.
('68', 94, 4, 16, 179099) But some ask, who will buy khadi at higher prices?
('68', 94, 4, 17, 179150) In my opinion this betrays ignorance and want of faith and resourcefulness.
('68', 94, 4, 18, 179226) Hitherto we have confined our attention to stimulating demand in the cities: we have been urban minded.
('68', 94, 4, 19, 179330) We have never cared to study the localities immediately surrounding centres of production, we have neglected the very producers themselves.
('68', 94, 4, 20, 179470) Now, before we even tested the latter, we seem to have confidence that they will respond.
('68', 94, 4, 21, 179560) Why should we not have the same confidence about the people in the surrounding localities?
('68', 94, 4, 22, 179651) Surely they need cloth for their daily use.
('68', 94, 4, 23, 179695) Is it too much to expect them to take in some khadi manufactured by their next door neighbours?
('68', 94, 4, 24, 179791) I know that those who have made an earnest effort in that direction have never failed.
('68', 94, 4, 25, 179878) Failure has been with us, not
('68', 94, 5, 26, 179908) 1 Not reproduced here 2 Vide “A.I.S.A. Resolution”, 11 10 1935.
('68', 95, 0, 1, 179972) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 95, 1, 2, 180013) with the prospective buyers.
('68', 95, 1, 3, 180042) They are always with us, it does not matter what they buy and use today.
('68', 95, 1, 4, 180115) If we 1 would study the wants of the surrounding localities, we would produce khadi that would suit their taste and arrest their attention.
('68', 95, 1, 5, 180255) Khadi workers have done that before now with success for the sake of the city dwellers.
('68', 95, 1, 6, 180343) Will they now turn their attention towards rural areas?
('68', 95, 1, 7, 180399) It is not so much the dearness of khadi that turns people away from it.
('68', 95, 1, 8, 180471) It is our want of faith and resourcefulness.
('68', 95, 1, 9, 180516) If we have faith, we shall find that the same millions are open to us as they are to the vendors of fents that come to us from the Far East.
('68', 95, 1, 10, 180657) They rely upon the cheapness of their pieces to produce a demand for their wares.
('68', 95, 1, 11, 180739) We may rely upon local patriotism and the tastefulness of our wares to tempt the would be buyers of cloth.
('68', 95, 1, 12, 180846) It is not without full justification that the Council of the A.I.S.A. has insisted upon every khadi organization being self supporting and hence autonomous.
('68', 95, 1, 13, 181003) They may no longer rely on the Centre to spoon feed them.
('68', 95, 1, 14, 181061) The central fund should be freed for tapping areas we have hitherto neglected.
('68', 95, 2, 15, 181140) Harijan, 26 10 1935

('68', 97, 4, 19, 183463) 117. PROBLEMS CONFRONTING A SANITARY WORKER
('68', 97, 5, 20, 183507) A volunteer who has taken up the task of sanitation in villages has written a long letter from which I give the following extract 2. This letter may be divided into two parts—one relating to the incopetence of the ordinary worker and the other about the difficulties involved in the work of sanitation.
('68', 97, 5, 21, 183810) It can certainly be said that very little progress, if at all, can be made in a task which is not done in an enlightened manner.
('68', 97, 5, 22, 183939) A volunteer who does his work with sincerity will indeed come at last to do it intelligently.
('68', 97, 5, 23, 184033) It may so happen that a person may do the work entrusted to him through a sense of loyalty to his superior but there may be an absence both of sincerity and knowledge.
('68', 97, 5, 24, 184201) Such volunteers continue to give the expected results and we can hardly hope for any enlightenment or of any new discoveries resulting from their work.
('68', 97, 5, 25, 184353) Every volunteer should become engrossed in the work entrusted to him and keep doing research in it.
('68', 97, 5, 26, 184453) From experiences published in Harijan we find that this has happened in certain places.
('68', 97, 5, 27, 184541) Some are seeking ways and means to do away with the indifference of the people, while others are trying to find out how night soil can be
('68', 97, 6, 28, 184679) 1 Vide “An Experience”, 30 11 1935. 2 Not translated here
('68', 98, 0, 1, 184737) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 99
('68', 98, 1, 2, 184782) disposed of with the least expenditure and in the simplest manner.
('68', 98, 1, 3, 184849) This is happening in relation to Sindi.
('68', 98, 1, 4, 184889) The people's indifference persists.
('68', 98, 1, 5, 184925) There is no response from them.
('68', 98, 1, 6, 184957) Hence, Mirabehn has as a last resort gone to live there.
('68', 98, 1, 7, 185014) Underlying this is the conviction that the people's indifference cannot be done away with so long as we do not find out someone to live amongst the people of every village.
('68', 98, 1, 8, 185187) Methods are being evolved also for the rapid disposal of night soil.
('68', 98, 1, 9, 185256) There is no end to the difficulties of volunteers; the work of sanitation is more difficult than all other forms of service, as it is regarded as the meanest of tasks.
('68', 98, 1, 10, 185424) There is a feeling of great disgust attached to it.
('68', 98, 1, 11, 185476) Very few persons are prepared to do this work.
('68', 98, 1, 12, 185523) I am of the opinion that there should be only one volunteer for every village.
('68', 98, 1, 13, 185602) It is possible that this will yield result most quickly.
('68', 98, 1, 14, 185659) He will realize that he alone is responsible for the sanitation of the entire village.
('68', 98, 1, 15, 185746) By himself, he will never be able to cope with the entire work of sanitation if people from the village itself do not come forward to help him.
('68', 98, 1, 16, 185890) When faced with problems, human beings find out new ways; hence the English saying: necessity is the mother of invention.
('68', 98, 1, 17, 186012) As in the work of sanitation so too in the task of disposal of night soil it is difficult to find assistance from the villagers.
('68', 98, 1, 18, 186141) Let us take the example of Sindi again.
('68', 98, 1, 19, 186181) People there defecate publicly in their own courtyards.
('68', 98, 1, 20, 186237) The neighbouring fields are surrounded by fences, so these cannot be used.
('68', 98, 1, 21, 186312) No one would be prepared to go very far.
('68', 98, 1, 22, 186353) The village popu lation consists of labourers.
('68', 98, 1, 23, 186400) How can the latter find the time to go to a distance?
('68', 98, 1, 24, 186454) How far can the womenfolk go?
('68', 98, 1, 25, 186484) If so, nothing need be said of children.
('68', 98, 1, 26, 186525) Hence, as a last resort, nothing but courtyards remain for the people to make use of.
('68', 98, 1, 27, 186611) Villagers are not accustomed to have a latrine in evey household.
('68', 98, 1, 28, 186677) Hence so long as there are no public latrines in fair numbers or people are not prepared to make their own, public roads will continue to be used as latrines.
('68', 98, 1, 29, 186836) In fact, so long as every individual does not acquire a knowledge of sanitation and he does not put it into practice, the practice of using roads as latrines, despite its being unseemly, is perhaps the least harmful from the hygienic point of view and may be tolerated.
('68', 98, 1, 30, 187106) How can a single volunteer living in a village facing such a situation carry out the work of sanitation?
('68', 98, 1, 31, 187211) He should set aside a certain time each day for this task.
('68', 98, 1, 32, 187270) So long as he is staying there, he should spend that time in educating the people and keeping the place clean to the extent that it is possible to do it singlehanded.
('68', 98, 1, 33, 187437) As soon as someone is ready to take up the work of sanitation in the locality, he
('68', 99, 0, 1, 187519) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 99, 1, 2, 187561) himself should seek out yet another locality in the same village.
('68', 99, 1, 3, 187627) If he is capable enough he should seek the assistance of the district board and such other authorities for sanitary work.
('68', 99, 1, 4, 187749) He should find out the best possible use for the night soil which accumulates every day.
('68', 99, 1, 5, 187838) He may either sell it to the owners of the fields nearby and use whatever he so earns for further sanitation work in that very area, or, if no one is prepared to purchase it, he should give it away to any farmer who is prepared to use the manure made out of it in his field and demonstrate how useful it is.
('68', 99, 1, 6, 188146) This is but a trend of thought presented to the reader.
('68', 99, 1, 7, 188202) I have not been able to put this idea totally into practice myself, nor to make others do so.
('68', 99, 1, 8, 188296) After all this field of work is but new.
('68', 99, 1, 9, 188337) Hence, for the present, there can only be an exchange of ideas.
('68', 99, 1, 10, 188401) Volunteers who are doing this work will adopt from this whatever is worth adopting.
('68', 99, 1, 11, 188485) They will inform me of any drawback in these ideas, and report to me the experience which they have gained wherever these have been put into practice.
('68', 99, 2, 12, 188636) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 27 10 1935

('68', 105, 4, 6, 197501) 128. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('68', 105, 5, 7, 197533) [About October 29, 1935] 3
('68', 105, 6, 8, 197560) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I have your letter.
('68', 105, 6, 9, 197600) We have to be prepared for ups and downs in Kamala's health.
('68', 105, 6, 10, 197661) I marvel at the resisting power Kamala is showing and so long as she has got this tremendous reserve of strength and will, we can hope for the best; at least I do.
('68', 105, 6, 11, 197825) When I said good bye to her in Bombay, I did not feel that we were parting for all time, and I naturally said: ‘We are going to meet again in a year's time, if I am out till then.’ I claim to have that hope still and I interpret your reports in that light.
('68', 105, 6, 12, 198082) I understand the depth of feeling behind your intense disinclination to see the “big folk”, 1 but I know that in spite of your disinclination, if there is a real approach to you, you are not going to be unapproachable.
('68', 105, 6, 13, 198301) I know that at a given moment your decisions are always correct.
('68', 105, 6, 14, 198366) Your firm decision, therefore, does not frighten me.
('68', 105, 6, 15, 198419) I share your view, however, that during the election fever nobody would want to see you, nobody would be in the mood to discuss things that are irrelevant to their electioneering campaign, and India has ever been irrelevant on such occasions.
('68', 105, 6, 16, 198662) From your standpoint you will be going to England at a safe time.
('68', 105, 6, 17, 198728) Khurshedbehn will be most probably leaving for Bombay on Wednesday.

('68', 112, 5, 13, 210452) [Before November 2, 1935]
('68', 112, 6, 14, 210478) Your meal is very meagre, it is starvation diet.

('68', 113, 8, 16, 212100) 139. A TALK 4
('68', 113, 9, 17, 212114) [Before November 2, 1935]
('68', 113, 10, 18, 212140) A visitor asked Gandhiji if he was not putting too much emphasis on the gospel of work, if not making a kind of fetish of work.
('68', 113, 10, 19, 212268) Gandhiji replied: Not at all.
('68', 113, 10, 20, 212298) I have always meant what I said.
('68', 113, 10, 21, 212331) There can never be too much emphasis placed on work.
('68', 113, 10, 22, 212384) I am simply repeating the gospel taught by the Gita where the Lord says: “If I did not remain ever at work sleeplessly, I should set a wrong example to mankind.” 5 Did I not appeal to the professional men to turn the wheel to set an example to the rest of our countrymen?
('68', 113, 11, 23, 212656) 1 From the reference to the new khadi scheme and to the addressee’s efforts towards the spread of khadi; vide “Two Questions”, 20 10 1935; “Dev Cotton”, 26 10 1935 and “Need for Humane Custom”, 2 11 1935. This was evidently written before the article in Harijan, 2 11 1935, wherein Gandhiji refers to this letter.
('68', 113, 11, 24, 212970) 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's "Weekly Letter" 3 Ibid 4 Ibid 5 Bhagavad Gita, III.

('68', 114, 5, 11, 213620) 140. NEED FOR HUMANE CUSTOM
('68', 114, 6, 12, 213648) Dr. P.C. Ray, who at his ripe age of 75 is exhibiting in the interest of suffering humanity the energy of youth, writes: 1
('68', 114, 7, 13, 213771) The custom for fine khadi has fallen off even before the expected or rather threatened rise in prices.
('68', 114, 7, 14, 213874) When it falls further, if it does, it will do so not because of the rise in prices but undoubtedly because of want of love or humanity in the buyer.
('68', 114, 7, 15, 214023) Humanity does not search for low prices in a spirit of bargain.
('68', 114, 7, 16, 214087) The humane in man, even in his purchases, seeks opportunities of service, and therefore wants to know first not the price of the article of purchase but the condition of its producers, and makes purchases in a manner that serves most the most needy and deserving.
('68', 114, 7, 17, 214351) If a sufficiently large number of men and women were actuated by this spirit of love of fellow beings, there would be an ever increasing demand for khadi, and now more than ever, because of the knowledge that extraordinary care is being taken to assure to the humblest spinner at least a subsistence wage—a wage which would enable her not merely to eke out a living somehow but which would enable her to get sustaining food.
('68', 114, 7, 18, 214776) Side by side with the attempt to give khadi artisans a subsistence wage there must be an attempt to find a better, i.e., more natural market for khadi.
('68', 114, 7, 19, 214928) We have hitherto been satisfied with the easy way of obtaining custom only in the big cities—such as Bombay, Calcutta, Madras, etc.
('68', 114, 7, 20, 215060) This was surely wrong.
('68', 114, 7, 21, 215083) I have suggested to Dr. Ray that
('68', 114, 8, 22, 215116) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('68', 114, 8, 23, 215153) P. C. Ray had written that they in Bengal had to seek the Bombay market as there was very little sale of fine khadi in Bengal.
('68', 115, 0, 1, 215280) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 115, 1, 2, 215322) he should, if his health permits, deliver his message of love to the places surrounding the producing centres.
('68', 115, 1, 3, 215433) The whole of Bengal wears fine cloth.
('68', 115, 1, 4, 215471) Why should it not wear fine khadi?
('68', 115, 1, 5, 215506) Under the new scheme it is possible to cheapen khadi if Bengal will produce cotton not for speculation but strictly for home use.
('68', 115, 1, 6, 215636) But that day may be far off.
('68', 115, 1, 7, 215665) For the time being Bengal as the rest of India should buy khadi for humanity's sake, not in a commercial spirit, counting the cost.
('68', 115, 1, 8, 215797) We do not count the cost and find out what our children or our aged parents cost us.
('68', 115, 1, 9, 215882) We support them at any cost.
('68', 115, 1, 10, 215911) Should we do less for our millions of brothers and sisters who are starving by reason of our criminal neglect of them for centuries?
('68', 115, 1, 11, 216044) We may leave no part of India neglected.
('68', 115, 1, 12, 216085) The science of khadi requires decentralization of pro duction and consumption.
('68', 115, 1, 13, 216164) Consumption should take place as nearly as possible where khadi is produced.
('68', 115, 1, 14, 216241) All effort should be directed towards that end.
('68', 115, 1, 15, 216289) We may produce for the demands of the cities, but should never depend upon them as we would on the local market.
('68', 115, 1, 16, 216402) We must first study the local market and supply its wants.
('68', 115, 1, 17, 216461) And since all khadi artisans and wherever possible all artisans working under the aegis of the A.I.S.A. or A. I. V. I. A. will be expected to use khadi, a minimum demand will thus always be assured.
('68', 115, 1, 18, 216660) Satis Babu and Shri Jethalal of Anantpur have made independent calculations and have concluded that self sufficing khadi will mean two yards of sale outside against three yards of wear by the artisans.
('68', 115, 1, 19, 216862) If the calculation is correct, self sufficing khadi to be popular will need considerable support from local markets.
('68', 115, 1, 20, 216979) Since other industries will go hand in hand with khadi, it may be that self sufficing khadi will receive help through village industries other than khadi.
('68', 115, 1, 21, 217134) The test of self sufficing khadi lies in the fact that it will cost the wearer practically nothing but his labour.
('68', 115, 1, 22, 217249) Self sufficing khadi will never spread unless local markets are created all over the country and demand stabilized.
('68', 115, 1, 23, 217365) In order to ensure stabilization it is necessary to define areas for every producing centre so as to avoid overlapping and unhealthy competition among workers attached to the same organization.

('68', 115, 3, 25, 217578) 141. GHEE
('68', 115, 4, 26, 217588) Those who can afford it are fond of eating ghee.
('68', 115, 4, 27, 217637) It enters into the preparation of almost all the sweetmeats.
('68', 115, 4, 28, 217698) And yet, or perhaps by reason of it, it is one of the most adulterated articles of food The vast
('68', 116, 0, 1, 217795) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 117
('68', 116, 1, 2, 217841) bulk of it that one gets in the bazar is undoubtedly adulterated.
('68', 116, 1, 3, 217907) Some, if not most, of it is mixed with injurious fats which non meat eaters must not eat.
('68', 116, 1, 4, 217997) Vegetable oils are often mixed with ghee.
('68', 116, 1, 5, 218039) This mixture diminishes the vitamin value of ghee when it does not contain rancid oils.When the oils mixed are rancid, the ghee is unfit for consumption.
('68', 116, 1, 6, 218193) At Maganwadi we have been insisting on procuring cow's ghee.
('68', 116, 1, 7, 218254) It has meant much difficulty and great expense.
('68', 116, 1, 8, 218302) We have paid as much as Rs. 29 per 40 lb.
('68', 116, 1, 9, 218344) plus railage.
('68', 116, 1, 10, 218358) This can only be for a rich man's pockets.
('68', 116, 1, 11, 218401) We are trying as much as we can to approximate the poor man's standard consistent with balanced diet scale.
('68', 116, 1, 12, 218509) I observed that Dr. Aykroyd had omitted ghee from his balanced diet scale.
('68', 116, 1, 13, 218584) 1 Medical testimony, while it insists on milk or buttermilk, does not insist on butter or ghee as an indispensable part of the daily menu.
('68', 116, 1, 14, 218723) We have tentatively dropped ghee from our menu, except for those who consider it to be necessary for their health.
('68', 116, 1, 15, 218838) We are issuing an equivalent in weight of pure fresh vegetable oils.
('68', 116, 1, 16, 218907) Millions in India never know the taste of ghee.
('68', 116, 1, 17, 218955) After all it should be borne in mind that those who take milk get some ghee in the purest and most assimilable form.
('68', 116, 1, 18, 219072) Apart from the question of relish it may safely be said that village workers can with impunity omit ghee from their diet so long as they can procure some milk or curds or buttermilk.
('68', 116, 1, 19, 219255) At the same time it is the duty of wealthy people and public bodies like municipalities to place at the disposal of the poor people cheap wholesome unadulterated milk and its products.
('68', 116, 1, 20, 219440) Adulteration of milk or other foods should be as difficult as counterfeit coin or note or postage stamp, and their value should be standardized as is that of postage stamps.
('68', 116, 1, 21, 219614) If half the skill that is today devoted to the management of commercial concerns meant for private gain were devoted to the conduct of dairies for the public benefit and shops for food stuffs, they could be run as self supporting institutions.
('68', 116, 1, 22, 219858) There is nothing to prevent them from becoming so, except the public disinclination to give the requisite skill and capital to such philanthropic concerns.
('68', 116, 1, 23, 220014) The benevolence of the wealthy is exhausted in the effort to run sadavrats 2, to misfeed the ever increasing army of beggars who are a burden on society.
('68', 116, 1, 24, 220168) For they eat without labouring.
('68', 116, 1, 25, 220200) It is benevolence misplaced, if it may not be described as mischievous.

('68', 117, 3, 5, 220772) 142. NOTES
('68', 117, 4, 6, 220783) APOLOGIES TO VISITORS
('68', 117, 5, 7, 220805) Maganwadi is taxed to its utmost limit.
('68', 117, 5, 8, 220845) It has guest quarters with maximum accommodation for 12. They are principally meant for A. I. V. I. A. Board members and those who are invited for consultation or otherwise by the Chairman or the Secretary.
('68', 117, 5, 9, 221052) But wherever I stay people gravitate from all parts.
('68', 117, 5, 10, 221105) I have made it a rule to ask them so far as possible to share with me what has been put at my disposal.
('68', 117, 5, 11, 221209) The result is that my abode has become a dharmashala without any private quarters.
('68', 117, 5, 12, 221292) In dry weather this is no hardship.
('68', 117, 5, 13, 221328) People sleep on the ample flat roof of the rooms occupied by me and the Board office.
('68', 117, 5, 14, 221414) In the daytime they spread out anyhow.
('68', 117, 5, 15, 221453) Living thus it is not possible for me to find comfortable rooms for an unlimited number of visitors.
('68', 117, 5, 16, 221554) Yet they come without notice and without appointment.
('68', 117, 5, 17, 221608) Add to this the fact that we are working without servants.
('68', 117, 5, 18, 221667) Cooking, washing and cleaning are all done by us.
('68', 117, 5, 19, 221717) The resources of Maganwadi are therefore truly taxed when visitors come as they do without notice.
('68', 117, 5, 20, 221816) I am obliged to refuse them accommodation or food.
('68', 117, 5, 21, 221867) The latter is always cooked according to the number known to be resident the previous night.
('68', 117, 5, 22, 221960) This is all contrary to convention.
('68', 117, 5, 23, 221996) In an Indian household, a chance comer becomes an honoured guest, and he shares what is prepared for the household.
('68', 117, 5, 24, 222112) But Maganwadi is not a household.
('68', 117, 5, 25, 222146) It is a trust created solely for the service of the semi starved unemployed or semi employed millions.
('68', 117, 5, 26, 222249) We are trying in the best manner we know to husband all our resources to save every pice we can.
('68', 117, 5, 27, 222346) We have therefore no warrant for providing a lavish table at which all who come may sit.
('68', 117, 5, 28, 222435) Hence even at the risk of being considered rude or miserly, I am obliged to be very strict and turn away those who come without previous appointment.
('68', 117, 5, 29, 222585) Those who have therefore been, much against my wish, refused hospitality will please extend their sympathy to me
('68', 118, 0, 1, 222698) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 119
('68', 118, 1, 2, 222744) and excuse me.
('68', 118, 1, 3, 222759) Future comers will take note of the peculiar position we are in at Maganwadi.
('68', 118, 1, 4, 222837) I may mention for the convenience of those who must come without notice that within a stone's throw of Maganwadi there is a well appointed dharmashala capable of taking in a fair number of guests.
('68', 118, 1, 5, 223034) It has private quarters too for a limited number.
('68', 118, 1, 6, 223084) I would like to add that in asking for appointments would be comers should have mercy on me.
('68', 118, 1, 7, 223177) It taxes all my strength to cope with the day to day work.
('68', 118, 1, 8, 223236) No appointment should therefore be sought except for the benefit of the tasks which at the moment engage my attention to the exclusion of all else.
('68', 118, 2, 9, 223384) LAJPAT RAI WEEK
('68', 118, 3, 10, 223400) The All India Achhutoddhar Committee, which was started by the late Lala Lajpat Rai, has decided to celebrate a Harijan Week in the revered memory of the Lion of the Punjab as from 11th November to 17th November.
('68', 118, 3, 11, 223613) Besides what local committees may arrange, the A. I. A. C. has circularized the workers in the Harijan cause all over India to observe certain common features.
('68', 118, 3, 12, 223773) They are as follows:
('68', 118, 4, 13, 223794) November 11: Prabhat pheris singing songs impressing upon the minds of all the necessity of treating the Harijans as brothers and sisters, and reciting the services of Lalaji in the Harijan cause.
('68', 118, 5, 14, 223991) November 12: Kathas of religious literature, such as Ramayana, Gita, Bhagawat, etc., to be read in Harijan quarters by purohits and pundits.
('68', 118, 5, 15, 224132) Other Hindus should be invited to these kathas.
('68', 118, 6, 16, 224180) November 13: Panchayats to be held in Harijan quarters or temples to which all groups of the Harijans should be invited.
('68', 118, 6, 17, 224301) Speeches emphasizing removal of untouchability among Harijans themselves and other evil habits.
('68', 118, 7, 18, 224397) November 14: Caste ladies to be persuaded to visit Harijan sisters in their quarters and establish social contacts with them.
('68', 118, 8, 19, 224523) November 15: Baby show.
('68', 118, 8, 20, 224547) Harijan mothers with their babies should be invited to a temple or dharmashala where caste ladies would meet them and award the babies presents and prizes for cleanliness and good health.
('68', 118, 9, 21, 224735) November 16: Games.
('68', 118, 9, 22, 224755) Caste students should fraternize with Harijan students and play with them indigenous games and end with light refreshments.
('68', 118, 9, 23, 224879) Shri Algurai Shastri who has sent circulars to friends informs me that the programme above sketched is subject to change.
('68', 118, 9, 24, 225001) Readers should therefore be ready for alterations that may be sent from headquarters.
('68', 118, 9, 25, 225087) The chief point to remember is that the celebrations
('68', 119, 0, 1, 225140) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 119, 1, 2, 225182) must be fitting to the great cause and the memory of the illustrious patriot and reformer.
('68', 119, 1, 3, 225273) Workers and committees should zealously devote themselves to the success of the celebrations.
('68', 119, 2, 4, 225367) Harijan, 2 11 1935

('68', 121, 4, 9, 228536) 147. A FATAL FALLACY 1
('68', 121, 5, 10, 228559) Among the questions that a correspondent asked me for discussion in Harijan there was one which I have kept on my file for some time:
('68', 121, 6, 11, 228693) Don't you think that it is impossible to achieve any great reform without winning political power?
('68', 121, 6, 12, 228792) The present economic structure has also got to be tackled.
('68', 121, 6, 13, 228851) No reconstruction is possible without a political reconstruction and I am afraid all this talk of polished and unpolished rice, balanced diet and so on and so forth is mere moonshine.
('68', 121, 6, 14, 229035) I have often heard this argument advanced as an excuse for failure to do many things.
('68', 121, 6, 15, 229121) I admit that there are certain things which cannot be done without political power, but there are numerous other things which do not at all depend upon political power.
('68', 121, 6, 16, 229290) That is why a thinker like Thoreau said that “that government is the best which governs the least.” This means that when people come into possession of political power, the interference with the freedom of people is reduced to a minimum.
('68', 121, 6, 17, 229528) In other words, a nation that runs its affairs smoothly and effectively without much State interference is truly democratic.
('68', 121, 6, 18, 229653) Where such a condition is absent, the form of government is democratic in name.
('68', 121, 6, 19, 229733) There is certainly no limit or restraint on the freedom of thought.
('68', 121, 6, 20, 229801) It may be remembered that many reformers are nowadays laying the greatest emphasis on a new ideology.
('68', 121, 6, 21, 229903) How few of us are going in for any reform in our opinions?
('68', 121, 6, 22, 229962) Modern scientists recognize the potency of thought and that is why it is said that as a man thinks so does he become.
('68', 121, 6, 23, 230080) One who always thinks of murder will turn a murderer, and one who thinks of incest will be incestuous.
('68', 121, 6, 24, 230183) On the contrary he who always thinks of truth and non violence will be
('68', 121, 7, 25, 230254) 1 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 3 11 1935.
('68', 122, 0, 1, 230316) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 123
('68', 122, 1, 2, 230362) truthful and non violent, and he whose thoughts are fixed on God will be godly.
('68', 122, 1, 3, 230442) In this realm of thought political power does not come into play at all.
('68', 122, 1, 4, 230515) Even so it must be obvious that political power or want of it is of no consequence in many of our activities.
('68', 122, 1, 5, 230625) I would make a humble suggestion to the correspondent.
('68', 122, 1, 6, 230680) Let him make a detailed note of all his daily activities and he is sure to find that many of them are performed independently of any political power.
('68', 122, 1, 7, 230830) Man has to thank himself for his dependence.
('68', 122, 1, 8, 230875) He can be independent as soon as he wills it.
('68', 122, 1, 9, 230921) The correspondent has raised the bugbear of ‘great’ reform and then fought shy of it.
('68', 122, 1, 10, 231007) He who is not ready for small reforms will never be ready for great reforms.
('68', 122, 1, 11, 231084) He who makes the best of his faculties will go on augmenting them, and he will find that what once seemed to him a great reform was really a small one.
('68', 122, 1, 12, 231236) He who orders his life in this way will lead a truly natural life.
('68', 122, 1, 13, 231303) One must forget the political goal in order to realize it.
('68', 122, 1, 14, 231362) To think in terms of the political goal in every matter and at every step is to raise unnecessary dust.
('68', 122, 1, 15, 231466) Why worry one's head over a thing that is inevitable?
('68', 122, 1, 16, 231520) Why die before one's death?
('68', 122, 1, 17, 231548) That is why I can take the keenest interest in discussing vitamins and leafy vegetables and unpolished rice.
('68', 122, 1, 18, 231657) That is why it has become a matter of absorbing interest to me to find out how best to clean our latrines, how best to save our people from the heinous sin of fouling Mother Earth every morning.
('68', 122, 1, 19, 231852) I do not quite see how thinking of these necessary problems and finding a solution for them has no political significance and how an examination of the financial policy of Government has necessarily a political bearing.
('68', 122, 1, 20, 232072) What I am clear about is that the work I am doing and asking the masses to do is such as can be done by millions of people, whereas the work of examining the policy of our rulers will be beyond them.
('68', 122, 1, 21, 232272) That it is a few people's business I will not dispute.
('68', 122, 1, 22, 232327) Let those who are qualified to do so do it as best as they can.
('68', 122, 1, 23, 232391) But until these leaders can bring great changes into being, why should not millions like me use the gifts that God has given them to the best advantage?
('68', 122, 1, 24, 232544) Why should they not make their bodies fitter instruments of service?
('68', 122, 1, 25, 232613) Why should not they clear their own doors and environments of dirt and filth?
('68', 122, 1, 26, 232691) Why should they be always in the grip of disease and incapable of helping themselves or anyone else?
('68', 122, 1, 27, 232792) No, I am afraid the correspondent’s question betrays his laziness and despair and the depression that has overtaken many of us.
('68', 123, 0, 1, 232920) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 123, 1, 2, 232962) confidently claim that I yield to none in my passion for freedom.
('68', 123, 1, 3, 233028) No fatigue or depression has seized me.
('68', 123, 1, 4, 233068) Many years’ experience has convinced me that the activities that absorb my energies and attention are calculated to achieve the nation's freedom, that therein lies the secret of non violent freedom.
('68', 123, 1, 5, 233267) That is why I invite everyone, men and women, young and old, to contribute his or her share to the great sacrifice.

('68', 123, 2, 7, 233402) 148. SOME WAYS OF SERVING THE COW
('68', 123, 3, 8, 233436) Shri Purushottam Narhar Joshi who calls himself a worker in the cause of the cow writes as follow: 1
('68', 123, 4, 9, 233537) This letter deserves consideration.
('68', 123, 4, 10, 233573) Only an institution can put into practice the suggestions made in it.
('68', 123, 4, 11, 233643) Some of them can be implemented by Government authority alone.
('68', 123, 4, 12, 233706) However, every reader of Harijanbandhu can implement one point.
('68', 123, 4, 13, 233770) He should use nothing but cow's milk and ghee made from cow’s milk.
('68', 123, 4, 14, 233838) Cow’s milk is better and more nourishing than buffalo’s milk.
('68', 123, 4, 15, 233900) Nothing but cow’s milk should be given to children.
('68', 123, 4, 16, 233952) Ghee made from this is easier to digest.
('68', 123, 4, 17, 233993) The testimony of doctors and vaids regarding these two points has already been published in Harijanbandhu.
('68', 123, 4, 18, 234100) Despite this, many people use buffalo's milk and ghee made from it for the sake of their taste.
('68', 123, 4, 19, 234196) Some others, while prepared to drink cow’s milk, are not ready to use ghee made from it.
('68', 123, 4, 20, 234285) They claim that the ghee made from buffalo's milk alone is good.
('68', 123, 4, 21, 234350) It is whiter in appearance and is thicker in consistency.
('68', 123, 4, 22, 234408) Many people who have become accustomed to its appearance and taste are not ready to give it up for the sake of the cow or the country.
('68', 123, 4, 23, 234543) In fact the whiteness and the consistency of ghee made from buffalo's milk are themselves points against it.
('68', 123, 4, 24, 234652) It seems impossible to keep both the cow and the buffalo alive.
('68', 123, 4, 25, 234716) If the buffalo is to survive, the cow must perish.
('68', 123, 4, 26, 234767) The buffalo is dying even now.
('68', 123, 4, 27, 234798) It is because we deliberately permit the slaughter of he buffaloes that the she buffalo survives.
('68', 123, 4, 28, 234896) If, therefore, we remain negligent, we shall be instrumental in destroying both the cow and the buffalo and shall become dependent upon milk and butter imported from countries where thousands of cows are slaughtered daily and not a single cow is even allowed to grow old.
