('68', 127, 2, 3, 239501) November 6, 1935
('68', 127, 3, 4, 239518) DEAR SRINIVASARAO,
('68', 127, 4, 5, 239537) I have a vivid recollection of our meeting at Bijapur but none of your letter.
('68', 127, 4, 6, 239616) All my ‘secretaries’ were not secretaries but youngsters who were doing their very best to share my burden.
('68', 127, 4, 7, 239724) Mahadev himself was in the Belgaum jail.
('68', 127, 4, 8, 239765) But to show how much I value your letters and your co operation, whenever you can give it to me, I hasten to reply per return.
('68', 127, 5, 9, 239892) 1. The story of Rama and Ravana is to my mind an allegory.
('68', 127, 5, 10, 239951) In my preface to Anasaktiyoga I have explained what I understand by ‘incarnation’.
('68', 127, 5, 11, 240034) What Rama used were spiritual weapons, i.e., satyagraha against the material weapons of the ten headed Ravana.
('68', 127, 5, 12, 240145) There is intrinsic support in Tulsidas’s Ramayana for this interpretation.
('68', 127, 5, 13, 240220) 2. The verse you quote from the Bhagavad Gita, in my opinion, emphasizes the interpretation that I have put upon the whole teaching of the Gita, namely, that when a man has lost his egotism and his
('68', 127, 6, 14, 240418) 1 The addressee, in his letter dated November 1, had asked: (1) When Ravana carried away Sita, why did not Shri Rama practise satyagraha instead of going to Lanka and destroying Ravana?
('68', 127, 6, 15, 240604) (2) Shri Krishna, the author of the Bhagavad Gita which you have annotated, says:
('68', 127, 7, 16, 240686) [XVIII.
('68', 127, 7, 17, 240694) 17] Not only did he say this but helped, though himself unarmed, the Pandavas to conquer the Kauravas after a bloody battle in which millions of warriors were killed, frequently with the power of his brain which proved superior to material weapons, in order to gain their birth right.
('68', 127, 7, 18, 240979) Does this not show that Shri Krishna did believe in the destruction of evil rather than in its reform by peaceful methods?
('68', 127, 7, 19, 241102) (3) When Vishwamitra proceeded to snatch away Kamadhenu by force and when she complained to her master Vasishtha, the latter told her that he was precluded by his vow from getting angry or retaliating, but at the same time permitted her to protect herself against the outrage.
('68', 127, 7, 20, 241379) Thereon soldiers fully armed cropped up from every hair of hers and routed the army of Vishwamitra with great slaughter.
('68', 127, 7, 21, 241500) Why did not Vasishtha permit her to be taken by Vishwamitra?
('68', 127, 7, 22, 241561) Why did he not practise satyagraha to retain her by peaceful means?
('68', 127, 7, 23, 241629) (4) It is said that Buddha died of poisoned animal food offered to him by a devotee.
('68', 127, 7, 24, 241714) We find all his followers to be flesh eaters.
('68', 127, 7, 25, 241760) How is this consistent with ahimsa?
('68', 127, 7, 26, 241796) (5) Is there any instance in history where evil— unreformable evil—was conquered by good only by peaceful means?
('68', 128, 0, 1, 241909) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 129
('68', 128, 1, 2, 241955) intellect remains untarnished, what though he should kill all life.
('68', 128, 1, 3, 242023) In other words, such a person would be incapable of killing.
('68', 128, 1, 4, 242084) 3. My interpretation of the version of Kamadhenu is hat the rage of Vishwamitra was impotent to touch even a single hair of the Kamadhenu.
('68', 128, 1, 5, 242223) It is an illustration of the famous saying that God is the help of the helpless.
('68', 128, 1, 6, 242304) 4. Eating of animal food as a matter of habit is not inconsistent with the observance of ahimsa, even as eating milk and vegetable which have also life is not inconsistent with the practice of ahimsa.
('68', 128, 1, 7, 242505) I have elsewhere argued that practice of absolute ahimsa by embodied life is an utter impossibility.
('68', 128, 1, 8, 242606) 5. Perhaps your question is not properly put.
('68', 128, 1, 9, 242652) There can be no question of conquering evil.
('68', 128, 1, 10, 242697) Evil will always retain its quality but what we endeavour always is to induce our companions, even as we try ourselves, to rid them and us of evil.
('68', 128, 1, 11, 242845) Is not history replete with instances of men and women, the most evilminded, being reformed by an appeal to their higher natures?
('68', 128, 1, 12, 242975) I have not entered into an elaborate argument because I assume that you will take the trouble of procuring a copy of my introduction to Anasaktiyoga.
('68', 128, 1, 13, 243125) It is translated into Marathi—I believe also in Kanarese.
('68', 128, 1, 14, 243183) An English translation was published in the pages of Young India, but so far as I am aware it has never been published in book form as yet.
('68', 128, 1, 15, 243323) I hope you are keeping well.

('68', 132, 1, 2, 248860) 158. NOTE ON CALCUTTA BUSTIS OR SLUMS 1
('68', 132, 2, 3, 248900) Many a time have I rehearsed to myself what I should do if I were a member of a corporation, and when years ago I used to walk through the streets of Calcutta and compare the palaces with their beautiful and sanitary surroundings with the ugliness and want of sanitation of its slums, I used to say to myself that the work and worth of the Corporation of Calcutta should be measured not by the number or beauty of its palaces, but by the condition of its slums, and I felt that then the Corporation had neglected its duties.
('68', 132, 3, 4, 249425) Harijan, 9 11 1935
('68', 132, 4, 5, 249444) 159. MEDICAL RELIEF
('68', 132, 5, 6, 249464) Medical relief as part of village work or social service plays an important part in many reports I receive from numerous organizations.
('68', 132, 5, 7, 249600) This relief consists of medicines supplied to patients who from far and near flock to any person who advertises himself as distributor of such relief.
('68', 132, 5, 8, 249751) It means no trouble on the part of the medicine man.
('68', 132, 5, 9, 249804) He need not have much or any knowledge of diseases and the symptoms.
('68', 132, 5, 10, 249873) Medicines he often receives free from obliging chemists.
('68', 132, 5, 11, 249930) Donations are always to be had from indiscriminate donors whose conscience is satisified if they can distribute their charity in aid of suffering humanity.
('68', 132, 5, 12, 250086) This social service has appeared to me to be the laziest form of service and often even mischievous.
('68', 132, 5, 13, 250187) It works mischief when the patient is expected to do nothing save to swallow the drug given to him.
('68', 132, 5, 14, 250287) He is none the wiser for having received the medicine.
('68', 132, 5, 15, 250342) If anything, he is worse off than before.
('68', 132, 5, 16, 250384) The knowledge that he can get for nothing, or for a trifle, a pill or a potion that will correct certain irregularities will tempt him to repeat them.
('68', 132, 5, 17, 250535) The fact that he gets such aid free of charge will undermine his self respect which should disdain to receive anything for nothing.
('68', 132, 5, 18, 250667) There is another type of medical relief which is a boon.
('68', 132, 6, 19, 250724) 1 A.V. Thakkar's article which appeared along with this note is not reproduced here.
('68', 133, 0, 1, 250809) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 133, 1, 2, 250851) given by those who know the nature of diseases, who will tell the patients why they have their particular complaints and will also tell them how to avoid them.
('68', 133, 1, 3, 251011) Such servants will rush to assist at all odd hours of the day or night.
('68', 133, 1, 4, 251083) Such discriminating relief is an education in hygiene, teaching the people how to observe cleanliness and to gain health.
('68', 133, 1, 5, 251205) But such service is rare.
('68', 133, 1, 6, 251231) In the majority of cases mention of medical relief in reports is a piece of advertisement leading to don ations for other activities requiring perhaps as little exertion or knowledge as medical relief.
('68', 133, 1, 7, 251433) I would therefore urge all workers in the social field, whether urban or rural, to treat their medical activity as the least important item of service.
('68', 133, 1, 8, 251585) It would be better to aviod all mention of such relief.
('68', 133, 1, 9, 251641) Workers would do well to adopt measures that would prevent disease in their localities.
('68', 133, 1, 10, 251729) Their stock of medicines should be as small as possible.
('68', 133, 1, 11, 251786) They should study the bazaar medicines available in their villages, know their reputed properties, and use them as far as possible.
('68', 133, 1, 12, 251918) They will find as we are finding in Sindi that hot water, sunshine, clean salt and soda with an occasional use of castor oil or quinine answer most purposes.
('68', 133, 1, 13, 252076) We make it a point to send all serious cases to the Civil Hospital.
('68', 133, 1, 14, 252144) Patients flock to Mirabehn and receive lessons in hygiene and prevention of diseases.
('68', 133, 1, 15, 252230) They do not resent this method of approach instead of simply being given a powder or a mixture.
('68', 133, 2, 16, 252326) Harijan, 9 11 1935
('68', 133, 3, 17, 252345) 160. SOYA BEANS
('68', 133, 4, 18, 252361) Inquiries are being made as to where soya beans are to be had and how they are to be sown and in what ways they are to be cooked.
('68', 133, 4, 19, 252491) The leaflet published by the Bombay Health Association was condensed in these columns only recently.
('68', 133, 4, 20, 252592) I now give below a free translation of the main parts of a Gujarati leaflet published by the Baroda State Food Survey Office.
('68', 133, 4, 21, 252718) Its cost is one pice:
('68', 133, 5, 22, 252740) Soya beans grow on a plant from one foot to fifteen inches in height.
('68', 133, 5, 23, 252810) Every pod has on an average three beans.
('68', 133, 5, 24, 252851) The plant has many varieties.
('68', 133, 5, 25, 252881) The bean may be white, yellow, blackish, variegated, etc.
('68', 133, 5, 26, 252939) The yellow variety has the largest percentage of protein and fat.
('68', 133, 5, 27, 253005) This variety is more nutritious than meat or eggs.
('68', 133, 5, 28, 253056) The Chinese eat beans with rice.
('68', 133, 5, 29, 253089) Soya bean flour may be mixed with ordinary flour in the proportion of one to five parts of wheat and turned
('68', 134, 0, 1, 253197) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 135
('68', 134, 1, 2, 253242) into chapatis.
('68', 134, 2, 3, 253257) Soya bean crop improves the soil.
('68', 134, 2, 4, 253291) Instead of deriving nitrogen like other plants from the soil, soya bean derives it from the air and thus enriches the soil.
('68', 134, 3, 5, 253415) Soya bean grows in practically all soils.
('68', 134, 3, 6, 253457) It thrives most in soils favourable to cotton or grain crops.
('68', 134, 3, 7, 253519) Slat soil improves if soya bean is sown in it.
('68', 134, 3, 8, 253566) In such soil more manure should be used.
('68', 134, 3, 9, 253607) Fermented cowdung, grass, leaves and dungheap manure are quite serviceable for this crop.
('68', 134, 4, 10, 253697) Temperate climate suits the bean.
('68', 134, 4, 11, 253731) It thrives where the rainfall is not more than 40 inches.
('68', 134, 4, 12, 253789) It should not be sown in water logged soil.
('68', 134, 4, 13, 253833) The bean is generally sown after the frist rains, but it can be sown during any season.
('68', 134, 4, 14, 253921) In the dry season it requires to be watered once a week, or twice if the soil is inclined to dry quickly.
('68', 134, 5, 15, 254027) The soil is best prepared in summer.
('68', 134, 5, 16, 254064) It should be ploughed up and exposed to the sun’s rays.
('68', 134, 5, 17, 254120) Then the clods should be broken up and pulverized.
('68', 134, 6, 18, 254171) The seed should be sown in rows twenty four to thrity six inches apart.
('68', 134, 6, 19, 254243) The plants should be three to four inches apart in their rows.
('68', 134, 6, 20, 254306) There should be frequent weeding.
('68', 134, 7, 21, 254340) One acre would take from 20 to 30 lb.
('68', 134, 7, 22, 254378) of seeds.
('68', 134, 7, 23, 254388) They should not be sown deeper than two inches.
('68', 134, 7, 24, 254436) One acre will require about 10 cartloads of manure.

('68', 134, 8, 26, 254572) All crust should be broken up.
('68', 134, 9, 27, 254603) The pods are ready for picking in 120 days after sowing.
('68', 134, 9, 28, 254660) They should be picked as soon as the leaves begin to turn yellow and drop off.
('68', 134, 9, 29, 254739) They should not be allowed to be on the plants till they open, or else the seeds will drop out and be lost in the soil.

('68', 149, 6, 11, 275949) 185. NEEM LEAVES AND TAMARIND
('68', 149, 7, 12, 275979) In answer to certain questions Dr. Aykroyd, Director of Nutrition Research, sends the following interesting replies:
('68', 149, 8, 13, 276096) You ask about food values.
('68', 149, 8, 14, 276123) Data on this point are being rapidly gathered here and elsewhere in India, and I hope that at no very distant period an authoritative book or pamphlet giving the chemical composition, vitamin, potency, etc., of all common foods will become available for those interested in dietetics.
('68', 149, 8, 15, 276408) I have little doubt that you are right in stating that in practice different vegetable fats and oils produce different physiological effects.
('68', 149, 8, 16, 276550) This is probably due to their chemical make up, but unfortunately we are not yet in a position to correlate chemical composition and dietary effect in this case.
('68', 149, 8, 17, 276712) In all probability some research worker somewhere in the world will soon enlighten us.
('68', 149, 9, 18, 276799) We have analysed neem leaves in the laboratory.
('68', 149, 9, 19, 276847) As compared with a number of other green vegetable previously investigated, they have a high nutritive value.
('68', 149, 9, 20, 276957) Both mature and tender leaves are rich in protein, calcium, iron and vitamin A activity and are superior in these respects to amaranth leaves, coriander leaves, drumstick leaves, lettuce, murraya leaves, and spinach.
('68', 149, 9, 21, 277174) This perhaps explains the tradition of their high nutritive value.
('68', 149, 9, 22, 277241) I believe that modern laboratory investigations in China have not infrequently domonstrated that herbs and other types of food recommended in ancient Chinese books are rich in vitamins, etc.
('68', 149, 10, 23, 277432) With regard to vitamin content, tamarind and lemon are roughly similar, except that the latter is richer in the antiscorbutic vitamin C. Tamarind plup, unlike lemon, contains a good deal of tartaric acid—about 14%; the chief acid
('68', 150, 0, 1, 277662) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 151
('68', 150, 1, 2, 277707) in lemon is citric acid.
('68', 150, 1, 3, 277732) Otherwise the two fruits resemble each other in food value.
('68', 150, 1, 4, 277792) Tamarind is stated to contain a laxative principle.
('68', 150, 1, 5, 277844) I can offer nothing in support of the popular belief that it induces fever and rheumatism.
('68', 150, 1, 6, 277935) The reader should know that I have been making extensive experiments in neem leaves and tamarind.
('68', 150, 1, 7, 278033) Neem leaves have been taken with impunity by several.
('68', 150, 1, 8, 278087) My difficulty has been to make them palatable.
('68', 150, 1, 9, 278134) Taken in the form of chutney containing sufficient tamarind pulp and salt or lemon and salt, it is least objectionable.
('68', 150, 1, 10, 278254) Some take two to three tolas of whole leaves with relish.
('68', 150, 1, 11, 278312) I am unable to say definitely what effect the taking of leaves produces on the system.
('68', 150, 1, 12, 278399) I have been tempting volunteers to try them because of the high merit attributed in Ayurveda to them and because of their decidedly good effect on Shri Bhansali 1. Their common use would enable the poor people without extra cost to take the green leaves upon which modern diet experts lay much stress.
('68', 150, 1, 13, 278701) That the use of the leaf produces no ill effect can be stated with perfect confidence.
('68', 150, 1, 14, 278788) Of the good effect of tamarind I can write with equal confidence.
('68', 150, 1, 15, 278854) One ounce of pulp taken with meals has in several cases induced free movement of bowels.
('68', 150, 1, 16, 278943) It can be mixed with vegetables or rice or dal.
('68', 150, 1, 17, 278991) It can be eaten as jam when mixed with sufficient quantity of gur.
('68', 150, 1, 18, 279058) I have used it with beneficial effect for reducing fevers by giving it in the form of tamarind water.
('68', 150, 1, 19, 279160) In no case have I found it to have induced cold or rheumatism or boils as many people believe it does.
('68', 150, 1, 20, 279263) There is hardly a man or woman in the South who does not eat tamarind in some shape or form.
('68', 150, 1, 21, 279356) It is the base for its famous rasam.
('68', 150, 1, 22, 279393) Village workers will have to find out cheap, effective and harmless substitutes for the expensive yet useful articles one uses in cities and which one cannot get in the villages for love or money.
('68', 150, 1, 23, 279590) Tamarind neem leaf are such substitutes.
('68', 150, 2, 24, 279631) Harijan, 16 11 1935
('68', 150, 3, 25, 279651) 186. CASTE HAS TO GO
('68', 150, 4, 26, 279672) I gladly publish Sir Govindrao Madgaonkar’s open letter 3 in this issue.
('68', 150, 4, 27, 279745) My own position has been often stated in these columns.
('68', 150, 4, 28, 279801) It may be summed up as follows:
('68', 150, 5, 29, 279833) 1 Jayakrishna P. Bhansali 2 Vide also “Need for Care”, 30 11 1935. 3 The letter appeared under the title “An Open Letter to Mahatma Gandhi and Hindu Leaders”.
('68', 150, 5, 30, 279992) The writer, a former judge of the Bombay High Court, had appealed to Gandhiji, Madan Mohan Malaviya and N.C. Kelkar and others “to give a clear and a courageous lead” in reforming the caste system.
('68', 151, 0, 1, 280190) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 151, 1, 2, 280232) 1. I believe in varnashrama of the Vedas which in my opinion is based on absolute equality of status, notwithstanding passages to the contrary in the smritis and elsewhere.
('68', 151, 1, 3, 280405) 2. Every word of the printed works passing muster as ‘Shastras’ is not, in my opinion, a revelation.
('68', 151, 1, 4, 280506) 3. The interpretation of accepted taxts has undergone evolution, and is capable of indefinite evolution, even as the human intellect and heart are.
('68', 151, 1, 5, 280654) 4. Nothing in the Shastras which is manifestly contrary to universal truths and morals can stand.
('68', 151, 1, 6, 280752) 5. Nothing in the Shastras which is capable of being reasoned can stand if it is in conflict with reason.
('68', 151, 1, 7, 280858) 6. Varnashrama of the Shastras is today non existent in practice.
('68', 151, 1, 8, 280924) 7. The present caste system is the very antithesis of varnashrama.
('68', 151, 1, 9, 280991) The sooner public opinion abolishes it the better.
('68', 151, 1, 10, 281042) 8. In varnashrama there was and should be no prohibition of intermarriage or inter dining.
('68', 151, 1, 11, 281133) Prohibition there is of change of one’s hereditary occupation for purposes of gain.
('68', 151, 1, 12, 281217) The existing practice is, therefore, doubly wrong in that it has set up cruel restrictions about inter dining and intermarriage and tolerates anarchy about choice of occupation.
('68', 151, 1, 13, 281395) 9. Thought there is in varnashrama no prohibition against intermarriage and inter dining, there can be no compulsion.
('68', 151, 1, 14, 281513) It must be left to the unfettered choice of the individuals as to where he or she will marry or dine.
('68', 151, 1, 15, 281615) If the law of varnashrama was observed there would naturally be a tendency, so far as marriage is concerned, for people to restrict the marital relations to their own varna.
('68', 151, 1, 16, 281789) 10. As I have repeatedly said there is no such thing as untouchability by birth in the Shastras.
('68', 151, 1, 17, 281886) I hold the present practice to to be a sin and the greatest blot on Hinduism.
('68', 151, 1, 18, 281964) I feel more than ever that if untouchability lives, Hinduism dies.
('68', 151, 1, 19, 282031) 11. The most effective, quickest, and the most unobtrusive way to destroy caste is for reformers to begin the practice with themselves and where necessary take the consequences of social boycott.
('68', 151, 1, 20, 282227) The reform will not come by reviling the orthodox.
('68', 151, 1, 21, 282278) The change will be gradual and imperceptible.
('68', 151, 1, 22, 282324) The so called higher classes will have to descend from their pedestal before they can make any impression upon the so called lower classed.
('68', 151, 1, 23, 282464) Day to day experience of village
('68', 152, 0, 1, 282497) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 153
('68', 152, 1, 2, 282542) work shows how difficult the task is of bridging the gulf that exists between the city dwellers and the villagers, the higher classes and the lower classes.
('68', 152, 1, 3, 282699) The two are not synonymous terms.
('68', 152, 1, 4, 282733) For the class distinction exists both in the cities and the villages.
('68', 152, 2, 5, 282803) Harijan, 16 11 1935
('68', 152, 3, 6, 282823) 187. AWFULNESS OF CHILD MARRIAGE
('68', 152, 4, 7, 282856) The Anti Child Marriage Committee has published a useful and instructive bulletin on child marriage.
('68', 152, 4, 8, 282957) I copy the main paragraphs below: 1
('68', 152, 5, 9, 282993) The Census Report for India of 1931 gave the following figures of the number of girls who are married under the age of 15 by age groups;
('68', 152, 6, 10, 283130) Age group Percentage married
('68', 152, 7, 11, 283159) 0 to 1 0.8
('68', 152, 8, 12, 283170) 1 ” 2 1.2
('68', 152, 9, 13, 283180) 2 ” 3 2.0
('68', 152, 10, 14, 283190) 3 ” 4 4.2
('68', 152, 11, 15, 283200) 4 ” 5 6.6
('68', 152, 12, 16, 283210) 5 ” 10 19.3
('68', 152, 13, 17, 283222) 10 ” 15 38.1
('68', 152, 14, 18, 283235) Thus nearly one girl in 100 girls of less than one year of age is married and the same horrible fact is repeated in all the other age groups under 15.
('68', 152, 15, 19, 283386) One consequence of this is the almost unbelievable number of child widows in the country.
('68', 152, 16, 20, 283476) The figures are:
('68', 152, 17, 21, 283493) Age group Actual number of widows
('68', 152, 18, 22, 283527) 0 to 1 1,515
('68', 152, 19, 23, 283540) 1 ” 2 1,785
('68', 152, 20, 24, 283552) 2 ” 3 3, 485
('68', 152, 21, 25, 283565) 3 ” 4 9,076
('68', 152, 22, 26, 283577) 4 ” 5 15,019
('68', 152, 23, 27, 283590) 5 ” 10 1,05,482
('68', 152, 24, 28, 283606) 10 ” 15 1,85,339
('68', 152, 25, 29, 283623) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('68', 153, 0, 1, 283660) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 153, 1, 2, 283702) Another consequence of child marriage is the number of young mothers who die in childbirth.
('68', 153, 1, 3, 283794) 2,00,000 deaths in child birth is the yearly average for India.
('68', 153, 1, 4, 283858) This works up to 20 deaths per hour, and a vast number of these deaths occur to girls in their teens .
('68', 153, 2, 5, 283961) Lastly, child marriage affects not merely the mother but the child and therefore the race.
('68', 153, 2, 6, 284052) In India out of every, 1,000 children born, 181 die.
('68', 153, 2, 7, 284105) This is the average; there are places in India where the average goes up to 400 per, 1,000. .
('68', 153, 3, 8, 284199) The figures should cause us all to hang our heads in shame.
('68', 153, 3, 9, 284259) But that won’t remedy the evil.
('68', 153, 3, 10, 284291) The evil of child marriage is at least as extensive in the villages as in the cities.
('68', 153, 3, 11, 284377) It is pre emi nently women’s work.
('68', 153, 3, 12, 284412) Men have no doubt to do their share.
('68', 153, 3, 13, 284449) But when a man turns into a beast, he is not likely to listen to reason.
('68', 153, 3, 14, 284522) It is the mothers who have to be educated to understand their privilege and duty of refusal.
('68', 153, 3, 15, 284615) Who can teach them this but women?
('68', 153, 3, 16, 284650) I venture to suggest therefore that the All India Women’s Conference to be true to its name has to descend to the villages.
('68', 153, 3, 17, 284774) The bulletins are valuable.
('68', 153, 3, 18, 284802) They only reach a few of the English knowing city dwellers.
('68', 153, 3, 19, 284862) What is needed is personal touch with the village women.
('68', 153, 3, 20, 284919) Even when, if ever, it is established, the task won’t be easy.
('68', 153, 3, 21, 284982) But some day or other the beginning has to be made in that direction before any result can be hoped for.
('68', 153, 3, 22, 285087) Will the All India Women’s Conference make common cause with the All India Village Industries Association?
('68', 153, 3, 23, 285194) No village worker, no matter how able he or she is, need expect to approach villagers purely for the sake of social reform.
('68', 153, 3, 24, 285318) They will have to touch all spheres of village life.
('68', 153, 3, 25, 285371) Village work, I must repeat, means real education, not in the three R’s but in opening the minds of the villagers to the needs of true life befitting thinking beings which humans are supposed to be.
('68', 153, 4, 26, 285570) Harijan, 16 11 1935

('68', 155, 1, 2, 286786) 190. LETTER TO DRAUPADI SHARMA
('68', 155, 2, 3, 286817) WARDHA, November 16, 1935
('68', 155, 3, 4, 286843) DRAUPADI,
('68', 155, 4, 5, 286853) I have your letter of the 30th October but not the one of October 8. Even the letter from Colombo has not been returned though the letter enclosed with Ramdas’s has been received.
('68', 155, 4, 6, 287033) I would not like to bother you this time to send me a copy of the letter from Ceylon.
('68', 155, 4, 7, 287119) Make enquiries there if possible.
('68', 155, 4, 8, 287153) To whom did you give it?

('68', 161, 4, 9, 295421) 200. LETTER TO H.L. SHARMA
('68', 161, 5, 10, 295448) WARDHA, November 21, 1935

('68', 161, 9, 16, 295774) 201. TALK WITH PROFESSORS AND STUDENTS 3
('68', 161, 10, 17, 295815) [Before November 23, 1935]
('68', 161, 11, 18, 295842) Finding that they were thinking of opening night schools for adults and children 4, Gandhiji wondered whether they were agreeable to working under All India Village Industries Association or would chalk out their own path.
('68', 161, 11, 19, 296065) If they did the latter he had naturally no suggestions to make.
('68', 161, 11, 20, 296129) If they would work under the All India
('68', 161, 12, 21, 296168) 1 A Harijan leader of Ahmedabad 2 The letter appeared under the date line “Ahmedabad, November 21, 1935”.
('68', 161, 12, 22, 296274) 3 Of a college newly started in Wardha.
('68', 161, 12, 23, 296314) This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('68', 161, 12, 24, 296370) 4 In Sindi
('68', 162, 0, 1, 296381) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 163
('68', 162, 1, 2, 296426) Village Industries Association he would give them his own idea of the educational needs of the villagers.
('68', 162, 1, 3, 296532) He Said: What they need is not a knowledge of the three Rs, but a knowledge of their economic life and how they can better it.
('68', 162, 1, 4, 296659) They are today working as mere automatons, without any responsibility whatsoever to their surroundings and without feeling the joy of work.
('68', 162, 1, 5, 296799) We are entirely responsible for this sate of things, as we have had no intimate contact with them.
('68', 162, 1, 6, 296898) We have indeed studied their Politico economic condition, as did the late Romesh Chandra Dutt.
('68', 162, 1, 7, 296993) But whilst we have been told of the state to which they have been reduced, they do not know how they themselves can partly or wholly remove their poverty.
('68', 162, 1, 8, 297148) Now I think it is possible to show them how to double their income.
('68', 162, 1, 9, 297216) You will say they are heavily taxed.
('68', 162, 1, 10, 297253) That they are, but I am not cancerned with that problem at the present moment.
('68', 162, 1, 11, 297332) Our present policy is to leave all politics or politico economics alone.
('68', 162, 1, 12, 297405) You will therefore begin with a study of their social, hygienic and moral condition.
('68', 162, 1, 13, 297490) You may use magic lantern slides for the purpose.
('68', 162, 1, 14, 297540) You have to show them that untouchability is no part of religion, and that the idea of superiority of status is foreign to any true religion.
('68', 162, 1, 15, 297682) Just as a healthy man does not regard an unhealthy man as inferior to him in status, even so a teacher or a merchant may not regard a scavenger as inferior to him.
('68', 162, 1, 16, 297846) You have to teach them these fundamentals of religion and ethics.
('68', 162, 1, 17, 297912) Then you will teach them geography and history—you will begin with the history of their own village.
('68', 162, 1, 18, 298013) Now I would teach them the three Rs as a means for imparting a knowledge of these things, but you do not need to make them matriculates or graduates for this purpose.
('68', 162, 1, 19, 298180) A knowledge of English may be a source of income in these days, but it is not necessary to add to the health of one’s mind or body.
('68', 162, 1, 20, 298312) All our energy has been sapped in mastering a foreign language and in reading tons of books which in no way help us to keep ourselves physically and morally fit or to serve the villagers.
('68', 162, 1, 21, 298500) You will thus see where I bring in a knowledge of the three Rs. It comes in at the end, and at the long end at that, and not in the beginning, and then, as a help to things permanent.
('68', 162, 1, 22, 298684) You cannot more usefully pass an hour every night with them than by teaching them the laws of health, social morals, and the way of a strenuous life of easy labour.
('68', 162, 2, 23, 298849) Harijan, 23 11 1935
('68', 163, 0, 1, 298869) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 163, 1, 2, 298911) 202. FEAR COMPLEX
('68', 163, 2, 3, 298929) Many workers are so frightened of village life that they fear that if they are not paid by some agency they will not be able to earn their living by labouring in villages, especially if they are married and have a family to support.
('68', 163, 2, 4, 299162) In my opinion this is a demoralizing belief.
('68', 163, 2, 5, 299207) No doubt, if a person goes to a village with the city mentality and wants to live in villages the city life, he will never earn enough unless he, like the city people, exploits the villagers.
('68', 163, 2, 6, 299399) But if a person settles in a village and tries to live like the villagers, he should hve no difficulty in making a ‘living by the sweat of his brow’.
('68', 163, 2, 7, 299549) He should have confidence that if the villagers who are prepared to toil all the year round in the traditional unintelligent manner can earn their living, he must also earn at least as much as the average villager.
('68', 163, 2, 8, 299764) This he will do without displacing a single villager, for he will go to village as a producer, not as a parasite.
('68', 163, 2, 9, 299878) If the worker has the ordinary size family, his wife and one other member should be full time workers.
('68', 163, 2, 10, 299981) Such a worker won’t immediately have the muscle of the villager, but he will more than make up for the deficiency by his intelligence, if only he will shed his difference and fear complex.
('68', 163, 2, 11, 300170) He would be doing productive work, and not be a mere consumer, unless he gets an adequate response from the villagers so as to occupy the whole of his time in seving them.
('68', 163, 2, 12, 300342) In that case he will be worth the commission on the additional production of the villagers induced by his effort.
('68', 163, 2, 13, 300456) But the experience of the few months that the village work has gone on under the aegis of the A.I.V.I.A. shows that the response from the villagers will be very slow and that the worker will have to become a pattern of virtue and work before the villagers.
('68', 163, 2, 14, 300713) That will be the best object lesson for them which is bound to impress them sooner or later provided that he lives as one of them and not a patron seated amongst them to be adored from a respectful distance.
('68', 163, 2, 15, 300921) The question, therefore, is: what remunerative work can he do in the village of his choice?
('68', 163, 2, 16, 301013) He and the members of the family will give some time to cleaning the village, whether the villagers help him or not, and he will give them such simple medical assistance as is within his power to give.
('68', 163, 2, 17, 301215) Every person can prescribe a simple opening drug or quinine, wash a boil or wound, wash dirty eyes and ears, and apply
('68', 164, 0, 1, 301334) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 165
('68', 164, 1, 2, 301379) a clean ointment to a wound.
('68', 164, 1, 3, 301408) I am trying to find out a book that will give the simplest directions in the ordinary cases occurrring daily in the villages.
('68', 164, 1, 4, 301534) Anyway these two things must be an integral part of village work.
('68', 164, 1, 5, 301600) This ought not to occupy more than two hours of his time per day.
('68', 164, 1, 6, 301666) The village worker has no such things as an eight hours’ day.
('68', 164, 1, 7, 301728) For him the labour for the villager is a labour of love.
('68', 164, 1, 8, 301785) For his living, therefore, he will give eight hours at least in addition to the two hours.
('68', 164, 1, 9, 301876) It should be borne in mind that under the new scheme propounded by the A.I.S.A. and A.I.V.I.A. all labour has an equal minimum value.
('68', 164, 1, 10, 302010) Thus a carder who works at his bow for one hour and turns out the average quantity of cards will get exactly the same wage that the weaver, the spinner or the papermaker would, for the given quantity of their respective works per hour.
('68', 164, 1, 11, 302246) Therefore the worker is free to choose and learn whatever work he can easily do, care being always taken to choose such labour whoes product is easily salable in his village or the surrounding area or is in demand by the Associations.
('68', 164, 1, 12, 302481) One great need in every village in an honest shop where unadulterated food stuffs and other things can be had for the cost price and a moderate commission.
('68', 164, 1, 13, 302637) It is true that a shop, be it ever so small, requires some capital.
('68', 164, 1, 14, 302705) But a worker who is at all known in the area of his work should command sufficient confidence in his honesty to enable him to make small wholesale purchases on credit.
('68', 164, 1, 15, 302873) I may not take these concrete suggestion much further.
('68', 164, 1, 16, 302928) An observant worker will always make important discoveries and soon know what labour he can do to earn a living and be at the same time an object lesson to the villagers whom he is to serve.
('68', 164, 1, 17, 303119) He will therefore have to choose labour that will not exploit the villagers, that will not injure their health or morals but will teach the villagers to take up industries to occupy their leisure hours and add to their tiny incomes.
('68', 164, 1, 18, 303352) His observations will lead him to direct his attention to the village wastes including weeds and the superficial natural resources of the village.
('68', 164, 1, 19, 303499) He will soon find that he can turn many of them to good account.
('68', 164, 1, 20, 303564) If he picks up edible weeds, it is as good as earning part of his food.
('68', 164, 1, 21, 303636) Mirabehn has presented me with a museum of beautiful marble like stones which serve several useful purposes as they are, and I would soon convert them into bazaar articles if I has leisure and would invest into simple tools to give them different shapes.
('68', 164, 1, 22, 303891) Kaka saheb had given to me split bamboo waste that was destined to be burnt, and with a rude knife he turned some of it into paper knives
('68', 165, 0, 1, 304029) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 165, 1, 2, 304071) and wooden spoons both salable in limited quantities.
('68', 165, 1, 3, 304125) Some workers in Maganwadi occupy their leisure in making envelopes out of waste paper blank on one side.
('68', 165, 1, 4, 304230) The fact is the villagers have lost all hope.
('68', 165, 1, 5, 304276) They suspect that every stranger’s hand is at their throats and that he goes to them only to exploit them.
('68', 165, 1, 6, 304383) Divorce between intellect and labour has paralysed their thinking faculty.
('68', 165, 1, 7, 304458) Their working hours they do not use to the best advantage.
('68', 165, 1, 8, 304517) The worker should enter such villages full of love and hope, feeling sure that where men and women labour unintelligently and remain unemployed half the year round, he working all the year round and combining labour with intelligence cannot fail to win the confidence of the villagers and earn his living honestly and well by labouring in their midst.
('68', 165, 1, 9, 304869) ‘But what about my children and their education?’—says the candidate worker.
('68', 165, 1, 10, 304946) If the children are to receive their education after the modern style, I can give no useful guidance.
('68', 165, 1, 11, 305048) If it be deemed enough to make them healthy, sinewy, honest, intelligent villagers, any day able to earn their livelihood in the home of their parents’ adoption, they will have their all around education under the parental roof and withal they will be partly earning members of the family from the moment they reach the years of understanding and are able to use their hands and feet in a methodical manner.
('68', 165, 1, 12, 305456) There is no school equal to a decent home and no teachers equal to honest virtuous parents.
('68', 165, 1, 13, 305548) Modern high school education is a dead weight on the villagers.
('68', 165, 1, 14, 305612) Their children will never be able to get it, and thank God they will never miss it if they have the training of the decent home.
('68', 165, 1, 15, 305741) If the village worker is not a decent man or woman, capable of conducting a decent home, he or she had better not aspire after the high privilege and honour of becoming a village worker.

('68', 168, 2, 3, 309381) WARDHA, November, 24, 1935
('68', 168, 3, 4, 309408) A sum of about Rs. 29,000 is needed for this year’s work of the Harijan Sevak Sangh of Gujarat.
('68', 168, 3, 5, 309504) Fifty seven schools and three ashrams are being run with the Sangh’s help.
('68', 168, 3, 6, 309579) The Sangh is under the supervision of no less a public worker than Thakkar Bapa.
('68', 168, 3, 7, 309660) Shri Parikshitlal Majmudar is giving his devoted services to it.
('68', 168, 3, 8, 309725) According to me the expenditure of Rs. 29,000 a year in nothing.
('68', 168, 3, 9, 309790) If we regard the service of Harijans as our dharma and if everybody who earns Rs. 500 a year decides to spare even Re.1 this charitable activity, we can get several Lakhs of rupees annually.
('68', 168, 3, 10, 309981) But we don’t yet have such religious awareness.
('68', 168, 3, 11, 310029) Moreover, not all caste Hindus regard untouchability as contrary to dharma and, therefore, accept service of the Harijan as their dharma.
('68', 168, 3, 12, 310167) Hence it doubly becomes a duty of those who regard the service of Harijans as their dharma to sustain the work of such service.
('68', 168, 3, 13, 310295) Eradication of untouchability is not one man’s job.
('68', 168, 3, 14, 310347) Neither can it be done only with the help of money.
('68', 168, 3, 15, 310399) Money can be regarded as a form of energy for the work of service.
('68', 168, 3, 16, 310466) If every caste Hindu who looks upon eradication of untouchability as his dharma regularly contributes to the fund according to his capacity, then the work being done at present can be kept up and those in charge of it will be saved from financial worries.
('68', 168, 3, 17, 310722) I shall be going to Ahmedabad in the second week of January for the Gujarati Sahitya Parishad.
('68', 168, 3, 18, 310817) I am hoping to collect at that time from Gujaratis the sum mentioned above.
('68', 168, 3, 19, 310893) It was suggested to me that I should appeal for help from friends outside Gujarat [also] but I rejected the suggestion.
('68', 168, 3, 20, 311013) If I did that, it would be a disgrace to Gujarat and so to me.
('68', 168, 3, 21, 311076) No one can say that Gujarat is among the poor provinces in the country.
('68', 168, 3, 22, 311148) It has, on the contrary, helped other provinces in their time of need.
('68', 168, 3, 23, 311219) It has never begged for anything from other provinces, and rightly too.
('68', 168, 3, 24, 311291) Why shouldn’t it, then, contribute for such a noble activity?
('68', 168, 3, 25, 311353) It is true that it has to contribute to many funds.
('68', 168, 3, 26, 311405) It is also true that the farmers of Gujarat have suffered many
('68', 168, 4, 27, 311468) 1 This appeared in the form of an open latter “To All Gujaratis” in Harijanbandhu, 8 12 1935.
('68', 169, 0, 1, 311562) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 169, 1, 2, 311604) calamities and borne great losses.
('68', 169, 1, 3, 311639) But I firmly believe that such arguments cannot be advanced as excuses for not doing one’s dharma.
('68', 169, 1, 4, 311738) I, therefore, hope that all friends, men and women, will work hard and collect the small amount mentioned above and thus relieve Thakkar Bapa, other workers and me of the worry.
('68', 169, 1, 5, 311916) The burden of most of the activities in Gujarat is generally borne by Sardar.

('68', 171, 2, 5, 314605) 214. LETTER TO CHANDAN PAREKH
('68', 171, 3, 6, 314635) WARDHA, November 27, 1935
('68', 171, 4, 7, 314661) CHANDU, I got your letter.
('68', 171, 4, 8, 314688) When I say that one per cent doubt remains, what I mean is that I am ready to listen to and think over what Father or you may say.
('68', 171, 4, 9, 314819) If I didn’t have even this one per cent doubt, there would be no need at all for me to here anybody.
('68', 171, 4, 10, 314920) Please don’t forget this, that before I discussed the matter with You I used to doubt the truth of what .
('68', 171, 4, 11, 315026) and his friends said.
('68', 171, 4, 12, 315048) After my long and patient talk with you, my attitude towards .
('68', 171, 4, 13, 315111) became more favourable.
('68', 171, 4, 14, 315135) Your story is something like this: you were bitten by a snake, but you did not feel the effect of poison although you already knew from experience the nature of the poison.
('68', 171, 4, 15, 315308) Just as this wouldn’t be a plausible story, so is your story of [the effect of] .
('68', 171, 4, 16, 315390) .’s touch not plausible.
('68', 171, 4, 17, 315415) The poison of a lustful man’s touch is far more than that of a snake.
('68', 171, 4, 18, 315485) And if a snake, while lifting its young one with its teeth.
('68', 171, 4, 19, 315545) accidentally bites it with its fangs, the young one also would feel the effect of poison.
('68', 171, 4, 20, 315635) Since a child is easily influenced by its parents, if they pour poison into it the child cannot but feel its effect.
('68', 171, 4, 21, 315752) Please, therefore, know that it is your own testimony that proves the innocence of .
('68', 171, 4, 22, 315837) to the extent of 99 per cent.
('68', 171, 4, 23, 315867) And that is why I have told you, and I repeat here, that you should continue to write to me and keep me informed about everything.
('68', 171, 4, 24, 315998) If you continue to help me, the remaining one per cent doubt also can be cleared.
('68', 171, 4, 25, 316080) After your testimony, I cannot bring myself to find .
('68', 171, 4, 26, 316134) guilty.
('68', 171, 4, 27, 316142) Nor can I bring myself to believe that you are telling a brazen lie.
('68', 171, 4, 28, 316211) Till, therefore, I get further evidence, the one per cent will remain in your favour.
('68', 171, 4, 29, 316297) If you are one hundred per cent truthful and if you continue your effort [to convince me], you will be able to raise the one per cent to 100 per cent.

('68', 173, 9, 9, 317989) 218. CASTE AND VARNA
('68', 173, 10, 10, 318010) WARDHA, November 28, 1935
('68', 173, 11, 11, 318036) A gentleman writes that I advocate the abolition of castes and maintain that the varnas are and ought to be enduring.
('68', 173, 11, 12, 318154) He wants me to explain this with illustrations.
('68', 173, 11, 13, 318202) Castes are numerous.
('68', 173, 11, 14, 318223) They are man made.
('68', 173, 11, 15, 318242) They undergo constant change.
('68', 173, 11, 16, 318272) The older ones die and new ones spring up.
('68', 173, 11, 17, 318315) Castes based on occupations are to be found all over the world.
('68', 173, 11, 18, 318379) It is only in India that there are restrictions, as regards intermarriage and inter dining, which defy reason.
('68', 173, 11, 19, 318490) This is very harmful.
('68', 173, 11, 20, 318512) It stands in the way of the community’s progress.
('68', 173, 11, 21, 318562) It has nothing to do with religion.
('68', 173, 11, 22, 318598) Varnas are just four and not numerous.
('68', 173, 11, 23, 318637) They have been sanctioned by the Shastras.
('68', 173, 11, 24, 318680) Whether or not people are conscious of them, they do exist all over the world as we see.
('68', 173, 11, 25, 318769) There are everywhere these four classes: one to impart knowledge of god for the welfare of
('68', 173, 12, 26, 318860) 1 The telegram was reproduced by Mahadev Desai in his letter to G. D. Birla dated November 28, 1935. 2 Which read: “Birla Mill’s labourers strike six days.
('68', 173, 12, 27, 319016) Heavy wage cuts.
('68', 173, 12, 28, 319033) Authorities unyielding.
('68', 173, 12, 29, 319057) Police and goondas employed.
('68', 173, 12, 30, 319086) Read National Call.
('68', 173, 12, 31, 319106) Pray intervene”.
('68', 173, 12, 32, 319123) 3 The workers of the Birla Cotton Mill had gone on strike in protest against reduction in their wages; vide also “Telegram to G.D. Birla”, 2 12 1935 and “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 5 12 1935.
('68', 174, 0, 1, 319312) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 175
('68', 174, 1, 2, 319357) the world, another to protect the people against manifold dangers, a third one to carry on the work of farming, etc., to sustain the community and one class to work for these three classes.
('68', 174, 1, 3, 319547) There is no feeling of high and low in this division.
('68', 174, 1, 4, 319601) But since this is not understood as a great law of nature, there has been confusion in it, that is, these four functions are no more confined to the respective varnas.
('68', 174, 1, 5, 319769) Instead men have been taking up any occupation they choose with a view to achieving their selfish ends.
('68', 174, 1, 6, 319873) At one time in India people used to consciously folllow this law and thus lived in peace.
('68', 174, 1, 7, 319963) One accepted the calling of one’s own varna and was satisfied in its pursuit for general welfare.
('68', 174, 1, 8, 320061) There was no unhealthy competition among people to jump from one varna to another for the sake of money or fame.
('68', 174, 1, 9, 320174) At present this significance of the varna system seems to have disappeared even in India.
('68', 174, 1, 10, 320264) Destructive competition is on the increase, everyone takes liberty of following any profession and the meaning of varna has been restricted to unnatural and meaningless restrictions on intermarriage and inter dining.
('68', 174, 1, 11, 320481) And that is why the country has stopped progressing.
('68', 174, 1, 12, 320534) Hinduism will once again shine forth if such senseless restrictions are abolished, the pristine varna system is resurrected and the distinctions of high and low are banished.
('68', 174, 1, 13, 320709) This would be to the good of India as well as the whole world.
('68', 174, 2, 14, 320772) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 19 1 1936

('68', 177, 1, 2, 324689) 223. DISCUSSION WITH G.D. BIRLA 1
('68', 177, 2, 3, 324723) [Before November 30, 1935]
('68', 177, 3, 4, 324750) G.D. BIRLA: That friend in charge of the tannery 2, you say, is working for a mere pittance.
('68', 177, 3, 5, 324843) It is highly commendable.
('68', 177, 4, 6, 324869) GANDHIJI: He is a brahmin and a graduate.
('68', 177, 4, 7, 324911) He does not accept more than eight annas a day.
('68', 177, 4, 8, 324959) His wife also works else where the whole day for a bare living wage.
('68', 177, 5, 9, 325028) Yes: All that surprises me, but I do not know how long this can go on in this machine age.
('68', 177, 5, 10, 325119) I have no such fear, because I have the conviction within me that when all these achievements of the machine age will have disappeared these our handicrafts will remain; when all exploitation will have ceased, service and honest labour will remain.
('68', 177, 5, 11, 325368) It is because this faith sustains me that I am going on with my work.
('68', 177, 5, 12, 325438) After all where is there any cause for despair?
('68', 177, 5, 13, 325486) What are a few years in the vast stretch of eternity?
('68', 177, 5, 14, 325540) A study of human origins would carry us back to millions of years.
('68', 177, 5, 15, 325607) Indomitable faith in their work sustained men like Stephenson and Columbus.
('68', 177, 5, 16, 325683) Faith in my work sustains me, but there is also added to it the conviction that all the other things that seem to challenge my faith are doomed.
('68', 177, 5, 17, 325828) Don’t you see that if India becomes industrialized, we shall need a Nadirshah to find out other worlds to exploit, that we shall have to pit ourselves against the naval and military power of Britain and Japan and America, of Russia and Italy?
('68', 177, 5, 18, 326071) My head reels to think of these rivalries.
('68', 177, 5, 19, 326114) No, I am clear that whilst this machine age aims at converting men into machines, I am aiming at reinstating man turned machine to his original estate.
('68', 177, 6, 20, 326266) I quite see your invincible faith.
('68', 177, 6, 21, 326301) But you seem to forget in your enthusiasm that you will not be with us until eternity.
('68', 177, 6, 22, 326388) You are getting old.
('68', 177, 6, 23, 326409) Why not make large collections and spread your work over a large area?
('68', 177, 6, 24, 326480) I do not believe in collecting more than I need.
('68', 177, 7, 25, 326529) But supposing you constructed twenty, even ten, model villages?
('68', 177, 7, 26, 326593) If it is such an easy thing, you might do so with your money.
('68', 177, 7, 27, 326655) But I know it is not easy.
('68', 177, 7, 28, 326682) You cannot bring a model village into being
('68', 177, 8, 29, 326726) 1 Extracted from Mahdev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.

('68', 178, 3, 9, 327433) 224. AN INTERESTING POINT
('68', 178, 4, 10, 327459) The Council of the Harijan Sevak Sangh met last week at Wardha.
('68', 178, 4, 11, 327523) In view of my article “Caste Has to Go” 2 some members raised the question whether in the pages of Harijan which was issued under the aegis of the Harijan Sevak Sangh I was justified in airing my views on the Sangh, or whether I could express views which went beyond the official policy of the Sangh, or lastly whether the Sangh could extend the scope of its objective.
('68', 178, 4, 12, 327893) I gave it as my opinion that I was free as an individual to advocate in the pages of Harijan views which I may know to be contrary to the views of some members or maybe in advance of the official policy of the Sangh.
('68', 178, 4, 13, 328110) In my opinion, any member of the Sangh is entitled to the same freedom so long as his views do not in any way tone down the Sangh’s objective.
('68', 178, 4, 14, 328253) Its policy represents the highest common factor between the views of the moderate reformer and those of the radical.
('68', 178, 4, 15, 328370) We have in the Harijan Sevak Sangh both the sections well represented.
('68', 178, 4, 16, 328441) There are sanatanists who would restrict removal of untouchability to the mere touch.
('68', 178, 4, 17, 328527) There are others who would extend it to inter dining and intermarriage.
('68', 178, 4, 18, 328599) The membership pledge lays down the minimum which every member has to subscribe to and practise in his or her own life.
('68', 178, 4, 19, 328719) It does not prevent any member from going further so long as he or she does not advocate the advanced view as the policy of the Sangh.
('68', 178, 4, 20, 328854) At its very origin all sections of Hindus had met and, in order to carry the largest number of Hindus with them, that representative gathering passed a compre 
('68', 178, 5, 21, 329014) 1 Vide “An Appeal”, 24 11 1935. 2 Vide “Caste Has to Go”, 16 11 1935.
('68', 179, 0, 1, 329084) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 179, 1, 2, 329126) hensive resolution 1 that would secure the hearty assent of the Largest number present.
('68', 179, 1, 3, 329214) The wisdom of the course was justified in that there was, thanks to Pandit Malaviyaji, practical unanimity.
('68', 179, 1, 4, 329322) It is obvious that if the resolution had contemplated the suppression of advanced views and practice by members acting in their individual capacity many members would not have subscribed to such restriction.
('68', 179, 1, 5, 329530) But on the other hands not even a majority of the members of the board could change the constitution so far as its objective is concerned.
('68', 179, 1, 6, 329669) That can only be done by a general representative meeting of Hindus convened specially for the purpose.
('68', 179, 1, 7, 329773) Therefore whilst the most cautious refor mer may rest secure about the fundamental policy of the Sangh, the extreme radical is in no way hampered in his advocacy, as an individual, of the views which in his opinion may promote the purity and health of Hinduism.
('68', 179, 1, 8, 330035) It may be mentioned, in passing, that the views expressed by me in the article “Caste Has to Go” have been often expressed in these columns though under different headings.
('68', 179, 1, 9, 330208) Moreover the article does not deal with the relations between caste Hindus and Harijan Hindus.
('68', 179, 1, 10, 330303) It deals with reform only among caste men or savarnas.
('68', 179, 1, 11, 330358) When untouchability goes, untouchables will occupy precisely the same position as caste men.
('68', 179, 1, 12, 330451) And whatever rule or custom then governs caste men will govern Harijans who are no longer Harijans.
('68', 179, 1, 13, 330551) If, therefore, caste remains as it is now, there will be no intermarriage and no interdining between Harijans and caste men.
('68', 179, 1, 14, 330676) But if caste goes in its present form, as it will some day, there will most undoubtedly be intermarriage and inter dining between Harijans and caste men as there will be between caste men and caste men.
('68', 179, 1, 15, 330879) And if varna remains, as I hope it will, occupations will be restricted as they were in the past; intermarriage and inter dining will not be restricted even as they were not in the past.
('68', 179, 1, 16, 331066) Whaterver happens it will happen not because of the activity of the Sangh as a body but because of other forces which the Sangh can neither regulate nor control.
('68', 179, 1, 17, 331228) Its members as individuals will no doubt take their due share in moulding those forces according to their predilections.
('68', 179, 2, 18, 331349) Harijan, 30 11 1935
('68', 179, 3, 19, 331369) 1 Vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932.
('68', 180, 0, 1, 331442) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 181
('68', 180, 1, 2, 331487) 225. THE IDEAL AND THE PRACTICAL
('68', 180, 2, 3, 331520) Shri Gopabandhu Chaudhry writes: 1
('68', 180, 3, 4, 331555) In the article “Need for Humane Custom” 2 you refer to a calculation that “self sufficing khadi will mean two yards of sale outside against three yards of wear by artisans, etc.” .
('68', 180, 3, 5, 331736) But the reading of the article leaves an impression that the success of self sufficing khadi entirely depends upon the sale of khadi.
('68', 180, 3, 6, 331870) But is this a correct ideal?It not the ideal of self sufficing khadi this that in a majority of cases the spinners will spin their own cotton or purchase their cotton and pay the weaver from their earnings from other village industries or agricultural labour?
('68', 180, 4, 7, 332130) Otherwise, when our aim is to make every home in the village self sufficient, where will the extra two yards for outside sale produced by the spinners sell?Will the demand of the cities be possibly so large?
('68', 180, 5, 8, 332338) Self sufficing khadi ought to thrive independently on its own merits, as there is enough unutilized land to grow the cotton required and unemployed leisure to spin the yarn.
('68', 180, 6, 9, 332512) The ideal no boubt is for every family to grow, spin, weave and wear its own cotton, just as it it for every family to own land and grow its own corn, cook and eat it.
('68', 180, 6, 10, 332680) But we know that every family won’t and can’t realize the ideal; we know, too, that success will not attend the worker immediately he begins to preach the unadulterated message of self sufficing khadi.
('68', 180, 6, 11, 332882) What Gopabandhu Babu has himself suggested is itself an intermediary stage, that of a householder buying enough cotton, spinning it himself, having the yarn woven and paying the charges from his savings.
('68', 180, 6, 12, 333086) But there are million who have no savings and there are millions who purchase their cloth without performing any of the processes.
('68', 180, 6, 13, 333217) To spin for oneself and pay for cotton and weaving out of the proceeds of some other industry is an intermediate stage.
('68', 180, 6, 14, 333337) To spin extra and from the proceeds of that labour to pay for weaving is yet another intermediate stage and perhaps the easiest both from the workers’ and the weavers’ points of view.
('68', 180, 6, 15, 333521) In working out this stage we have ready made khadi centres.
('68', 180, 6, 16, 333581) There the workers have to induce spinners and other artisans to wear khadi if
('68', 180, 7, 17, 333659) 1 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('68', 180, 7, 18, 333712) 2 Vide “Need for Humane Custom”, 2 11 1935.
('68', 181, 0, 1, 333756) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 181, 1, 2, 333798) they are to continue to get work through the All India Spinners’ Association agency.
('68', 181, 1, 3, 333883) There are many among them who depend for their maintenance entirely on their labour spent on spinning, weaving, carding or dyeing.
('68', 181, 1, 4, 334014) These can only wear khadi if they work at producing surplus khadi and command the sale of such products.
('68', 181, 1, 5, 334119) This ought not to be difficult, if in spite of the rise in the spinners’ wage the existing demand for khadi continues.
('68', 181, 1, 6, 334238) In practice all the stages will be worked simultaneously.
('68', 181, 1, 7, 334296) What the new scheme does is to put the emphasis on the right spot and state what the goal is in unmistakable terms.
('68', 181, 1, 8, 334412) Khadi workers will no longer concentrate on increasing sales and reducing the price of khadi.
('68', 181, 1, 9, 334506) They are henceforth to concentrate on people becoming self sufficing about their cloth requirements at least to the extent of spinning.
('68', 181, 1, 10, 334642) They will have to establish personal touch with the artisans, befriend them, know their wants and help them, progressively to improve their economic condition by making the best possible use of their leisure hours consistently with equal opportunity for all.
('68', 181, 1, 11, 334901) This ought to be a good enough programme for the most ambitious worker.
('68', 181, 1, 12, 334973) The most difficult task will be on the one hand to open the eyes of understanding of the millions and persuade them to use their leisure hours for their own betterment and on the other to persuade the buying class—the city people and the middle men—to realize that in the long run it pays them if they buy village manufactures even though their cost may be apparently some what higher than they have hitherto paid and even though the appearance be not quite what they have been used to.
('68', 181, 1, 13, 335460) It pays them because it raises the material condition of the people and therefore their purchasing power.
('68', 181, 1, 14, 335566) The new scheme is therefore calculated to draw the best out of the whole of the nation irrespective of ‘caste, colour or creed’.
('68', 181, 1, 15, 335695) The question ultimately resolves itself into this: Have we for this task workers enough of the requisite purity, self sacrifice, industry and intelligence?
('68', 181, 2, 16, 335851) Harijan, 30 11 1935
('68', 182, 0, 1, 335871) VOL. 68: 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 183
('68', 182, 1, 2, 335916) 226. AN EXPERIENCE
('68', 182, 2, 3, 335935) A correspondent who has for years been wearing khadi made out of his own yarn writes:
('68', 182, 3, 4, 336021) This year I had 80 yards of khadi of 50 inches width.
('68', 182, 3, 5, 336075) It cost me twenty
('68', 182, 4, 6, 336093) rupees in round figures.
('68', 182, 4, 7, 336118) People want my khadi at 10 as.
('68', 182, 4, 8, 336149) per yard.
('68', 182, 4, 9, 336159) i.e., Rs. 50
('68', 182, 5, 10, 336172) for the whole piece.
('68', 182, 5, 11, 336193) Thus if I want to use three yards for myself I need to sell only 11 2 yards.
('68', 182, 5, 12, 336270) If I keep for myself 20 yards and sell the rest, besides paying for
('68', 182, 6, 13, 336338) my own khadi, I would make a profit of Rs. 17/8. I know this correspondent.
('68', 182, 6, 14, 336414) He stands in an exceptionally favourable position becuase his yarn is a fine, even and strong.
('68', 182, 6, 15, 336509) Weavers weave it at reasonable rates, and the khadi being therefore strong and fine looking is greatly in demand.
('68', 182, 6, 16, 336623) Everyone having faith and patiene may verify the truth of the statement by making the experiment himself.
('68', 182, 6, 17, 336729) Strong, even and fine yarn is the secret of successful khadi.
('68', 182, 7, 18, 336791) Harijan, 30 11 1935
('68', 182, 8, 19, 336811) 227. NEED FOR CARE
('68', 182, 9, 20, 336830) Apropos of my reproduction of Dr. Aykroyd’s letter 1 on neem leaves and tamarind, the reader will appreciate the following further letter 2 from the Director of Nutrition Research.
('68', 182, 10, 21, 337011) 1. I think there is a certain danger in publishing small items of dietetic knowledge apart, as it were, from their scientific context.
('68', 182, 10, 22, 337146) Ignorant readers are apt to make faulty interpretations.
('68', 182, 10, 23, 337203) For example, on rereading the paragraph in my letter of Novermber 6 relating to neem leaves, which you wish to publish in your paper, I think it might possibly give the impression that everyone should consume great quantities of this vegetable as a cure for all human ills.
('68', 182, 10, 24, 337477) Actually, the small series of analyses we have carried out to date show neem leaves to be somewhat richer in certain food factors than a number of other leafy vegetables, but it is only a question of degree.
('68', 182, 10, 25, 337685) In a word, it would be better, for purposes of popular education, to stress the value of all green leafy vegetables rather than to single out one particular vegetable for special
('68', 182, 11, 26, 337864) 1 Vide “Neem Leaves and Tamarind”, 16 11 1935. 2 From which only extracts are reporduced here.
('68', 183, 0, 1, 337959) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 183, 1, 2, 338001) commendation.
('68', 183, 1, 3, 338015) I should therefore prefer the paragraph, which refers to the bitter variety of neem leaves (Azadirachta Indica) to read as follows:
('68', 183, 2, 4, 338147) QUEESTION: What is the nutritive value of neem leaves?
('68', 183, 3, 5, 338202) ANSWER: Neem leaves resemble other green leafy vegetables in com position.
('68', 183, 3, 6, 338277) Both mature and tender leaves are richer in protein, calcium, iron and carotene than amaranth leaves, coriander leaves, drumstick leaves, lettuce, marraya leaves and spinach.
('68', 183, 3, 7, 338452) Their composition makes them valuable as a supplement to a diet largely composed of cereals, and in this respect they resemble the leafy vegetables in general.
('68', 183, 4, 8, 338612) 2. The paragraph relating to tamarind and lemon might be modified as follows:
('68', 183, 5, 9, 338690) With regard to vitamin content, tamarind and lemon are roughly similar, except that the latter is richer in the antiscorbutic vitamin C. Tamarind pulp, unlike lemon, contains a good deal of tartaric acid—about 14%; the chief acid in lemon is citric acid.
('68', 183, 5, 10, 338945) Fresh tamarind, which is more solid than fresh lemon, contains a somewhat higher percentage of protein, corbohydrate and minerals than lemon; in the dried state tamarind yields about 3% protein and 73% carbohydrate (by difference).
('68', 183, 5, 11, 339177) Tamarind is stated to contain a laxative principle.
('68', 183, 5, 12, 339229) I can offer nothing in support of the popular belief that it induces fever and rheumatism .
('68', 183, 6, 13, 339321) Harijan, 30 11 1935

('68', 185, 1, 2, 341014) 231. LETTER TO DR.
('68', 185, 1, 3, 341033) GOPICHAND BHARGAVA
('68', 185, 2, 4, 341052) WARDHA, December 1, 1935
('68', 185, 3, 5, 341077) DEAR DR.
('68', 185, 3, 6, 341086) GOPICHAND, I have your letter enclosing the budget.
('68', 185, 3, 7, 341138) Its critical examination will rest with Shankerlal.
('68', 185, 3, 8, 341190) So far as I am concerned, I shall require to be satisfied that no new obligations are taken by the central organization.
('68', 185, 3, 9, 341311) Provinces may frame their budgets in any manner they like (1) so long as they do not run a single store at loss, (2) so long as they pay the minimum wage to all the artisans whom they employ — the minimum wage being fixed for each province in consultation with the centre, and (3) so long as the budget convincingly shows that the provincial organization can be run without loss.
('68', 185, 3, 10, 341691) You suggest that no interest should be charged.
('68', 185, 3, 11, 341739) But it has been suggested by others that Per cent should be charged for covering expenses of the centre.

('68', 186, 12, 16, 343170) 234. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('68', 186, 13, 17, 343205) December 2, 1935
('68', 186, 14, 18, 343222) I got your letter.
('68', 186, 14, 19, 343241) I am getting confirmed in the views which I have publicly expressed.
('68', 186, 14, 20, 343310) Your argument 2 applies to all similar things, but just as it would not be right to carry on public propaganda for such things so also it would not be right to do so in this case.
('68', 186, 14, 21, 343490) One may propagate a thing that is spiritually elevating.
('68', 186, 14, 22, 343547) How can one propagate something that has a lowering tendency?
('68', 186, 14, 23, 343609) “A lowering tendency” need not be taken in a deprecatory sense here.
('68', 186, 14, 24, 343678) Everybody would welcome sex gratification without having to have children.
('68', 186, 14, 25, 343753) Therefore the means of ensuring this are spreading like intoxicants.
('68', 186, 14, 26, 343822) If there is any cause for regret, it is only that what is morally bad is being regarded as morally desirable.
('68', 186, 14, 27, 343932) I have recently been given Mrs.
('68', 186, 15, 28, 343964) 1 The workers of the Birla Cotton Mill had gone on strike in protest against reduction in their wages, and under the leadership of Satyavati had formed an ad hoc committee to fight their cause.

('68', 187, 1, 4, 344419) It also advocates control but in a different way.
('68', 187, 1, 5, 344469) I have no time to write more.

('68', 187, 6, 10, 344581) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS,
('68', 187, 7, 11, 344600) I have seen both your letters and you must have got the wire I sent you this morning.
('68', 187, 7, 12, 344686) In my opinion no harm can come out of seeing Satyavati.
('68', 187, 7, 13, 344742) After all, your aim is justice.
('68', 187, 7, 14, 344774) But she should hold an authority from the workers.
('68', 187, 7, 15, 344825) The best thing would be to take all the complaints to an agreed arbitrator with the initial condition that there should be no future strike.

('68', 187, 7, 17, 345042) You have to appoint someone else as the arbitrator.
('68', 187, 7, 18, 345094) I hope you will be patient in everything.

('68', 187, 10, 21, 345216) 236. LETTER TO SURENDRA
('68', 187, 11, 22, 345240) WARDHA, December 3, 1935
('68', 187, 12, 23, 345265) SURENDRA,
('68', 187, 13, 24, 345275) I had your previous letter.
('68', 187, 13, 25, 345303) It did not particularly call for a reply, hence I saved my time for some other work.
('68', 187, 13, 26, 345388) Now I shall not treat your letter of the 29th ultimo in the same manner.
('68', 187, 13, 27, 345461) Do continue to post me with your bitter sweet experiences.
('68', 187, 13, 28, 345520) It would be a mistake to regard the experiences at Sindi as fully
('68', 187, 14, 29, 345586) 1 The letter carries the following note by Mahadev Desai: “A Hindustan Times issues reports Satyavati as the ‘wife of dismissed employee’.
('68', 187, 14, 30, 345725) It hurt Bapu.
('68', 187, 14, 31, 345739) He wrote to Satyavati who had complained to him that it was a stupid blunder by a reporter and that even Ghanshyamdas would not like it.”
('68', 188, 0, 1, 345877) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 189
('68', 188, 1, 2, 345923) comprehensive.
('68', 188, 1, 3, 345938) I fail to see a reflection of my own experiences in the picture that I form in my mind by putting together Mahaev's description of the experiences at Sindi.
('68', 188, 1, 4, 346095) There is a restraint in Mahadev's description, hence the bitter experiences included in it are like sugar refined in a factory.
('68', 188, 1, 5, 346223) I can summarize my experience of Sindi in one sentence.
('68', 188, 1, 6, 346279) Justice has not yet been done to Sindi.
('68', 188, 1, 7, 346319) But willy nilly I happen to be its director.
('68', 188, 1, 8, 346364) And what sort of a director?
('68', 188, 1, 9, 346393) I used to pay only short visits.
('68', 188, 1, 10, 346426) Now I visit the place daily and stay there for a few minutes.
('68', 188, 1, 11, 346488) I have not mixed with the people.
('68', 188, 1, 12, 346522) Mirabehn tried hard to do it.
('68', 188, 1, 13, 346552) But she had gone there only to stop me from settling down in the place.
('68', 188, 1, 14, 346624) 1 She had not set her mind on it.
('68', 188, 1, 15, 346658) She was staying under my pressure.
('68', 188, 1, 16, 346693) Now Gajanan 2 is there but it is also only an experiment.
('68', 188, 1, 17, 346751) Hence it is likely you are mistaken in placing Sindi in line with the others.
('68', 188, 1, 18, 346829) I can say that for me [the work at] Sindi is vast enough.
('68', 188, 1, 19, 346887) We have done nothing about.
('68', 188, 1, 20, 346915) A separate ashram has come into being at Nalawadi.
('68', 188, 1, 21, 346966) it cannot be said that it has any appreciable impact on the people of Nalawadi.
('68', 188, 1, 22, 347046) It is a different kind of activity.
('68', 188, 1, 23, 347082) We have not yet mastered the art of living in a village.
('68', 188, 1, 24, 347139) We still have to learn the way of mingling with them.
('68', 188, 1, 25, 347193) Hence Nalawadi, Vadaj and Sindi, and all the three are different things.
('68', 188, 1, 26, 347266) Your experiment is the fourth and it is in line with the experiments that are now being carried on.
('68', 188, 1, 27, 347366) Let us see what finally comes out of it.
('68', 188, 1, 28, 347407) I am therefore closely watching your work.
('68', 188, 1, 29, 347450) I am intentionally forgoing the temptation of taking more work from you.
('68', 188, 1, 30, 347523) I had to exercise great firmness in sending my reply to Navli .
