('68', 189, 4, 7, 348282) 238. INTERVIEW TO MARGARET SANGER 1
('68', 189, 5, 8, 348318) [December 3/4, 1935] 2
('68', 189, 6, 9, 348341) Gandhiji poured his whole being into his conversation.
('68', 189, 6, 10, 348396) He revealed himself inside out, giving Mrs. Sanger an intimate glimpse of his own private life.
('68', 189, 6, 11, 348492) He also declared to her his own limitations, especially the stupendous limitation of his own philosophy of life—a philosophy that seeks self realization through self control, and said that from him there could be one solution and one alone:
('68', 189, 7, 12, 348733) [G.] I could not recommend the remedy of birth control to a woman who wanted my approval.
('68', 189, 7, 13, 348823) I should simply say to her: My remedy is of no use to you.
('68', 189, 7, 14, 348882) You must go to others for advice.
('68', 189, 8, 15, 348916) Mrs. Sanger cited some hard cases.
('68', 189, 8, 16, 348951) Gandhiji said: I agree, there are hard cases.
('68', 189, 8, 17, 348997) Else birth control enthusiasts would have no case.
('68', 189, 8, 18, 349048) But I would say, do devise remedies by all means, but the remedies should be other than the ones you advise.
('68', 189, 8, 19, 349157) If you and I as moral reformers put our foot down on this remedy and said, ‘You must fall back on other remedies’, those would surely be found.
('68', 189, 9, 20, 349301) Both seemed to be agreed that woman should be emancipated, that woman should be the arbiter of her destiny.
('68', 189, 9, 21, 349409) But Mrs. Sanger would have Gandhiji work for woman's emancipation through her pet device, just as believers in violence want Gandhiji to win India's freedom through violence, since they seem to be sure that non violence can never succeed.
('68', 189, 10, 22, 349648) She forgets this fundamental difference in her impatience to prove that Gandhiji does not know the women of India.
('68', 189, 10, 23, 349763) And she claims to prove this on the ground that he makes an impossible appeal to the women of India—the appeal to resist their husbands.
('68', 189, 10, 24, 349900) Well, this is what he said:
('68', 189, 11, 25, 349928) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai's article “Mrs. Sanger and Birthcontrol” 2 According to Gandhi—1915 1948: A Detailed Chronology, Margaret Sanger met Gandhiji on December 3 and 4.
('68', 190, 0, 1, 350107) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 191
('68', 190, 1, 2, 350153) My wife I made the orbit of all women.
('68', 190, 1, 3, 350192) In her I studied all women.
('68', 190, 1, 4, 350220) I came in contact with many European women in South Africa, and I knew practically every Indian woman there.
('68', 190, 1, 5, 350329) I worked with them.
('68', 190, 1, 6, 350349) I tried to show them they were not slaves either to their husbands or parents, not only in the political field but in the domestic as well.
('68', 190, 1, 7, 350489) But the trouble was that some could not resist their husbands.
('68', 190, 1, 8, 350552) The remedy is in the hands of women themselves.
('68', 190, 1, 9, 350600) The struggle is difficult for them, and I do not blame them.
('68', 190, 1, 10, 350661) I blame the men.
('68', 190, 1, 11, 350678) Men have legislated against them.
('68', 190, 1, 12, 350712) Man has regarded woman as his tool.
('68', 190, 1, 13, 350748) She has learned to be his tool and in the end found it easy and pleasurable to be such, because when one drags another in his fall the descent is easy .
('68', 190, 1, 14, 350901) 1 I have felt that during the years still left to me if I can drive home to women's minds the truth that they are free, we will have no birth control problem in India.
('68', 190, 1, 15, 351069) If they will only learn to say ‘no’ to their husbands when they approach them carnally!
('68', 190, 1, 16, 351157) I do not suppose all husbands are brutes and if women only know how to resist them, all will be well.
('68', 190, 1, 17, 351259) I have been able to teach women who have come in contact with me how to resist their husbands.
('68', 190, 1, 18, 351354) The real problem is that many do not want to resist them.
('68', 190, 1, 19, 351412) No resistance bordering upon bitterness will be necessary in 99 out of 100 cases.
('68', 190, 1, 20, 351494) If a wife says to her husband, ‘No, I do not want it’, he will make no trouble.
('68', 190, 1, 21, 351574) But she hasn't been taught.
('68', 190, 1, 22, 351602) Her parents in most cases won't teach it to her.
('68', 190, 1, 23, 351651) There are some cases, I know, in which parents have appealed to their daughters' husbands not to force motherhood on their daughters.
('68', 190, 1, 24, 351785) And I have come across amenable husbands too.
('68', 190, 1, 25, 351831) I want woman to learn the primary right of resistance.
('68', 190, 1, 26, 351886) She thinks now that she has not got it .
('68', 190, 2, 27, 351927) Mrs. Sanger raises the phantasmagoria of “irritations, disputes, and thwarted longings that Gandhiji's advice would bring into the home.” .
('68', 190, 2, 28, 352067) She cited cases of great nervous and mental breakdowns as a result of the practice of self control.
('68', 190, 2, 29, 352167) Gandhiji spoke from a knowledge of the numerous letters he receives every mail, when he said to her: The evidence is all based on examination of imbeciles.
('68', 190, 2, 30, 352323) The conclusions are not drawn from the practice of healthy minded people.
('68', 190, 2, 31, 352397) The people they take for examples have not lived a life of even tolerable continence.
('68', 190, 2, 32, 352483) These neurologists assume that people are expected to exercise self restraint while they continue to lead the same ill regulated life.
('68', 190, 2, 33, 352618) The consequence is that they do not exercise self restraint but become lunatics.
('68', 190, 2, 34, 352699) I carry on correspondence with many of
('68', 190, 3, 35, 352738) 1 Omissions as in the source
('68', 191, 0, 1, 352767) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 191, 1, 2, 352809) these people and they describe their own ailments to me.
('68', 191, 1, 3, 352866) I simply say that if I were to present them with this method of birth control they would lead far worse lives.
('68', 191, 2, 4, 352977) He told her that when she went to Calcutta she would be told by those who knew what havoc contraceptives had worked among unmarried young men and women.
('68', 191, 2, 5, 353130) But evidently for the purpose of the conversation, at any rate, Mrs. Sanger confined herself to propagation of knowledge of birthcontrol among married couples only .
('68', 191, 2, 6, 353296) The distinction that Gandhiji drew between love and lust will be evident from the following excerpts from the conversation:
('68', 191, 3, 7, 353420) When both want to satisfy animal passion without having to suffer the consequences of their act it is not love, it is lust.
('68', 191, 3, 8, 353544) But if love is pure, it will transcend animal passion and will regulate itself.
('68', 191, 3, 9, 353624) We have not had enough education of the passions.
('68', 191, 3, 10, 353674) When a husband says, ‘Let us not have children, but let us have relations”, what is that but animal passion?
('68', 191, 3, 11, 353783) If they do not want to have more children they should simply refuse to unite.
('68', 191, 3, 12, 353861) Love becomes lust the moment you make it a means for the satisfaction of animal needs.
('68', 191, 3, 13, 353948) It is just the same with food.
('68', 191, 3, 14, 353979) If food is taken only for pleasure it is lust.
('68', 191, 3, 15, 354026) You do not take chocolates for the sake of satisfying your hunger.
('68', 191, 3, 16, 354093) You take them for pleasure and then ask the doctor for an antidote.
('68', 191, 3, 17, 354161) Perhaps you tell the doctor that whisky befogs your brain and he gives you an antidote.
('68', 191, 3, 18, 354249) Would it not be better not to take chocolates or whisky?
('68', 191, 4, 19, 354306) S. No I do not accept the analogy.
('68', 191, 5, 20, 354341) G. Of course you will not accept the analogy because you think this sex expression without desire for children is a need of the soul, a contention I do not endorse.
('68', 191, 6, 21, 354506) S. Yes, sex expression is a spiritual need and I claim that the quality of this expression is more important than the result, for the quality of the relationship is there regardless of results.
('68', 191, 6, 22, 354700) We all know that the great majority of children are born as an accident, without the parents having any desire for conception.
('68', 191, 6, 23, 354827) seldom are two people drawn together in the sex act by their desire to have children.
('68', 191, 6, 24, 354913) Do you think it possible for two people who are in love, who are happy together, to regulate their sex act only once in two years, so that relationship would only take place when they wanted a child?
('68', 191, 6, 25, 355113) Do you think is possible?
('68', 191, 7, 26, 355139) G. I had the honour of doing that very thing and I am not the only one.
('68', 191, 8, 27, 355211) Mrs. Sanger thought it was illogical to contend that sex union for the purpose of having children would be love and union for the satisfaction of the sexual appetite
('68', 192, 0, 1, 355377) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 193
('68', 192, 1, 2, 355423) was lust, for the same act was involved in both.
('68', 192, 1, 3, 355472) Gandhiji immediately capitulated and said he was ready to describe all sexual union as partaking of the nature of lust.
('68', 192, 1, 4, 355592) I know, from my own experience that as long as I looked upon my wife carnally, we had no real understanding.
('68', 192, 1, 5, 355701) Our love did not reach a high plane.
('68', 192, 1, 6, 355738) There was affection between us always, but we came closer and closer the more we or rather I became restrained.
('68', 192, 1, 7, 355850) There never was want of restraint on the part of my wife.
('68', 192, 1, 8, 355908) Very often she would show restraint, but she rarely resisted me although she showed disinclination very often.
('68', 192, 1, 9, 356019) All the time I wanted carnal pleasure I could not serve her.
('68', 192, 1, 10, 356080) The moment I bade good bye to a life of carnal pleasure our whole relationship became spiritual.
('68', 192, 1, 11, 356177) Lust died and love reigned instead.
('68', 192, 2, 12, 356213) Mrs. Sanger is so impatient to prove that Gandhiji is a visionary that she forgets the practical ways and means that Gandhiji suggested to her.
('68', 192, 2, 13, 356357) she asked:
('68', 192, 3, 14, 356368) Must the sexual union take place only three or four times in an entire lifetime?
('68', 192, 4, 15, 356449) G. Why should people not be taught that it is immoral to have more than three or four children and that after they have had that number they should sleep separately?
('68', 192, 4, 16, 356615) If they are taught this it would harden into custom.
('68', 192, 4, 17, 356668) And if social reformers cannot impress this idea upon the people, why not a law?
('68', 192, 4, 18, 356749) If husband and wife have four children, they would have had sufficient animal enjoyment.
('68', 192, 4, 19, 356838) Their love may then be lifted to a higher plane.
('68', 192, 4, 20, 356887) Their bodies have met.
('68', 192, 4, 21, 356910) After they have had the children they wanted, their love transforms itself into a spiritual relationship.
('68', 192, 4, 22, 357016) If these children die and they want more, then they may meet again.
('68', 192, 4, 23, 357084) Why must people be slaves of this passion when they are not of others?
('68', 192, 4, 24, 357155) When you give them education in birth control,you tell them it is a duty.
('68', 192, 4, 25, 357229) You say to them that if they do not do this thing they will interrupt their spiritual evolution.
('68', 192, 4, 26, 357326) You do not even talk of regulation.
('68', 192, 4, 27, 357362) After giving them education in birth control, you do not say to them, ‘thus far and no further’.
('68', 192, 4, 28, 357459) You ask people to drink temperately, as though it was possible to remain temperate.
('68', 192, 4, 29, 357543) I know these temperate people .
('68', 192, 5, 30, 357575) And yet as Mrs. Sanger was so dreadfully in earnest Gandhiji did mention a remedy which could conceivably appeal to him.
('68', 192, 5, 31, 357696) That method was the avoidance of sexual union during unsafe periods confining it to the “safe” period of about ten days during the month.
('68', 192, 5, 32, 357834) That had at least an element of self control which had to exercised during the unsafe period.
('68', 192, 5, 33, 357928) Whether this appealed to Mrs. Sanger or not I do not know.
('68', 192, 5, 34, 357987) But therein spoke Gandhiji the truth seeker.
('68', 192, 5, 35, 358032) Mrs. Sanger has not referred to it anywhere in her interviews or her Illustrated Weekly article.
('68', 192, 5, 36, 358129) Perhaps if birth 
('68', 193, 0, 1, 358147) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 193, 1, 2, 358189) controllers were to be satisfied with this simple method, the birth control clinics and propagandists would find their trade gone .

('68', 193, 6, 10, 358712) 240. LETTER TO MANU GANDHI
('68', 193, 7, 11, 358739) WARDHA, December 4, 1935
('68', 193, 8, 12, 358764) MANUDI, I sent you yesterday the letters from Natal.
('68', 193, 8, 13, 358817) But though I spent money on postage, I didn't reply to you and so am writing again.
('68', 193, 8, 14, 358901) I am glad you wrote to me.
('68', 193, 8, 15, 358928) Do write to me from time to time.
('68', 193, 8, 16, 358962) You did very well in going there.
('68', 193, 8, 17, 358996) Serve your mother's sisters devotedly and, if they permit you, return soon.
('68', 193, 8, 18, 359072) Keep yourself well occupied all the time.
('68', 193, 8, 19, 359114) Describe your daily programme to me.
('68', 193, 8, 20, 359151) We had quite a crowd of guests here.
('68', 193, 8, 21, 359188) The number has come down today, but will go up again.
('68', 193, 8, 22, 359242) Take proper care of your health.
('68', 193, 8, 23, 359275) If you are careful about your food, you are bound to keep well.

('68', 198, 1, 2, 366028) 249. LETTER TO GIRIJAPRASAD CHINUBHAI

('68', 198, 3, 4, 366094) BHAI GIRIJAPRASAD: SIR CHINUBHAI MADHAVLAL,
('68', 198, 4, 5, 366138) It is against my nature to announce beforehand what I intend to do.
('68', 198, 4, 6, 366206) Doing So makes me feel ashamed.
('68', 198, 4, 7, 366238) Quite often, an impression has got around of my having done something only after having announced my intention of doing it.
('68', 198, 4, 8, 366362) Your letter raises such a question.
('68', 198, 4, 9, 366398) I really consider myself disqualified for the Sahitya Parishad.
('68', 198, 4, 10, 366462) But I was forgetting that you brothers and sisters want to use me to keep the Parishad free from feuds.
('68', 198, 4, 11, 366566) Doubtless I can be useful in that way and I am accepting your invitation in the hope that I may be instrumental in doing something in that direction.
('68', 198, 4, 12, 366716) Keep my burden as light as possible.
('68', 198, 4, 13, 366753) It is a matter of consolation to me that you are the Chairman of the Reception Committee.
('68', 198, 4, 14, 366843) I take it for granted that the Parishad would not be meeting at least this year.
('68', 198, 4, 15, 366924) If it is scheduled to meet some time in January or after that, there will be no inconvenience.
('68', 198, 4, 16, 367019) But it will suit me if it is scheduled for as early as possible in the new year.
('68', 198, 4, 17, 367100) I have destroyed your personal letter.
('68', 198, 5, 18, 367139) Regards from MOHANDAS GANDHI PRESIDENT SAHITYA MANDAL G. S. SAMMELAN AHMEDABAD

('68', 199, 0, 1, 367711) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 199, 1, 2, 367753) 250. DISCUSSION WITH A VILLAGE WORKER 1
('68', 199, 2, 3, 367793) [Before December 7, 1935]
('68', 199, 3, 4, 367819) [VILLAGE WORKER:] Why are we laying such an emphasis on khadi and wholesome food stuffs, when you know that even before the advent of the British, khadi was there and our good food stuffs were there, and yet we were in no better case?
('68', 199, 3, 5, 368054) [GANDHIJI:] This question was discussed threadbare in the columms of Young India and Navajivan if you read them.
('68', 199, 3, 6, 368167) But I shall sum up the reply for you.
('68', 199, 3, 7, 368205) We had khadi, but we did not know its significance; we were self contained, but without realizing its nec essity.
('68', 199, 3, 8, 368319) There was little intelligence behind khadi and our handicrafts, and we little realized that they sustained us.
('68', 199, 3, 9, 368430) Therefore, when they were lost to us we did not miss them, and today when an attempt is being made to restore them, some of us are wondering what use there could be in their restoration.
('68', 199, 4, 10, 368617) Then that means that political education and propaganda is needed, and you have tabooed this.
('68', 199, 4, 11, 368711) No political propaganda is needed to teach people the lesson of self help, of reform in their diet, and of throwing off their inertia and making the best of their idle hours.
('68', 199, 5, 12, 368886) My difficulty is this, that though people in our villages are working like asses from morning until night without an hour's respite they do not get enough to eat.
('68', 199, 5, 13, 369049) And you are asking them to labour still more?
('68', 199, 5, 14, 369095) What you say is news to me.
('68', 199, 5, 15, 369123) The villages I know are those in which quantities of time are being wasted.
('68', 199, 5, 16, 369199) But if as you say there are people who are being overworked, I am asking such people to accept nothing less than a living wage for nothing more than eight hours' work.
('68', 199, 6, 17, 369367) But why not accept the machine with all its good points, eliminating the bad ones?
('68', 199, 6, 18, 369450) I cannot afford to keep our human machines idle.
('68', 199, 6, 19, 369499) We have such an amount of human power lying idle that we have no room for other power driven machines.
('68', 199, 7, 20, 369602) Introduce the power driven machines and get them to work for only as long as is needed for our purposes.
('68', 199, 7, 21, 369707) How do you mean?
('68', 199, 7, 22, 369724) Supposing X produced all the cloth we needed, in mills specially constructed for the purpose, and gave work
('68', 199, 8, 23, 369832) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”
('68', 200, 0, 1, 369881) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 201
('68', 200, 1, 2, 369927) to say three million men, also distributing all the profit between them, what then?
('68', 200, 1, 3, 370011) Then these three million men will be having all the money that used to be distributed between 300 million a hundred years ago.
('68', 200, 2, 4, 370138) No, Sir, I propose that our men should not work more than is necessary for our purposes.
('68', 200, 2, 5, 370227) same work is indeed necessary for all of us, but why should we work, say, more than a couple of hours a day and not devote the rest of our time to pleasant occupations?
('68', 200, 2, 6, 370396) So you would be satisfied if our men were to work only for one hour a day?
('68', 200, 3, 7, 370471) That should be worked out.
('68', 200, 3, 8, 370498) But I should certainly be satisfied.
('68', 200, 3, 9, 370535) Well there's the rub.
('68', 200, 3, 10, 370557) I should never be satisfied until all men had plenty of productive work, say, eight hours a day.
('68', 200, 4, 11, 370654) But why, I wonder, should you insist on this eight hours' minimum?
('68', 200, 4, 12, 370721) Because I know that millions will not employ themselves in work for the sake of it.
('68', 200, 4, 13, 370805) If they did not need to work for their bread, they would lack the incentive.
('68', 200, 4, 14, 370882) Supposing a few millionaires from America came and offered to send us all our food stuffs and implored us not to work but to permit them to give vent to their philanthropy, I should refuse point blank to accept their kind offer.
('68', 200, 5, 15, 371111) That would be because the offer would hurt your self respect?
('68', 200, 5, 16, 371173) No, not only because of that; but especially because it strikes at the root of the fundamental law of our being, viz., that we must work for our bread, that we eat our bread by the sweat of our brow.
('68', 200, 6, 17, 371373) But that is your personal view.
('68', 200, 6, 18, 371405) Would you leave the organization of society to society itself, or would you leave it to a few good guides?
('68', 200, 6, 19, 371512) I should leave it to a few good guides.
('68', 200, 7, 20, 371552) Which means that you are for a dictatorship.
('68', 200, 7, 21, 371597) No, for the simple reason that my fundamental principle is non violence and I should not coerce any individual or community.
('68', 200, 7, 22, 371722) Guidance is not dictatorship.
('68', 200, 8, 23, 371752) Harijan, 7 12 1935
('68', 200, 9, 24, 371771) 251. EVIL OF CREDIT SALES
('68', 200, 10, 25, 371797) Whilst the whole policy of the A.I.S.A. about khadi is being overhauled, it is well to remind those who are in charge of the numerous khadi depots that the custom of selling khadi on credit has on the whole resulted in loss rather than gain to khadi.
('68', 200, 10, 26, 372048) The temptation to give credit to friends, acquaintances and monied men is no doubt very great.
('68', 200, 10, 27, 372143) Often it offends them if credit is refused when, they
('68', 201, 0, 1, 372197) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 201, 1, 2, 372239) contend, no risk is to be run.
('68', 201, 1, 3, 372270) These good people do not realize that it is wrong to expect a salesman to make invidious distinctions.
('68', 201, 1, 4, 372373) Numerous complaints are received from managers of khadi depots about friends and well to do men not discharging the debts incurred by them.
('68', 201, 1, 5, 372513) To issue processes of law for the recovery of debts is a thankless and expensive task and often means more worry than it is worth.
('68', 201, 1, 6, 372644) Hence even at the risk of offending and even losing some customers the safe course is never to depart from the golden rule of ‘no credit sales’.
('68', 201, 1, 7, 372789) Let the khadi workers realize that the mission of khadi is not to be confined to the cities, it has to spread among the millions of villagers who are waiting to hear the call.
('68', 201, 1, 8, 372965) We do not know how to reach them.
('68', 201, 1, 9, 372999) We have hitherto tried the roundabout way.
('68', 201, 1, 10, 373042) We shall not find the direct and the true way in the vain attempt to show ever increasing sales in the books of city depots.
('68', 201, 1, 11, 373167) Let them know that it is the surplus khadi that is to find its way to cities.
('68', 201, 1, 12, 373245) The vast quantity has to be made and used by the villagers themselves.
('68', 201, 1, 13, 373316) The true way to reach the villagers is to concentrate on them in their own cottages.
('68', 201, 1, 14, 373401) City sales, therefore, car be no index of the progress of the mission of khadi.
('68', 201, 1, 15, 373481) Khadi statistics of the future have to show the progress made from year to year in the villages.
('68', 201, 1, 16, 373578) If a large number of workers are to be freed for the spread of khadi in the villages, we must reduce our labours in the cities.
('68', 201, 1, 17, 373706) One way of doing it is religiously to do away with credit sales and confine our attention to those who really want khadi and appreciate the virtue of cash payment.
('68', 201, 1, 18, 373870) Credit sales invariably mean increase in prices for they involve more work, i.e., more expenses.
('68', 201, 1, 19, 373967) Considered from all points of view credit sales have nothing to recommend them except the doubtful convenience of a few customers.
('68', 201, 1, 20, 374098) But khadi exists not for the convenience of the few.
('68', 201, 1, 21, 374151) It is intended for the benefit of all.
('68', 201, 1, 22, 374190) In restricting khadi sales, therefore, to cash transactions the A. I. S. A. seeks the welfare not only of the hungry millions but also of the city buyers of khadi.
('68', 201, 2, 23, 374354) Harijan, 7 12 1935

('68', 202, 10, 25, 375820) In his letter dated December 13 to Jawaharlal Nehru, Mahadev Desai wrote: “He [Gandhiji] has been having high blood pressure for several months, I think, and we should not have noticed it but for a timely warning ten days ago when he had some unaccountable pain in the back regions of the head—no headache, no neuralgic or rheumatic pain, but a certain pain accompanied by numbness which disappeared with careful massage but recurred every two or three hours.
('68', 202, 10, 26, 376280) It was only when the doctors were called—I wired to Jivaraj—that it was found that he had a blood pressure over 200 (syst.) and 120 (diast.).
('68', 202, 10, 27, 376422) He has since been having perfect rest in bed, attending to no correspondence, writing nothing, dictating nothing.”

('68', 203, 6, 12, 377232) 256. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('68', 203, 7, 13, 377265) WARDHA, December 11, 1935

('68', 205, 1, 2, 379597) 259. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('68', 205, 2, 3, 379629) WARDHA, December 19, 1935
('68', 205, 3, 4, 379655) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL,
('68', 205, 4, 5, 379675) I wrote to you last week about the sudden breakdown in Bapu's health.
('68', 205, 4, 6, 379745) 1 He is progressing well, but it will be some time before his bloodpressure becomes normal again.
('68', 205, 4, 7, 379843) He seems to have worked at high pressure all these months and Dr. Jivraj and Dr. Gilder who examined him two days ago are definitely of opinion that he must have a couple of months' rest.
('68', 205, 4, 8, 380031) This he has agreed to do.
('68', 205, 4, 9, 380057) For ten days now he has been in bed resting and sleeping, never reading or writing or dictating.
('68', 205, 4, 10, 380154) But you will be surprised to know that he continued to do his reading on the commode even during these days!
('68', 205, 4, 11, 380263) And he finished the 9th Part of your magnum opus—which it really is— this evening.
('68', 205, 5, 12, 380346) And as soon as he finished it he called me to his bedside and asked me to send you his impressions.
('68', 205, 5, 13, 380446) If he had been well he should have written himself or dictated something but he did not want to strain himself in the teeth of the doctors' advice and so told me in Gujarati in a minute or two what he felt.
('68', 205, 5, 14, 380653) What I say will, therefore, be in my language and not his.
('68', 205, 5, 15, 380712) He said: It is needless to say that it is a brilliantly written book, and a great literary production.
('68', 205, 5, 16, 380815) There are parts where I have my fundamental differences with you and which I would like to criticize, but I will not do so as it is scarcely necessary or useful.
('68', 205, 5, 17, 380977) For when all is said and done it is a highly introspective narrative containing an expression of your innermost thoughts and convictions.
('68', 205, 5, 18, 381115) Even if you could be persuaded to moderate or soften that expression, I should not attempt it, as it would result in taking away from its naturalness, if not aslo its truthfulness.
('68', 205, 5, 19, 381296) After all we are helpless actors in the mighty flow of events, we have to act according to our lights allowing or expecting the events to correct us where we err.
('68', 205, 5, 20, 381459) There is just one thing where perhaps I might make a helpful suggestion.
('68', 205, 5, 21, 381532) The attack on the Liberals seems to have been overdone.
('68', 205, 5, 22, 381588) It seems to obtrude on the reader's attention over and over again and sometimes mars the grace and beauty of the narrative.
('68', 205, 5, 23, 381712) Not that there is any venom in anything that you have said; far from it; but you should not be even unconsciously guilty of doing an injustice to them.
('68', 205, 5, 24, 381864) What you have said about Sastri leaves that impression on me.
('68', 205, 5, 25, 381926) These friends served the country in their time according to their lights, and whilst we may
('68', 205, 6, 26, 382018) 1 Vide 1st footnote of Letter to Fulchand K. Shah.
('68', 206, 0, 1, 382069) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 207
('68', 206, 1, 2, 382115) have our serious differences with them we do not exactly serve the cause of the country by publicly pillorying them.
('68', 206, 1, 3, 382232) If you have not, therefore, already sent the book on to the publishers, you might alter these portions.
('68', 206, 2, 4, 382336) Yours affectionately, MAHADEV

('68', 207, 3, 4, 383867) 262. FOREWORD TO “SATYAGRAHA IN GANDHIJI'S OWN WORDS” 1
('68', 207, 4, 5, 383923) [ Before December 27,1935] 2
('68', 207, 5, 6, 383952) A dear friend on seeing Rajendra Babu's letter asking for a pamphlet, among others, on the philosophy represented by the name ‘satyagraha’ asked me if I would write such a pamphlet.
('68', 207, 5, 7, 384134) Rajendra Babu who knew my preoccupations did not make any such demand upon my time.
('68', 207, 5, 8, 384218) I, therefore, pleaded my inability when the suggestion came to me.
('68', 207, 5, 9, 384285) Another suggestion was then put forward that some friend who knew my writings should make relevant extracts from them and prepare the booklet required.
('68', 207, 5, 10, 384437) I readily endorsed it.
('68', 207, 5, 11, 384460) The result was the following pages prepared after much labour of love.
('68', 207, 5, 12, 384531) The workers desire to remain unknown.
('68', 207, 5, 13, 384569) I glanced through the manuscript and I felt that the work was ably done.
('68', 207, 5, 14, 384642) I believe that it will enable the reader to appreciate the very important implications of satyagraha.
('68', 207, 5, 15, 384744) The fascination of the doctrine as an epitome of non violence is daily growing on me, and I doubt not that if an individual or a nation adopts it as a plan of life, it will promote their happiness and peace and it would be their highest contribution to the attainment of the world peace after which we are all hankering.
('68', 207, 6, 16, 385065) Satyagraha in Gandhiji's Own Words, p.

('68', 208, 6, 9, 385999) [1935]3
('68', 208, 7, 10, 386007) Not to believe in the possibility of permanent peace is to disbelieve the godliness of human nature.
('68', 208, 7, 11, 386108) Methods hitherto adopted have failed because rock bottom sincerity on the part of those who have striven has been lacking.
('68', 208, 7, 12, 386231) Not that they have realized this lack.
('68', 208, 7, 13, 386270) Peace is unattainable by part performance of conditions, even as a chemical combination is impossible without complete fulfilment of the conditions of attainment thereof.
('68', 208, 7, 14, 386441) If the recognized leaders of mankind who have control over engines of destruction were wholly to renounce their use, with full knowledge of its implications, permanent peace can be obtained.
('68', 208, 7, 15, 386632) This is clearly impossible without the great Powers of the earth renouncing their imperialistic design.
('68', 208, 7, 16, 386736) This again seems impossible without great nations ceasing to believe in soul destroying competition and to desire to multiply wants and therefore increase their material possessions.
('68', 208, 7, 17, 386919) It is my conviction that the root of the evil is want of a living faith in a living God.
('68', 208, 7, 18, 387008) It is a first class human tragedy that peoples of the earth who claim to believe in the message of Jesus who they describe as the Prince of Peace show little of that belief in actual practice.
('68', 208, 7, 19, 387201) It is painful to see sincere Christian divines limiting the scope of Jesus' message to select individuals.
('68', 208, 7, 20, 387308) I have been taught from my childhood and tested the truth by experience that the primary virtues of mankind are possible of cultivation by the meanest of the human species.
('68', 208, 7, 21, 387481) It is this undoubted universal possibility that distinguishes the humans from the rest of

('68', 212, 1, 2, 392109) 272. INTERVIEW TO YONE NOGUCHI 1
('68', 212, 2, 3, 392142) [Before January 11, 1936]
('68', 212, 3, 4, 392168) It was in the teeth of the doctors' advice that Gandhiji made an exception in favour of Japan's poet Yone Noguchi and invited him to visit him.
('68', 212, 3, 5, 392312) He said: He is not going to discuss anything with me.
('68', 212, 3, 6, 392366) I shall simply have the pleasure of listening to him.
('68', 212, 4, 7, 392420) So the poet came and saw Gandhiji in his bed lying with a wet earth bandage on his head.
('68', 212, 4, 8, 392509) Gandhiji said: I sprang from Indian earth and so it is Indian earth that crowns me.
('68', 212, 5, 9, 392593) NOGUCHI: In fundamentals, we are the same, in the virtue of negation, of simplicity, of the unification [of] poetry with life, and I am here to give you a few words of adoration.
('68', 212, 6, 10, 392772) On Gandhiji asking him his impressions of his visit to India, he said: “India has deeply interested me.
('68', 212, 6, 11, 392876) So many things I have seen that I had never dreamed of seeing.
('68', 212, 6, 12, 392939) Sometimes I have had disappointments, too.
('68', 212, 6, 13, 392982) In the exhibition at Nagpur I found a new India, people very busy working” ..
('68', 212, 6, 14, 393060) He asked Gandhiji if he knew anything about Japan.
('68', 212, 6, 15, 393111) Gandhiji said: Nothing except through Edwin Arnold whose descriptions 2 of Japanese life I read exactly 45 years ago with great avidity as they were appearing in his letters published weekly in an English journal.
('68', 212, 6, 16, 393325) He had married a Japanese wife and all that he wrote he did with intimate sympathy.
('68', 212, 7, 17, 393409) NOGUCHI: You are right, Arnold's book is true even today.
('68', 212, 7, 18, 393467) Without love and sympathy you cannot give a correct picture of a people.
('68', 212, 8, 19, 393540) GANDHIJI: Yes, and it is easiest to see the darker side.
('68', 212, 8, 20, 393597) You must have seen our darker side, as we know the darker side of Japan through Japan's traffic and trade rivalry.
('68', 212, 8, 21, 393712) But it is best to see the brighter side, and Japan's brighter side I know through Kagawa 3.
('68', 212, 9, 22, 393804) Kasturba came and she was introduced to the poet.
('68', 212, 9, 23, 393854) Gandhiji said: Don't you think, she is the picture of a Japanese woman?
('68', 212, 10, 24, 393926) NOGUCHI: Yes, she is like my mother.
('68', 212, 11, 25, 393963) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter” 2 In Seas and Lands (1891) and Japonica (1892) 3 A Japanese sadhu who had stayed with Gandhiji at his Ashram
('68', 213, 0, 1, 394121) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 213, 1, 2, 394163) Gandhiji was apparently unsatisfied with the very little that the poet said about India.
('68', 213, 1, 3, 394252) So he said once again: Yours is the most hospitable country in the world, I know.
('68', 213, 1, 4, 394334) I hope you found my country at least a second best.
('68', 213, 2, 5, 394386) NOGUCHI: Yours is the most hopitable.
('68', 213, 3, 6, 394424) He perhaps did not want to tax Gandhiji in his weak condition.
('68', 213, 3, 7, 394487) He said: “I have nothing to ask you since your life is an open book to me.
('68', 213, 3, 8, 394562) You have had nothing to conceal.”
('68', 213, 4, 9, 394596) But as he was leaving he just asked if Gandhiji would give him any message for Japan.
('68', 213, 4, 10, 394682) Gandhiji said: My message is included in the message you have received from our poet Dr. Tagore.
('68', 213, 4, 11, 394779) His message includes all the messages that many of us can give.
('68', 213, 5, 12, 394843) Gandhiji requested the poet to visit Ahmedabad and also arranged through Seth Ambalal Sarabhai an invitation to him.

('68', 220, 1, 2, 403914) 288. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('68', 220, 2, 3, 403938) [February 13, 1936] 1
('68', 220, 3, 4, 403960) MIRA, I see you dread going to Segaon.
('68', 220, 3, 5, 403999) 2 Don't if you do not have the urge.
('68', 220, 3, 6, 404036) You know the verse 3 in Gita What will compulsion avail?
('68', 220, 3, 7, 404093) This is compulsion against oneself.
('68', 220, 3, 8, 404129) Resistance up to a point is a duty.
('68', 220, 3, 9, 404165) It becomes compulsion when the urge and the joy is lacking.
('68', 220, 3, 10, 404225) All resistance is good and obligatory so long as it gives us strength.
('68', 220, 3, 11, 404296) But when one is exhausted with every effort, be sure it is compulsion which must be avoided.
('68', 220, 3, 12, 404389) The evil with you is that you have compelled yourself against your will to do certain things.
('68', 220, 3, 13, 404483) This is an untruth.
('68', 220, 3, 14, 404503) Therefore don't go to Segaon unless you feel you must and will be miserable if you did not go.
('68', 220, 3, 15, 404598) Is this quite clear?
('68', 220, 3, 16, 404619) Kanti and Kanu are looking after me with great diligence and care.
('68', 220, 3, 17, 404686) BAPU From the original: C.W. 6312. Courtesy: Mirabehn.

('68', 225, 4, 7, 413282) 296. SPEECH AT HARIJAN ASHRAM 2
('68', 225, 5, 8, 413314) [February 16, 1936] 3
('68', 225, 6, 9, 413336) Though I have been having rest for the last two months or more I have been constantly thinking of the rules and vows 4 of our Ashram.
('68', 225, 6, 10, 413470) Quite a number of the Ashram inmates, old and young, have given up or have failed to live up to the vows of the Ashram and I wondered if that meant that there was anything inherently defective about those vows.
('68', 225, 6, 11, 413681) But I came to the conclusion that there was no such thing and that it was well that we had kept those vows in front of us and tried, each according to his or her ability, to observe them, and that there was absolutely no cause for regret that the vows had been taken.
('68', 225, 6, 12, 413949) I am devotee of the Gita and a firm believer in the inexorable law of karma.
('68', 225, 6, 13, 414026) Even the least little tripping or stumbling is not without its cause and I have wondered why one who has tried to follow the Gita in thought, word and deed should have any ailment.
('68', 225, 6, 14, 414207) The doctors have assured me that this trouble of high blood pressure is entirely the result of mental strain and worry.
('68', 225, 6, 15, 414327) If that is true, it is likely that I have been unnecessarily worrying myself, unnessarily fretting and secretly harbouring passions like anger, lust, etc.
('68', 225, 6, 16, 414482) The fact that any event or incident should disturb my mental equilibrium, in spite of my serious efforts, means not that the Gita ideal is defective but that my devotion to it is defective.
('68', 225, 6, 17, 414672) The Gita ideal is true for all time, my understanding of it and observance of it is full of flaws.
('68', 225, 6, 18, 414771) The same is the case about the vows.
('68', 225, 6, 19, 414808) The vows are true for all time, our observance of them has
('68', 225, 7, 20, 414867) 1 Not available 2 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 1 3 1936. 3 Gandhiji visited Harijan Ashram on this date; vide the following item.
('68', 225, 7, 21, 415017) 4 Vide “Satyagraha Ashram”, 14 6 1928.
('68', 226, 0, 1, 415056) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 227
('68', 226, 1, 2, 415102) been defective.
('68', 226, 1, 3, 415118) The very contemplation of those vows is a source of perennial joy to me.
('68', 226, 1, 4, 415191) I know that several inmates of the old Satyagraha Ashram are staying here.
('68', 226, 1, 5, 415266) They must be living here for some purpose; it can be none other than service of the Harijans.
('68', 226, 1, 6, 415360) If they cherish the old vows and insist on their observance, they will be thereby rendering a service to the Harijans.
('68', 226, 1, 7, 415479) Monetary help is not the only way to serve the Harijans.
('68', 226, 1, 8, 415536) Our spirit of service and self purification may take that concrete shape, but that is not the only shape it can take.
('68', 226, 1, 9, 415654) We can, for instance, never render monetary help to the extent that Government can do.
('68', 226, 1, 10, 415741) The essence of our help consists in our passionate desire to help and suffer for them, and that desire can come only out of self purification, out of the observance of the vows we have been endeavouring to keep all these years.
('68', 226, 1, 11, 415969) That will be the measure of our service to them, and of our capacity to make them true ‘Harijans’— men of God.

('68', 229, 7, 10, 420615) Do not forget that the aims and objects 5 of the Vidyapith continue to be what they were.
('68', 229, 7, 11, 420705) They were framed after much thought and deliberation by the organizers and the teachers.
('68', 229, 7, 12, 420794) You have to keep them all in front of you.
('68', 229, 7, 13, 420837) They are all contained in the prayer you have just now recited.
('68', 229, 7, 14, 420901) We have all to march from untruth to truth, from darkness to light .Truth is at the very root of all our aims and vows and the plant of truth will not grow and fructify if you do not water its roots with ahimsa.
('68', 229, 7, 15, 421113) But for you the truth lies in cultivating true rural mindedness.

('68', 229, 7, 17, 421329) But you are not children of city dwellers.You come from villages, you are children of villagers who have gone through suffering and sacrifice in the fight for freedom, and your duty towards the villages is therefore greater.

('68', 232, 8, 18, 425191) BARDOLI, February 21, 1936
('68', 232, 9, 19, 425218) ANASUYABEHN,
('68', 232, 10, 20, 425231) Unable to resist your love I brought along your gift with me here.
('68', 232, 10, 21, 425298) And today I had a look at them.
('68', 232, 10, 22, 425330) The bowl is made in Germany.
('68', 232, 10, 23, 425359) The razor of course is foreign made, your dharma and mine lies in making do with things made in our villages (not even in our cities).
('68', 232, 10, 24, 425494) For this reason and in pursuance of the ideal of non possession I manage without many things.
('68', 232, 10, 25, 425588) So while on tour I shave with whatever razor I can get hold of.
('68', 232, 10, 26, 425652) In Wardha there is a nationalist barber who shaves me with a village made razor.
('68', 232, 10, 27, 425733) Such being the situation, how can I make use of your bowl and things?
('68', 232, 10, 28, 425803) Also we must spend every
('68', 232, 11, 29, 425828) 1 Vide “Letter to Prabhavati”, 13 2 1936. 2 A kind of woollen cloth
('68', 233, 0, 1, 425896) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 233, 1, 2, 425938) pie with the utmost care because it belongs to the poor, but you go on lavishly spending on me.
('68', 233, 1, 3, 426034) These thoughts strike me most poignantly here in Bardoli.
('68', 233, 1, 4, 426092) Hence this letter.
('68', 233, 1, 5, 426111) Here they have built a hut for me under a mango tree.
('68', 233, 1, 6, 426165) The walls are of dried stems of tuver in a framework of bamboo.
('68', 233, 1, 7, 426229) Khadi has been used where found necessary.
('68', 233, 1, 8, 426272) Not a single pie has been spent in making the hut.

('68', 233, 6, 22, 427071) GANDHIJI: Is the prejudice against colour growing or dying out?
('68', 233, 7, 23, 427135) THURMAN 3: It is difficult to say because in one place things look much improved, whilst in another the outlook is still dark.
('68', 233, 7, 24, 427262) Among many of the Southern white students there is a disposition to improve upon the a attitude of their forbears, and the nigration occasioned by the World War did contribute appreciably to break down the barriers.

('68', 233, 7, 26, 427644) Among the masses of workers there is a great amount of tension, which
('68', 233, 8, 27, 427714) 1 This appeared under the title “With Our Negro Guests” by Mahadev Desai.

('68', 234, 1, 2, 428080) is quite natural when the white thinks that the Negro’s very existence is a threat to his own.
('68', 234, 2, 3, 428175) G. Is the union between Negroes and the whites recognized by law?
('68', 234, 3, 4, 428241) CARROL 1 Twenty five States have laws definitely against these unions, and I have had to sign a bond of 500 dollars to promise that I would not register any such union.
('68', 234, 4, 5, 428410) T. But there has been a lot of intermixture of races as for 300 years or more the Negro woman had no control over her body.

('68', 234, 5, 7, 428594) G. No, I purposely did not invite them.
('68', 234, 5, 8, 428634) It would have endangered their cause.

('68', 234, 6, 11, 428982) “We are often told”, said Dr. Thurman, “that but for the Arabs there would have been no slavery.
('68', 234, 6, 12, 429079) I do not believe it.”
('68', 234, 7, 13, 429101) G. No, it is not true at all.
('68', 234, 7, 14, 429131) For, the moment a slave accepts Islam he obtains equality with his master, and there are several instances of this in history.
('68', 234, 8, 15, 429258) The whole discussion led to many a question and cross question during which the guests had an occasion to see that Gandhiji‘s principle of equal respect for all religions was no theoretical formula but a practical creed.
('68', 234, 8, 16, 429479) “Is non violence from your point of view a form of direct action”inquired Dr. Thurman.
('68', 234, 9, 17, 429567) G. It is not one form, it is the only form.
('68', 234, 9, 18, 429611) I do not of course confine the words ‘direct action’ to their technical meaning.
('68', 234, 9, 19, 429692) But without a direct active expression of it, non violence to my mind is meaningless.
('68', 234, 9, 20, 429778) It is the greatest and the activest force in the world.
('68', 234, 9, 21, 429834) One cannot be passively non violent.
('68', 234, 9, 22, 429871) In fact‘non violence’ is a term I had to coin in order to bring out the root meaning of ahimsa.
('68', 234, 9, 23, 429967) In spite of the negative particle ‘non’, it is no negative force.
('68', 234, 9, 24, 430033) Superficially we are surrounded in life by strife and bloodshed, life living upon life.
('68', 234, 9, 25, 430121) But some great seer, who ages ago penetrated the centre of truth, said: It is not through strife and violence, but through non violence that man can fulfil his destiny and his duty to his fellow creatures.
('68', 234, 9, 26, 430327) It is a force which is more positive than electricity and more powerful than even ether.
('68', 234, 9, 27, 430416) At the centre of non violence is a force which is self acting.
('68', 234, 10, 28, 430479) 1 Pastor of Salem
('68', 235, 0, 1, 430497) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('68', 235, 1, 2, 430539) Ahimsa means ‘love’ in the Pauline sense, and yet something more than the ‘love’ defined by St. Paul, although I know St. Paul's beautiful definition is good enough for all practical purposes.
('68', 235, 1, 3, 430732) Ahimsa includes the whole creation, and not only human.
('68', 235, 1, 4, 430788) Besides, love in the English language has other connotations too, and so I was compelled to use the negative word.
('68', 235, 1, 5, 430903) But it does not, as I have told you, express a negative force, but a force superior to all the forces put together.
('68', 235, 1, 6, 431019) One person who can express ahimsa in life exercises a force superior to all the forces of brutality.
('68', 235, 2, 7, 431120) Q. And is it possible for any individual to achieve this?
('68', 235, 3, 8, 431178) G. Certainly.
('68', 235, 3, 9, 431192) If there was any exclusiveness about it, I should reject it at once.
('68', 235, 4, 10, 431261) Q. Any idea of possession is foreign to it?
('68', 235, 5, 11, 431305) G. Yes.
('68', 235, 5, 12, 431313) It possesses nothing, therefore it possesses everything.
('68', 235, 6, 13, 431370) Q. Is it possible for a single human being to resist the persistent invasion of the quality successfully?
('68', 235, 7, 14, 431476) G. It is possible.
('68', 235, 7, 15, 431495) Perhaps your question is more universal than you mean.

('68', 235, 8, 18, 431761) DR.T. Yes, that is one half of the question.
('68', 235, 8, 19, 431806) I wanted to know if one man can hold the whole violence at bay?
('68', 235, 9, 20, 431870) G. If he cannot, you must take it that he is not a true representative of ahimsa.
('68', 235, 9, 21, 431952) Supposing I cannot produce a single instance in life of a man who truly converted his adversary, I would then say that is because no one had yet been found to express ahimsa in its fulness.
('68', 235, 10, 22, 432142) Q. Then it overrides all other forces?
('68', 235, 11, 23, 432181) G. Yes, it is the only true force in life.
('68', 235, 12, 24, 432224) DR.T. Forgive the weakness, but may I ask how are we to train individuals or communities in this difficult art?
('68', 235, 13, 25, 432336) G. There is no royal road, except through living the creed in your life which must be a living sermon.
('68', 235, 13, 26, 432439) Of course the expression in one's own life presupposes great study, tremendous perseverance, and thorough cleansing of one's self of all the impurities.
('68', 235, 13, 27, 432592) If for mastering of the physical sciences you have to devote a whole lifetime, how many lifetimes may be needed for mastering the greatest spiritual

('68', 236, 1, 4, 432867) For if this is the only permanent thing in life, if this is the only thing that counts,then whatever effort you bestow on mastering it is well spent.
('68', 236, 1, 5, 433017) Seek ye first the kingdom of Heaven and everything else shall be added unto you.

('68', 237, 3, 4, 435164) 310. SPEECH AT VILLAGE WORKERS’ MEETING 2
('68', 237, 4, 5, 435206) BARDOLI, February 22, 1936
('68', 237, 5, 6, 435233) The first question was about the duties of the village workers.
('68', 237, 5, 7, 435297) The only duty of the village worker was to serve the villagers, said Gandhiji, and he could best serve them if he kept the eleven vows 3 in front of him as a beacon light.
('68', 237, 6, 8, 435469) The other question was about the livelihood of the village worker.
('68', 237, 6, 9, 435536) How was he to earn it?
('68', 237, 6, 10, 435559) Was he to draw an allowance from an institution, or to earn it by labouring for it, or to depend upon the village for it?
('68', 237, 6, 11, 435681) The ideal way, said Gandhiji, was to depend upon the village.
('68', 237, 6, 12, 435743) There was no shame therein, but humility.
('68', 237, 6, 13, 435785) There was no scope for self indulgence either, for he could not think of a village which would encourage or tolerate self indulgence.
('68', 237, 6, 14, 435919) All that the worker need do was to work for the village all his working hours, and to collect whatever grain and vegetables he needed from the village.
('68', 237, 6, 15, 436071) He might collect a little money too (for postage and other monetary expenditure) if he should need it, though Gandhiji did not think he could not do without it.
('68', 237, 6, 16, 436232) The village would willingly support him if he had gone there at the invitation of the village.
('68', 237, 6, 17, 436327) He could conceive an occasion when the villagers might not be able to tolerate his views and withdraw their support, as, for instance, they did when he admitted untouchables in the Satyagraha Ashram in 1915. Then he should work for his living.
('68', 237, 6, 18, 436571) It was no use depending on an institution.
('68', 237, 7, 19, 436614) The third question was about body labour.
('68', 237, 7, 20, 436656) The village worker was in the village to do as much body labour as possible and to teach the villagers to outgrow idleness.
('68', 237, 7, 21, 436780) He might do any kind of labour, but give preference to scavenging.
('68', 237, 7, 22, 436847) Scavenging was certainly productive labour.
('68', 237, 7, 23, 436891) He liked some of the workers' insistence on devoting at least half an hour to work entirely of service and of a productive kind.
('68', 237, 8, 24, 437020) 1 Before taking leave of Gandhiji Mrs. Thurman sang two famous Negro spirituals: “Were you there, when they crucified my Lord” and “We are climbing Jacob's ladder.” 2 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 1 3 1936. The village workers gave a list of questions to Gandhiji and requested him to enlighten them.
('68', 237, 8, 25, 437340) 3 Non violence, truth, non stealing, brahmacharya, non possession, bodylabour, control of the palate, fearlessness, equal respect for all religions, swadeshi (restricting oneself to the use and service of one's nearest surroundings in preference to those more remote) and spirit of unexclusive brotherhood
('68', 238, 0, 1, 437646) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 239
('68', 238, 1, 2, 437692) Scavenging certainly came under that category.
('68', 238, 1, 3, 437739) Also grinding; for money saved is money got.
('68', 238, 2, 4, 437784) The fourth question was about maintaining a diary.
('68', 238, 2, 5, 437835) Gandhiji had no doubt that the village worker must be prepared to account for every minute of his waking hours and must fill them with work and mention it distenctly in his diary.
('68', 238, 2, 6, 438015) A real diary was a mirror of the diarist's mind and soul, but many might find it difficult to make a truthful record of their mind's activities.
('68', 238, 2, 7, 438160) In that case they might confine themselves to a record of their physical activities.
('68', 238, 2, 8, 438245) But it should not be done in a haphazard way.
('68', 238, 2, 9, 438291) Simply sayng, “Worked in the kitchen” would not do.
('68', 238, 2, 10, 438343) One may have whiled away one's time in the kitchen.
('68', 238, 2, 11, 438395) Specific items of work should be mentioned.
('68', 238, 3, 12, 438439) The fifth question was about work among Dublas who work more or lesss as serfs in certain parts of Gujarat.
('68', 238, 3, 13, 438547) Service of Dublas, said Gandhiji, meant readiness to share their toil and their hardships, and to get into touch with their masters and to see that they dealt with them justly and kindly.
('68', 238, 4, 14, 438735) Summing up, Gandhiji said: The village worker will leave politics alone.
('68', 238, 4, 15, 438808) He may become a Congress member, but he may not take part in an election campaign.
('68', 238, 4, 16, 438891) He has his work cut out for himself.
('68', 238, 4, 17, 438928) The Village Industries Association and the Spinners' Association were both created by the Congress.
('68', 238, 4, 18, 439028) and yet they work independently of the Congress.
('68', 238, 4, 19, 439077) That is why they and their members steer clear of all Congress politics.
('68', 238, 4, 20, 439150) That is the non violent way.
('68', 238, 4, 21, 439179) He will also leave village factions alone.
('68', 238, 4, 22, 439222) He must go and settle there determined to do without most of the things he does not do without in a city.
('68', 238, 4, 23, 439328) If I sit down in a village I should have to decide what things I should not take with me in the village, however inherently harmless those things may be.
('68', 238, 4, 24, 439482) The question is whether those things will sort well or ill with the life of an ordinary villager.
('68', 238, 4, 25, 439580) He will be incorruptible and stand like a rock against the inroad of temptations and save the village from them.
('68', 238, 4, 26, 439693) Even one pure soul can save a whole village, as one Vibhishana 1 saved Lanka.
('68', 238, 4, 27, 439771) Sodom and Gomorrah were not destroyed so long as there was one pure soul left in them.
('68', 238, 4, 28, 439858) 2 That is why I said long ago that I would far rather that India perished than sacrifice truth in order to save it.

('68', 245, 1, 2, 447942) 323. NOTHING WITHOUT GRACE
('68', 245, 2, 3, 447969) By the grace of medical friends and self constituted gaolers, Sardar Vallabhbhai and Jamnalalji, I am now able by way of trial to resume to a limited extent my talks with the readers of Harijan.
('68', 245, 2, 4, 448164) The restrictions that they have put on my liberty and to which I have agreed, are that, for the time being at any rate, I shall not write for Harijan more than I may consider to be absolutely necessary and that, too, not involving more than a few hours' writing per week.
('68', 245, 2, 5, 448436) I shall not carry on private correspondence with reference to correspondents' personal problems or domestic difficulties, except those with which I have already concerned myself, and I shall not accept public engagements or attend or speak at public gatherings.
('68', 245, 2, 6, 448698) There are positive directions about sleep, recreation, exercise and food, with which the reader is not concerned and with which therefore I need not deal.
('68', 245, 2, 7, 448853) I hope that the readers of Harijan and correspondents will co operate with me and Mahadev Desai, who has in the first instance to attend to all correspondence, in the observance of these restrictions.
('68', 245, 2, 8, 449054) It will interest the reader to know something about the origin of the breakdown and the measures taken to cope with it.
('68', 245, 2, 9, 449174) So far as I have understood the medical friends, after a very careful and painstaking examination of my system they have found no functional derangement.
('68', 245, 2, 10, 449328) Their opinion is that the breakdown was most probably due to deficiency of proteins and carbohydrates in the form of sugar and starches, coupled with overstrain for a prolonged period involving long hours and concentration on numerous taxing private problems in addition to the performance of daily public duty.
('68', 245, 2, 11, 449640) So far as I can recollect I had been complaining for the past twelve months or more that, if I did not curtail the volume of ever growing work, I was sure to break down.
('68', 245, 2, 12, 449810) Therefore when it came, it was nothing new to me.
('68', 245, 2, 13, 449860) And it is highly likely that the world would have heard little of it but for the over anxiety of one of the friends who, on seeing me indisposed, sent a sensational note to Jamnalalji who gathered together all the medical talent that was available in Wardha and sent messages to Nagpur and Bombay for further help.
('68', 245, 2, 14, 450175) The day I collapsed I had a warning on rising in the morning that there was some unusual pain about the neck, but I made light of it and never mentioned it to anybody.
('68', 245, 2, 15, 450343) I continued to go through the
('68', 246, 0, 1, 450373) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 247
('68', 246, 1, 2, 450419) daily programme.
('68', 246, 1, 3, 450436) The final stroke was a most exhausting and serious conversation I had with a friend whilst I was having the daily evening stroll.
('68', 246, 1, 4, 450566) The nerves had already been sufficiently taxed during the preceding fortnight with the consideration and solution of problems which for me were quite as big and as important as, say, the paramount question of swaraj.
('68', 246, 1, 5, 450783) Even if no fuss had been made over the collapse, I would have taken nature's peremptory warning to heart, given myself moderate rest and tided over the difficulty.
('68', 246, 1, 6, 450947) But looking back upon the past I feel that it was well that the fuss was made.
('68', 246, 1, 7, 451026) The extraordinary precautions advised by the medical friends and equally extraordinary care taken by the two ‘gaolers’ enforced on me the exacting rest which I would not have taken and which allowed ample time for introspection.
('68', 246, 1, 8, 451255) Not only have I profited by it but the introspection has revealed vital defects in my following out of the interpretation of the Gita as I have understood it.
('68', 246, 1, 9, 451414) I have discovered that I have not approached with adequate detachment the innumerable problems that have presented themselves for solution.
('68', 246, 1, 10, 451554) It is clear that I have taken many of them to heart and allowed them to rouse my emotional being and thus affect my nerves.
('68', 246, 1, 11, 451678) In other words they have not, as they should have in a votary of the Gita, left my body or mind untouched.
('68', 246, 1, 12, 451785) I verily believe that one who literally follows the prescription of the eternal Mother need never grow old in mind.
('68', 246, 1, 13, 451901) Such a one's body will wither in due course like leaves of a healthy tree, leaving the mind as young and as fresh as ever.
('68', 246, 1, 14, 452024) That seems to me to be the meaning of Bhishma delivering his marvellous discourse to Yudhishthira though he was on his death bed.
('68', 246, 1, 15, 452154) Medical friends were never tired of warning me against being excited over or affected by events happening around me.
('68', 246, 1, 16, 452271) Extra precautions were taken to keep from me news of a tragic character.
('68', 246, 1, 17, 452344) Though, I think, I was not quite so bad a devotee of the Gita as their precautions Lead me to suppose, there was undoubtedly substance behind them.
('68', 246, 1, 18, 452492) For I discovered with what a wrench I accepted Jamnalalji's conditions and demand that I should remove from Maganwadi to Mahila Ashram.
('68', 246, 1, 19, 452628) Anyway I had lost credit with him for detached action.
('68', 246, 1, 20, 452683) The fact of the collapse was for him eloquent enough testimony for discrediting my vaunted detachment.
('68', 246, 1, 21, 452786) I must plead guilty to the condemnation.
('68', 246, 1, 22, 452827) The worst however was to follow.
('68', 246, 1, 23, 452860) I have been trying to follow brahmacharya consciously and deliberately since 1899. My definition of it is purity not merely of body but of both speech and
('68', 247, 0, 1, 453015) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 248
('68', 247, 1, 2, 453057) thought also.
('68', 247, 1, 3, 453071) With the exception of what must be regarded as one lapse, I can recall no instance, during more than thirty six years' constant and conscious effort, of mental disturbance such as I experienced during this illness.
('68', 247, 1, 4, 453286) I was disgusted with myself.
('68', 247, 1, 5, 453315) The moment the feeling came I acquainted my attendants and the medical friends with my condition.
('68', 247, 1, 6, 453413) They could give me no help.
('68', 247, 1, 7, 453441) I expected none.
('68', 247, 1, 8, 453458) I broke loose after the experience from the rigid rest that was imposed upon me.
('68', 247, 1, 9, 453539) The confession of the wretched experience brought much relief to me.
('68', 247, 1, 10, 453608) I felt as if a great load had been raised from over me.
('68', 247, 1, 11, 453664) It enabled me to pull myself together before any harm could be done.
('68', 247, 1, 12, 453733) 1 But what of the Gita?
('68', 247, 1, 13, 453757) Its teaching is clear and precise.
('68', 247, 1, 14, 453792) A mind that is once hooked to the Star of stars becomes incorruptible.
('68', 247, 1, 15, 453863) How far I must be from Him, He alone knows.
('68', 247, 1, 16, 453907) Thank God, my much vaunted Mahatmaship has never fooled me.
('68', 247, 1, 17, 453967) But this enforced rest has humbled me as never before.
('68', 247, 1, 18, 454022) It has brought to the surface my limitations and imperfections.
('68', 247, 1, 19, 454086) But I am not so much ashamed of them, as I should be of hiding them from the public.
('68', 247, 1, 20, 454171) My faith in the message of the Gita is as bright as ever.
('68', 247, 1, 21, 454229) Unwearied ceaseless effort is the price that must be paid for turning that faith into rich infallible experience.
('68', 247, 1, 22, 454343) But the same Gita says without any equivocation that the experience is not to be had without divine grace.
('68', 247, 1, 23, 454450) We should develop swelled heads if Divinity had not made that ample reservation.
('68', 247, 2, 24, 454531) Harijan, 29 2 1936

('68', 250, 5, 13, 460684) In my view we cannot formulate any exact rule about it.
('68', 250, 5, 14, 460740) We can no doubt say that we shall not go beyond a certain limit.
('68', 250, 5, 15, 460805) For instance, the Sangh has set the limit of Rs. 75 as monthly wage.

('68', 250, 5, 18, 461017) Nor is so much money needed there.

('68', 250, 5, 20, 461096) They have their own difficulties.

('68', 250, 5, 22, 461282) And they cannot maintain themselves on low wages either.
('68', 250, 5, 23, 461339) To such people we can give even Rs. 75. But we give this reluctantly and they too accept it reluctantly.
('68', 250, 5, 24, 461444) This, however, is not a matter to be considered by others.
('68', 250, 5, 25, 461503) But, if one person can carry on with Rs. 5, why should he demand Rs. 50 Merely because some other parson is getting Rs. 50?
('68', 250, 5, 26, 461627) The person earning Rs. 50 or Rs. 75 has either poor health or has some other handicaps which the person earning Rs. 5 does not have.

('68', 258, 2, 3, 478877) SAVLI, March 3, 1936
('68', 258, 3, 4, 478898) Ramnarayanji 1 has passed on a letter to the President.
('68', 258, 3, 5, 478954) He showed it to me, and I read it too.
('68', 258, 3, 6, 478993) Then I wished to know what this committee 2
('68', 258, 4, 7, 479037) for Gandhian thought was, who were the persons constituting it, what were its powers and so on.
('68', 258, 4, 8, 479133) Then I was informed about all that happened yesterday.
('68', 258, 4, 9, 479188) I was told at the same time that this committee was not a body authorized by this session.
('68', 258, 4, 10, 479279) This session does not function by passing resolutions.
('68', 258, 4, 11, 479334) When the occasion arose, a suggestion was made, and then those who favoured the suggestion formed a committee.
('68', 258, 4, 12, 479445) At first I felt that I should not involve myself in this matter.
('68', 258, 4, 13, 479510) I felt also that since I had not been able to be present at the discussion, I was not entitled to express any opinion.
('68', 258, 4, 14, 479629) Nevertheless, I do have an opinion on the subject and I consider it my duty to express it even if it should be considered an impertinence on my part.
('68', 258, 4, 15, 479779) I wish to make clear to the committee its scope.
('68', 258, 4, 16, 479828) If it undertakes any work, it should only be one of collecting my thoughts and beliefs.
('68', 258, 4, 17, 479916) If it does anything more, I am afraid the misgivings 3 expressed by Ramnarayanji are bound to come true.
('68', 258, 4, 18, 480021) I have conceived no such thing as Gandhism.
('68', 258, 4, 19, 480065) I am not an exponent of any sect.
('68', 258, 4, 20, 480099) I never claimed to have originated any philosophy.
('68', 258, 4, 21, 480150) Nor am I endeavoring to do so.
('68', 258, 4, 22, 480181) Several people said to me

('68', 259, 1, 2, 481344) that I should write a smriti 1 of Gandhian thought.

('68', 259, 1, 8, 481750) Like a child I did whatever occurred to me on the spur of the moment during the course of events.

('68', 266, 7, 24, 500103) A. There are quite a few similarities.

('68', 267, 3, 6, 501327) Q. What should be the limits of the worker's individual service?
('68', 267, 4, 7, 501392) A. A very fine criterion for this is to be found in the sloka 2
('68', 267, 5, 8, 501456) which lays down that for the good of the family the individual may be sacrificed.
('68', 267, 5, 9, 501538) An individual may be served only as far as it does not hamper service of the society.

('68', 267, 5, 11, 501745) In such a situation, I would leave my son, mother and wife in charge of my brother, etc., and go.
('68', 267, 6, 12, 501843) Q. Can people who believe in non violence take unfertilized eggs?

('68', 267, 7, 14, 501937) Those who have no objection can take such eggs.

('68', 273, 2, 3, 511780) SAVLI, March 5, 1936
('68', 273, 3, 4, 511801) For the past two days I have been trying to get acquainted with each one of you.
('68', 273, 3, 5, 511882) But I have failed.
('68', 273, 3, 6, 511901) I had a desire to meet every one of you and resolve your doubts.
('68', 273, 3, 7, 511966) That would have satisfied you as well as me.
('68', 273, 3, 8, 512011) I have grown rather fond of meeting people individually.
('68', 273, 3, 9, 512068) But I found I should overcome this temptation if I wanted to work.
('68', 273, 3, 10, 512135) You exercised restraint and thus put a check on this fondness.
('68', 273, 3, 11, 512198) None of you sought to meet me and with great reluctance I gave up my desire.
('68', 273, 3, 12, 512275) I had to restrain myself a great deal today.
('68', 273, 3, 13, 512320) It pained me that I could not say anything at the wedding of Krishnadas.
('68', 273, 3, 14, 512393) I did not address even a few words to the newly married couple.
('68', 273, 3, 15, 512457) Some day one will have to suffer even physical separation.
('68', 273, 3, 16, 512516) Then why should we not prepare ourselves for it right from now on?
('68', 273, 3, 17, 512583) The relationship between you and me should be so lasting that it would not be affected by physical separation.
('68', 273, 3, 18, 512694) Let me now reply to Prabhudas Gandhi's questions.
('68', 273, 3, 19, 512744) He has asked me how we can become one with the poor.
('68', 273, 3, 20, 512797) This means that he has been trying, but has not succeeded so far.
('68', 273, 3, 21, 512863) The conclusion to be drawn is that it is only with difficulty that such a state can be attained.
('68', 273, 3, 22, 512960) We have lived on urban life, and we still have a lingering desire for that life.
('68', 273, 3, 23, 513041) On the other hand, the desire to serve the villages is growing.
('68', 273, 3, 24, 513105) I cannot prescribe any method for becoming one with the people.
('68', 273, 3, 25, 513169) Nor do I have one.
('68', 273, 3, 26, 513188) If Vinoba has suggested something, I am not aware of if.
('68', 273, 3, 27, 513245) 1 One cannot say to what extent oneness with the poor in a broad sense is possible.
('68', 273, 3, 28, 513329) Some may be able to attain it in full, and some partially and some not at all throughout their life.
('68', 273, 3, 29, 513430) But we must attain that oneness at any rate in our own hearts.
('68', 273, 3, 30, 513493) Once the heart has begun to experience such oneness, the mind would automatically follow, and we would gradually progress in that direction.
('68', 273, 3, 31, 513634) Whether or not we succeed is in the hands of God.
('68', 273, 3, 32, 513684) What really matters is the effort.
('68', 273, 3, 33, 513719) His second question is whether we should make it a rule that Rs. 4 out of Rs. 15 should be sent direct to some poor person every

('68', 274, 0, 1, 513915) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 275
('68', 274, 1, 2, 513961) It is not up to me to make such a rule.
('68', 274, 1, 3, 514001) Nor is it necessary.
('68', 274, 1, 4, 514022) Even after giving away that amount it cannot be said oneness would have been established between us.
('68', 274, 1, 5, 514123) An external act is no proof of the inner reality.
('68', 274, 1, 6, 514173) If any such rule were to be enforced by the State, people would seek to evade it.
('68', 274, 2, 7, 514255) Q. So long as we do not put an end to economic exploitation of our rural masses and bring them concrete financial gain, they will continue to be indifferent towards us.
('68', 274, 2, 8, 514424) How can we help them?
('68', 274, 3, 9, 514446) A. We face all these difficulties not because the village people do not understand us, but because we are not able to understand them.

('68', 274, 3, 13, 514673) It is not even a year since it started.
('68', 274, 3, 14, 514713) We do not have enough experience to serve the people.

('68', 274, 3, 18, 514960) I also know from experience that we have not yet thought about the reasons why we have not been able to inspire confidence among the villagers.
('68', 274, 3, 19, 515104) We must discover these reasons.
('68', 274, 3, 20, 515136) We are working and spending money in the hope that the villagers will accept what we say.
('68', 274, 3, 21, 515226) When we understand these people they, too, will cling to us.
('68', 274, 3, 22, 515287) Till then, let us scavenge for them, distribute some medicines and teach them the laws of sanitation.
('68', 274, 3, 23, 515389) Let us not go there as physicians.
('68', 274, 3, 24, 515424) Let us be satisfied with giving the medicines which they accept.
('68', 274, 3, 25, 515489) Let us not expect any further rewards.
('68', 274, 3, 26, 515528) Let us not be worried whether or not we give financial help, whether or not they are indifferent.
('68', 274, 3, 27, 515626) I have repeatedly told the village workers that they should not feel disappointed.
('68', 274, 3, 28, 515709) Have they not turned themselves into sweepers?
('68', 274, 3, 29, 515756) And a sweeper is satisfied even with the left overs.
('68', 274, 3, 30, 515809) Let us also go to them with such an attitude.
('68', 274, 3, 31, 515855) If they abuse us, let us bear it in silence.
('68', 274, 3, 32, 515900) If they beat us, let us bear that also.
('68', 274, 3, 33, 515940) It is not that they are not coming forward because their economic conditions are not good.
('68', 274, 3, 34, 516031) They would not come even if you offered them money.
('68', 274, 3, 35, 516083) They would take the money and also expect us to do the scavenging for them.
('68', 274, 3, 36, 516159) That is all.
('68', 274, 3, 37, 516172) Let us work so that the sick are given medicines.
('68', 274, 3, 38, 516222) Let the people defecate wherever they choose.
('68', 274, 3, 39, 516268) Let us not even ask them to avoid a particular place or go elsewhere.
('68', 274, 3, 40, 516338) But let us go on cleaning up without a word.
('68', 274, 3, 41, 516383) That is non violence.
('68', 274, 3, 42, 516405) Protecting their health, showing them the way and going on cleaning up is the only path we have to follow.
('68', 274, 4, 43, 516512) 1 Gandhiji then replied to the questions asked by Swami Anand.
('68', 275, 0, 1, 516575) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 276
('68', 275, 1, 2, 516617) Some day they are bound to understand.
('68', 275, 1, 3, 516656) If this does not work, then there is no such thing as non violence.
('68', 275, 2, 4, 516724) Q. Is it or is it not necessary to do something more than this?
('68', 275, 3, 5, 516788) A. We may if we can.
('68', 275, 3, 6, 516809) But it is not necessary to connect the two.
('68', 275, 3, 7, 516853) They are two independent services.

('68', 275, 3, 9, 517006) And let us not worry if we can do nothing more.
('68', 275, 4, 10, 517054) Q. Can a village worker, with a view to making consumer articles available to the villagers at low prices, run a shop and sell betel leaves, bidis, tobacco, fish, tea, etc.?
('68', 275, 5, 11, 517228) A. We can resort to every means to put an extra pice into the villagers' pockets.
('68', 275, 5, 12, 517310) But whether or not a village worker can open a shop depends on his own capacity and resourcefulness.
('68', 275, 5, 13, 517411) I cannot lay down any hard and fast rule as to the articles a village worker may have in his shop.
('68', 275, 5, 14, 517510) Let each worker fix a limit for himself in accordance with his own ability.
('68', 275, 5, 15, 517586) He will have to compete with the village shopkeepers and also consider the habits of the villagers.
('68', 275, 5, 16, 517686) If I go to the villages and find that the people cannot do without tobacco and bidis, I would sell these, too, even though I consider tobacco worse than alcohol.
