('68', 282, 3, 31, 535854) The perfect marriage is founded on brahmacharya.
('68', 282, 3, 32, 535903) When can a marriage be called perfect?
('68', 282, 3, 33, 535942) In a perfect marriage a couple may have children when they are necessary and cohabit only when they need a child.
('68', 282, 3, 34, 536056) That is to say, procreation ought to be looked upon as a duty and sexual union resorted to for that purpose only.
('68', 282, 3, 35, 536170) Apart from this they should never engage in the sex act.
('68', 282, 3, 36, 536227) Nor should they allow themselves privacy.
('68', 282, 3, 37, 536269) If a man controls his semen, except on the occasion of such purposeful cohabitation, he is
('68', 283, 0, 1, 536360) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 284
('68', 283, 1, 2, 536402) as good as an avowed brahmachari.
('68', 283, 1, 3, 536436) Just imagine, how many occasions for such cohabitation can there be in a lifetime?
('68', 283, 1, 4, 536519) In the life of a healthy and virile man or woman, there may be only one such occasion.
('68', 283, 1, 5, 536606) Why should such persons not be looked upon as avowed brahmacharis?
('68', 283, 1, 6, 536673) This truth, of which I had only a glimpse earlier, is now as clear as daylight.
('68', 283, 1, 7, 536753) Those who are married should think of it.
('68', 283, 1, 8, 536795) I had mentioned this subject earlier also; but I had not so much faith then.
('68', 283, 1, 9, 536872) I used to think that it was impracticable.
('68', 283, 1, 10, 536915) Today I think it is practicable.
('68', 283, 1, 11, 536948) It might be different in the animal world.
('68', 283, 1, 12, 536991) But it must be a rule in the married life of man, that no couple should procreate without the need for a child nor should they cohabit without the object of procreation.
('68', 283, 2, 13, 537161) [From Hindi]
('68', 283, 3, 14, 537174) Gandhi Seva Sanghke Dwitiya Adhiveshan (Savli) Ka Vivaran, pp.
('68', 283, 4, 15, 537237) 339. A CONTRAST
('68', 283, 5, 16, 537253) Savli is a little village in the District of Chanda, C.P. It has a large Harijan population, and Harijans are for the most part devoted to khadi production under the aegis of the Maharashtra Charkha Sangh.
('68', 283, 5, 17, 537459) Member of the Gandhi Seva Sangh and some other workers met there between 29th February and 6th March.
('68', 283, 5, 18, 537561) In the Hindi notices sent to the invitees, among the things they were to bring were lantern, writing material, postcards, envelopes, postage stamps and soap.
('68', 283, 5, 19, 537719) The notices mentioned that it was difficult to procure any milk in Savli and cow's milk was practically unprocurable.
('68', 283, 5, 20, 537837) Those who would take no ghee other than cow's ghee were advised to bring their own supply.
('68', 283, 5, 21, 537928) On reaching Savli, it was further discovered that for the 300 men and women gathered there, milk had to be brought all the way from Chanda, a distance of 34 miles, and fresh vegetables from Nagpur, a distance of over 120 miles.
('68', 283, 5, 22, 538156) Savli is a typical village.
('68', 283, 5, 23, 538184) The difficulties mentioned above are to be met with in most of the villages of this land.
('68', 283, 5, 24, 538274) India worships the cow, and cow's milk is unprocurable in the majority of our villages!
('68', 283, 5, 25, 538362) She has a climate fit enough everywhere for vegetable growth, and fresh vegetables are not to be found in many of her villages!
('68', 283, 5, 26, 538490) It is no wonder that writing material and stationery are scarce in the thousands of our impoverished villages.
('68', 283, 5, 27, 538601) The villagers are
('68', 284, 0, 1, 538619) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 285
('68', 284, 1, 2, 538665) mostly illiterate and those who can write have not money enough to invest in writing material or stamps.
('68', 284, 1, 3, 538770) It is profitless to find out whether the villages of India were always what they are today.
('68', 284, 1, 4, 538862) If they were never better it is a reflection upon the ancient culture in which we take so much pride.
('68', 284, 1, 5, 538964) But if they were never better, how is it that they have survived centuries of decay which we see going round us and of which Savli is but a type?
('68', 284, 1, 6, 539110) The task before every lover of the country is how to prevent this decay or, which is the same thing, how to reconstruct the villages of India so that it may be as easy for anyone to live in them as it is supposed to be in the cities.
('68', 284, 1, 7, 539344) Indeed, it is the task before every patriot.
('68', 284, 1, 8, 539389) It may be that the villages are beyond redemption, that rural civilization has had its day and that the seven hundred thousand villages have to give place to seven hundred well ordered cities supporting a population not of three hundred millions but thirty.
('68', 284, 1, 9, 539647) If such is to be India’s fate, even that won't come in a day.
('68', 284, 1, 10, 539709) It must take time to wipe out a large number of villages and villagers and transform the remainder into cities and citizens.
('68', 284, 1, 11, 539834) However, those who believe in the possibility of village reconstruction have to follow out their programme logically and truthfully and not be satisfied with any make believe.
('68', 284, 1, 12, 540010) For them Savli is an eye opener.
('68', 284, 1, 13, 540043) Any village ought to be able easily to accommodate a party of 300 men and women with perfect comfort and give them fresh open air, fragrant grass and good rich milk from healthy cows and fresh vegetables and fruit in addition.
('68', 284, 1, 14, 540270) Surely there is something radically wrong if many of these things have to be brought from cities.
('68', 284, 1, 15, 540368) There is no trick of magic that can bring about this change overnight.
('68', 284, 1, 16, 540439) But with patience and perseverance, the programme of reconstruction can be carried out without much difficulty.
('68', 284, 1, 17, 540551) But nothing can be done if ardent workers do not settle down in villages with the fixed determination of reconstructing their villages in the right manner.
('68', 284, 2, 18, 540707) Harijan, 7 3 1936
('68', 285, 0, 1, 540725) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286

('68', 291, 6, 26, 551439) 353. A LETTER
('68', 291, 7, 27, 551453) March 11, 1936
('68', 291, 8, 28, 551468) RANCHHODLAL, Ever since I left Ahmedabad I have been intending to write to you but could not, as it was left out or forgotten at the time of writing the few letters that I am permitted.
('68', 291, 8, 29, 551654) Today, however, early in the morning I made a note of doing this.
('68', 291, 8, 30, 551720) The reason for the letter is the pain caused to Bhai Mavalankar, who had put his entire trust in you and held you in great respect.
('68', 291, 8, 31, 551852) Now, that confidence being no longer there, he writes to Sardar that you have yourself given him cause to
('68', 292, 0, 1, 551958) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 293
('68', 292, 1, 2, 552004) lose his faith in you, as you neither consulted him nor so much as informed him of your going to Bombay.
('68', 292, 1, 3, 552109) He feels aggrieved in the matter, has even begun doubting the purity of your motives, and repents that he put so much trust in you.
('68', 292, 1, 4, 552241) You should explain to me all that has happened, as Mavalankar writes that he helped you in the nick of time trustfully though several friends had warned him against you.
('68', 292, 1, 5, 552411) You should remove the doubts in Mavalankar's mind and see that you do not lose such an open hearted and disinterested friend as he.
('68', 292, 1, 6, 552543) You should not lose the faith your creditors put in you.
('68', 292, 1, 7, 552600) No matter if you have to turn a penniless beggar, you ought not to lose your credit for truthfulness.
('68', 292, 1, 8, 552702) I shall be waiting for your reply by return of post.

('68', 295, 5, 10, 557210) 360. BIRTH CONTROL [−I ]
('68', 295, 6, 11, 557235) A co worker 1 who is a careful reader of my writings was disturbed to read that I was likely to approve of the 'safe period' method of birth control.
('68', 295, 6, 12, 557385) I endeavoured to make it clear to the friend that the safe period method did not repel me as did the use of contraceptives and that it was open largely only to married couples.
('68', 295, 6, 13, 557562) But the discussion of the topic led us into much deeper waters than either of us had expected.
('68', 295, 6, 14, 557657) The fact that my friend was repelled by the safe period method as much as by that of contraceptives showed to me that he believed in the possibility of ordinary persons practising the restraint imposed by the smritis, i.e., that the union between husband and wife was permitted only when the parties really desired to have children.
('68', 295, 6, 15, 557990) Whilst I knew the rule I had never regarded it in the light that I began to do at the discussion.
('68', 295, 6, 16, 558088) All these long years I had regarded it as a counsel of perfection not to be carried out literally and that so long as married couples carried on intercourse by mutual consent but without special regard to the desire for progeny, they were carrying out the purpose of marriage without breaking any positive injunction of the smriti.
('68', 295, 6, 17, 558420) But the new light in which I viewed the smriti text was a revelation to me.
('68', 295, 6, 18, 558496) I understood now as I never had done before the statement that married people, who strictly observed the
('68', 295, 7, 19, 558601) 1 Vinoba Bhave
('68', 296, 0, 1, 558616) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 297
('68', 296, 1, 2, 558662) injunction of the smritis, were as much brahmacharis as those who were never married and lived chaste lives.
('68', 296, 1, 3, 558771) The sole object of sexual intercourse according to the new light was the desire for progeny, never gratification of the sexual instinct.
('68', 296, 1, 4, 558908) Simple gratification of the instinct would be counted according to this view of marriage as lust.
('68', 296, 1, 5, 559006) This may appear to be a harsh expression to use for our enjoyment which has hitherto been regarded as innocent and legitimate.
('68', 296, 1, 6, 559133) But I am not dealing with custom.
('68', 296, 1, 7, 559167) I am dealing with the science of marriage as propounded by Hindu sages.
('68', 296, 1, 8, 559239) Their presentation may be faulty, it may be altogether wrong.
('68', 296, 1, 9, 559301) But for one like me who believes in several smriti texts as inspired and based on experience, there is no escape from a full acceptance of their meaning.
('68', 296, 1, 10, 559455) I know no other way of finding the truth of things and testing certain old texts in accordance with their full meaning no matter how hard the test may appear and how harsh its deductions may sound.
('68', 296, 1, 11, 559653) In the light of what I have said above, birth controls by contraceptives and the like is a profound error.
('68', 296, 1, 12, 559760) I write thus with a full sense of my responsibility.
('68', 296, 1, 13, 559813) I have great regard for Mrs. Margaret Sanger and her followers.
('68', 296, 1, 14, 559877) She impressed me much by her great zeal for her cause.
('68', 296, 1, 15, 559932) 1 I know that she has great sympathy for the women who suffer because they have to bear the burden of carrying and rearing unwanted children.
('68', 296, 1, 16, 560074) I know also that this method of birth control has the support of many Protestant divines, scientists, learned men and doctors, many of whom I have the hounour of knowing personally and for whom I entertain high regard.
('68', 296, 1, 17, 560293) But I should be false to my God who is Truth and nothing but Truth, if I concealed my belief from the reader or these great advocates of the method.
('68', 296, 1, 18, 560442) Indeed, if I hid my belief, I should never discover my error if my present belief is one.
('68', 296, 1, 19, 560532) Moreover, its declaration is due to those many men and women who accept my guidance and advice in many moral problems including this one concerning birth control.
('68', 296, 1, 20, 560695) That birth requires to be regulated and controlled is common cause between the advocates of contraceptives and the like.
('68', 296, 1, 21, 560816) The difficulty of control through self restraint is not to be denied.
('68', 296, 1, 22, 560886) Yet there is no other way of attaining the end, if mankind is to fulfil its destiny.
('68', 296, 1, 23, 560971) It is my innermost conviction that if the method under discussion gains universal acceptance, mankind will suffer moral
('68', 296, 2, 24, 561091) 1 Vide “Interview to Margaret Sanger”, 3/4 12 1935.
('68', 297, 0, 1, 561143) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 298
('68', 297, 1, 2, 561185) deterioration.
('68', 297, 1, 3, 561200) This I say in spite of the evidence to the contrary that is often produced by the advocates of the method.
('68', 297, 1, 4, 561307) I believe I have no superstition in me.
('68', 297, 1, 5, 561347) Truth is not truth merely because it is ancient.
('68', 297, 1, 6, 561396) Nor is it necessarily to be regarded with suspicion because it is ancient.
('68', 297, 1, 7, 561471) There are some fundamentals of life which cay not be lightly given up because they are difficult of enforcement in one's life.
('68', 297, 1, 8, 561598) Birth control through self control is no doubt difficult.
('68', 297, 1, 9, 561656) But no one has yet been known seriously to dispute its efficacy and even superiority over the use of contraceptives.
('68', 297, 1, 10, 561773) Then, I feel that full of acceptance of the implication of the injuction of the Shastras as to the strictly confined use of the sexual act makes the observance of self control much easier than if one regards the act itself as a source of supreme enjoyment.
('68', 297, 1, 11, 562030) The function of the organs of generation is merely to generate progeny obviously of the highest type possible for a married couple.
('68', 297, 1, 12, 562162) This can and should only take place when both parties desire, not sexual union but progeny which is the result of such union.
('68', 297, 1, 13, 562288) Desire for such union, therefore, without the desire for progeny, must be considered unlawful and should be restrained.
('68', 297, 1, 14, 562408) The possibility of such control for the ordinary man will be examined in the next issue.
('68', 297, 2, 15, 562497) Harijan, 14 3 1936

('68', 299, 3, 4, 564353) MANILAL,
('68', 299, 4, 5, 564362) After I had written the letters today, I remembered your inquiry regarding the diet for diabetes.
('68', 299, 4, 6, 564460) There should be no starch and no sugar in the diet; so one ought not to take bananas, potatoes, rice, wheat, jaggery, sugar, etc.
('68', 299, 4, 7, 564590) One may take a little of porridge made of broken wheat—such as remains after the flour is sifted out.
('68', 299, 4, 8, 564692) Salt may be added to the porridge.
('68', 299, 4, 9, 564727) Or, one may grind the sifted wheat pieces into flour and make chapates out of it.
('68', 299, 4, 10, 564809) One may take milk, curds, leafy vegetables, green peas, gourd, and sour fruits but no sweet fruits.
('68', 299, 4, 11, 564909) The main food should be milk and vegetables, and this should restore one's health fully.

('68', 302, 4, 16, 569458) 369. LETTER TO KHUSHALCHAND GANDHI 2
('68', 302, 5, 17, 569495) March 16, 1936
('68', 302, 6, 18, 569510) MURABBI BHAI,
('68', 302, 7, 19, 569524) I had decided in the presence of Kashi 3 to write to you regarding Chi.

('68', 312, 1, 8, 584797) Let someone else be Chairman of the Reception Committee.

('68', 312, 4, 13, 585022) 387. BIRTH CONTROL−II
('68', 312, 5, 14, 585044) There is nothing in our society today which would conduce to self control.
('68', 312, 5, 15, 585119) Our very upbringing is against it.
('68', 312, 5, 16, 585154) The primary concern of parents is to marry their children anyhow so that they may breed like rabbits.
('68', 312, 5, 17, 585256) If they are girls, they are married at as early an age as they conveniently can be, irrespective of their moral welfare.
('68', 312, 5, 18, 585377) The marriage ceremony is one longdrawn out agony of feasting and frivolity.
('68', 312, 5, 19, 585453) The householder’s life is in keeping with the past life.
('68', 312, 5, 20, 585510) It is a prolongation of self indulgence.
('68', 312, 5, 21, 585551) Holidays and social enjoyments are so arranged as to allow one the greatest latitude for sensuous living.
('68', 312, 5, 22, 585657) The literature that is almost thrust on one generally panders to the animal passion.
('68', 312, 5, 23, 585742) The most modern literatuee almost teaches that indulgence in it is a duty and total abstinence a sin.
('68', 312, 5, 24, 585844) Is it any wonder if control of the sexual appetite has become difficult if not almost impossible?
('68', 312, 5, 25, 585942) If then birth control through self restraint is the most desirable and sensible and totally harmless method, we must change the soical ideal and environment.
('68', 312, 5, 26, 586100) The only way to bring about the desired end is for individuals who believe in the method of self control to make the beginning themselves and with unqunenchable faith to affect their surroundings.
('68', 312, 5, 27, 586297) For them the conception of marriage I discussed 1 last week has, it seems to me, the greatest significance.
('68', 312, 5, 28, 586405) A proper grasp of it means a complete mental revolution.
('68', 312, 5, 29, 586462) It is not meant merely for a few select individuals.
('68', 312, 5, 30, 586515) It is presented as the law of the human species.
('68', 312, 5, 31, 586564) Its breach reduces the status of human beings and brings swift punishment in the shape of multiplicity of unwanted children, a train of ever increasing diseases
('68', 312, 6, 32, 586725) 1 Vide “Birth Control [ I], 14 3 1936.
('68', 313, 0, 1, 586764) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 314
('68', 313, 1, 2, 586806) and disruption of man as a moral being responsbile to his Maker.
('68', 313, 1, 3, 586871) Birth control by contraceptives no doubt regulates to a certain extent the number of newcomers and enables persons of moderate means to keep the wolf from the door.
('68', 313, 1, 4, 587036) But the moral harm it does to the individual and society is incalculable.
('68', 313, 1, 5, 587110) For one thing, the outlook upon life for those who satisfy the sexual appetite for the sake of it is wholly changed.
('68', 313, 1, 6, 587227) Marriage ceases to be a sacrament for them.
('68', 313, 1, 7, 587271) It means a revaluation of the social ideals hitherto prized as a precious treasure.
('68', 313, 1, 8, 587355) No doubt this argument will make little appeal to those who regard the old ideals about marriage as a superstition.
('68', 313, 1, 9, 587471) My argument is only addressed to thsoe who regard marriage as a sacrament and woman not as an instrument of animal pleasure but as mother of man and trustee of the virtue of her progeny.
('68', 313, 1, 10, 587658) My experience of self control by fellow workers and myself confirms me in the view presented here.
('68', 313, 1, 11, 587757) It assumes overwhelming force from the discovery in a vivid light of the ancient conception of marriage.
('68', 313, 1, 12, 587862) For me brahmacharya in married life now assumes its natural and inevitable position and becomes as simple as the fact of marriage itslef.
('68', 313, 1, 13, 588000) Any other method of birth control seems useless and unthinkable.
('68', 313, 1, 14, 588065) Once the idea that the only and grand function of the sexual organ is generation possesses man and woman, union for any other purpose they will hold as criminal waste of the vital fluid and consequent excitement caused to man and woman as an equally criminal waste of precious energy.
('68', 313, 1, 15, 588350) It is now easy to understand why the scientists of old have put such great value upon the vital fluid and why they have insisted upon it strong transmutation into the highest form of energy for the benefit of society.
('68', 313, 1, 16, 588568) They boldly declare that one who has acquired a perfect control over his or her sexual energy strengthens the whole being, physical, mental and spiritual, and attains powers unattainable by any other means.
('68', 313, 1, 17, 588775) Let not the reader be disturbed by the absence of many or even any living specimen of such giant brahmacharis .
('68', 313, 1, 18, 588887) The brahmacharis we see about us today are very incomplete specimens.
('68', 313, 1, 19, 588957) At best they are aspirants who have acquired control over their bodies but not their minds.
('68', 313, 1, 20, 589049) They have not become proof against temptation.
('68', 313, 1, 21, 589096) This is not because brahmacharya is so difficult of attainment.
('68', 313, 1, 22, 589160) Social environ ment is against them, and the majority of those who are making an honest effort unknowingly isolate the control of the animal passion from all other passions, whereas the effort to be successful must include control over all the passions to which man is prey.
('68', 314, 0, 1, 589435) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 315
('68', 314, 1, 2, 589481) brahmacharya is not impossible of attainment by the average man and woman.
('68', 314, 1, 3, 589556) it must not be supposed that it requires less effort than that required by an average student who has set his heart upon becoming a master of any one of the sciences.
('68', 314, 1, 4, 589723) Attainment of brahmacharya in the sense here meant means mastery of the Science of Life.
('68', 314, 2, 5, 589812) Harijan, 21 3 1936
('68', 314, 3, 6, 589831) 388. LIMITATION OF REFORMERS
('68', 314, 4, 7, 589860) Ever since Dr. Ambedkar has thrown his bomb shell in the midst of Hindu society in the shape of threatened conversion, frantic efforts have been made to wean him from the proposed step.
('68', 314, 4, 8, 590046) Dr. Ambedkar’s threat has had its repercussions on Harijans, too, who are at all literate and are able to read newspapers.
('68', 314, 4, 9, 590169) They have begun to approach Hindu institutions or reformers with a demand for posts, scholarships or the like, accompanying it with the statement that the writer might, in the event of refusal, be obliged to change to another faith, aid having been offered on behalf of the representatives of that faith.
('68', 314, 4, 10, 590474) Without a doubt these threats are a portent and a matter of grave concern to those who care at all for the religion of their forefathers.
('68', 314, 4, 11, 590612) But it will not be served by coming to terms with those who have lost faith in Hinduism or for that matter in any religion.
('68', 314, 4, 12, 590736) Religion is not a matter of barter.
('68', 314, 4, 13, 590772) It is a matter for every individual to decide for himself to which faith he will belong.
('68', 314, 4, 14, 590861) It does not lend itself to purchase in any shape or form.
('68', 314, 4, 15, 590919) Or if such an expression can be used in connection with things of the spirit, religion can only be purchased with one’s own blood.
('68', 314, 4, 16, 591050) If therefore any Harijan wants to give up Hinduism, he should be entirely free to do so.
('68', 314, 4, 17, 591139) There must be a searching of heart for the reformer.
('68', 314, 4, 18, 591192) Has his practice or that of his neighbours caused the defection?
('68', 314, 4, 19, 591257) If it has and if it is found to be improper, it must be changed.
('68', 314, 4, 20, 591322) It is an admitted fact that the conduct of a vast number of Hindus who call themselves sanatanists is such as to cause the greatest inconvenience and irritation to the Harijans all over India.
('68', 314, 4, 21, 591515) The wonder is that many more Harijans than already have, have not left Hinduism.
('68', 314, 4, 22, 591596) It speaks volumes for their loyalty or for the innate virtue of Hinduism that millions of Harijans have clung to it in spite of the
('68', 315, 0, 1, 591728) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 316
('68', 315, 1, 2, 591770) inhumanities to which in the name of that very faith they have been subjectd.
('68', 315, 1, 3, 591848) This wonderful loyalty of Harijans and their unexampled patience render it imperative for every savarna Hindu to see that Harijans receive the same treatment that every other Hindu does.
('68', 315, 1, 4, 592035) The course before savarnas is, therefore, on the one hand not to interfere with Harijans wishing to leave the Hindu fold by trying to keep them within it by the offer of bribes in the shape of finding employment or scholarships and, on the other hand, to insist on full justice being done to Harijans in every walk of life.
('68', 315, 1, 5, 592359) Indeed reformers should anticipate the Harijans’requirements and not wait till they begin to complain.
('68', 315, 1, 6, 592462) The Harijan Sevak Sangh is the biggest institution for the removal of untouchability.
('68', 315, 1, 7, 592548) It has wisely adpoted a most liberal policy of giving scholarships to deserving students.
('68', 315, 1, 8, 592638) It employs as many Harijans as possible.
('68', 315, 1, 9, 592679) But it is in no sense a bureau for finding jobs for unemployed Harijans.
('68', 315, 1, 10, 592752) Generally speaking, there, is no dearth of jobs for Harijans who are fit for the jobs for which they offer themselves.
('68', 315, 1, 11, 592871) The greatest hardship felt by thousands of Harijans is want of pure water for drinking and domestic use, denial of access to public schools and other institutions, constant pinpricks in villages and, last but not least, denial of access to temples of worship.
('68', 315, 1, 12, 593131) These disabilities are stern realities in the lives of the vast mass of Harijans.
('68', 315, 1, 13, 593213) If they as a mass give up Hinduism, they will do so becasue of these common disabilities which brand them as lepers of Hindu society.
('68', 315, 1, 14, 593347) Hinduism is passing through a fiery ordeal.
('68', 315, 1, 15, 593391) It will perish not through individual conversions, not even through mass conversions, but it will perish because of the sinful denial by the so called savarna Hindus of elementary justice to Harijans.
('68', 315, 1, 16, 593592) Every threat of conversion is, therefore, a warning to the savarnas that if they do not wake up in time, it may be too late !
('68', 315, 1, 17, 593718) One word to the impatient and needy Harijans.
('68', 315, 1, 18, 593764) They must not use threats when they approach Hindu institutions or indviduals for help.
('68', 315, 1, 19, 593852) They should rely upon the strength of their case commanding a hearing.
('68', 315, 1, 20, 593923) The majority of Harijans do not know what change of religion can mean.
('68', 315, 1, 21, 593994) They mutely suffer the continuing degradation to which savarnas in their selfishness have consigned them.
('68', 315, 1, 22, 594100) They must be the primary care of Hindu reformers whether they complain or do not.
('68', 315, 1, 23, 594182) Those who are enlightened enough to know and feel the degradation and know also what change of religion means, are either
('68', 316, 0, 1, 594304) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 317
('68', 316, 1, 2, 594350) too good Hindus to desert their ancestral faith and deserve every help they need, or being indifferent as to religion may not claim help from savarna Hindus in exhange for their condescending to remain in the Hindu fold.
('68', 316, 1, 3, 594571) I would, therefore, plead with enlightened Harijans for their own sakes not to seek material betterment under threat of conversion.
('68', 316, 1, 4, 594703) And whilst reformers must on no account yield to threats, they must ceaselessly strive to secure justice for Harijans at the hands of savarna Hindus.
('68', 316, 2, 5, 594853) Harijan, 21 3 1936

('68', 324, 1, 2, 608214) 400. DISCUSSION WITH HARIJAN SEVAKS 1
('68', 324, 2, 3, 608252) [March 27, 1936] 2
('68', 324, 3, 4, 608271) HARIJAN SEVAKS 3: We received our inspiration from Swami Shraddhanandji.
('68', 324, 4, 5, 608344) GANDHIJI: Not only you, but many of us received inspiration from the noble life of the late Swamiji.
('68', 324, 5, 6, 608445) Why don’t you take some steps to counteract the vicious propaganda of the
('68', 324, 6, 7, 608519) missionaries?
('68', 324, 6, 8, 608533) Why not have Hindu missionaries for counter propaganda?
('68', 324, 6, 9, 608589) 4 Of course,
('68', 324, 7, 10, 608602) Mahatmaji, you are there enough to cover the whole field.
('68', 324, 7, 11, 608660) But pracharaks are needed.
('68', 324, 7, 12, 608687) Let me explain to you.
('68', 324, 7, 13, 608710) The Sangh was not created for that purpose.
('68', 324, 7, 14, 608754) Our object was to end the disabilities of Harijans and to put them on the same social level as the rest of the Hindus.
('68', 324, 7, 15, 608873) As for propaganda that you have in mind, the best propaganda is that of personal example.
('68', 324, 7, 16, 608963) Let every Harijan sevak lead a model life of purity and simplicity, clothe the Harijans with love and, I am quite sure, no counter propaganda will be necessary.
('68', 324, 8, 17, 609124) But there are places where the missionaries rush to the scene, do nothing but provide a few amenities like a water pipe or a good road and make the recipients declare that they are Christians.
('68', 324, 8, 18, 609317) The poor recipients often do so, but beyond the declaration they do nothing.
('68', 324, 8, 19, 609394) They share in the life of their Harijan brethren, celebrate the same Hindu festivals, and remian Hindus in every respect, except perhaps for census purposes.
('68', 324, 8, 20, 609552) They will remain Harijans and even the missions will not set much store by them.
('68', 324, 8, 21, 609633) Our duty is to work hard amongst the orthodox Hindus and to get them to admit the Harijans in their fold as their kith and kin and to end the disabilities they suffer from.
('68', 324, 9, 22, 609806) But how are we to persuade the orthodox?
('68', 324, 9, 23, 609847) May we storm their fortresses?
('68', 324, 9, 24, 609878) There are local board wells, for instance, which have been thrown open to the Harijans but the orthodox people will not allow them to use them.
('68', 324, 9, 25, 610022) May we advise the Harijans to defy the opposition and challenge them to do their worst?
('68', 324, 9, 26, 610110) You might, where you are fearless and where you are sure that
('68', 324, 10, 27, 610172) 1 The workers, including some Harijans, met Gandhiji “on the last day” of his stay in Delhi i.e., March 27 2 ibid 3 Those who belonged to the Arya Samaj 4 Propaganda workers
('68', 325, 0, 1, 610346) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('68', 325, 1, 2, 610388) there will be no clash and that the Harijans will not be cowed down.
('68', 325, 1, 3, 610457) But the opposition is melting away gradually everywhere and I trust no storming will be necessary.
('68', 325, 2, 4, 610556) When untouchability is no more, Mahatmaji, what varna will you assign to us?
('68', 325, 2, 5, 610633) Who am I to assign a varna to you?
('68', 325, 2, 6, 610668) But if I had the power, I should declare that we are Hindus, all of the same varna.
('68', 325, 2, 7, 610752) As I have made it clear over and over again there is no real varna today.
('68', 325, 2, 8, 610826) When we have come to our own, when we have cleansed ourselves, we may have the four varnas according to the way in which we can express the best in us.
('68', 325, 2, 9, 610978) But varna then will invest no one with a superior status or right, it will invest one with higher responsibility and duties.
('68', 325, 2, 10, 611103) Those who will impart knowledge in a spirit of service will be called Brahmins.
('68', 325, 2, 11, 611183) They will assume no superior airs but will be true servents of society.
('68', 325, 2, 12, 611255) When ineqaulity of status or rights is ended, every one of us will be equal.
('68', 325, 2, 13, 611332) I do not know, however, when we sahll be able to revive true varnadharma.
('68', 325, 2, 14, 611406) Its real revival would mean true democracy.
('68', 325, 3, 15, 611450) What we want today is not that the caste Hindus eat with us or have marital ties with us.
('68', 325, 3, 16, 611540) We want rights of true citizenship, equal opportunities.
('68', 325, 3, 17, 611597) I want my son to have the liberty to be a vakil or a barrister or a doctor according to his own wish You know there is no legal bar against your son being anything he likes.
('68', 325, 3, 18, 611771) There is custom, hard prejudice and blind superstition.
('68', 325, 3, 19, 611827) That the Snagh is trying its best to fight.
('68', 325, 3, 20, 611871) Dr. Ambedkar is a barrister and now a professor.
('68', 325, 3, 21, 611920) But blind orthodoxy will not treat him as equal with the savarnas.
('68', 325, 3, 22, 611987) You cannot force them by legal enactment.
('68', 325, 3, 23, 612029) You can do it by education, by converting the orthodox.
('68', 325, 3, 24, 612085) There was, for instance, a Harijan who used to sell bidis in Nasik.
('68', 325, 3, 25, 612153) So long as no one knew that he was a Harijan, he had very good custom.
('68', 325, 3, 26, 612224) The moment they came to know that he was Harijan, they stopped pruchasing bidis at his shop, How are we to compel people to purchase bidis at his shop, otherwise than by showing them that it is inhuman and irreligious of them to boycott anybody by reason of his birth?
('68', 325, 4, 27, 612493) But why should we be called Harijans and not Hindus?
('68', 325, 4, 28, 612546) I know that a small section of you resents the name.
('68', 325, 4, 29, 612599) But you may know the genesis of the name.
('68', 325, 4, 30, 612641) You used to be called ‘depressed classes’ or ‘asprishyas’ or ‘achhoots’ (untouchables).
('68', 325, 4, 31, 612729) All these names the vast mass of you naturally resented.
('68', 325, 4, 32, 612786) Some of you sent their protests to me and asked me to find out a better name.
('68', 325, 4, 33, 612864) In English I
('68', 326, 0, 1, 612877) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 327
('68', 326, 1, 2, 612923) had adopted a better word than ‘depressed’, viz., ‘suppressed’, but whilst I was casting about for a good Indian word a friend suggested the word ‘Harijan’ taken from the song of one of the best of our saints 1. It appealed to me because it best described your condition and still had no bad odour about it.
('68', 326, 1, 3, 613231) It means a devotee of God, and as God is the help of the helpless, and as it is the helpless who naturally turn to God, I thought you deserved the name better than I for instance.
('68', 326, 1, 4, 613411) For whilst I have to aspire to become a Harijan you are Harijans in the very nature of things.
('68', 326, 1, 5, 613506) But you will say, ‘When your objective is to make Harijans Hindus why don’t you start by calling them Hindus straightaway?’ What am I to do so long as I have not succeeded in abolishing untouchability?
('68', 326, 2, 6, 613708) But today, sir, it is an opprobrious term.
('68', 326, 2, 7, 613751) There is a Brahmin who threatens to hammer us if we call him a Harijan.
('68', 326, 2, 8, 613823) Then he is no Brahmin.
('68', 326, 2, 9, 613846) You know the word ‘Harijan’ occurs in Tulsidas’s Ramayana?
('68', 326, 2, 10, 613905) There Lakshmana describes to Parashurama the characteristic of a true Kshatriya.
('68', 326, 2, 11, 613986) He says:
('68', 326, 3, 12, 613995) (It is the trait of our clan never to use force towards a god, a Brahimin, a Harijan or a cow.) ‘Harijan’ there means a man of God, a devotee, no matter to what caste or varna he belongs.
('68', 326, 3, 13, 614183) We all have to treasure the beautiful connotation of the word and try to be worthy of the name.
('68', 326, 3, 14, 614279) One more question.
('68', 326, 3, 15, 614298) You call your Sangh “Harijan Sevak Sangh.” You are unnecessarily exploiting our name.
('68', 326, 3, 16, 614384) Fourteen annas in the rupee expended by the Harijan Sevak Sangh goes into the pockets of non Harijans, 2 annas barely goes into the pockets of the poor Harijans.
('68', 326, 3, 17, 614546) Now, now, there you are betraying gross ignorance.
('68', 326, 3, 18, 614597) I can prove to you the reverse of what you say.
('68', 326, 3, 19, 614645) Have you got any proof in support of your statement?
('68', 326, 3, 20, 614698) I make you a sporting offer.
('68', 326, 3, 21, 614727) If you can prove what you say, you can come to Wardha, at the Sangh’s expense, with all the evidence in your possession, and if you succeed in convincing me I shall declare myself beaten and do proper penance.
('68', 326, 3, 22, 614937) In case you fail, I will not ask you to pay back to me the train fare.
('68', 326, 3, 23, 615008) But I will expect you to publicly apologize for bringing a baseless charge against the Sangh.
('68', 326, 3, 24, 615102) The Sangh’s books are there open to inspection by anyone, and I tell you the books will convince you that
('68', 326, 4, 25, 615208) 1 Narasinha Mehta; vide “My Notes”, 6 8 1931.
('68', 327, 0, 1, 615254) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 328
('68', 327, 1, 2, 615296) the truth is the reverse of what you say.
('68', 327, 1, 3, 615338) There is one thing certainly that you can prove.
('68', 327, 1, 4, 615387) It is that there are a few sevaks who are paid even as much as a hundred rupees per month.
('68', 327, 1, 5, 615478) But where that is the case, through such a sevak we distribute thousands to Harijans.
('68', 327, 1, 6, 615564) Also he who is being paid a hundred rupees could easily earn in the market much more than what he receives.
('68', 327, 1, 7, 615672) I am ready to confess, too, that, there are some who have to be paid as much as their market value but if no volunteer workers are available, or if you cannot get the services of the present staff on better terms, what can be done?
('68', 327, 1, 8, 615904) I can, however, assure you that our administrative charges do not exceed 15 per cent, and the balance goes for the benefit of the Harijans.
('68', 327, 2, 9, 616044) Harijan, 4 4 1936
('68', 327, 3, 10, 616062) 401. TEMPLE ENTRY
('68', 327, 4, 11, 616080) The reader will recall the important resolution 2 on temple entry passed recently by the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('68', 327, 4, 12, 616190) No one need run away with the idea that because not much is nowadays heard of the questions it has been forgotten or given up by the Sangh.
('68', 327, 4, 13, 616330) Pandit Malaviyaji’s visit to Nasik and the vast audiences that gathered round him show that the people as a whole are not averse to the removal of untouchability, though it showed also that orthodoxy was not yet prepared to give up its untouchability.
('68', 327, 4, 14, 616582) But it is not possible to await developments.
('68', 327, 4, 15, 616628) The local Sanghs should make a sustained effort to have the existing temples thrown open and even to build new ones, not for Harijans only but for all.
('68', 327, 4, 16, 616780) If they are situated in healthy localities and have a school, a meeting place and a dharmashala attached to them, they must prove useful and popular among all classes of Hindus.
('68', 327, 4, 17, 616958) There may be public prayers held there every evening or at
('68', 327, 5, 18, 617017) 1 Harijans who were present at the meeting repudiated the suggestion and admitted that the bulk of the funds went into Harijans’ pockets.
('68', 327, 5, 19, 617155) 2 At the annual meeting held in Delhi from February 6 to 8. It read: “Since any further delay in securing temple entry for Harijans will result in great harm to Hindu dharma, and since such temple entry is part of the immediate justice to which the Harijans are entitled, the Central Board of the All India Harijan Sevak Sangh resolves that effective steps be taken immediately for achieving temple entry for Harijans and, with a view to achieving this purpose, the Executive Committee be asked to take necessary steps in consultation with Gandhiji”.
('68', 328, 0, 1, 617706) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 329
('68', 328, 1, 2, 617752) stated periods and religious discourses may be occasionally arranged.
('68', 328, 1, 3, 617822) If these temples are properly conducted, they would go a long way towards removing the prejudice against the opening of existing temples to Harijans.
('68', 328, 1, 4, 617972) Care must be taken, where temples are opened to Harijans, that no discrimination is made against them.
('68', 328, 1, 5, 618075) They must be opened on precisely the same terms as they are opened to the other Hindus.
('68', 328, 1, 6, 618163) It is hardly necessary to state that in different localities different methods may be adopted for securing the desired end.
('68', 328, 1, 7, 618287) Perfect non violence must of course be maintained in all cases.
('68', 328, 1, 8, 618351) An all India simultaneous movement of the same type is not contemplated.
('68', 328, 1, 9, 618424) It will vary in intensity and method according to the circumstances in each locality.
('68', 328, 1, 10, 618510) Nowhere should temples be opened where there is an active minority opposed to the opening.
('68', 328, 1, 11, 618601) Practical unanimity should be secured before any temple is opened.
('68', 328, 1, 12, 618668) Thus what is required is sustained effort to convert local public opinion in favour of temple entry.
('68', 328, 1, 13, 618769) The position in the Hindu States is somewhat different.
('68', 328, 1, 14, 618825) Where the Prince or his officials are favourably inclined, there should be no difficulty about opening them.
('68', 328, 1, 15, 618934) The question has assumed a great importance in Travancore.
('68', 328, 1, 16, 618993) In most other places Harijans are indiffernt about temple entry.
('68', 328, 1, 17, 619058) The position is otherwise in Travancore.
('68', 328, 1, 18, 619099) The vast majority of Harijans of that State are far more advanced then in other places.
('68', 328, 1, 19, 619187) They have many men belonging to the learned professions.
('68', 328, 1, 20, 619244) Many have passed through colleges.
('68', 328, 1, 21, 619279) They naturally chafe under any restriction of their liberty but most of all on the entry into temples.
('68', 328, 1, 22, 619382) One hears that the large body of savarnas there are wholly in favour of the removal of the bar.
('68', 328, 1, 23, 619478) Travancore has an enlightened Prince and an enlightened Maharani.
('68', 328, 1, 24, 619544) Surely the opposition of a few orthodox persons, however influential they may be in their own spheres, cannot be allowed to prevent a much needed reform which has become long overdue.
('68', 328, 1, 25, 619728) But Harijan sevaks should by an accurate referendum or some such means show beyond all doubt that a great majority of savarna Hindus are decidedly in favour of the opening of Travancore temples to Harijans precisely on the same terms as themselves.
('68', 328, 1, 26, 619977) The Maharaja may not march in advance of the public opinion of his State, but I can hardly imagine his flouting clearly expressed public opinion.
('68', 328, 2, 27, 620123) Harijan, 28 3 1936
('68', 329, 0, 1, 620142) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 330
('68', 329, 1, 2, 620184) 402. FOR THE YOUNG
('68', 329, 2, 3, 620203) It is the fashion in some quarters nowadays for the young to discredit whatever may be said by old people.
('68', 329, 2, 4, 620310) I am not prepared to say that there is absolutely no justification for this belief.
('68', 329, 2, 5, 620394) But I warn the youth of the country against always discounting whatever old men or women may say for the mere fact that it is said by such persons.
('68', 329, 2, 6, 620542) Even as wisdom often comes from the mouths of babes, so does it often come from the mouths of old people.
('68', 329, 2, 7, 620648) The golden rule is to test everything in the light of reason and experience, no matter from whom it comes.
('68', 329, 2, 8, 620755) I want to revert to the subject of birth control by contraceptives.
('68', 329, 2, 9, 620823) It is dinned into one’s ears that gratification of the sex urge is a solemn obigation like the obligation of discharging debts lawfully incurred, and that not to do so would involve the penalty of intellectual decay.
('68', 329, 2, 10, 621040) This sex urge has been isolated from the desire for progeny, and it is said by the protagonists of the use of contraceptives that conception is an accident to be prevented except when the parties desire to have children.
('68', 329, 2, 11, 621261) I venture to suggest that this is a most dangerous doctrine to preach anywhere; much more so in a country like India where the middle class male population has become imbecile through abuse of the creative function.
('68', 329, 2, 12, 621477) If satisfaction of the sex urge is a duty, the unnatural vice of which I wrote 1 some time ago and several other ways of gratification would be commendable.
('68', 329, 2, 13, 621634) The reader should know that even persons of note have been known to approve of what is commonly know as sexual perversion.
('68', 329, 2, 14, 621757) He may be shocked at the statement.
('68', 329, 2, 15, 621793) But if it somehow or other gains the stamp of respectability, it will be the rage among boys and girls to satisfy their urge among members of their own sex.
('68', 329, 2, 16, 621950) For me the use of contraceptives is not far removed from the means to which persons have hitherto resorted for the gratification of their sexual desire with results that very few know.
('68', 329, 2, 17, 622135) I know what havoc secret vice has played among schoolboys and schoolgirls.
('68', 329, 2, 18, 622210) The introuduction of contra ceptives under the name of science and imprimatur of known leaders society has intensified the complication and made the task of reformers who work for purity of social life well nigh impossible for the moment.
('68', 329, 2, 19, 622449) I betray no confidence when I inform the reader that
('68', 329, 3, 20, 622502) 1 Vide “Duty of Reformers”, 19 10 1935 and also “A Growing Vice?”, 27 4 1935.
('68', 330, 0, 1, 622580) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 331
('68', 330, 1, 2, 622626) there are unmarried girls of impressionable age studying in schools and colleges who study birth control literature and magazines with avidity and even possess contraceptives.
('68', 330, 1, 3, 622802) It is impossible to confine their use to married women.
('68', 330, 1, 4, 622858) Marriage loses its sanctity when its purpose and highest use is conceived to be the satisfaction of the animal passion without contemplating the natural result of such satisfaction.
('68', 330, 1, 5, 623040) I have no doubt that those learned men and women who are carrying no propaganda with missionary zeal in favour of the use of contraceptives are doing irreparable harm to the youth of the country under the false belief that they will be saving thereby the poor women who may be obliged to bear children against their will.
('68', 330, 1, 6, 623362) Those who need to limit their children will not be easily reached by them.
('68', 330, 1, 7, 623437) Our poor women have not the knowledge or the training that the women of the West have.
('68', 330, 1, 8, 623524) Surely the propaganda is not being carried on on behalf of the middle class women, for they do not need the knowledge, at any rate so much as the poor classes do.
('68', 330, 1, 9, 623687) The greatest harm, however, done by that propaganda lies in its rejection of the old ideal and substitution in its place of one which, if carried out, must spell the moral and physical extinction of the race.
('68', 330, 1, 10, 623896) The horror with which ancient literature has regarded the fruitless use of the vital fluid was not a superstition born of ignorance.
('68', 330, 1, 11, 624029) What shall we say of a husbandmanwho will sow the finest seed in his possession on stony ground or of the owner of a field who will receive in his field rich with fine soil good seed under conditions that will make it impossible for it to grow?
('68', 330, 1, 12, 624276) God has blessed man with seed that has the highest potency and woman with a field richer than the richest earth to be found anywhere on this globe.
('68', 330, 1, 13, 624424) Surely it is criminal folly for man to allow his most precious possession to run to waste.
('68', 330, 1, 14, 624515) He must guard it with a care greater than he will bestow upon the richest pearls in his possession.
('68', 330, 1, 15, 624615) And so is a woman guilty of criminal folly who will receive the seed in her life producing field with the deliberate intention of letting it run to waste.
('68', 330, 1, 16, 624770) Both he and she will be judged guilty of misuse of the telents given to them and they will be dispossessed of what they have been given.
('68', 330, 1, 17, 624907) Sex urge is a fine and noble thing.
('68', 330, 1, 18, 624943) There is nothing to be ashamed of in it.
('68', 330, 1, 19, 624984) But it is meant only for the act of creation.
('68', 330, 1, 20, 625030) Any other use of it is a sin against God and humanity.
('68', 330, 1, 21, 625085) Contraceptives of a kind there were before and there will be hereafter, but the use of them was formerly regarded as sinful.
('68', 330, 1, 22, 625210) It was reserved for our generation to glorify vice by calling it virtue.
('68', 331, 0, 1, 625283) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 332
('68', 331, 1, 2, 625325) The greatest disservice protagonists of contraceptives are rendering to the youth of India is to fill their minds with what appears to me to be wrong ideology.
('68', 331, 1, 3, 625485) Let the young men and women of India who hold her destiny in their hands beware of this false god and guard the treasure with which God has blessed them and use it, if they wish, for the only purpose for which it is intended.

('68', 331, 3, 5, 625730) 403. SPEECH AT KHADI AND VILLAGE INDUSTRIES EXHIBITION, LUCKNOW 1
('68', 331, 4, 6, 625796) March 28, 1936
('68', 331, 5, 7, 625811) I am glad and thankful to be able to come to Lucknow to open this khadi and other village industries exhibition.
('68', 331, 5, 8, 625924) I may tell you that I was eager to be here at the opening.
('68', 331, 5, 9, 625983) Though I know that Dr. Murarilal and Sjt.
('68', 331, 5, 10, 626025) Shankerlal Banker have devoted themselves heart and soul to organizing it, at the back of it all was my conception.
('68', 331, 5, 11, 626141) This exhibition, to my mind, brings out concretely for the first time the conception of a true rural exhibition I have nursed in my breast for several years.
('68', 331, 5, 12, 626299) In 1921 when we met in Ahmedabad in the first year of the new Congress Constitution, we took the first step towards rural mindedness, and the exhibition organized under the auspices of the Congress held there was the beginning of the process which you find reaching its maturity today after 15 years.
('68', 331, 5, 13, 626600) I have believed and repeated times without number that India is to be found not in its few cities but in its 7, 00, 000 villages.
('68', 331, 5, 14, 626730) But we who have gathered here are not villagers.
('68', 331, 5, 15, 626779) We are town dwellers.
('68', 331, 5, 16, 626801) We town dwellers have believed that India is to be found in its towns and that the villages were created to minister to our needs.
('68', 331, 5, 17, 626932) We have hardly ever paused to inquire of those poor folks get sufficient to eat and clothe themselves with and whether they have a roof to shelter themselves from sun and rain.
('68', 331, 5, 18, 627109) Now I do not think any Congress worker has travelled through the length and breadth of India as much as I have done during the past twenty years.
('68', 331, 5, 19, 627255) That in itself is hardly thing to be proud of.
('68', 331, 5, 20, 627302) I, however, humbly claim, as a result of those peregrinations, to know the Indian villages more than any other Congress worker or leader.
('68', 331, 5, 21, 627440) I have found that the town dweller has generally exploited the villager, in fact he has lived on the poor villager’s substance.
('68', 331, 5, 22, 627568) Many a British official has written about the
('68', 331, 6, 23, 627614) 1 This appeared under the title “A Unique Exhibition”.
('68', 332, 0, 1, 627669) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 333
('68', 332, 1, 2, 627715) conditions of the people of India.
('68', 332, 1, 3, 627750) No one has, to my knowledge, said that the Indian villager has enough to keep body and soul together.
('68', 332, 1, 4, 627852) On the contrary they have admitted that the bulk of the population live on the verge of starvation and ten per cent are semi starved, and that millions have to rest content with a pinch of dirty salt and chillies and polished rice or parched grain.
('68', 332, 1, 5, 628101) You may be sure that if any of us were to be asked to live on that diet, we should not expect of survive it longer than a month or should be afraid of losing our mental faculties.
('68', 332, 1, 6, 628281) And yet our villagers go through that state from day to day.
('68', 332, 1, 7, 628342) The Village Industries Association was formed last year 1 in order to study the conditions in which they lived and the state of their handicrafts, and to revive such village arts and crafts as may be revived.
('68', 332, 1, 8, 628551) Simultaneously with the creation of the A.I.V.I. Association was passed a resolution 2 to the effect that future exhibitions should be organized by the Spinners’ and the Village Industries Associations.
('68', 332, 1, 9, 628754) This exhibition I am about to declare open today is the first of that kind.
('68', 332, 1, 10, 628830) As I have told you the whole conception here is mine, and yet I must confess that we are still far from bringing out that conception fully.
('68', 332, 1, 11, 628970) It is an evidence of the organizers’ wonderful industry, and yet it is not perfect of its kind.
('68', 332, 1, 12, 629066) It was not humanly possible to achieve it during the time at their disposal.
('68', 332, 1, 13, 629143) It is no easy job to bring village artisans form their villages.
('68', 332, 1, 14, 629208) You will find here villagers from South India who perhaps don’t know where they have come to.
('68', 332, 1, 15, 629302) It is the purpose of this Exhibition to show that even this starving India of the villages is capable of producing things which we town dwellers may use both to the villagers’ and our advantage.
('68', 332, 1, 16, 629497) This exhibition is not a spectacular show like its predecessors.
('68', 332, 1, 17, 629562) Those earlier ones were bound to be big shows.
('68', 332, 1, 18, 629609) They were designed for a different purpose.
('68', 332, 1, 19, 629653) Congress expenses were generally found out of the takings of the exhibition.
('68', 332, 1, 20, 629730) The whole outlook was changed last year.
('68', 332, 1, 21, 629771) We decided not to have things of spectacular interest, but we decided to give the spectators a glimpse of the Indian villager and his craft.
('68', 332, 1, 22, 629912) This therefore is a vast educative effort.
('68', 332, 1, 23, 629955) Not that we will have no takings this time.
('68', 332, 1, 24, 629999) Only they will depened on those Congressmen who are intent on freedom and will win it by rehabilitating the village.
('68', 332, 1, 25, 630116) If they will establish a living bond between towns and villages, they will
('68', 332, 2, 26, 630191) 1 Vide “A.I.V.I.A—Object and Constitution”, 14 12 1934. 2 Vide “Letter to Jivanji D. Desai”.
('68', 333, 0, 1, 630284) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 334
('68', 333, 1, 2, 630326) flock to the exhibition and will make a point of studying the various demonstrations in the exhibition.
('68', 333, 1, 3, 630430) This cannot be done by one visit only.
('68', 333, 1, 4, 630469) You should visit it daily and carefully study every section.
('68', 333, 1, 5, 630530) If you will do this, you will marvel at the energy and industry expended in organizing it.
('68', 333, 1, 6, 630621) You will be deeply interested in it if you approach it in a spirit of service.
('68', 333, 1, 7, 630700) You will find here craftsmen and craftswomen for Kashmir and South India, form Sind and Assam, and learn how they earn their scanty living.
('68', 333, 1, 8, 630840) You will find that it is within your power to add a little to their income and to enable them to have square meal, if only you will make up your minds to pay for their wares enough to ensure them a living wage.
('68', 333, 1, 9, 631051) You will not expect me to describe all or even one of the numerous sections of the exhibition.
('68', 333, 1, 10, 631146) It is impossible for me to do so.
('68', 333, 1, 11, 631180) Let me tell you that you will have an inkling of the inside even from where you are sitting.
('68', 333, 1, 12, 631273) For in fornt of you are no triumphal arches but there are simply but exquisitely decorated walls done by Sjt.
('68', 333, 1, 13, 631383) Nandlal Bose, the eminent artist from Santiniketan, and his co workers who have tried to represent all the villagers’ crafts in simple artistic symbols.
('68', 333, 1, 14, 631536) And when you go inside the art gallery on which Babu Nandlal Bose has lavished his labours for weeks, you will feel, as I did, like spending there hours together.
('68', 333, 1, 15, 631699) But even the other sections will attract you.
('68', 333, 1, 16, 631745) You may not find in the exhibition anything to amuse you like music or cinema shows but I assure you you will find much to learn.
('68', 333, 2, 17, 631875) In conclusion, I want you all to be voluntary advertising agents of the exhibition so that numbers may be attracted to see it.
('68', 333, 2, 18, 632002) The exhibition has not been organized for the villagers, it is organized for the city dweller to enable him to see how the villager lives and what he is capable of.
('68', 333, 2, 19, 632167) The Reception Committee has spent something like Rs. 35, 000 in order to bring this exhibition into being.
('68', 333, 2, 20, 632274) The lest that you must do is to enable them to meet the expenses.
('68', 333, 2, 21, 632340) This you can do if you become their enthusiastic advertising agents.
('68', 333, 2, 22, 632409) Commission I can promise none, though I dare say you will get it for work dutifully done when you appear before the Great White Throne.
('68', 333, 2, 23, 632545) I may tell you that I am staying here for some days and expect to visit the exhibition as often as I can.
('68', 333, 2, 24, 632651) I shall therefore know how you have discharged your trust.
('68', 334, 0, 1, 632710) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 335
('68', 334, 1, 2, 632756) It is our intention to throw the exhibition open to the people from villages if the expenses are covered.
('68', 334, 1, 3, 632862) You will find in the exhibition many a drawback, but you and I are to blame for them, not the villagers.
('68', 334, 1, 4, 632967) Let me tell you, however, that the organizers have attempted the stupendous task of achieving in a few weeks the work which should take many months to be properly done.
('68', 334, 1, 5, 633136) You will therefore bear with us and forgive the shortcomings you will no doubt see.

('68', 340, 7, 16, 641885) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have had your letters to which Mahadev has been replying.
('68', 340, 7, 17, 641962) I have been permitted for some time to write few letters daily and to write to a limited extent for Harijan.
('68', 340, 7, 18, 642071) This is however to inform you that Gurudev’s presence in Delhi whilst I was there made it possible to collect the whole of the deficit, i.e., Rs. 60, 000. Gurudev was pleased beyond measure and cancelled the rest of the tour.
('68', 340, 7, 19, 642297) So you see how God worked.
('68', 340, 7, 20, 642324) This news ought to help you to get rid or anxiety complex.
('68', 340, 7, 21, 642383) I am just now in Lucknow for the Khadi Exhibition and the Congress.
('68', 340, 7, 22, 642451) I am not taking any active part in the latter.
('68', 340, 7, 23, 642498) We hope to return to Wardha by the middle of the month.
('68', 340, 7, 24, 642554) I hope you are, i.e., your work is, prospering.

('68', 341, 1, 2, 642733) 416. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON April 3, 1936
('68', 341, 2, 3, 642778) DEAR AGATHA,
('68', 341, 3, 4, 642791) Every mail day I think of you and then let it pass by so as not to add to the number of letters I am permitted to write.
('68', 341, 3, 5, 642912) Though no numerical limit has been put, I try to carry our the spirit of their advice.
('68', 341, 3, 6, 642999) I have had very long and quiet chats with Jawaharlal.
('68', 341, 3, 7, 643053) By the time this reaches you, you will know the result of the Congress deliberations.
('68', 341, 3, 8, 643139) You must have been filled with disgust as we have been here over the sensational and false news published in the Indian Press about the supposed interview to take place between the coming Viceroy and myself.
('68', 341, 3, 9, 643347) 1 Poor Lord Halifax has also been dragged in.
('68', 341, 3, 10, 643393) Nowadays I never believe anything that appears in the papers.
('68', 341, 3, 11, 643455) I hope you, too, do likewise.

('68', 341, 6, 14, 643530) 417. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('68', 341, 7, 15, 643557) April 3, 1936
('68', 341, 8, 16, 643571) DAUGHTER AMTUSSALAAM,
('68', 341, 9, 17, 643593) I have your long letter and have read it carefully.
('68', 341, 9, 18, 643645) Bapa’s letter has not at all pained me.
('68', 341, 9, 19, 643685) I know you are not the one to take defeat and I believe the taunting words of Rukminibehn 2 will not affect you.

('68', 341, 9, 23, 644035) Hence I have written to Bapa to send you to me if you are not really needed there.
('68', 341, 9, 24, 644118) Now do what Bapa says.

('68', 342, 4, 11, 644815) 418. FOR CONTRACEPTIVES
('68', 342, 5, 12, 644839) A correspondent writes: 1
('68', 342, 6, 13, 644865) I would like to say a few words on the report of the interview 2 between Mrs. Sanger and Mahatma Gandhi that appeared recently in the Harijan.
('68', 342, 7, 14, 645008) The cardinal fact that I see missed in the interview is that it has not been taken into consideration that man is above all an artist and a creator.
('68', 342, 7, 15, 645157) He is not satisfied with bare necessity, but must have beauty, colour and charm as well .
('68', 342, 7, 16, 645247) He has made every necessity into an art and has spent tons of blood on them.
('68', 342, 7, 17, 645324) His creative instinct impels him to add to his difficulties and problems and solve them over again.
('68', 342, 7, 18, 645424) He cannot be ‘simple’ as Rousseau, Ruskin, Tolstoy, Thoreau, and Gandhiji would like him to be.
('68', 342, 7, 19, 645520) War he must have as its necessary corollary which also he has transformed into a great art.
('68', 342, 8, 20, 645612) To appeal to him [to copy] the example of nature would be in vain, for it is totally incompatible with his very being.
('68', 342, 8, 21, 645731) ‘Nature’ cannot be his teacher .
('68', 342, 8, 22, 645764) “From an artistic standpoint,” says Nietzsche the iconoclast, ‘nature is no model.
('68', 342, 8, 23, 645847) It exaggerates, distorts and leaves gaps.
('68', 342, 8, 24, 645889) Nature is the accident.
('68', 342, 8, 25, 645913) To study ‘from nature’ seems to me bad sign; thus lying in the dust before trivial facts is unworthy of a thorough artist”.
('68', 342, 8, 26, 646037) To end sexual life when the need of propagation is no longer there, or to enjoin sex communion expressly with the desire of begetting offspring, is too calculating.
('68', 342, 8, 27, 646202) too natural, too ‘matter of fact’ .
('68', 342, 9, 28, 646238) I do not mean to underrate the value of the discipline of self control or what is technically knows as brahmacharya.
('68', 342, 9, 29, 646355) I would always admire it as the
('68', 342, 10, 30, 646387) 1 Only extracts of the letter are reproduced here.
('68', 342, 10, 31, 646438) 2 Vide “Interview to Margaret Sanger”, 3/4 12 1935.
('68', 343, 0, 1, 646490) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('68', 343, 1, 2, 646532) art of the control of the sex instinct carried to perfection.
('68', 343, 1, 3, 646594) But just as the perfection of other arts does not interfere with the science of life, with the whole life (in the Nietzschean sense of the term), with the proper scheme of all the values of life, so also I will not allow the value of the ideal of brahmacharya dominate other values, far less use is as an instrument of solving problems, such as over population.
('68', 343, 1, 4, 646956) I believe it was with an eye to such a scheme of values that the scriptures said,
('68', 343, 2, 5, 647038) or, there is brahmacharya where sexual union occurs only at night (i.e., as opposed to abnormal cohabitation during the day time).
('68', 343, 2, 6, 647169) Here normal sex life itself is sopken of as brahmacharya, the rigid conception of which began after we had already topsyturvied the proper scheme of all values of life.
('68', 343, 3, 7, 647338) I gladly publish this letter as I should any such letter that is not full of declamation, abuse or insinuations.
('68', 343, 3, 8, 647451) The reader should have both the sides of the question to enable him to come a decision.
('68', 343, 3, 9, 647539) I am myself eager to know why a thing which is claimed to be scientific and beneficial and which has many distinguished supporters repels me notwithstanding my effort to see the bright side of it.
('68', 343, 4, 10, 647736) Thus it is not proved to my satisfaction that sexual union in marriage is in itself good and beneficial to the unionists.
('68', 343, 4, 11, 647858) To the contrary effect I can bear ample testimony from my own experience and that of many friends.
('68', 343, 4, 12, 647957) I am not aware of any of us having derived any benefit, mental, spiritual or physical.
('68', 343, 4, 13, 648044) Momentary excitement and satisfaction there certainly was.
('68', 343, 4, 14, 648103) But it was invariably followed by exhaustion.
('68', 343, 4, 15, 648149) And the desire for union returned immediately the effect of exhaustion had worn out.
('68', 343, 4, 16, 648234) Although I have always been a conscientious worker, I can clearly recall the fact that this indulgence interfered with my work.
('68', 343, 4, 17, 648362) It was the consciousness of this limitation that put me on the track of self restraint and I have no manner of doubt that the self restraint is responsible for the comparative freedom form illnesses that I have enjoyed for long periods and for my output of energy and work both physical and mental which eye witnesses have described as phenomenal.
('68', 343, 5, 18, 648710) I fear that the correspondent has misapplied his reading.
('68', 343, 5, 19, 648768) Man is undoubtedly an artist and creator.
('68', 343, 5, 20, 648810) Undoubtedly he must have beauty and therefore colour.
('68', 343, 5, 21, 648864) His artistic and creative nature at its best taught him to see art in self restraint and ugliness in uncreative union.
('68', 343, 5, 22, 648983) His instinct for the artistic taught him to discriminate and to know that any
('68', 344, 0, 1, 649061) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 345
('68', 344, 1, 2, 649107) conglomeration of colours was no mark of beauty, nor every sense enjoyment good in itself.
('68', 344, 1, 3, 649198) His eye for art taught man to seek enjoyment in usefulness.
('68', 344, 1, 4, 649258) Thus he learnt at an early stage if his evolution that he was to eat for its own sake as some of us still do, but he should eat to enable him to live.
('68', 344, 1, 5, 649409) At a later stage he learnt further that there was neither beauty nor joy in living for its own sake but that he must live to serve his fellow creatures and through them his Maker.
('68', 344, 1, 6, 649589) Similarly, when he pondered over the phenomenon of the pleasurableness of sexual union, he discovered that like every other organ of sense, this one of generation had its use and abuse.
('68', 344, 1, 7, 649775) And he saw that its true function, its right use, was to restrict it to generation.
('68', 344, 1, 8, 649859) Any other use, he saw, was ugly and he saw further that it was fraught with very serious consequences as well to the individual as to the race.
('68', 344, 1, 9, 650003) It is hardly necessary for me to prolong the argument.
('68', 344, 2, 10, 650058) The correspondent says well than man makes art out of his necessities.
('68', 344, 2, 11, 650129) Necessity is not only the mother of invention, it is the mother also of art.
('68', 344, 2, 12, 650206) We should therefore beware of that art which has not necessity as its basis.
('68', 344, 2, 13, 650283) Nor may we dignify every want by the name of necessity.
('68', 344, 2, 14, 650339) Man’s estate is one of probation.
('68', 344, 2, 15, 650373) During that period he is played upon by evil forces as well as good.
('68', 344, 2, 16, 650442) He is every prey to temptations.
('68', 344, 2, 17, 650475) He has to prove his manliness by resisting and fighting temptations.
('68', 344, 2, 18, 650544) He is no warrior who fights outside foes of his imagination and is powerless to lift his little finger against the innumerable foes within, or, what is worse, mistakes them for friends.
('68', 344, 2, 19, 650730) “War he must have”.
('68', 344, 2, 20, 650750) But the correspondent is wrong when he says that “as its necessary corollary he has transformed it into a great art”.
('68', 344, 2, 21, 650868) He has hardly yet learnt the art of war.
('68', 344, 2, 22, 650909) He has mistaken false war for true even as our forefathers under a mistaken view of sacrifice instead of sacrificing their base passions sacrificed innocent non human fellow creatures as many even do at the present day.
('68', 344, 2, 23, 651129) We have yet to learn the art of true war.
('68', 344, 2, 24, 651171) Surely there is neither beauty nor art in what is going on today on the Abyssinian frontier.
('68', 344, 2, 25, 651264) The correspondent has chosen unhappy (for him) names for his illustrations.
('68', 344, 2, 26, 651340) Rousseau, Ruskin, Thoreau and Tolstoy were firstclass artists of their time.
('68', 344, 2, 27, 651417) They will live even after many of us are dead, cremated and forgotten.
('68', 344, 2, 28, 651488) The correspondent seems to have misapplied the word ‘nature’.
('68', 344, 2, 29, 651550) When an appeal to man is made to copy or study nature, he is not invited to follow what the reptiles do or even what the King of the
('68', 345, 0, 1, 651683) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 346
('68', 345, 1, 2, 651725) forest does.
('68', 345, 1, 3, 651738) He has to study man’s nature at its best, i.e., I presume his regenerate nature, whatever it may be.
('68', 345, 1, 4, 651839) Perhaps it requires considerable effort to know what regenerate nature is.
('68', 345, 1, 5, 651914) It is dangerous nowadays to refer to old teachers.
('68', 345, 1, 6, 651965) I suggest to the correspondent that it is unnecessary to bring in Neitzsche or even Prashnopanishad.
('68', 345, 1, 7, 652066) The question for me is past the stage of quotations.
('68', 345, 1, 8, 652119) What has cold reason to say on the point under discussion?
('68', 345, 1, 9, 652178) Is it or is it not correct to say that the only right use of the generative organ is to confine it solely to generation and that any other use is its abuse?
('68', 345, 1, 10, 652335) If it is, no difficulty in achieving the right use and avoiding the wrong should baffle the scientific seeker.
('68', 345, 2, 11, 652446) Harijan, 4 4 1936
('68', 345, 3, 12, 652464) 419. HINDI PRACHAR APPEAL
('68', 345, 4, 13, 652490) The following appeal 1 has been issued by Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj and others:
('68', 345, 5, 14, 652565) The Dakshin Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha is the body at present engaged in carrying out Mahatma Gandhi’s work of propagating Hindi in South India, inaugurated by him eighteen years ago at the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan held at Prayag in 1918. Since its inception the Sabha has succeeded in laying the work of Hindi prachar in South India on a firm and sure basis.
('68', 345, 5, 15, 652923) For the last five or six years it has been functioning in a self sufficient manner.
('68', 345, 5, 16, 653007) It is at present operating through its 450 centres in four different provinces with different languages in South India.
('68', 345, 5, 17, 653127) Besides, the teaching of Hindi is being pushed forth through the various arts schools and colleges through the efforts of the Sabha.
('68', 345, 5, 18, 653260) The total number of students receiving instruction in Hindi in South India through the agency of the Sabha today stands over 40,000.
('68', 345, 6, 19, 653393) It is now proposed to erect a bhavan for the Sabha to house its various departments.
('68', 345, 6, 20, 653478) The Madras Corporation has donated three acres and a half of land for the purpose.
('68', 345, 6, 21, 653561) The scheme would cost one lakh rupees and when completed will include, besides residential quarters for the workers, a college with hostel accommodation for at least 50 for training workers for Hindi prachar work, an arts school where Hindi will be compulsory and a prayer hall and a gymnasium for the use of students and workers of the Sabha and the neighbouring public.
('68', 345, 7, 22, 653933) 1 Of which only extracts are reproduced here.
('68', 346, 0, 1, 653979) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 347
('68', 346, 1, 2, 654025) All remittances should be sent to the Treasurer, Dakshin Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha, 107, Armenian Street or to Indo Commercial Bank, Madras.
('68', 346, 1, 3, 654167) I heartily endorse the appeal and hope that it will receive adequate response.
('68', 346, 2, 4, 654246) Harijan, 4 4 1936

('68', 347, 6, 18, 656377) The country was undoubtedly starving.

('68', 349, 1, 2, 658503) 425. LETTER TO ALBERT H. WEST
('68', 349, 2, 3, 658533) LUCKNOW, April 8, 1936
('68', 349, 3, 4, 658556) MY DEAR WEST 1, I was delighted to have your letter, and see your well known signature, after a long time.
('68', 349, 3, 5, 658663) Is it not years?
('68', 349, 3, 6, 658680) I am sorry about Sorabji 2. Though I am far away from where I can get access to books I can say with confidence that for years I have received no payments either through Reuter’s Agency or the East Indian Trading Co., or Dr. Nanji.
('68', 349, 3, 7, 658912) Amounts received by me through the Trust were, upon recommendation of Mr. Doull if I remember aright, backed by other trustees, sent back for Sorabji’s use as a loan, his policy being accepted as received security.
('68', 349, 3, 8, 659127) The premium for the policy has not been paid and probably it has lapsed.
('68', 349, 3, 9, 659200) I gave this loan with the greatest reluctance.
('68', 349, 3, 10, 659247) But I felt that I could do so.
('68', 349, 3, 11, 659278) For in those circumstances had Parsi Rustomji been alive he would have liked me to help Sorabji.
('68', 349, 3, 12, 659375) Of course no part of the loan has been returned.
('68', 349, 3, 13, 659424) I had years ago small payment for giving prizes to children.
('68', 349, 3, 14, 659485) That sum still is held and prizes are still being distributed annually.
('68', 349, 3, 15, 659557) Beyond that there is nothing to report as there is no money in my hands on behalf of the two Trusts.
('68', 349, 3, 16, 659658) In order to get the authoritative statement I am forwarding your letter with this reply to Narandas Gandhi who is in charge of the books of the Ashram.
('68', 349, 3, 17, 659810) And if there is any error in what I have said, I shall rectify it.
('68', 349, 3, 18, 659877) You will please keep me informed of the results of your investigations.
('68', 349, 3, 19, 659949) I hope you are all doing well including Mrs. Pywell who must be nearing her century.
('68', 349, 3, 20, 660034) How are you doing now?
('68', 349, 3, 21, 660057) With love to you all.
('68', 349, 3, 22, 660079) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI ALBERT H. WEST, ESQ.
('68', 349, 3, 23, 660130) 256 MOORE ROAD DURBAN, NATAL (S. A.)

('68', 350, 1, 2, 660347) 426. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('68', 350, 2, 3, 660373) April 8, 1936
('68', 350, 3, 4, 660387) MY DEAR REBEL,
('68', 350, 4, 5, 660402) I am waiting for your wire in reply to mine.
('68', 350, 4, 6, 660447) You ought not to catch cold as often as you do.
('68', 350, 4, 7, 660495) I am quite sure that you can avoid these colds by a judiciously natural life.
('68', 350, 4, 8, 660573) I have a vague fear that your silk underwear has not a little to do with the delicacy of your skin.
('68', 350, 4, 9, 660673) There is also the constant irritation you subject your skin to by frequent baths and still more frequent face washes.
('68', 350, 4, 10, 660791) Add to this the criminal use of soap which destroys all the grease with which nature protects the skin.
('68', 350, 4, 11, 660895) These three exterior causes perhaps largely account for your colds.
('68', 350, 4, 12, 660963) Discuss this with Shummy and if the physician in him endorses my view, make the necessary change, not perhaps all at once but one by one.
