('68', 352, 1, 2, 663213) 430. DANGER FROM WITHIN
('68', 352, 2, 3, 663237) No movement or organization having vitality dies from external attack.
('68', 352, 2, 4, 663308) It dies of internal decay.
('68', 352, 2, 5, 663335) This is true at any rate of great all India organizations like the A.I.S.A. and A.I.V.I.A. or the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('68', 352, 2, 6, 663454) I omit mention of others which are no less for all India than these three.
('68', 352, 2, 7, 663529) I single out the first two for they seek to represent and promote the immediate welfare of the millions of villagers who do not earn enough to keep body and soul together because they have to live in enforced idleness for at least four months in the year for want of work.
('68', 352, 2, 8, 663802) And I refer to the third because it seeks to represent the despised millions of society.
('68', 352, 2, 9, 663891) The three causes are thus worthy.
('68', 352, 2, 10, 663925) They should, therefore, not only be able to survive all external attack but even to thrive on it.
('68', 352, 2, 11, 664023) It is clear that they cannot flourish on mere pecuniary support.
('68', 352, 2, 12, 664088) They will always need it, but it must come as a direct fruit of honest work.
('68', 352, 2, 13, 664165) Therefore, what is necessary is character above suspicion, ceaseless effort accompanied by ever increasing knowledge of the technique of the work and a life of rigorous simplicity.
('68', 352, 2, 14, 664346) Workers without character, living far above the ordinary life of villagers, and devoid of the knowledge required of them for their work, can produce no impression on the villagers whether Harijan or other.
('68', 352, 2, 15, 664552) As I write these lines instances of those workers who for want of character or simple living damaged the cause and themselves recur to my mind.
('68', 352, 2, 16, 664696) Happily instances of positive misconduct are rare.
('68', 352, 2, 17, 664747) But the greatest hindrance to the progress of the work lies in the inability of workers of quality of support themselves on the village scale.
('68', 352, 2, 18, 664890) If every one of such workers puts on his work a price which village service cannot sustain, ultimately these organizations must be wound up.
('68', 352, 2, 19, 665031) For the existence of payments on the city scale except in rare and temporary cases would imply that the gulf between cities and villages is unbridgeable.
('68', 352, 2, 20, 665185) The village movement is as much an education of the city people as of the villagers.
('68', 352, 2, 21, 665270) Workers drawn from cities have to develop village mentality and learn the art of living after the manner of villagers.
('68', 352, 2, 22, 665389) This does not mean that they have to starve like the villagers.
('68', 352, 2, 23, 665453) But it does mean that there must be a radical change in the old style of life.
('68', 352, 2, 24, 665532) While the standard of living in the villages must be raised, the city standard has to undergo considerable revision, without the worker being required in any way to adopt a mode of life that would impair his health.
('68', 352, 3, 25, 665748) Harijan, 11 4 1936
('68', 353, 0, 1, 665767) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 354
('68', 353, 1, 2, 665809) 431. UNCERTIFIED KHADI
('68', 353, 2, 3, 665832) The Secretary of the Tamil Nad Branch of the A.I.S.A. writes to Shri Shankerlal Banker: 1
('68', 353, 3, 4, 665922) The old khadi merchants of Tirupur have started an association for certifying their khadi products.
('68', 353, 4, 5, 666022) Their object is to sell their existing stocks at enhanced rates and allow liberal commission to retail merchants throughout the province and to continue khadi production at old system and pay low wages.
('68', 353, 4, 6, 666225) Many an old spinner, who is either unable to purchase cotton from us or improve the quality of yarn, may continue to spin for these merchants.
('68', 353, 4, 7, 666368) We are, however, making arrangements to counteract these merchants’ efforts by vigorous propaganda among the villagers by pamphlets, private talks and lectures about the object and work of our Association and that of these merchants.
('68', 353, 4, 8, 666602) Our workers go from house to house and teach the spinners how to hank and improve the quality of yarn.
('68', 353, 5, 9, 666705) These merchants still continue to use our name for deceiving the public.
('68', 353, 5, 10, 666778) Their sign boards, letter heads, bills, invoices, labels on clothes are all printed as certified by the A.I.S.A. I sent them letters the other day asking them to strike out our name at once.
('68', 353, 5, 11, 666969) One merchant has replied as follows:
('68', 353, 6, 12, 667006) ‘I am surprised to read your letter dated 2 3 ’36. You say that if I do not strike off the words “Certified by A.I.S.A.” within a week you are going to take legal action.
('68', 353, 6, 13, 667177) The All India Spinners’ Association is not a registered body.
('68', 353, 6, 14, 667239) .’ Neither you nor anybody else has the right to object or protest.
('68', 353, 7, 15, 667307) I have written to the Press.
('68', 353, 7, 16, 667336) I am making arrangements to stock A. I. S. A. certified khadi at every Congress sabha.
('68', 353, 7, 17, 667423) Already two committees, the Mylapore Congress Committee and the Vedaranyam Town Congress Committee, have taken sales certificates.
('68', 353, 7, 18, 667554) I hope before long other committees will apply for certificates and arrange to stock and sell khadi.
('68', 353, 8, 19, 667655) I request that you will kindly explain the situation to Mahatmaji and request him to issue an appeal in the Press asking people who cannot spin for themselves to purchase only A. I, S. A. certified khadi and also to sound a note of warning to the merchants of Tirupur.
('68', 353, 9, 20, 667924) It is certainly wrong of the erstwhile certified khadi merchants to continue their trade in uncertified khadi after refusing to conform to the new rules about khadi and thus making themselves unfit for
('68', 353, 10, 21, 668126) 1 Only extracts of the letter are reproduced here.
('68', 354, 0, 1, 668177) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 355
('68', 354, 1, 2, 668223) certificates.
('68', 354, 1, 3, 668237) Their conduct is unpatriotic and unhuman.
('68', 354, 1, 4, 668279) They ought not to exploit the poor spinners and to a much lesser degree the credulous buyers.
('68', 354, 1, 5, 668373) I would urge them to conform to the new rules and take out certificates, or if they are not satisfied with the new scale, to take to some other business.
('68', 354, 1, 6, 668527) It ill becomes them to retort that the A.I.S.A. is not a registered body and that therefore they can do what they like.
('68', 354, 1, 7, 668647) I suggest to the objectors that their defiance of a body which they have hitherto obeyed is a breach of the moral and social code.
('68', 354, 1, 8, 668778) But whilst I hope that my appeal to the sellers of uncertified khadi will bear fruit, I would like the Secretary of the Tamil Nad Branch to acquaint the spinners of the new rules and persuade them not to spin for lower wages.
('68', 354, 1, 9, 669004) The most effective remedy lies in the hands of the spinners.
('68', 354, 1, 10, 669065) Of course I heartily endorse the Secretary’s appeal to Congress Committees and other lovers of the poor villagers to take out certificates for the sale of khadi and thus render concrete sevice to the toiling spinners.
('68', 354, 1, 11, 669283) Their active co operation will largely check the sale of uncertified khadi.
('68', 354, 2, 12, 669359) Harijan, 11 4 1936

('68', 355, 1, 2, 669689) 433. SPEECH AT KHADI AND VILLAGE INDUSTRIES EXHIBITION II
('68', 355, 2, 3, 669747) LUCKNOW, April 12, 1936
('68', 355, 3, 4, 669771) [Gandhiji] appealed to them to go and visit the Exhibition, once, twice, three
('68', 355, 4, 5, 669850) times, even four times, with their eyes and ears open, and if possible with the eyes and ears of their souls open.
('68', 355, 4, 6, 669965) They would then see miracles in the Exhibition.
('68', 355, 4, 7, 670013) When I told 1 you the other day that the Exhibition was not a cinema show, I meant more than I said.
('68', 355, 4, 8, 670114) 2 If you move about this Exhibition with my eyes and ears, you will spontaneously exclaim, ‘Hurrah!
('68', 355, 4, 9, 670214) what a splendid exhibition!’ There may be many young men here who shout ‘hurrah’ on witnessing the dance and gesticulations of a woman.
('68', 355, 4, 10, 670350) But God has given us eyes not to see and appreciate the dance of a woman, but to recognize the mother in her.
('68', 355, 4, 11, 670460) The ‘hurrah’ that will spontaneously come to your lips on witnessing the Exhibition with my eyes and ears will be clean and not filthy.
('68', 355, 4, 12, 670596) We go into raptures no hearing the name of Khuda or Rama in a durgah, mosque or a temple.
('68', 355, 4, 13, 670686) You can look upon this Exhibition as an equally sacred place.
('68', 355, 4, 14, 670748) You will not find here anything to captivate you in a sensual way.
('68', 355, 4, 15, 670815) You have to see it with my eyes.
('68', 355, 4, 16, 670848) It does not mean you should see it with the eyes of a mahatma.
('68', 355, 4, 17, 670911) I am only a villager, a simple man.
('68', 355, 4, 18, 670947) Therefore you have to look at this village industries exhibition with the eyes of a simple villager.
('68', 355, 4, 19, 671048) Anyone who pays a rupee, the charge for seeing the Exhibition four times, can learn four lessons in the bargain.
('68', 355, 4, 20, 671161) I am sure you have heard about spectacles made of pebble.
('68', 355, 4, 21, 671219) Now, here you can actually witness them being made.
('68', 355, 4, 22, 671271) Where else would you go to learn this craft?
('68', 355, 4, 23, 671316) But then this is a rather difficult job.
('68', 355, 4, 24, 671357) They also make paper here.
('68', 355, 4, 25, 671384) You will be amazed at the progress made by the paper industry.
('68', 355, 4, 26, 671447) Even a lad of ten can make paper if he wants to.
('68', 355, 4, 27, 671496) If you closely study here the process of paper making you will be able to pursue the craft in your home.
('68', 355, 4, 28, 671601) Here you will come across a novelty at every step and stop to marvel at it.

('68', 356, 1, 2, 671927) When you go to a cinema show you meet with things there to captivate in a sensual way your eyes and ears.
('68', 356, 1, 3, 672033) I may tell you that we have tried to boycott from this Exhibition everything that had no educative value.
('68', 356, 1, 4, 672139) We have tried to make the Exhibition a sacred and holy place, a feast for your eyes and ears, a spiritual feast capable of purifying the senses.
('68', 356, 1, 5, 672284) I shall tell you why.
('68', 356, 1, 6, 672306) Do you know Orissa and its skeletons?
('68', 356, 1, 7, 672344) Well, form that hungerstricken, impoverished land of skeletons have come men who have wrought miracles in bone and horn and silver.
('68', 356, 1, 8, 672476) Go and see these things not only ready made but in the making, and see how the soul of man even in an impoverished body can breathe life into lifeless horns and metal.
('68', 356, 1, 9, 672644) A poor potter has also worked miracles out of clay.
('68', 356, 2, 10, 672696) I have bought from the stall a nice little ink pot to hold my ink.
('68', 356, 2, 11, 672763) I thought its price would be six or seven annas, but I was surprised to learn that it was just one pice.
('68', 356, 2, 12, 672868) Well, when you look at it you will no doubt wonder if it had not come from Germany or Japan.
('68', 356, 2, 13, 672961) But the article is village made.
('68', 356, 2, 14, 672994) If this is not a wonder, what is?
('68', 356, 3, 15, 673028) Things which I thought would be worth several annas are worth only a copper or a couple of coppers and yet they are delicate little pieces of art.
('68', 356, 3, 16, 673175) A dear sister purchased the other day a little ‘Krishna’ in ivory.
('68', 356, 3, 17, 673242) She was not given to worshipping Lord Krishna, but she now tells that she has begun to worship the exquisite little form.
('68', 356, 3, 18, 673364) The Exhibition is thus not a spectacular show, but a kind of fairyland.
('68', 356, 3, 19, 673436) But our tastes have been so debased that miracles happening before our very eyes appear like so much dust or clay and trifles coming from abroad become exquisite pieces of art; water from a spring in far off Europe with the witchery of an unintelligible name becomes invested with miraculous quality, while the water of the holy Ganges which is said to be a purifier and a natural disinfectant seems to be no better than water from a dirty pool.
('68', 356, 3, 20, 673882) You can, of course, see that craftsmen from distant Travancore, Kashmir and Cuttack have congregated here.
('68', 356, 3, 21, 673989) These poor people have come here to earn a few coins by exhibiting their crafts.
('68', 356, 3, 22, 674070) Therefore those people on whom God has bestowed money ought to purchase here something or other.
('68', 356, 3, 23, 674167) Things are not overpriced here.
('68', 356, 3, 24, 674199) It is another matter if you yourself pay a fabulous price for a piece which pleases you.
('68', 356, 3, 25, 674288) The price you pay here will not go to fill the pockets of any rich

('68', 357, 1, 4, 674609) We are all living at the cost of the villagers.
('68', 357, 1, 5, 674657) The city dwellers are exploiting the villagers, and they must repay the debt, at least partially.

('68', 359, 8, 11, 678984) I got your letter.

('68', 359, 8, 13, 679060) It puts forth a good argument but it cannot be said that it is written in good English.

('68', 364, 9, 21, 688785) Mirabehn who is here in your midst came here with the intention of settling down for good.

('68', 364, 9, 26, 689207) God willing, therefore, I shall come to stay in

('68', 365, 0, 1, 689436) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 366
('68', 365, 1, 2, 689478) your midst.
('68', 365, 1, 3, 689490) Maybe God will give me the strength that He did not vouchsafe to her.
('68', 365, 1, 4, 689560) But even God’s will is expressed through various agencies and unless I have your goodwill even I may fail in my mission.
('68', 365, 1, 5, 689681) Ever since my childhood it has been a principle with me that I should not think of inflicting myself on those who view my going in their midst with mistrust, misgivings or apprehension.
('68', 365, 1, 6, 689867) I should not think of coming here, except to serve you.
('68', 365, 1, 7, 689923) But in many places my presence and the programme I stand for are viewed with considerable dread.
('68', 365, 1, 8, 690020) At the back of this dread is the fact that I have made the removal of untouchability a life’s mission.You must have known from Mirabehn that I have cost out all untouchability from myself, that I hold all classes of peopleBrahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Shudra, Rajput, Mahar, Chamarall alike, and I regard these distinctions based on birth as immoral.
('68', 365, 1, 9, 690375) We have suffered because of these distinctions, and this sense of high and low has vitiated our lives.
('68', 365, 1, 10, 690478) But I may tell you that I should not think of imposing these convictions on you.
('68', 365, 1, 11, 690559) I should try to do so by persuasion, above all by my own example.
('68', 365, 1, 12, 690625) I shall try to serve you by cleaning your roads and your surroundings, by trying to render such help as I can if there is illness in the village, by teaching you self help by way of helping you to revive your handicrafts.
('68', 365, 1, 13, 690847) If you will co operate with me I shall be happy, if you will not I shall be content to be absorbed among you as one among the few hundreds that live here.

('68', 365, 3, 18, 691269) 445. FOR CHRISTIAN FRIENDS
('68', 365, 4, 19, 691296) DEAR BR.
('68', 365, 5, 20, 691305) You have had your name blazoned abroad.
('68', 365, 5, 21, 691345) as one of the greatest philosophers and sacrificial workers on earth.
('68', 365, 5, 22, 691415) In India you have been proclaimed the Mahatma, and actually worshipped as one of the incarnations of India‘s many deities.
('68', 365, 5, 23, 691538) Your practice also of fasting when sin has been committed.
('68', 365, 5, 24, 691597) has had a tendency to make Indians believe that you can merit
('68', 366, 0, 1, 691659) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 367
('68', 366, 1, 2, 691705) blessing which can be communicated to others, but has anybody been loving and courageous enough to write and challenge you as to how personally you are going to obtain atonement for your own sin?
('68', 366, 1, 3, 691901) All your self denials and fastings and prayer and good deeds cannot blot out one sin of your early days.
('68', 366, 1, 4, 692006) For thirty or more years of your life you lived the carnal, self life, seeking and following your own plans and ambitions without seeking to know God’s purpose for your life or to honour His holy name.
('68', 366, 2, 5, 692208) Even if, as you profess to believe, Christ was only one of many incarnations of God, and the latest of them, you must either accept His tremendous claims as of Divine origin, or reject them as only human and fallible.
('68', 366, 2, 6, 692426) And when He declares as He did to the Jews of His day ‘If ye believe
('68', 366, 3, 7, 692496) not that I am He, ye shall die in your sins’ or ‘I am the way, the truth, and the life, no man cometh unto the Father, but by me’, you must either believe Him to have been self deceived, or deliberately false.
('68', 366, 3, 8, 692706) I pray daily that Christ may grant you a revelation of Himself as He did to Saul of Tarsus, that.
('68', 366, 3, 9, 692804) you may be used to proclaim to India’s millions the sacrificial efficacy of His precious blood.
('68', 366, 3, 10, 692900) This is a typical letter 1 from an old English friend who regularly writes such letters almost every six months.
('68', 366, 3, 11, 693013) This friend is very earnest and well known to me.
('68', 366, 3, 12, 693063) But there are numerous other correspondents unknown to me who write in the same strain without arguing.
('68', 366, 3, 13, 693167) Since now I cannot for reasons of health write to individual writers, I use this letter as a text for a general reply.
('68', 366, 3, 14, 693286) Incidentally this effort will enable the readers of Harijan who accpet my guidance to understand the nature of my religious belief.
('68', 366, 3, 15, 693418) My correspondent is a literalist.
('68', 366, 3, 16, 693452) He gives its literal meaning to every text of the Bible in spite of its clear statement that “the letter killeth, the spirit giveth life”.
('68', 366, 3, 17, 693591) My very first reading of the Bible showed me that I would be repelled by many things in it if I gave their literal meaning many texts or even took every passage in it as the word of God.
('68', 366, 3, 18, 693778) I found as I proceeded with my study of the scriptures of the various religions that every scripture had to be treated likewise, not excepting the Vedas or the Upanishads.
('68', 366, 3, 19, 693950) Therefore the story of the immaculate conception when I interpret it mystically does not repel me.
('68', 366, 3, 20, 694049) I should find it hard to believe in the literal meaning of the verses relating to the immaculate conception of Jesus.
('68', 366, 3, 21, 694167) Nor would it deepen my regard for Jesus if I gave those verses their literal meaning.
('68', 366, 3, 22, 694253) This does not mean that the writers of the Gospels were untruthful persons.
('68', 366, 4, 23, 694329) 1 Of which only extracts have been reproduced here
('68', 367, 0, 1, 694380) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 368
('68', 367, 1, 2, 694422) They wrote in a mood of exaltation.
('68', 367, 1, 3, 694458) From my youth upward I learnt the art of estimating the value of scriptures on the basis of their ethical teaching.
('68', 367, 1, 4, 694574) Miracles therefore had no interest for me.
('68', 367, 1, 5, 694617) The miracles said ot have been performed by Jesus, even in I had believed them literally, would not have reconciled me to any teaching that did not satisfy universal ethics.
('68', 367, 1, 6, 694791) Somehow or other, words of religious teachers have for me, as I presume for millions, a living force which the same words uttered by ordinary mortals do not possess.
('68', 367, 1, 7, 694957) Jesus then to me is a great world teacher among others.
('68', 367, 1, 8, 695013) He was to the devotees of his generation no doubt ‘the only begotten son of God’.
('68', 367, 1, 9, 695095) Their belief need not be mine.
('68', 367, 1, 10, 695126) He affects my life no less because I regard him as one among the many begotten sons of God.
('68', 367, 1, 11, 695218) The adjcetive ‘begotten’ has, for me, a deeper and possibly a grander meaning than its literal meaning.
('68', 367, 1, 12, 695322) For me it implies spiritual birth.
('68', 367, 1, 13, 695357) In his own times he was the nearest of God.
('68', 367, 1, 14, 695401) Jesus atoned for the sins of those who accepted his teachings by being an infallible example to them.
('68', 367, 1, 15, 695503) But the example was worth nothing to those who never troubled to change their lives.
('68', 367, 1, 16, 695588) A regenerate outgrows the original taint even as purified gold outgrows the original alloy.
('68', 367, 1, 17, 695680) I have made the frankest admission of my many sins.
('68', 367, 1, 18, 695732) But I do not carry their burden on my shoulders, If I am journeying Godward, as I feel I am, it is safe with me.
('68', 367, 1, 19, 695845) For I feel the warmth of the sunshine of His presence.
('68', 367, 1, 20, 695900) My austerities, fastings and prayers are, I know, of no value, if I rely upon them for reforming me.
('68', 367, 1, 21, 696001) But they have an inestimable value, it they represent, as I hope they do, the yearnings of a soul striving to lay his weary head in the lap of his Maker.
('68', 367, 1, 22, 696155) The Gita has become for me the key to the scriptures of the world.
('68', 367, 1, 23, 696222) It unravels for me the deepest mysteries to be found in them.
('68', 367, 1, 24, 696284) I regard them with the same reverence that I pay to the Hindu scriptures.
('68', 367, 1, 25, 696358) Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians, Parsis, Jews, are convenient labels.
('68', 367, 1, 26, 696427) But when I tear them down, I do not know which is which.
('68', 367, 1, 27, 696484) We are all children of the same God.
('68', 367, 1, 28, 696521) “Verily, verily, I say unto you, not everyone that sayeth unto me Lord Lord, shall enter the Kingdom of heaven, but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven shall enter the Kingdom”, was said, though in different words, by all the great teachers of the world.
('68', 367, 2, 29, 696795) Harijan, 18 4 1936

('68', 368, 2, 3, 696886) WARDHA.

('68', 368, 3, 5, 696909) MY DEAR IDIOT, We reached here yesterday noon quite comfortably.

('68', 378, 2, 3, 712530) April 23, 1936
('68', 378, 3, 4, 712545) I have just received your interesting letter.
('68', 378, 3, 5, 712591) Yes, I am following the events in Germany and the other parts of Europe.
('68', 378, 3, 6, 712664) It is all confusion worse confounded.
('68', 378, 3, 7, 712702) It is a mere trial of physical strength, it is also a trial of diplomacy of the worst kind ever experienced in history.
('68', 378, 3, 8, 712822) As you know my attempt is wholly on a different plane.
('68', 378, 3, 9, 712877) I can show nothing and yet my faith is growing stronger—more so for the events of Europe.
('68', 378, 5, 10, 712967) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('68', 378, 5, 11, 713013) Courtesy: Narayan Desai.

('68', 379, 1, 2, 713599) 466. SPEECH AT AKHIL BHARATIYA SAHITYA PARISHAD
('68', 379, 2, 3, 713647) NAGPUR, April 24, 1936
('68', 379, 3, 4, 713670) Introducing his printed speech to the audience, Gandhiji said he was out of place in a conference of litterateurs especially as he knew better than anyone else that his knowledge of Hindi literature, and even of Gujarati literature, was nothing to speak of, that his knowledge even of Gujarati grammar was indifferent.
('68', 379, 3, 5, 713989) But he had been told that it was an impossible task to get together formidable litterateurs, who were like lions safe enough in their own cages, but difficult to keep together and to be made to work together.
('68', 379, 3, 6, 714198) It had been thought that he as a neutral man and a ‘mahatma’ might be of some service in bringing them together.
('68', 379, 3, 7, 714311) There he was available to them for what he might be worth, but he wanted to make it clear that he was there simply to initiate the work of bringing [together] the literary men of every province speaking the different languages, and of serving the masses of India by making available to them the best in all the rich languages of our country 1.
('68', 379, 4, 8, 714655) In the course of his extempore speech Gandhiji said that doctors had advised him not to exert himself too much.
('68', 379, 5, 9, 714767) I am here for a brief while for the limited purpose I have told you, but you may know that my heart is neither here nor even in Wardha.
('68', 379, 5, 10, 714903) My heart is in the villages.
('68', 379, 5, 11, 714932) For days I have been striving with the Sardar to let me go to a village near Wardha.
('68', 379, 5, 12, 715017) He is still unconvinced, but my mind won’t rest, and God willing, I hope to go and settle in a village near Wardha in a short while.
('68', 379, 5, 13, 715150) But that does not mean that I will not do the work I am doing now, or that I shall cease to be available for consultation to friends, or for advice to those who will seek it.
('68', 379, 5, 14, 715325) Only my address will be a village where I would be living ordinarily.
('68', 379, 5, 15, 715395) I have been asking all my co workers who are doing village work to go and settle in villages and to serve the villagers.
('68', 379, 5, 16, 715516) I feel that I cannot do so effectively until I go and settle in village myself.
('68', 379, 6, 17, 715596) Proceeding, Gandhiji referred to the conflict between Hindi (Hindustani) and Urdu which was due mainly because Hindus and Muslims considered each other as enemies.
('68', 379, 6, 18, 715760) He noticed disputes ever since he returned to India from Africa.
('68', 379, 6, 19, 715825) In fact there was no cause for dispute because even if Muslims took the vow not to use a single

('68', 379, 7, 21, 715980) The following paragraph is from The Hitavada.
('68', 379, 7, 22, 716026) 2 What follows is from Harijan.
('68', 380, 0, 1, 716058) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 381
('68', 380, 1, 2, 716104) Hindi word they were unable to keep it mainly because the grammatical systems of both were identical.
('68', 380, 1, 3, 716206) Neither could the staunch advocates of Hindi abolish Persian or Urdu words as could be seen from Tulsidas’s Ramayana which abounded in Persian and Arabic words.
('68', 380, 2, 4, 716367) Gandhiji said that Hindi or Hindustani stood the best chances of becoming India’s lingua franca since it was a comprehensive language and was receptive to outside influences, in that it had absorbed the best from every other literature.
('68', 380, 2, 5, 716604) He favoured simplification of Hindi and deprecated the tendency to Sanskritize it.
('68', 380, 2, 6, 716687) He also urged that all current expressions in different languages should be adopted.
('68', 380, 3, 7, 716772) Proceeding, Gandhiji deplored the tendency to translate Hindi books first into English and then into Bengali or other [languages].
('68', 380, 3, 8, 716903) If they wanted to revive the vernacular, if they wanted to achieve the object they had in view, they must banish English so far as Indian masses were concerned.
('68', 380, 3, 9, 717064) He had no desire to underestimate the value of English which was a universal language and had international significance but Hindustani must become India’s lingua franca and the pernicious notion that they could produce excellent literature only in English must go.
('68', 380, 4, 10, 717330) Gandhiji deplored the present state of things where people were, so to say, in a hide bound way content to remain in their own linguistic and cultural wells, not ready even to acquaint themselves with the language and literature of their neighbouring provinces.
('68', 380, 4, 11, 717592) A handful of our literary men may be studying different provincial literatures and exchanging the treasures of other provincial languages.
('68', 380, 4, 12, 717731) But we had to seek do do more .
('68', 380, 4, 13, 717763) We must not only seek to know the picturesque language of the village folk, but also to spread a knowledge of modern useful literature among the villagers.
('68', 380, 4, 14, 717919) It is a shame that Chaitanya’s 3 lyrics are a sealed book to people outside Bengal and Orissa.
('68', 380, 4, 15, 718014) Few of us here may know the name of Tiruvalluvar.
('68', 380, 4, 16, 718064) People in the North are innocent even of the great saint’s name.
('68', 380, 4, 17, 718129) Few saints have given us treasures of knowledge contained in pithy epigrams as he has done.
('68', 380, 4, 18, 718221) In this context, I can at this moment recall the name only of Tukaram.
('68', 380, 5, 19, 718292) But for that purpose not only the existing literary treasures had to be made available in a language which could be easily learnt by the masses in all the provinces, but even new literature had to be created—new literature of a healthy and

('68', 381, 1, 2, 718790) health giving type.
('68', 381, 2, 3, 718810) If we were to enter the vast field of Indian literature, should we stop somewhere?
('68', 381, 2, 4, 718893) In my opinion there should certainly be a limit.
('68', 381, 2, 5, 718942) I never had the temptation of increasing the number of books.
('68', 381, 2, 6, 719004) I do not consider it necessary that every book written or published in the language of every province should be introduced to all the other languages.
('68', 381, 2, 7, 719155) Even if such an attempt were possible, I think it would be harmful.
('68', 381, 2, 8, 719223) Such interature as fosters unity, morality, valour and such other qualities, and science, should profitably spread to every province.
('68', 381, 3, 9, 719357) Today a plethora of highly objectionable erotic literature seems to be in evidence in every province.
('68', 381, 3, 10, 719459) Indeed, there are some who say that barring the erotic there is no other rasa 3 worth the name; and because the erotic is at a premium, those who insist on restraint in literature are held up to ridicule as devoid of all rasa.
('68', 381, 3, 11, 719686) They forget that even those who are said to sacrifice everything do not sacrifice rasa.
('68', 381, 3, 12, 719774) Each one of us feeds himself on some rasa or sacred passion.
('68', 381, 3, 13, 719835) Dadabhai Naoroji sacrificed everything for the country, but he was fired by the sacred passion of patriotism.
('68', 381, 3, 14, 719945) That gave him all his inner happiness.
('68', 381, 3, 15, 719984) To say that Chaitanya was devoid of rasa is to confess innocence of all rasa.
('68', 381, 3, 16, 720062) Narasinh Mehta, the poet saint of Gujarat, has described himself as a bhogi 4, but his bhoga was that of singleminded devotion to God.
('68', 381, 3, 17, 720197) If you will not be annoyed, I would go to the length of saying that the erotic is the lowest of all rasas, and when it partakes of the obscene it is wholly to be eschewed.
('68', 381, 3, 18, 720369) If I had the power I should taboo all literature calculated to promote communalism, fanaticism and ill will and hatred between individuals, classes or races.
('68', 381, 4, 19, 720527) How can all this be achieved?
('68', 381, 4, 20, 720557) Munshiji and Kakasaheb have cleared our way to a certain extent.
('68', 381, 4, 21, 720622) Literature of wider appeal can only be spread by a widely [spoken] language.
('68', 381, 4, 22, 720699) Hindi Hindustani is such a language compared to the other languages.
('68', 381, 4, 23, 720768) The reason why Hindi is qualified by the word ‘Hindustani’ is that words originating from the Persian idiom may not be shunned in that language.

('68', 382, 1, 4, 721543) It was with this end in view that Munshi started the monthly Hans with the help of the famous writer Premchandji.

('68', 382, 3, 7, 721768) 467. A YOUTH’S DIFFICULTY
('68', 382, 4, 8, 721794) A correspondent who prefers to remain anonymous seeks an answer to a question arising out of my article 1 in Harijan addressed to the young.
('68', 382, 4, 9, 721935) Although it is a sound rule to ignore anonymous correspondence, I do sometimes make an exception when the question put is substantial as in the present case.
('68', 382, 4, 10, 722093) The letter is in Hindi and is longer than it need have been.
('68', 382, 4, 11, 722154) Its purport is: From your writing I doubt if you understand the young mind.
('68', 382, 4, 12, 722230) What has been possible for you is not possible for all young men.
('68', 382, 4, 13, 722296) I happen to be married.
('68', 382, 4, 14, 722320) I can restrain myself.
('68', 382, 4, 15, 722343) My wife cannot.
('68', 382, 4, 16, 722359) She does not want children but she does want to enjoy herself.
('68', 382, 4, 17, 722422) What am I to do?
('68', 382, 4, 18, 722439) Is it not my duty to satisfy her?
('68', 382, 4, 19, 722473) I am not generous enough to look upon her satisfying her desire through other channels.
('68', 382, 4, 20, 722561) I read from the papers that you are not averse to promoting marriages and blessing them.
('68', 382, 4, 21, 722650) Surely you know or ought to know that they are not contracted with the high purpose that you have mentioned.
('68', 382, 4, 22, 722759) The correspondent is right.
('68', 382, 4, 23, 722787) The fact that I bless so many marriages, when they satisfy the tests that I have set as to age, economy, etc., perhaps shows somewhat that I know the youth of the country to an extent that would justify my guiding them when they seek my guidance.
('68', 382, 4, 24, 723034) My correspondent’s case is typical.
('68', 382, 4, 25, 723070) He deserves sympathy.
('68', 382, 4, 26, 723092) That the sole purpose of sexual connection is procreation is in the nature of a new discovery for me.
('68', 382, 4, 27, 723194) Though I had known the rule, I had never before given it the weight it deserved.
('68', 382, 4, 28, 723275) I must have till recently
('68', 382, 5, 29, 723301) 1 Vide “For the Young”, 28 3 1936.
('68', 383, 0, 1, 723336) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 384
('68', 383, 1, 2, 723378) regarded it as a mere pious wish.
('68', 383, 1, 3, 723412) I now regard it as a fundamental law of married state which is easy of observance if its paramount importance is duly recognized.
('68', 383, 1, 4, 723542) My object will be fulfilled when the law is given its due place in society.
('68', 383, 1, 5, 723618) To me it is a living law.
('68', 383, 1, 6, 723644) We break it always and pay heavily for its breach.
('68', 383, 1, 7, 723695) If my correspondent realizes its inestimable value and if he has love for her and has faith in himself, he will convert his wife to his view.
('68', 383, 1, 8, 723837) Is he sincere when he says he can restrain himself?
('68', 383, 1, 9, 723889) Has the animal passion become transmuted in his case into a higher passion, say, for service of fellow beings?
('68', 383, 1, 10, 724000) Does he naturally refrain from doing anything to excite the passion in his wife?
('68', 383, 1, 11, 724081) Let him know that Hindu science denotes eight kinds of unious which include sexual suggestions made even by signs.
('68', 383, 1, 12, 724196) Is the correspondent free from these?
('68', 383, 1, 13, 724234) If he is not 1 and if he is sincerely desirous that his wife should be weaned from the sexual desire, let him surround her with the purest love, let him explain the law to her, let him explain the physical effects of union without the desire for procreation, let him tell her what the vital fluid means.
('68', 383, 1, 14, 724538) Let him further engage his wife in healthy pursuits and strive to regulate her diet, exercise etc., so as to still the passion in her.
('68', 383, 1, 15, 724673) Above all, if he is a man of religion he will try to transmit to his companion his own living faith.
('68', 383, 1, 16, 724774) For I must confess that the observance of the law of continence is impossible without a living faith in God which is living Truth.
('68', 383, 1, 17, 724905) It is the fashion nowadays to dismiss God from life altogether and insist on the possibility of reaching the highest kind of life without the necessity of a living faith in a living God.
('68', 383, 1, 18, 725092) I must confess my inability to drive the truth of the law home to those who have no faith in and no need for a Power infinitely higher than themselves.
('68', 383, 1, 19, 725244) My own experience has led me to the knowledge that fullest life is impossible without an immovable belief in a living Law in obedience to which the whole universe moves.
('68', 383, 1, 20, 725414) A man without that faith is like a drop thrown out of the ocean bound to perish.
('68', 383, 1, 21, 725495) Every drop in the ocean shares its majesty and has the honour of giving us the ozone of life.
('68', 383, 2, 22, 725589) Harijan, 25 4 1936
('68', 383, 3, 23, 725608) 1 Could this be a slip for “If he is” ?

('68', 387, 1, 2, 729754) 474. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('68', 387, 2, 3, 729789) SEGAON, ,
('68', 387, 3, 4, 729799) April 29/30, 1936 1
('68', 387, 4, 5, 729819) BHAI BAPA, I have written to Chimandas.
('68', 387, 4, 6, 729859) To Choithram 2 I wrote from Lucknow itself.
('68', 387, 4, 7, 729903) The case of Amtussalaam is a difficult one.
('68', 387, 4, 8, 729947) She is not going to be happy with me, too, and I am now going to settle in a village.
('68', 387, 4, 9, 730033) For the present, however, I am going to Nandi Durg with Sardar.
('68', 387, 4, 10, 730097) He has been confined and I am banding jailor to him; I mean he is ill and I am to act as his number I am prepared to take Amtussalaam there.
('68', 387, 4, 11, 730238) It is not good morning away from Rukmini's harassment of her.
('68', 387, 4, 12, 730300) That women encourage her in her ways.
('68', 387, 4, 13, 730338) We must find out a way to reform Rukmini.
('68', 387, 4, 14, 730380) Therefore, consider Amtussalaam's case in this way.
('68', 387, 4, 15, 730432) Is it necessary to have her there?
('68', 387, 4, 16, 730467) If it is so, keep her there and clip Rukmini's wings.
('68', 387, 4, 17, 730521) If she is not needed she should be sent to me forthwith.
('68', 387, 4, 18, 730578) I sent her there with a view to satisfying her ambition to serve and under the belief that she was needed there.
('68', 387, 4, 19, 730691) She is certainly not to be accommodated on the assumption that work may be taken from whoever is there.
('68', 387, 4, 20, 730795) You are fully entitled to do what you think right after looking at the question from this angle.

('68', 391, 7, 23, 738736) I have been talking theory all these days, talking and giving advice on village work, without having personally come to grips with the difficulties of village work.
('68', 391, 7, 24, 738901) If I undertook the tour, say, after passing three seasons in a village and among the villagers, a year hence I should be able to talk with knowledge and experience which I have not got today.

('68', 395, 11, 24, 745400) 486. FOR WOMEN REFORMERS
('68', 395, 12, 25, 745425) From a serious discussion I had with a sister 2 I fear that my position on the use of contraceptives has not yet been sufficiently understood.
('68', 395, 12, 26, 745568) My opposition is not due to their having come to us from the West.
('68', 395, 12, 27, 745635) I thankfully use some Western things when I know that they
('68', 395, 13, 28, 745694) 1 Walchand Hirachand, an industrialist 2 Mrs. Margaret Sanger; vide “Interview to Margart Sanger”, 3/4 12 1935.
('68', 396, 0, 1, 745806) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 397
('68', 396, 1, 2, 745852) benefit us as they benefit those in the West.
('68', 396, 1, 3, 745898) My opposition to contraceptives is based on merits.
('68', 396, 1, 4, 745950) I take it that the wisest among the protagonists of contraceptives restrict their use to married women who desire to satisfy their and their husbands' sexual appetite without wanting children.
('68', 396, 1, 5, 746143) I hold this desire as unnatural in the human species and its satisfaction detrimental to the spiritual progress of the human family.
('68', 396, 1, 6, 746276) As against this is often cited the following testimony among others of Lord Dawson of Penn: 1
('68', 396, 2, 7, 746370) Sex love is one of the clamant, dominating forces of the world.
('68', 396, 2, 8, 746434) You may guide it into healthy channels but an outlet it will have, and if that outlet is inadequate or unduly obstructed, irregular channels will be forced.
('68', 396, 2, 9, 746591) Self control has a breaking point, and if in any community marriage is difficult or late of attainment, an increase of irregular unions will inevitably result.
('68', 396, 3, 10, 746751) Sex love has, apart from parenthood, a purport of its own.
('68', 396, 3, 11, 746810) It is an essential part of health and happiness in marriage.
('68', 396, 3, 12, 746871) The attainment of mutual and reciprocal joy in their relations constitutes a firm bond between two people and makes for durability of their marriage tie.
('68', 396, 4, 13, 747025) I will pass on to consider the all important question of birth control .
('68', 396, 4, 14, 747098) The reasons which lead parents to limit their offspring are sometimes selfish, but more often honourable and cogent.
('68', 396, 4, 15, 747215) The desire to marry and to rear children well equipped for life's struggle, limited incomes, the cost of living, burdensome taxation, are forcible motives.
('68', 396, 4, 16, 747371) Absence of birth control means late marriages and these carry with them irregular unions and all the baneful consequences.
('68', 396, 4, 17, 747494) But say many, ‘Birth control may be necessary, but the only birth control which is justifiable is voluntary abstention.’ Such abstention would be either ineffective or, if effective, impracticable and harmful to health and happiness.
('68', 396, 4, 18, 747728) To limit the size of a family to, say, four children, would be to impose on a married couple an amount of abstention which for long period would almost be equivalent to celibacy, and when one remembers that owing to economic reasons the abstention would have to be most strict during the earlier years of married life when desires are strongest, I maintain a demand is being made which, for the mass of people it is impossible to meet; that the endeavours to meet it would impose a strain hostile to health and happiness and carry with them grave dangers to morals .
('68', 396, 4, 19, 748295) Lord Dawson's eminence is not to be denied.
('68', 396, 4, 20, 748339) But with all due respect to his greatness as a physician, I am tempted to question the
('68', 396, 5, 21, 748426) 1 Only extracts from the quotation are reproduced here.
('68', 397, 0, 1, 748482) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 398
('68', 397, 1, 2, 748524) value of his evidence, specially when it is pitted against the experience of men and women who have lived a life of continence without suffering any moral or physical harm.
('68', 397, 1, 3, 748697) Physicians generally come across those who have so defied laws of health that they have contracted some illness.
('68', 397, 1, 4, 748810) They, therefore, often successfully prescribe what sufferers should do to become well, but they cannot always know what healthy men and women can do in any particular direction.
('68', 397, 1, 5, 748988) Lord Dawson's evidence, therefore, about the effect of continence on married people has to be taken with the greatest caution.
('68', 397, 1, 6, 749115) No doubt the tendency among married people is to regard sexual satisfaction for itself as legitimate.
('68', 397, 1, 7, 749217) But in the modern age in which nothing is taken for granted and everything is rightly scrutinized, it is surely wrong to take it for granted that because we have hitherto indulged in the sexual appetite in married life, the practice is either legitimate or healthy.
('68', 397, 1, 8, 749483) Many old practices have been discontinued with good results.
('68', 397, 1, 9, 749544) Why should this particular practice be exempt from examination especially in the light of the experience of those who even as married men and women are living a life of restraint with mutual benefit both physical and moral?
('68', 397, 1, 10, 749768) But I object to contraceptives also on special grounds in India.
('68', 397, 1, 11, 749833) Young men in India do not know what sexual restraint is.
('68', 397, 1, 12, 749890) It is not their fault.
('68', 397, 1, 13, 749913) They are married early.
('68', 397, 1, 14, 749937) It is the custom.
('68', 397, 1, 15, 749955) Nobody tells them to exercise restraint in married life.
('68', 397, 1, 16, 750012) Parents are impatient to see grandchildren.
('68', 397, 1, 17, 750056) The poor girl wives are expected by their surroun dings to bear children as fast as they can.
('68', 397, 1, 18, 750150) In such surroundings, the use of contraceptives can only further aggravate the mischief.
('68', 397, 1, 19, 750239) The poor girls who are expected to submit to their husbands' desires are now to be taught that it is a good thing to desire sexual satisfaction without the desire to have children.
('68', 397, 1, 20, 750420) And in order to fulfil the double purpose they are to have recourse to contraceptives !!!
('68', 397, 1, 21, 750510) I regard this to be most pernicious education for married women.
('68', 397, 1, 22, 750575) I do not believe that woman is prey to sexual desire to the same extent as man.
('68', 397, 1, 23, 750655) It is easier for her than for man to exercise self restraint.
('68', 397, 1, 24, 750717) I hold that the right education in this country is to teach woman the art of saying no even to her husband, to teach her that it is not part of her duty to become a mere tool or a doll in her husband’s hands.
('68', 397, 1, 25, 750926) She has rights as well as duties.
('68', 397, 1, 26, 750960) Those who see in Sita a willing slave under Rama do not realize the loftiness of either her independence or Rama's consideration for her in everything.
('68', 397, 1, 27, 751112) Sita was no helpless weak woman incapable of protecting herself or her
('68', 398, 0, 1, 751183) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 399
('68', 398, 1, 2, 751229) honour.
('68', 398, 1, 3, 751237) To ask India's women to take to contraceptives is, to say the least, putting the cart before the horse.
('68', 398, 1, 4, 751341) The first thing is to free her from mental slavery, to teach her the sacredness of her body and to teach her the dignity of national service and the service of humanity.
('68', 398, 1, 5, 751511) It is not fair to assume that India's women are beyond redemption and that they have therefore to be simply taught the use of contraceptives for the sake of preventing births and preserving such health as they may be in possession of.
('68', 398, 1, 6, 751746) Let not the sisters who are rightly indignant over the miseries of women who are called upon to bear children whether they will or no, be impatient.
('68', 398, 1, 7, 751895) Not even the propaganda in favour of contraceptives is going to promote the desired end overnight.
('68', 398, 1, 8, 751994) Every method is a matter of education.
('68', 398, 1, 9, 752033) My plea is for the right type.
('68', 398, 2, 10, 752064) Harijan, 2 5 1936

('68', 402, 1, 2, 757139) 494. SPEECH AT A.I.V.I.A. EXHIBITION 1
('68', 402, 2, 3, 757178) WARDHA, May 3, 1936 2
('68', 402, 3, 4, 757200) As I was coming to Maganwadi I saw the weekly bazaar that is held here every Sunday.
('68', 402, 3, 5, 757285) That bazaar has the raw produce as well as manufactures from raw produce exhibited in abundance.
('68', 402, 3, 6, 757382) This exhibition has these exhibited on a very humble scale.
('68', 402, 3, 7, 757442) I therefore wondered how our exhibition compared with the weekly bazaar.
('68', 402, 3, 8, 757515) The fundamental difference is that the exhibition is held entirely with a view to service of the village and the townsfolk, whereas the bazaar is a business concern in which the villager is exploited.
('68', 402, 3, 9, 757716) He is made to sell his wares as cheap as possible, often even below cost price.
('68', 402, 3, 10, 757796) At this exhibition there is hardly any buying and selling.
('68', 402, 3, 11, 757855) This exhibition is an attempt to educate the residents of Wardha in their duty towards the villages surrounding them and to educate the villagers in what is possible for them to better themselves in every way.
('68', 402, 3, 12, 758065) The exhibition teaches them how to keep their villages clean, what food to eat and how to improve their industries and thus earn a little more than they do today.
('68', 402, 3, 13, 758228) So far as the town dweller in concerned the exhibiton forcibly brings to his mind the various ways in which he is exploiting the villager, and how best he may serve the villager by going in for his wares.
('68', 402, 3, 14, 758433) The Lucknow Exhibition opened the eyes of those who visited it to the wonderful capacity of our village craftsman, and even this will do so somewhat.
('68', 402, 3, 15, 758583) I may tell you here that though the admission here has been kept free, at Lucknow it was not free.
('68', 402, 3, 16, 758682) Reports have been published that the exhibition there resulted in a heavy loss.
('68', 402, 3, 17, 758762) They are wrong.
('68', 402, 3, 18, 758778) The receipts from the sale of tickets exceeded Rs. 25,000. There were, besides, receipts from stall holders.
('68', 402, 3, 19, 758887) It is just possible that there will be a nominal profit.
('68', 402, 3, 20, 758944) Those around Lucknow will not see such an exhibition in Lucknow for years to come.
('68', 402, 3, 21, 759027) The Kumbh Mela recurs at long but regular intervals.
('68', 402, 3, 22, 759080) The Congress and the Exhibition may not be held again at the same place, and even if it is, it may be held at an indefinitely long interval, especially because the tendency, I
('68', 402, 4, 23, 759256) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”.
('68', 402, 4, 24, 759307) Gandhiji inaugurated the exhibition arranged at Maganwadi.
('68', 402, 4, 25, 759366) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 5 5 1936
('68', 403, 0, 1, 759404) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 404
('68', 403, 1, 2, 759446) hope, now will be to select not big cities but small towns for their venue.
('68', 403, 1, 3, 759522) But local exhibitions like this should be inexpensive annual efforts of growingly educative value.
('68', 403, 1, 4, 759621) The village oilman has, for instance, deteriorated nowadays.
('68', 403, 1, 5, 759682) He adulterates the oil with cheap and spurious stuffs.
('68', 403, 1, 6, 759737) He will learn here how it is profitable to make the oil absolutely pure and unadulterated.
('68', 403, 1, 7, 759828) The paper maker will learn here how to make the paper neat and lasting.
('68', 403, 1, 8, 759900) As time goes we should be able to show improvements in these processes.
('68', 403, 1, 9, 759972) I know that we have been able to produce little effect, during the year, on our surroundings or on the villages in the neighbourhood.
('68', 403, 1, 10, 760106) But that does not disappoint me.
('68', 403, 1, 11, 760139) We have to plod on.
('68', 403, 1, 12, 760159) Those of you who have come here have to go forth to the villages as advertising agents and to draw the villagers to such exhibitions.
('68', 403, 1, 13, 760293) The tragedy today is that the town dweller is becoming increasingly indifferent to the villages, that he even believes that the villages are going to be destroyed in the near future.
('68', 403, 1, 14, 760476) They certainly will be if we continue to prefer mill made articles to hand made.
('68', 403, 1, 15, 760557) Those of you who have come here have to go out as preachers of the gospel of rural mindedness.
('68', 403, 1, 16, 760652) A factory employs a few hundreds and renders thousands unemployed.
('68', 403, 1, 17, 760719) I may produce tons of oil from an oil mill, but I also drive thousands of oilmen out of employment.
('68', 403, 1, 18, 760819) I call this destructive energy, whereas production by the labour of millions of hands is constructive and conductive to the common good.
('68', 403, 1, 19, 760956) 1 Mass production through power driven machinery, even when Stateowned, will be of on avail.
('68', 403, 1, 20, 761049) But why not, it is asked, save the labour of millions and give them more leisure for intellectual pursuits?
('68', 403, 1, 21, 761157) Leisure is good and necessary up to a point only.
('68', 403, 1, 22, 761207) God created man to eat his bread by the sweat of his brow, and I dread the prospect of our being able to produce all that we wnt, including our Food stuffs, out of a conjurer's hat.
('68', 403, 2, 23, 761389) Harijan, 16 5 1936
('68', 403, 3, 24, 761408) 1 The report in The Bombay Chronicle, 5 5 1936, here has: “The method of production of necessaries through power driven machinery displacing tens of thousands of men and providing prolonged leisure was, in his opinion, asuric, whereas the ancient method of production by human labour in co operation was daivic— that is to say, conducive to the progress of humanity.
('68', 403, 3, 25, 761775) The ancient method had its effects.
('68', 403, 3, 26, 761811) The All India Village Industries Association was endeavouring to remedy the evil and exhibitions were a method of encompassing that end.”

('68', 405, 4, 10, 763968) 497. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('68', 405, 5, 11, 763994) SEGAON, May 5, 1936
('68', 405, 6, 12, 764014) MY DEAR IDIOT,
('68', 405, 7, 13, 764029) Surely by this time you have had more than one letter from Segaon.
('68', 405, 7, 14, 764096) I am sure in a day or two you would have begun to like the place and the life.
('68', 405, 7, 15, 764175) Ba came with me yesterday.
('68', 405, 7, 16, 764202) I walked the whole distance.
('68', 405, 7, 17, 764231) It took me full two hours.

('68', 405, 7, 19, 764301) We were all novices without a guide.

('68', 405, 7, 21, 764356) I can comfortably do the whole distance on 1 3 4 hours.

('68', 413, 4, 7, 777490) 508. SPEECH AT A.I.V.I.A. MEETING 1
('68', 413, 5, 8, 777526) WARDHA, May 7, 1936
('68', 413, 6, 9, 777546) I take it that those who are members of the A. I. V. I. A. know the rules of the Association, one of which is that there is to be an annual general meeting.
('68', 413, 6, 10, 777703) Either such a meeting is necessary or it is not.
('68', 413, 6, 11, 777752) If it is, surely it is the duty of every member to attend the meeting unless he is unavoidably absent.
('68', 413, 6, 12, 777855) What I cannot understand is that the absentees have not all written to say what prevented them from attending the meeting.
('68', 413, 6, 13, 777978) The feeling on the part of an individual member that his absence alone cannot affect the quorum is obviously wrong.
('68', 413, 6, 14, 778094) Our ambition is to make at least one member for each of our 7,00,000 villages, but our actual membership is 517!
('68', 413, 6, 15, 778207) And the bulk of the members are not present!
('68', 413, 6, 16, 778252) It is deplorable, but it does not dismay me.
('68', 413, 6, 17, 778297) Let those who are present carry to the absentees at least this message that it was their duty to inform the Secretary as to the reason of their failure.
('68', 413, 6, 18, 778450) Failure even to intimate the reason argues lethargy, which certainly should disqualify one to be the member of an association like ours.
('68', 413, 7, 19, 778587) Mahatma Gandhi observed that the duty of the workers was to serve the villagers and if they found that the atmosphere in some place was not congenial to them for the pursuit of service owing to the hostility of local officials, nothing would be lost by their shifting their centres of work.
('68', 413, 7, 20, 778878) The country was wide enough to provide ample scope for work in places other than those in which conditions were
('68', 413, 8, 21, 778990) 1 The first annual general meeting of the Association scheduled to be held at 3 p.m.
('68', 413, 8, 22, 779075) had to be adjourned for want of quorum and was held at 8 p.m.
('68', 413, 8, 23, 779137) 2 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”.
('68', 413, 8, 24, 779195) The following paragraph is from The Bombay Chronicle.
('68', 414, 0, 1, 779249) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 415
('68', 414, 1, 2, 779295) rendered difficult owing to extraneous forces.
('68', 414, 1, 3, 779342) Difficulties occasioned by internal forces it would be the duty of workers, however, to overcemo.
('68', 414, 2, 4, 779440) Some members talk of difficulties created from outside.
('68', 414, 2, 5, 779496) I think most of them are imaginary.
('68', 414, 2, 6, 779532) How much have we been able to do where there are no difficulties from outside?
('68', 414, 2, 7, 779611) Take Sindi and Segaon where Gajanan and Mirabehn have both been working with a zeal and rural mindedness that every one of us might envy.
('68', 414, 2, 8, 779749) How much have they achieved that could be shown?
('68', 414, 2, 9, 779798) The reason is the inertia, the lethargy of our people, the masters.
('68', 414, 2, 10, 779866) We want them to do something, i.e., to keep their surroundings clean, to eat wholesome food and to regulate their working hours so as to increase their income.
('68', 414, 2, 11, 780026) They have no faith in all this.
('68', 414, 2, 12, 780058) They have lost hope of bettering their lot.
('68', 414, 2, 13, 780102) We have to tackle the triple malady which holds our villages fast in its grip: (1) Want of corporate sanitation; (2) Deficient diet; (3) Inertia.
('68', 414, 2, 14, 780248) In Segaon where Mirabehn is working, all the outside circumstances are more favourable than anywhere else.
('68', 414, 2, 15, 780355) The zamindars there are Jamnalalji and Babasaheb Deshmukh.
('68', 414, 2, 16, 780414) They place no obstacles; they, on the contrary, help her.
('68', 414, 2, 17, 780472) And yet, do you think she gets much co operation from the people?
('68', 414, 2, 18, 780538) Not that they are wilfully obstructive.
('68', 414, 2, 19, 780578) They are not interested in their own welfare.
('68', 414, 2, 20, 780624) They don't appreciate modern sanitary methods.
('68', 414, 2, 21, 780671) They don't want to exert themselves beyond scratching their farms or doing such labour as they are used to.
('68', 414, 2, 22, 780779) These difficulties are real and serious.
('68', 414, 2, 23, 780820) But they must not baffle us.
('68', 414, 2, 24, 780849) We must have an unquenchable faith in our mission.
('68', 414, 2, 25, 780900) We must be patient with the people.
('68', 414, 2, 26, 780936) We are ourselves novices in village work.
('68', 414, 2, 27, 780978) We have to deal with a chronic disease.
('68', 414, 2, 28, 781018) Patience and perseverance, if we have them, overcome mountains of diffculties.
('68', 414, 2, 29, 781097) We are like nurses who may not leave their patients because they are reported to have an incurable disease.
('68', 414, 2, 30, 781205) The only way is to sit down in their midst and work away in steadfast faith, as their scavengers, their nurses, their servants, not as their patrons, and to forget all our prejudices are prepossessions.
('68', 414, 2, 31, 781408) Let us for a moment forget even swaraj, and certainly forget the ‘haves’ whose presence oppresses us at every step.
('68', 414, 2, 32, 781524) They are there.
('68', 414, 2, 33, 781540) There are many who are dealing with these big problems.
('68', 414, 2, 34, 781596) Let us tackle the humbler work of the village which is necessary now and would be
('68', 415, 0, 1, 781678) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 416
('68', 415, 1, 2, 781720) even after we have reached our goal.
('68', 415, 1, 3, 781757) Indeed, the village work when it becomes successful will itself bring us nearer the goal.
('68', 415, 2, 4, 781847) He hoped to see Segaon become an ideal centre of persistent effort, and he trusted that worker's elsewhere would apply to the work before them the same zest and energy.
('68', 415, 2, 5, 782016) It was too early to judge the progress achieved, but he hoped that they would also attempt to understand thoroughly the implications of the threefold programme that had been placed before them by the Association.
('68', 415, 2, 6, 782229) The first part of this was the improvement of sanitary conditions, removal of filth and the eradication of habits which gave rise to uncleanliness.
('68', 415, 2, 7, 782377) That meant the education of the village population by personal example and steady work.
('68', 415, 3, 8, 782465) The next part of the programme called for a radical change in the dietary of the people so that they might be enabled to draw greater sustenance from the articles of food ordinarily available in villages.
('68', 415, 3, 9, 782670) This required that the processing of food stuffs should be done in the villages, as in the past, and that pure food stuffs should be made available in villages and not be drained away to towns.
('68', 415, 3, 10, 782864) The last portion of the programme was the utilization of spare time of the cultivators, the revival of dead or dying industries, and teaching all classes of people the right use of leisure.
('68', 415, 4, 11, 783054) All these were difficult tasks, Mahatma Gandhi admitted, and those friends of his were not wrong who warned him that he had now in the evening of his life taken upon his head a heavier responsibility than the promotion of the charkha movement or the removal of untouchability.
('68', 415, 4, 12, 783331) Both these activities, important as they were, formed only a part of the vast work of rural reconstruction.

('68', 416, 13, 15, 784754) I may confess that I was sceptical about the opening of the school.

('68', 418, 4, 12, 788826) 512. HINDI OR HINDUSTANI
('68', 418, 5, 13, 788851) Elsewhere the reader will find a deeply interesting letter 2 from an esteemed friend which was read to the delegates who recently assembled in Nagpur and who inaugurated the Akhil Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad.
('68', 418, 5, 14, 789059) There is a similar letter from another Muslim friend enclosing leading article 3 on the subject in The Bombay Chronicle dated 27th April last.
('68', 418, 5, 15, 789202) These letters and the Chronicle article generally represent my views on the question of common inter provincial speech.
('68', 418, 5, 16, 789322) However, I fear that there are perhaps limitations to my agreement which need to be publicly stated.
('68', 418, 5, 17, 789423) The limitations if they may be so called are designed to compass the very end that my friends have in view.
('68', 418, 5, 18, 789531) At the outset I must dismiss from consideration the suspicion entertained by some Muslims.
('68', 418, 5, 19, 789622) The whole atmosphere is surcharged with suspicion.
('68', 418, 5, 20, 789673) No person's declarations or acts are above suspicion.
('68', 418, 5, 21, 789727) The best way, in my opinion, for those who sincerely desire full communal unity and have themselves given no cause for suspicion is to act on the square without being swayed one way or the other by the passions of the moment, especially in matters like the Parishad which have nothing to do with the passions.
('68', 418, 5, 22, 790037) The object of the Parishad is to gather together all that is best in all the languages of India and to
('68', 418, 6, 23, 790140) 1 What follows is from The Bombay Chronicle.

('68', 419, 1, 2, 790378) make it available to the largest number of her inhabitants and therefore through a speech understood by the largest number.
('68', 419, 1, 3, 790502) Urdu is undoubtedly one of the many languages and contains treasures which should be the common property of all India.
('68', 419, 1, 4, 790621) No Indian who wishes to know the Muslim mind or to know all about Islam as it is being interpreted through the Indian medium can afford to ignore Urdu literature.
('68', 419, 1, 5, 790784) And the Parishad just established will fail in its duty and purpose if it does not unlock for all India the treasures to be found in the current Urdu literature.
('68', 419, 1, 6, 790946) My correspondent has made a mistake which needs to be cleared.
('68', 419, 1, 7, 791009) He could not have had before him the full test of Tandonji's speech 1 made not as the friend thinks at Banaras but at Allahabad, or he would not have made the serious mistake of thinking that when Tandonji talked of 22 crores speaking Hindi, he had in mind only those who wrote the modern artificial Hindi.
('68', 419, 1, 8, 791316) He made it clear that he referred to the vast mass of people of north of the Vindhya including the seven crores of Mussalmans who more or less spoke and understood the language which is evolved from Vrajabhasha and which has the latter's grammatical structure.
('68', 419, 1, 9, 791577) The name Hindi given to it is not original.
('68', 419, 1, 10, 791621) It was given by Muslim writers to what they wrote for the people of the North and what was undoubtedly like that which their Hindu brethren wrote.
('68', 419, 1, 11, 791768) Later on a bifurcation took place and Hindi written in Devanagari came to be the speech of the Hindus of the North and Urdu written in Arabic or Persian script came to be the speech of the Muslims of the North.
('68', 419, 1, 12, 791979) It is hardly true as yet to say that Urdu is common to the Mussalmans all over India.
('68', 419, 1, 13, 792065) I know that the Ali Brothers 2 and I found it difficult to make ourselves understood by the Moplahs of Malabar through our Urdu.
('68', 419, 1, 14, 792194) We had to have a Malayalee interpreter.
('68', 419, 1, 15, 792234) We found a similar diffiulty in East Bengal among its numerous Mussalmans.
('68', 419, 1, 16, 792309) Both Tandonji and Rajendra Babu 3 therefore meant the same thing absolutely as my friend when they used the word ‘Hindi’.
('68', 419, 1, 17, 792431) The use of the word ‘Hindustani’ would not make their position clearer.
('68', 419, 1, 18, 792503) But the writer of the letter is on sure ground when he complains of the writers of the North who write a language which they call ‘Hindi’ but which very few persons even of the North would

('68', 420, 1, 2, 792891) understand.
('68', 420, 1, 3, 792903) It is an effort which is doomed to fail like Johnsonian speech.
('68', 420, 1, 4, 792967) Then why insist on ‘Hindi or Hindustani’ and why not simply say ‘Hindustani’, the writer may say.
('68', 420, 1, 5, 793065) For one simple reason that it would be impertinent for me, a newcomer, to ask an association 1 of 25 years' standing to alter its name when the need for it is not clearly proved.
('68', 420, 1, 6, 793244) The new Parishad is an offspring of the older Association and wants to cater both for the Muslims and Hindus of the North who speak the common mother tongue, it does not matter whether it is called Hindi or Hindustani.

('68', 420, 1, 12, 793870) The Indian culture of our times is in the making.

('68', 420, 1, 17, 794259) What does interest me is the fact that my remote ancestors blended with one another with the utmost freedom and we of the present generation are a result of that blend.
('68', 420, 1, 18, 794428) Whether we are doing any good to the country of our birth and the tiny globe which sustains us or whether we are a burden, the future alone will show.

('68', 433, 2, 3, 815809) May 14, 1936
('68', 433, 3, 4, 815822) MIRA, I have your letter.
('68', 433, 3, 5, 815848) Yes, it is very delightful here.
('68', 433, 3, 6, 815881) My personal love wishes you were here to share with us the quiet and isolation of this beautiful hill.
('68', 433, 3, 7, 815984) My impersonal love tells me you are better off where you are for it is the part of duty.
('68', 433, 3, 8, 816073) Kumarappya and Shanta came in yesterday.
('68', 433, 3, 9, 816114) Sardar is feeling much better here.
('68', 433, 3, 10, 816150) He takes very long walks with impunity and eats much better than before.
('68', 433, 3, 11, 816223) Dr. Ansari’s death was a great shock to me.
('68', 433, 3, 12, 816267) I have hardly got over it yet.
('68', 433, 3, 13, 816298) I feel the want of his presence in so many things.
('68', 433, 3, 14, 816349) I am glad you are making good progress with the hut.
('68', 433, 3, 15, 816402) I understand what you say about the road.
('68', 433, 3, 16, 816444) You will do what is the best.
('68', 433, 3, 17, 816474) I have implicit faith in your judgement in these matters.
('68', 433, 3, 18, 816532) Balwantsingh and Munnalal must not be a burden on you in any shape or form.
('68', 433, 3, 19, 816608) I enclose notes for them.
('68', 433, 4, 20, 816634) I hope by the time this reaches you, the land 2 in Varoda will have been taken.
('68', 433, 4, 21, 816714) BAPU From the original: C.W. 6334. Courtesy: Mirabehn.

('68', 435, 1, 2, 818307) 534. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('68', 435, 2, 3, 818342) May 14, 1936
('68', 435, 3, 4, 818355) BHAI BAPA,
('68', 435, 4, 5, 818366) I send with this a cheque for Rs. 200 received from Sophia Wadia 1. The receipt need not be sent to her.
('68', 435, 4, 6, 818471) Send it to me.
('68', 435, 4, 7, 818486) I understand what you say regarding Sastri.
('68', 435, 4, 8, 818530) I enclose [a report of] the work done in Madras in four hours.
('68', 435, 4, 9, 818593) Jagannathdas had arranged a prayer meeting in Kodambakkam, but I refused to go till an assurance was given that the institution would be continued.
('68', 435, 4, 10, 818741) Jagannathdas gave the required assurance, which I send with this.
('68', 435, 4, 11, 818807) Please preserve it.
('68', 435, 4, 12, 818827) I met Pratapmalji also.
('68', 435, 4, 13, 818851) He, too, has undertaken to solve the financial worries, but he asked for somebody who would be able to create there the atmosphere that we have in the Ashram.
('68', 435, 4, 14, 819010) How can I find such a person?
('68', 435, 4, 15, 819040) I met Venkatasubbiah here and discussed the problem with him.
('68', 435, 4, 16, 819102) He and the others expressed their dislike of Sastri.
('68', 435, 4, 17, 819155) Venkatasubbiah says, however, that they will do without Sastri and Ganesan.
('68', 435, 4, 18, 819231) One of the four will visit the place daily by turns.
('68', 435, 4, 19, 819284) This is what I have been able to do.
('68', 435, 4, 20, 819321) Kindly write from there now and ask them clearly to relieve Ganesan.
('68', 435, 4, 21, 819390) Sastri’s resignation has already been accepted.
('68', 435, 4, 22, 819438) You can mention Jagannathdas’s letter and say that you hope that the four of them will carry on the work.
('68', 435, 4, 23, 819544) Since Dr. Ansari had detained Amtussalaam please accommodate her.
('68', 435, 4, 24, 819610) Malkani, poor man, writes and tells me that he could not tolerate the thought that she had to leave because of Rukmini.
('68', 435, 4, 25, 819730) The latter does not tolerate anybody.
('68', 435, 4, 26, 819768) But does that mean that they should all leave?
('68', 435, 4, 27, 819815) I have written a strong letter 2 to her.
('68', 435, 4, 28, 819856) Amtussalaam is not likely to pay attention to Rukmini’s words.
('68', 435, 4, 29, 819919) She will remain happy if you go on giving her some work.
('68', 435, 4, 30, 819976) I hope that your letters are opened before they are sent to you.
('68', 435, 4, 31, 820041) If there is any cheque or such things in an envelope, they should not follow you from place to place.
('68', 435, 4, 32, 820143) You, too, have been travelling a good deal.
('68', 435, 4, 33, 820187) It seems you are becoming young again.
('68', 435, 4, 34, 820226) If you share your experiences with the people, they will be of priceless value to them, Garhwal is a ‘sealed
('68', 435, 5, 35, 820335) 1 Madam Sophia Wadia, Indian representative on the P.E.N. 2 Vide “Letter to Rukmini Malkani”, 7 5 1936.
('68', 436, 0, 1, 820439) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 437
('68', 436, 1, 2, 820485) book’ for most people.
('68', 436, 1, 3, 820508) I have heard that it is a very beautiful but a very poor region.
('68', 436, 1, 4, 820573) We are in Nandi Durg, enjoying its pleasant air.
('68', 436, 2, 5, 820622) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 1122
('68', 436, 3, 6, 820686) 535. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAM AND VIJAYA GANDHI May 14, 1936 CHI.
('68', 436, 3, 7, 820749) PURUSHOTTAM AND VIJAYA 2, May you live a long married life, and may you both devote your life to service.
('68', 436, 3, 8, 820855) These are my wishes and my blessings.
('68', 436, 3, 9, 820893) There is no place for sensual pleasure in married life; the coming together of man and wife should be only for the sake of begetting progeny.
('68', 436, 3, 10, 821035) Recently I wrote an article 1 suggesting this.
('68', 436, 3, 11, 821082) You should try to live accordingly if you like my idea.
('68', 436, 3, 12, 821138) A certain discipline has to be observed to be able to live such a life.
('68', 436, 3, 13, 821210) Only then can one find the aim within reach.
('68', 436, 3, 14, 821255) Blessings from BAPU
('68', 436, 4, 15, 821275) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('68', 437, 1, 2, 822078) 537. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('68', 437, 2, 3, 822107) May 14, 1936 CHI.
('68', 437, 2, 4, 822125) LILAVATI, I have your letter.
('68', 437, 2, 5, 822155) How can it be hot there?
('68', 437, 2, 6, 822180) That is the beauty of a coastal place.
('68', 437, 2, 7, 822219) You are a rash and impatient person.
('68', 437, 2, 8, 822256) You could not have seen your way even if you had not indulged in the adventure at Segaon.
('68', 437, 2, 9, 822346) Adventure is a good thing if undertaken at the right time and for a right cause.
('68', 437, 2, 10, 822427) Otherwise it is sheer rashness.
('68', 437, 2, 11, 822459) Your coming to Segaon was no better.
('68', 437, 2, 12, 822496) The point in recalling this incident is only to prevent its recurrence.
('68', 437, 2, 13, 822568) Yes, there you have of course to act with caution.
('68', 437, 2, 14, 822619) I have already written to Mirabehn 1 to accommodate you if you go there before me.
('68', 437, 2, 15, 822702) I have also her reply in the affirmative.
('68', 437, 2, 16, 822744) But if you go, do it realizing that it is your dharma; do not go merely to please me.
('68', 437, 2, 17, 822830) I have already told you that I am surely going to take you to Segaon.
('68', 437, 2, 18, 822900) I am not going to change my word.
('68', 437, 2, 19, 822934) Do not neglect your health.
('68', 437, 2, 20, 822962) We are all fine here.
('68', 437, 2, 21, 822984) The place is very quiet and small.
('68', 437, 2, 22, 823019) Blessings from BAPU
('68', 437, 3, 23, 823039) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 9341. Also C.W. 6616. Courtesy: Lilavati Asar

('68', 438, 1, 2, 823774) 539. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('68', 438, 2, 3, 823804) May 14, 1936
('68', 438, 3, 4, 823817) KRISHNACHANDRA,
('68', 438, 4, 5, 823833) My previous opinions have changed.
('68', 438, 4, 6, 823868) In the past I insisted on eschewing quinine, etc., but now I do not.
('68', 438, 4, 7, 823937) There is no harm in taking them as a temporary measure.
('68', 438, 4, 8, 823993) We do not know all the natural cures and the ones that we know are not effective against all diseases.
('68', 438, 4, 9, 824096) Neem leaves ought not to be shunned simply on account of their bitter taste; their efficacy is well known.
('68', 438, 4, 10, 824203) Similarly, some qualities of tamarind also are universally acknowledged.
('68', 438, 4, 11, 824276) However, there is no such rule that one or the other thing must prove beneficial to everyone.
('68', 438, 4, 12, 824370) There is no reason, either, to believe that milk no more agrees with you because of the quinine.
('68', 438, 4, 13, 824467) The rule about forgoing the morning meal [on the day] of the does not apply to those who do not take the evening meal.
('68', 438, 4, 14, 824586) But you may discontinue the morning meal if it does not suit you.
('68', 438, 4, 15, 824652) Nor do you need to make it a rule to have a weekly fast.
('68', 438, 4, 16, 824709) In case of a feeling like indigestion you should of course abstain from food.
('68', 438, 4, 17, 824787) It is good that the pain in your spine has disappeared.
('68', 438, 4, 18, 824843) Yes, I do intend to settle in Segaon.
('68', 438, 5, 19, 824881) Blessings from BAPU
('68', 438, 6, 20, 824901) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 4270

('68', 439, 5, 7, 825473) 542. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR
('68', 439, 6, 8, 825501) NANDI HILL.
('68', 439, 6, 9, 825513) May 15,1936 CHI.
('68', 439, 6, 10, 825530) MARY, I have just had a wire saying that Tara died at Hrishikesh.
('68', 439, 6, 11, 825596) The news is stunning, unbelievable.
('68', 439, 6, 12, 825632) I have no further particulars.
('68', 439, 6, 13, 825663) I had warned her against braving the pilgrimage.
('68', 439, 6, 14, 825712) But she had an iron will.
('68', 439, 6, 15, 825738) Once it was made up it was immovable.
('68', 439, 6, 16, 825776) I have wired for particulars.
('68', 439, 6, 17, 825806) Perhpas you have them already.
('68', 439, 6, 18, 825837) Her forgiving nature and charity had captivated me.
('68', 439, 6, 19, 825889) Her belief in the goodness of human nature was beyond all praise.
('68', 439, 6, 20, 825955) She has sacrificed herself for the cause she believed in.
('68', 439, 6, 21, 826013) Shanta is here and she has given Miss Blythe’s address.
('68', 439, 6, 22, 826069) Miss B. was her partner.
('68', 439, 6, 23, 826094) You will tell me all you know and I ought to know about Tara.
('68', 439, 6, 24, 826156) I got your letter yesterday.
('68', 439, 6, 25, 826185) All these days I had taken you at your word and never wrote to you.
('68', 439, 6, 26, 826253) I am looking forward to Miss Madden’s letter.
('68', 439, 6, 27, 826299) I am glad she will be with you for one year.
('68', 439, 6, 28, 826344) Tara wanted me to invite her to see me again.
('68', 439, 6, 29, 826390) There was no question of doing so immediately as I was coming to Nandi.
('68', 439, 6, 30, 826462) But I think the present arrangement is better.
('68', 439, 6, 31, 826509) Only, she must go slow in making changes in her life.
('68', 439, 6, 32, 826563) Europeans simply cannot make some changes.
('68', 439, 6, 33, 826606) Each one has to recognize his limitations.
('68', 439, 6, 34, 826649) Of course you can spend for the roof and the like what you might have saved from your expenses.
('68', 439, 6, 35, 826745) You will take a lesson form Tara’s life and not overdo things.
