('68', 440, 4, 27, 828005) Unrevised May 15, 1936
('68', 440, 5, 28, 828028) DEAR SATIS BABU,
('68', 440, 6, 29, 828045) Cholera cases need organized treatment.
('68', 440, 6, 30, 828085) But I suppose nothing of the kind is yet possible in our country.
('68', 440, 6, 31, 828151) There is not that corporate sense of responsibility.
('68', 440, 6, 32, 828204) The few of us who have must persevere before a visible impression is made.
('68', 440, 6, 33, 828279) Do you suggest anything to make the exhibition less expensive, and more instructive?
('68', 440, 6, 34, 828364) This one 3 was instructive enough as far as it went.
('68', 440, 6, 35, 828417) It was not inexpensive.
('68', 440, 6, 36, 828441) Later on it drew huge crowds and there will be practically no loss, if at all.
('68', 440, 6, 37, 828520) We had Rs. 25, 000 entrance fees and Rs. 5, 000 from stalls.
('68', 440, 6, 38, 828581) Khadi sold very well and so did many other things.
('68', 440, 6, 39, 828632) You must have got the detailed guide book.
('68', 440, 6, 40, 828675) Go through it and make concrete suggestions.

('68', 442, 3, 4, 830306) SPINNERS’ WELFARE 1
('68', 442, 4, 5, 830326) A few points why Khadi Pratishthan, devoted to the khadi work in Bengal, should
('68', 442, 5, 6, 830406) continue to give work (in a graduated higher scale of wages) to spinners and find sale for their products in conjunction with self spinning work:
('68', 442, 6, 7, 830552) 1. Khadi is never meant to enter into competition with machine (i.e., mill ) made
('68', 442, 8, 8, 830634) 2. Khadi represents ‘back to village’ cry.
('68', 442, 9, 9, 830677) 3. Village life means simplicity and freedom from contamination of urban
('68', 442, 10, 10, 830750) ‘civilized and refined’ mode of life, i.e., life represented by cinemas, race gambling and other nonsensical things.
('68', 442, 11, 11, 830867) 4. In the mills the workmen get higher wages, but they are converted into so many
('68', 442, 12, 12, 830949) automata and drudges in the mill area.
('68', 442, 12, 13, 830988) Half their wages again are consumed in drink and prostitution.
('68', 442, 13, 14, 831051) 5. The poor women (generally widows) who ply the charkha and earn a bare
('68', 442, 14, 15, 831124) pittance are thereby enabled to be self supporting and not dependent on their male
('68', 442, 15, 16, 831207) relatives who really sit idle and make the helpless women dependent on them work like drudges and galley slaves.
('68', 442, 15, 17, 831320) Thus the latter are really freed from sweated labour.
('68', 442, 16, 18, 831374) 6. Those who ply the charkha are seldom or never whole time workers; only
('68', 442, 17, 19, 831448) during the intervals of household duties they utilize their leisure hours.
('68', 442, 17, 20, 831523) So it would be wrong to compare their off time labour with that of the sweated labour of the mills.
('68', 442, 18, 21, 831623) 7. In Bengal there is only one crop (the Aman Paddy) in most parts.
('68', 442, 18, 22, 831691) That gives
('68', 442, 19, 23, 831702) peasants occupation for barely three months in the year.
('68', 442, 19, 24, 831759) Even where there is second crop which gives employment for a couple of extra months or so, for seven months they sit idle.
('68', 442, 19, 25, 831882) Hence, if the people could be persuaded to ply the charkha, they would have a second occupation or another string to the bow.
('68', 442, 19, 26, 832008) Thus during a failure of crop due to drought or flood (as is often the case in Bengal at any rate) plying the charkha would be a ‘God send’.
('68', 442, 19, 27, 832149) The people won’t starve or be dependent on chance doles distributed in the relief centres.
('68', 442, 20, 28, 832240) 8. The spinners are not the only people benefited; along with the spinners a large
('68', 442, 21, 29, 832323) body of weavers find occupation; in fact, on week days (especially during the hat or village market days) the weavers in the khadi centres with their woven dhotis and
('68', 442, 22, 30, 832490) 1 Vide “Acharya P. C. Ray on Spinners’ Welfare”.
('68', 443, 0, 1, 832539) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 444
('68', 443, 1, 2, 832581) shirtings eagerly look for payment.
('68', 443, 1, 3, 832617) Then other subsidiary artisans would be benefited, e.g., the village carpenters, etc., making charkhas.
('68', 443, 2, 4, 832721) 9. A unique experiment is going on in the Atral and Talora centres (visited by you
('68', 443, 3, 5, 832804) in 1925).
('68', 443, 3, 6, 832814) After 12 years of hard labour, expenses, not to speak of the sacrifices of voluntary workers, at last we have got a body of willing ‘self spinners’.
('68', 443, 3, 7, 832963) I have myself watched with interest and joy how the women look forward to the saris, bodices, and chadars for children, supplied in exchange for the yarn
('68', 443, 4, 8, 833117) P. C. RAY
('68', 443, 5, 9, 833127) Harijan, 28 9 1935
('68', 443, 6, 10, 833146) APPENDIX II
('68', 443, 7, 11, 833158) A.I.S.A. RESOLUTION 1
('68', 443, 8, 12, 833180) [On or before October 11, 1935]
('68', 443, 9, 13, 833212) 1. This Council is of opinion that the wages now paid for spinning are inadequate,
('68', 443, 10, 14, 833295) and therefore resolves that they be raised and a suitable standard be fixed so that spinners may at least receive a minimum wage calculated on the basis of eight hours’ efficient work, sufficient at least to procure clothing (20 yards per year) and maintenance in accordance with a scientifically prescribed scale of minimum food requirements.
('68', 443, 10, 15, 833639) All concerned should try, as circumstances permit, for a progressive rise in the wages scale, so as to reach a standard enabling each spinning family to be properly maintained out of earning of its working members.
('68', 443, 11, 16, 833854) 2. In order to guide the A.I.S.A. workers in the execution of the principle
('68', 443, 12, 17, 833930) underlying the foregoing proposition, the following should be regarded by all branches and bodies, working in affiliation to or in any other way under the Association, as the settled policy of the Association until it is altered in the light of further experience by the Council:
('68', 443, 13, 18, 834210) (a) The mission of the Association is to make every home in India selfsufficing
('68', 443, 14, 19, 834290) through khadi with reference to its clothing requirements, and to promote the welfare of spinners who are the least paid among khadi artisans and all others engaged in the different cotton processes beginning with growing cotton and ending with weaving of khadi.
('68', 443, 15, 20, 834553) (b) It is therefore imperative that those who work for the production of khadi,
('68', 443, 16, 21, 834633) whether as artisans, sellers or otherwise, shall use khadi for their clothing requirements to the exclusion of every other kind of cloth.
('68', 443, 17, 22, 834771) 1 Vide “Sixty Three Years ago and Today”, 13 10 1935 and “New Khadi
('68', 443, 18, 23, 834839) Scheme”, 26 10 1935.
('68', 444, 0, 1, 834860) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 445
('68', 444, 1, 2, 834906) (c) All the branches and affiliated bodies shall so work the scheme as to avoid all
('68', 444, 2, 3, 834990) losses, that is, so as to restrict their production to the demand within their own selected
('68', 444, 3, 4, 835082) areas commencing with their immediate neighbourhood and never extending beyond their
('68', 444, 4, 5, 835167) province except in so far as they are called upon by other provinces to meet the latter's
('68', 444, 5, 6, 835257) demand.
('68', 444, 6, 7, 835265) (d) In order to avoid surplus production, producers may restrict their operations
('68', 444, 7, 8, 835347) only to those spinners who solely depend upon spinning for their daily bread for part of
('68', 444, 8, 9, 835436) the year or the whole of it.
('68', 444, 8, 10, 835465) Branches and other bodies shall maintain an accurate register
('68', 444, 9, 11, 835527) of all the spinners and other artisans employed by them and shall deal directly with them.
('68', 444, 10, 12, 835618) In order to ensure the use of the wages for clothing and food, a part or the whole of them
('68', 444, 11, 13, 835709) may be paid in kind, i.e., khadi or other necessaries of life.
('68', 444, 12, 14, 835772) (e) In order to avoid overlapping, undue competition, or duplicating of expenses
('68', 444, 13, 15, 835853) where there are more khadi producing organizations than one, the area of operation of
('68', 444, 14, 16, 835939) each shall be previously defined.
('68', 444, 14, 17, 835973) Private certified producers will not be encouraged by
('68', 444, 15, 18, 836027) the Association.
('68', 444, 15, 19, 836044) Among those that are already certified, those only who will work strictly
('68', 444, 16, 20, 836118) under the same rules that govern the Association branches and take all risks without any
('68', 444, 17, 21, 836207) prospect of recouping themselves from the Association will have their certificates
('68', 444, 18, 22, 836290) renewed on the strict understanding that any breach of the rule that may be laid down
('68', 444, 19, 23, 836376) from time to time or instructions given will involve automatic withdrawal of their
('68', 444, 20, 24, 836459) certificates.
('68', 444, 21, 25, 836473) (f) It should be understood that it is the primary and imperatiye duty of all
('68', 444, 22, 26, 836551) organizations working under the Association to promote the scheme of self sufficing
('68', 444, 23, 27, 836635) Production of khadi for meeting the demand of cities or of khadi wearers out side
('68', 444, 24, 28, 836717) cities who do not spin for themselves is a secondary or supplementary duty.
('68', 444, 25, 29, 836793) organization will be considered bound to produce or sell such khadi.

('68', 445, 1, 2, 836976) APPENDIX III
('68', 445, 2, 3, 836989) FOR HINDUSTANI ONLY 1
('68', 445, 3, 4, 837011) That the Hindi Urdu question is in imminent danger of becoming a communal
('68', 445, 4, 5, 837085) issue is evident from the speech Mr. Purshottamdas Tandon delivered at the opening caremony of the Hindi Museum at Benares in the first week of this month.
('68', 445, 4, 6, 837241) He declared that next to Chinese, Hindi was the most widely spoken language in Asia.
('68', 445, 4, 7, 837326) This means, in other words, that the problem of a common language is solved; it is going to be Hindi, because Hindi is spoken by the majority of Indians.
('68', 445, 4, 8, 837480) Those who clamour for Hindustani can be outnumbered, therefore they cannot matter.
('68', 445, 4, 9, 837563) But the counting of heads is no more a remedy than breaking of heads.
('68', 445, 4, 10, 837633) Whatever Mr. Tandon may have really meant, it seems to me that ground is being prepared for another such indignity as the Communal Award.
('68', 445, 5, 11, 837771) It is only your prestige and the confidence inspired by your personality that can
('68', 445, 6, 12, 837853) rescue us.
('68', 445, 6, 13, 837864) I am giving below a number of points which in my humble opinion are rational in themselves and provide a sound basis for a common language.
('68', 445, 6, 14, 838004) If you consider them and find them worthy, not in your own estimation only but also of the cause they are meant to serve, you may make them known to others.
('68', 445, 6, 15, 838161) What I am dreaming of just now is that they might become the basis of a public pronouncement by you.
('68', 445, 7, 16, 838262) The points are:
('68', 445, 8, 17, 838278) 1. That our common language shall be called ‘Hindustani’, not ‘Hindi’.
('68', 445, 9, 18, 838349) 2. That Hindustani shall not be considered to have any peculiar association with
('68', 445, 10, 19, 838430) the religious traditions of any community.
('68', 445, 11, 20, 838473) 3. That the test of ‘foreign’ and ‘indigenous’ shall not be applied to any word, but
('68', 445, 12, 21, 838558) only the test of currency.
('68', 445, 13, 22, 838585) 4. That all words used by Hindu writers of Urdu and Muslim writers of Hindi
('68', 445, 14, 23, 838661) shall be deemed current.
('68', 445, 14, 24, 838686) This of course shall not apply to Urdu and Hindi as sectional languages.
('68', 445, 15, 25, 838759) 5. That in the choice of technical terms, specially political terminology, no
('68', 445, 16, 26, 838837) preference be given to Sanskrit terms as such, but as much room as possible be allowed for natural selection from among Urdu, Hindi and Sanskrit terms.
('68', 445, 17, 27, 838989) 6. That the Devnagari and the Arabic scripts shall both be considered current and
('68', 445, 18, 28, 839071) official, and that in all institutions whose policy is directed by the official promoters of Hindustani, facilities shall be provided for learning both scripts.
('68', 445, 19, 29, 839232) There may be friends to whom these suggestions will look like Muslim demands.
('68', 445, 20, 30, 839310) 1 Vide “Letter to M. Mujeeb”, 2 5 1936; “Hindi or Hindustani”, 9 5 1936; “Hindi
('68', 445, 21, 31, 839390) or Hindustani II”, 16 5 1936 and “Letter to Zakir Husain”, 25 5 1936. Only the concluding portion of M, Mujeeb’s letter is reproduced here.
('68', 446, 0, 1, 839530) VOL. 68 : 23 SEPTEMBER, 1935 15 MAY, 1936 447
('68', 446, 1, 2, 839576) They are not.
('68', 446, 1, 3, 839590) But I know that unless an assurance of some such kind is given by you and the Parishad, there can be no question of Muslim literary effort being harnessed in the cause of a common language.
('68', 446, 1, 4, 839780) So I have submitted these suggestions to you.
('68', 446, 1, 5, 839826) If they are extravagant, I know you will pardon me, and if they are unjustified, they will not offend you.
('68', 446, 1, 6, 839933) So far as I am concerned I have only wanted to do my duty, and to show, by an appeal to you, my unlimited respect for your judgment and my confidence in your deep feeling of justice and tolerance.
('68', 446, 2, 7, 840130) Harijan, 9 5 1936
('68', 446, 3, 8, 840148) APPENDIX IV
('68', 446, 4, 9, 840160) POPULARIZE HINDUSTANI 1
('68', 446, 5, 10, 840184) The All India Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, the twenty fifth session of which was
('68', 446, 6, 11, 840260) held at Nagpur during the week end, has two main objects before it: to develop Hindi literature and popularize Hindi throughout the country.
('68', 446, 6, 12, 840401) We shall consider here the latter object mainly.
('68', 446, 6, 13, 840450) The need for a national language is undeniable.
('68', 446, 6, 14, 840498) That English cannot possibly be that language is equally undeniable.
('68', 446, 6, 15, 840567) The popular form of Hindi or of Urdu, generally called Hindustani, has alone the prospect of being a perfect national language if earnest efforts are made to popularize this form in every possible way, particularly by developing Hindustani literature, that is to say, Hindi and Urdu literature without a large admixture of classical words.
('68', 446, 7, 16, 840907) CALL IT HINDUSTANI
('68', 446, 8, 17, 840926) Unfortunately, however, this national aim is not precisely understood.
('68', 446, 8, 18, 840997) Many, who
('68', 446, 9, 19, 841007) possess wrong notions of purity of language or literary elegance, persist in using too many classical expressions, the Hindus from Sanskrit and the Muslims from Persian and Arabic.
('68', 446, 9, 20, 841188) Sometimes this tendency is deliberately fostered by communalists, whence has arisen the Hindi Urdu controversy.
('68', 446, 9, 21, 841300) Babu Rajendra Prasad much deplored this spirit of exclusiveness both because it hindered the growth of national language and because it widened the gulf between the authors and the common readers.
('68', 446, 9, 22, 841497) He rightly commended the use of a simple language and at the same time urged the absorption of foreign words wherever necessary.
('68', 446, 9, 23, 841626) He would have brought out his point more clearly if he had definitely suggested that the language which should be specially cultivated should be Hindustani.
('68', 446, 9, 24, 841783) That is, we believe, the suggestion made by Gandhiji himself at the Nagpur Conference.
('68', 446, 9, 25, 841870) The most effective way to end once for all the Hindi Urdu controversy and to develop a national language is not only to propagate a simple or popular form of Hindi
('68', 446, 10, 26, 842034) 1 Vide “Hindi or Hindustani”, 9 5 1936. Only extracts from the article are
('68', 446, 11, 27, 842109) reproduced here.
('68', 447, 0, 1, 842126) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 448
('68', 447, 1, 2, 842168) and Urdu but also to call that language Hindustani, which in fact is its most appropriate name.
('68', 447, 1, 3, 842264) In order that much confusion and needless controversy regarding the respective claims of Hindi and Urdu may be avoided, may we suggest to the Congress President to issue definite instructions to all Congress organizations that the only national language to be recognized by them should be Hindustani and that Congressmen should not carry on propaganda in favour of either Urdu or Hndi being the national language?
('68', 447, 2, 4, 842678) USE BOTH SCRIPTS
('68', 447, 3, 5, 842695) The question of a common script for the national language has come very much to
('68', 447, 4, 6, 842775) the fore during the last two years or so.
('68', 447, 4, 7, 842817) Many suggest that the Nagari script should be the national one, with some improvements made therein, as it is the basis of the scripts of all the vernaculars derived from Sanskrit and, therefore, intelligible to a large majority of the people.
('68', 447, 4, 8, 843061) A few have suggested the use of the Roman script, and the rumour was abroad some time ago that President Jawaharlal had supported it.
('68', 447, 4, 9, 843195) He has now made it clear that, though he sees some advantage in it, he does not see any chance of its being adopted by any considerable community in the country.
('68', 447, 4, 10, 843357) Even as regard the Nagari script there is not at present that consensus of opinion in its favour which can justify its exclusive adoption in writing Hindustani.
('68', 447, 4, 11, 843518) Apart from this the claims of the Arabic script, which is being used in many Asiatic and African and even European countries as well as in India cannot lightly be ignored.
('68', 447, 4, 12, 843690) In the circumstances the best immediate approach to the problem is for every Indian to learn both the Nagari and the Arabic scripts.
('68', 447, 4, 13, 843823) That was Gandhiji's suggestion during the N.C.O. Movement and many national schools and colleges loyally followed it.
('68', 447, 4, 14, 843941) We believe he has not changed his mind on this point.
('68', 447, 5, 15, 843995) The Bombay Chronicle, 27 4 1936
